Title: Police: Man accused of shooting 2 teens found hiding in attic
Summary:
JACKSONVILLE, Fla. - A man accused of shooting two teenagers last month burst a pipe in the attic and fell through a bathroom ceiling covered in asbestos when investigators showed up last Thursday to arrest him at his family's apartment, the Jacksonville Sheriff's Office said.

Justus Milan Harp, 20, is charged with two counts of attempted murder in the shooting of a pair of teenagers in March in the parking lot of the Courtney Manor Apartments on Collins Road in Ortega Hills.

Police said two friends, ages 18 and 16, were seriously injured in the shooting and two vehicles and an apartment unit were damaged by stray bullets.

Officers went to Harp's apartment last Thursday to serve a warrant on the attempted murder charges and at first, couldn't find him inside, according to his arrest report.

His mother, his 13-year-old sister and a 19-year-old woman were in the Baymeadows Road apartment.

Police said Harp's mother admitted he was in the apartment when the officers came back a second time. After the two women and the girl were safely out of the apartment, a K-9 team came in and officers found an entrance to the attic in a bedroom closet, the report said.

One of the officers spotted Harp hiding under a pile of asbestos when he reached up to grab onto a PVC pipe. Harp then fell through the ceiling and the pipe burst, sending water gushing into the apartment below, police said.

An officer took Harp, who was covered with asbestos, into custody, police said.

Harp is being held on a $1 million bond.

Copyright 2019 by WJXT News4Jax - All rights reserved.

Title: Former foster child testifies in Sarasota sex abuse trial
Summary:
North Port man is accused of committing acts on girl who was 3 at the time

SARASOTA — Wearing a pink dress and braided hair, a young girl took the witness stand Tuesday and spoke in low, mumbling tones.

With her golden retriever therapy dog watching from the audience, the child repeated what she had told police investigators a year earlier — that her former foster father had approached her in a bedroom and put “his pee-pee” in her mouth.

Her testimony — spoken haltingly and quietly in a breathless circuit courtroom — is central to the case that the state is building against 64-year-old Gilberto Rios, a longtime foster father in North Port who is charged with sexual battery against the then-3-year-old girl.

In his defense, attorneys representing Rios used their opening arguments to ask the four-woman, four-man jury to keep in mind that Rios and his wife, Nereida, fostered hundreds of children over the past 25 years in Pennsylvania and Florida.

Attorney Jeffrey Young promised that caseworkers and other state employees would testify they were a “wonderful foster family.”

“Everybody seemed to be happy, they were caring for the children, they would get them to school, to doctor’s appointments, to Disney World,” Young said. “There’s no witnesses, nobody who said they saw anything; there’s no physical evidence.”

But the accusations for which Rios is being tried are not the first to surface.

Read more: North Port foster dad accused of sexual abuse stands trial today

In an article Tuesday, GateHouse Media detailed suspicions voiced by two parents and a former case manager that four more children were allegedly abused by Rios. One mother said she told the Department of Children & Families in 2016 that both of her daughters had been molested. But DCF could not substantiate her claims and continued placing children with Rios and his wife.

Tuesday afternoon, as the first witnesses took the stand, DCF announced it would review its policy on placing children with foster parents previously accused of abuse, even if unconfirmed.

“I, and all the employees of DCF, are appalled by the allegations in this case,” DCF Secretary Chad Poppell said in a statement Tuesday. “A foster care placement should be a safe place where we would be comfortable sending our own children.”

Rios, who appeared in a black suit jacket with a small oxygen tank, did not speak on the first day of his trial.

The investigation into his alleged abuse was triggered in 2018, when the now 7-year-old’s adoptive mother overheard her tell her older sister that she had once “bit” a man’s penis.

When questioned further, her daughter “shut down,” the mother testified. Three days later, on their way to therapy, the girl disclosed that the man in question was Rios. The mother called the abuse hotline the next day.

“She was placed there for safety and security, but it became a house of horrors,” Assistant State Attorney Brooke Kernan told the jury in her opening arguments.

Prior to the girl’s disclosure, family members also noticed the girl playing with Barbie dolls, stripping them naked, and simulating sex acts with them, according to testimony from the mother and an older sister.

The typically bubbly and cheerful young girl also displayed other worrisome behaviors, according to witnesses.

Guardian ad litem Marca Markwitz testified that while the girl seemed otherwise happy and well-cared for in the Rios home, she also had issues with potty training and smearing feces on the walls.

When Markwitz suggested the child go to therapy, Nereida Rios was resistant.

“I asked her didn’t she think she should see a therapist and Ms. Rios said no, we can handle it,” Markwitz said.

Markwitz also said she rarely, if ever, saw the couple’s two teenage children or their adopted son during visits.

Later in the week, jurors are expected to hear the testimony of a second former foster child who told investigators years earlier that she was also sexually abused by Rios while in his care.

The two children’s placements at the Rios home overlapped, according to testimony from child welfare workers.

Rios’ attorneys moved to block the testimony, raising concerns about inconsistencies in her story. But Judge Charles Roberts overruled their motion on grounds that the second child’s testimony had “striking and significant” similarities.

The trial is expected to end Thursday.
Address: 1777 Main St, Sarasota, FL 34236, USA

Title: Lawmakers back off public records exemption for foster parent names
Summary:
Florida lawmakers backed off a proposal Tuesday that sought to conceal the names of foster parents through new public record exemptions.

The move came on the same day GateHouse Media reported allegations of child sex abuse against Gilberto Rios, who fostered 48 children with his wife since 2009.

On trial this week over charges that he sexually abused a 3-year-old girl in his care, Rios faced similar allegations from another foster girl two years earlier, GateHouse Media found — yet state officials continued to place children in his home.

Experts say the case illustrates why foster parents, who receive funding from the state of Florida, should not be exempt from public oversight. But that’s exactly what Florida legislators, backed by the Department of Children & Families, intended. A pair of bills making their way through the House and Senate would have protected the identities of foster parents, which are now public record under Florida statutes.

The bills came in response to a records request made by GateHouse and the Sarasota Herald-Tribune in July 2018 as part of an ongoing investigation into alleged misconduct of foster parents. The organizations asked for a list of all foster parents in the state. But even though DCF officials agreed that the names were not exempt under current public records law, they declined the request and then set about changing the law.

But on the heels of allegations against Rios, state lawmakers on the Florida House of Representatives Health and Human Services Committee amended the bill on Tuesday to instead conceal just the names of foster parents who operate human trafficking safe houses — refuges for children once engaged in the sex trade.

“These homes are notoriously difficult to keep open because traffickers find out where the children are,” said Robert Latham, a professor and associate director of the University of Miami Children & Youth Law Clinic. He estimates it removes maybe 10 or 20 names from the list of foster parents.

In a statement emailed to GateHouse Media, DCF Secretary Chad Poppell denied that his organization was trying to hide anything from public view.

“DCF is absolutely committed to transparency and accountability, and we have no tolerance for any abuse of any kind by any caregiver,” Poppell wrote. “The intent of HB 1249 is to provide protection to make foster parents and children in their care feel safe. However, we recognize there is a balance with transparency and accountability.”

Co-sponsors of the proposed legislation — Rep. Spencer Roach, R-North Fort Myers, and Rep. Toby Overdorf, R-Palm City — had argued the measure was necessary to protect foster parents against reprisal from biological parents.

But some child welfare advocates feared it would go too far — potentially putting vulnerable children further at risk.

The Children’s Campaign sent a call for action Tuesday to demonstrate opposition to earlier versions of the bill, citing the Herald-Tribune’s reporting as evidence.

“We felt like it removed transparency and accountability in the foster system,” said Roy Miller, president and founder of The Children’s Campaign. “The Rios trial just confirms all of our concerns.”

As of Tuesday, the Senate version of the bill remained unchanged.

“This bill and the associated amendment exemplify the risk many foster parents endure when caring for children who also happen to be victims of human trafficking,” Overdorf said before the Health and Human Services Committee. “Parents who care for these commercially, sexually exploited children are at an increased risk due to the relationship between human trafficking and various forms of associated violence.”
Address: 1777 Main St, Sarasota, FL 34236, USA

Title: Port St. Lucie couple charged with child neglect
Summary:
Port St. Lucie police obtained arrest warrants Friday against a city resident and his wife, charging each of them with two counts each of child neglect and contributing to the delinquency or dependency of a child.

Christopher Michael Walker, 37, and Vanessa Ann Walker, 34, were arrested Saturday and released from the St. Lucie County Jail the same day, records show. Christopher Walker posted a $30,000 bond and Vanessa Walker’s bond was $16,500, records show.

The couple knew for more than a year that two boys were actively aggressive when they engaged in repeated sexual activity with a girl, but did not call authorities or seek counseling for the girl, according to an affidavit police used to obtain the warrant.

The Florida Department of Children and Families called police in on the case April 9.

Title: Video: Women attack Good Samaritan during wild gas station fight over hot dogs
Summary:
A dispute over hot dogs led to a violent fight at an Ohio gas station.Witnesses told WOIO that a good Samaritan stepped in to stand up for a woman being attacked, and that's when a group of women turned on him at an Akron gas station.“I know the video makes it look like he was trying to fight them, but they were actually jumping him,” Cam Dancy said. “They were throwing trash cans and the windshield wiper thing, and one girl ripped the gas pump off and tried to hit him with that.”The shocking video shows one woman ripping off a gas pump hose and swinging it around. A gas station clerk said the trouble began when a customer called the women out for stealing hot dogs in the store. When the group went after that customer, the man in the video stepped in to break it up.“Then I see gasoline flying everywhere and they’re all just jumping at him,” Dancy said.The wild video of the incident has been viewed millions of times on social media. It is not clear if anyone was arrested after the incident.

Title: Zephyrhills man accused of human trafficking with 15-year-old girl
Summary:
Copyright 2019 Nexstar Broadcasting, Inc. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten, or redistributed. Pasco County Sheriff's Office

TAMPA (WFLA) - A Zephyrhills man is behind bars after deputies say he had sex with a 15-year-old runaway.

Deputies say Jael Aguayo, 24, offered the victim a hotel room and Xanex in exchange for sex with him and his friend.

Law enforcement officials were able to locate the child prior to the sex act. Text messages between the victim and defendant were located. which confirmed the victim's account of the events.

Because he was accused of offering to exchange the Xanax and hotel room for sexual favors, Aguayo has been charged with Human Trafficking and Lewd and Lascivious Battery.

HAINES CITY, Fla. (WFLA) - The Haines City Police Department needs the public's help locating Diamond Shanall Hodges, 17.

Hodges was last seen at her home on Avenue East on April 10. She was reported missing on Friday and has been in contact with her family, informing them that she will be home soon.

Title: Girl bitten by shark at Crescent Beach while celebrating her 10th birthday
Summary:
A Macclenny girl was bitten by a shark late Friday afternoon in the waters off Crescent Beach.

Peyton Shields turned 10 last week and for her birthday, she and her family left their Baker County home to spend the weekend at the Four Winds condominiums on A1A. They had only been at the beach for about an hour at the time of the shark attack.

Peyton, who had been boogie boarding, said she was in waist-deep water about 5:45 p.m. Friday when she was bitten on both knees by a shark. She said she tried to push it away and she was bitten on her left hand before the shark swam off.

Her parents saw her screaming and struggling in the water. Her father, Steven Shields, told News4Jax that a shark bite was the last thing that went through his head, saying he thought she was yelling because she had thought had been stung by a jellyfish. But then he saw the blood coming from her legs.

Peyton's parents put pressure on the wounds and called 911. Other children were in the water with Peyton, but she was the only one bitten, according to a St. Johns County Sheriff's Office report.

She was taken to Flagler Hospital, where she got about 40 stitches and she was bandaged up.

Fortunately, Peyton was still able to celebrate at her birthday party Saturday in the condo.

Her parents said Peyton had a follow-up doctor's appointment Monday afternoon. Though Peyton, who's on spring break this week, was bummed she was unable to get in the water again over the weekend after the shark attack, she said that as soon as she's cleared by a doctor, she can't wait to get back in the ocean.

According to News4Jax records, there has been one shark bite so far this year in the Northeast Florida and Southeast Georgia area. Last year, there were four reported shark bites in that area. There were three locally recorded shark bites in 2017.

Address: 4 Broadcast Pl, Jacksonville, FL 32207, USA

Title: Grant Amato 'unable to function' without cam girl before family's slaying, letter shows
Summary:
Excerpts form a letter written by Grant Amato to an online community whom he shared a relationship with a cam girl in the months before his father, mother and brother were killed.

SEMINOLE COUNTY, Fla. - Before prosecutors say Grant Amato killed his parents and brother, he sent a letter to an online porn group involved with the woman to whom he sent more than $200,000, apologizing for lying about his lifestyle; however, he didn’t say the money was stolen from his family before they ultimately found out three months before the deaths.

That apology letter, documents and video interviews with Amato were released Monday by prosecutors as part of the case against the 29-year-old accused of killing his family after he says they forced him to cut ties with a woman with whom he formed a relationship via the website MyFreeCams, where people can pay women for sexual photos and videos.

Grant Amato’s parents, Chad and Margaret, along with his brother, Cody Amato, 31, were fatally shot at their Chuluota home Jan. 25. Photos and other evidence from the home shows Cody Amato was shot as soon as he walked in the door. He was still wearing his green hospital scrubs after returning home from work at Orlando Health, according to the discovery.

Records show Grant Amato had argued with his family in the months leading up to the shooting because he had stolen $200,000 from his father and brother to wire to a Bulgarian cam girl, called Silvie, with whom he had an online relationship on the website MyFreeCams.

“My family found out about her, the website and all the money I had been spending on everything,” Amato wrote in the eight-page apology letter to the online group also involved with the woman.

After learning about the relationship and the stolen funds in November, his family sent Grant Amato to a rehabilitation center for internet and sex addiction, according to investigators.

In a letter written sometime after the suspect left the rehabilitation center on Jan. 9, Amato tells his MyFreeCams friends he stayed there until he was “able convince my family that I was fine and able to be released.”

According to recorded interviews and in Amato’s own words, he felt misunderstood by his family.

“My father is controlling and abusive, my mother is simply around for the security and my brother is also controlling and does not understand how I could care for someone as much as I care for Silvie," Grant Amato wrote.

Amato apologizes to his online friends, saying, “I am not a professional gamer, did not own my own house and did not drive a BMW," adding “while the money I have, the tips I gave and the way that I was and am are my true personality and way of being.”

At least $200,000 he used for the MyFreeCams website to send to Silvie was stolen from his father and brother, according to investigators.

It’s unclear if any of Amato’s own money was also used to fund the online relationship, which involved sending Silvie gifts including flowers and outfits, the letter shows. Users are encouraged to "tip" the models on the website.

The cam girl had cut ties with Amato in January, according to the letter, because while he was in rehab, his “family had hacked my computer at home, gained access to my phone records and all my personal things related to Silvie.” The Amato family also contacted Silvie, according to the letter.

Excerpts form a letter written by Grant Amato to an online community whom he shared a relationship with a cam girl in the months before his father, mother and brother were killed.

By January, Amato wrote he was reduced "to only being able to send her DM’s on her public Twitter.”

Amato was devastated about losing contact and access to the woman. He writes, “I am unable to function normally without her,” and, “I will never get over her.”

The 29-year-old entered a not guilty plea in March to three counts of first-degree murder. He faces the death penalty if convicted.

He continues to deny his role in the slayings, according to jail messages also released on Monday.

A message written by Grant Amato from the Seminole County jail to a legal advocate.

Amato was worried about his nursing license and requested several “The King Killer Chronicle” books. A criminal defense mitigation expert advised him, “please don’t worry about your nursing license … there are much bigger things happening now," messages from March 12 show.

“This is not some drama, it’s the greatest tragedy of my life that I am being wrongfully accused of,” Amato wrote to a reporter in March.

Before his Jan. 28 arrest, Amato sought access to the online porn community group again, according to his letter.

Amato wrote, “I wish I could simply say that everyone deserves a chance to right their wrongs, but unfortunately it is not up to me.”

Copyright 2019 by WKMG ClickOrlando - All rights reserved.
Address: 4466 N John Young Pkwy, Orlando, FL 32804, USA

Title: 100 rescued from rip currents along Florida's coast
Summary:
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. - Lifeguards rescued more than 100 people from rough surf along a stretch of beaches on Florida's Atlantic coast.

Volusia County Ocean Rescue Capt. Mike Berard said lifeguards rescued 48 people Saturday and at least 55 Sunday.

Those rescued included a 7-year-old girl pulled into the ocean by strong rip currents. Berard says the child and another child in nearby New Smyrna Beach were taken to hospitals as a precaution.

[WHAT TO KNOW: Rip currents, warning flags]

Berard says the rip currents were "pretty bad" over the weekend as spring break crowds flocked to the beaches.

What to do if caught in a rip current

If you do find yourself caught in a rip current, there are a few steps you should take to escape the pull.

First, do not panic. If you begin to get tired, turn on your back and float for a few seconds to rest your arms and legs.

Next, start swimming parallel to the coastline until you begin to feel the pull relax.

From there, start swimming back to shore at an angle. Many panicked swimmers try swimming straight back to shore. That causes them to swim directly against the current, which increases their risk of drowning due to fatigue.

What do those flags mean?

One of the first things beachgoers should do when arriving at the beach is to look for the colored beach flag, located near lifeguard towers. These flags are posted to identify different tide and surf conditions in that area. This nationwide warning flag system was adopted by the International Lifesaving Federation.

No matter the day or the color of the flag, it is always best to swim near a lifeguard and never let your guard down while you’re in the water.

Enjoy the beach season, have fun and stay safe.

Title: Florida couple leaves 1 of 8 children behind at park, don't report toddler missing until next day, deputies say
Summary:
Passersby found the 2-year-old girl "wandering alone" at a park just before sunset Friday, deputies said. Her parents didn't report her missing until the following afternoon.

A Florida couple left one of their eight children behind at a park after a family outing Friday night and didn't report the toddler missing until nearly noon Saturday, deputies said.

Jolanda Larose Alexandre and Makenson Alexandre, 34, told the Palm Beach County Sheriff's Office they didn't realize they'd left the 2-year-old girl behind.

Passersby found the child "wandering alone" at Haverhill Park on Friday evening just before sunset, deputies said.

When deputies were called, they spent about three hours trying to find the girl’s caregivers, including making loudspeaker announcements and bringing in search and rescue dogs, the sheriff's office said.

The department had no idea whom the girl belonged to until the Alexandres called authorities the next day, deputies said.

The Alexandres were arrested and charged with child neglect, and officials with the Florida Department of Children and Families also removed the remaining seven children from the home, deputies said.

The girl had been left behind at about 7 p.m. Friday and was missing for more than 14 hours, according to the sheriff's office.

At about 8 a.m. Saturday, the sheriff's office posted a photo of the girl, who turns 3 this Thursday, asking "Does anyone know who this little beautiful baby girl belongs to?" with a "heartbroken" emoji on Facebook.

"We were dumbfounded. We were so upset," PBSO Public Information Officer Teri Barbera said, adding that the girl was in "great condition," dressed nicely in a pink “Adorable” T-shirt and white tutu, and otherwise seemed to be generally well cared-for.

Jolanda Alexandre told authorities she had taken all the kids to the park to let them play for about an hour after picking Makenson up from work, then told them to get back into the minivan before she drove home and let them continue playing outside their apartment, according to a probable cause affidavit released Monday morning.

Jolanda Alexandre said she thought the little girl was with all the other kids but that on Saturday morning after she woke up, she and Makenson realized at about 9 a.m. that the toddler was missing, according to the affidavit.

Frantically searching for the girl, the mother was "crying and shaking" as she asked authorites for help and said she couldn't believe this happened, the affidavit said. Both parents said they usually check on all the children before bed but had not on Friday night, the document states.
Address: 455 6th St NW, Winter Haven, FL 33881, USA

Title: Florida man pretended to be 'Instagram famous' to lure, rape Texas girl, police say
Summary:
ORANGE COUNTY, Fla. (WESH) - Police have arrested a man who they said used Instagram to lure a Texas girl to his home in Orange County.

The girl said she was then forced to stay there, but eventually escaped and called for help.

Edward Brown, 24, of Apopka, is in the Orange County Jail facing a host of charges including sexual battery on a 17-year-old girl and contributing to the delinquency of a minor.

The alleged victim told police Brown told her he was: "Instagram famous and he would be able to take care of (the victim)," who was reported missing out of San Antonio, Texas.

The arrest report also said Brown: "ordered an Uber from San Antonio all the way to his home in Apopka."

WESH 2 News spoke with Zachary Russ, who said he's Brown's best friend.

"He's not a rapist, man, he's got a thing for young girls, but he's got to wise up and make sure they're 18," Russ said.

The juvenile told police she had been at his house for three to four days and he allegedly forced her to have sex and he did drugs.

The house belongs to Brown's parents:

The juvenile also told police that Brown wouldn't let her leave, allegedly saying: "No, you owe me now for bringing you all the way out here."

The girl told police she escaped through the front door when Brown fell asleep.

Investigators said Brown told them the two were, "only friends and nothing more," and that they "never had any type of sexual contact, and that he does not consume any drugs."

Officials said he showed police a receipt that he: "paid for an Uber from Louisiana to Apopka in the amount of $822."

Brown is in jail under a $40,000 bond.

The Florida Department of Children and Families is investigating the case.
Address: 200 S Parker St, Tampa, FL 33606, USA

Title: Crawfish Fest, Mullet Toss and Pensacola Triathlon highlight busy week | Seven days out
Summary:
Buy Photo Jay Boatwright, left, and David Harrison, prepare a hot batch of boiled crawfish for the lunch crowd at a past Pensacola Crawfish Festival. The festival returns to downtown Pensacola Friday. (Photo: PNJ file photo)

MONDAY

Monday Night Blues

8 p.m. Monday, April 22. Seville Quarter, 130 E. Government St. The Blues Society of Northwest Florida presents the Monday Blues Open Jam in a “smoke-free” atmosphere. Enjoy a great jam session and memorable performances of the blues. 434-6211. sevillequarter.com.

TUESDAY

RePurposed Art Show

9 a.m. Tuesday through Friday, April 23 through 26. Pensacola Habitat for Humanity ReStore, 6931 N. Ninth Ave. Pensacola State College Art Department is partnering with Pensacola Habitat for Humanity’s ReStore to present a repurposed art show and auction to benefit Pensacola Habitat for Humanity and further their mission. The benefit auction and reception will begin at 5 p.m. Friday. Free. More info: 850-476-0001 or pensacolahabitat.org.

Sail with the Blue Angels

9 a.m. Tuesday and Wednesday, April 23 and 24. Gulf Breeze Sailing, 715 Pensacola Beach Blvd., Pensacola Beach. Sail and watch the Blue Angels fly overhead as they practice their world-class maneuvers. Get involved in sailing and crewing on the boat as much or as little as you like. The group leaves Pensacola Beach at 9 a.m. and returns at 2 p.m. More info and cost details: 850-293-1434 or gulfbreezesailing.com.

Blue Angels Practice

11:30 a.m. Tuesday and Wednesday, April 23 and 24. National Naval Aviation Museum, 1878 S. Blue Angel Parkway. There’s nothing quite like watching the Blue Angels, even in practice flights. The skill and courage required to perform aerial maneuvers in tight formations at 400 to 700 mph, all while maintaining as little as 18 inches of separation, is awe-inspiring. Practices typically last about 55 minutes. Free. More info: 850-452-3604 or navalaviationmuseum.org.

An Evening of Great Jazz

6:30 p.m. Tuesdays. Seville Quarter, 130 E. Government St. Gino Rosaria, award-winning pianist, will perform jazz standards, smooth jazz, and Latin jazz in the Lili Marlene’s listening room. Rosaria performs with his award-winning band Groove Symphony and features some of the best jazz artists on the Gulf Coast, Los Angeles, Atlanta, and New York City. More info: 850-434-6211 or sevillequarter.com.

Hundreds of people enjoy a past Bands on the Beach concert at the Pensacola Beach Gulfside Pavilion. The free, weekly concert series features a different band every Tuesday. (Photo: Jody Link/online@pnj.com)

Bands on the Beach

7 to 9 p.m. Tuesday, April 23. Gulfside Pavilion at Casino Beach, Pensacola Beach. Pensacola Beach's popular outdoor summer concert series with performers for every musical taste. Featuring a lineup of regional artists, Bands on the Beach delivers an eclectic musical experience throughout the entire summer. This week features The Legend Band. Spectators are encouraged to bring their own lawn chairs and blankets. Free. More info: 850-932-2257 or visitpensacolabeach.com.

WSRE Public Square: Cynthia Barnett

7 p.m. Tuesday, April 23. WSRE Jean & Paul Amos Performance Studio, Pensacola State College, 1000 College Blvd. In her program, Blue Revolution: A Water Ethic for Florida, Barnett will show how one of the most water-rich states in the nation could come to face water scarcity and quality woes and how it doesn't have to be that way. Free. More info: 850-484-1200 or wsre.org/events.

UWF Singers Concert

7:30 p.m. Tuesday, April 23. First United Methodist Church, 6 E. Wright St. Featured guests, the Woodlawn Beach Middle School Choir, will perform with the UWF ensembles. Dr. Peter Steenblik will conduct the ensembles as they present French composer Maurice Duruflé's “Requiem.” Shorter works will also be presented including Whitney Berry's “Prayer,” Rosephanye Powell's “Still I Rise,” and Andrea Ramsey's “Letter from a Girl to the World.” More info: 850-857-6285 or uwf.edu/cfpa.

WEDNESDAY

Mullet Swing Golf Classic

6:30 p.m. Wednesday, April 24. Perdido Bay Golf Club, 1 Doug Ford Drive. The 22nd annual Mullet Swing Golf Classic will be a four-person scramble with a maximum handicap per player of 30. A package of two mulligans and two red tee busters will be available on tournament day for $25. These cannot be used for hole-in-one prizes. One package is allowed per player. More info: florabama.com or 850-492-6838.

THURSDAY

Christopher's Concerts

6 p.m. Thursday, April 25. St. Christopher's Episcopal Church, 3200 N. 12th Ave. The best in local bands live on the lawn. Bring lawn chairs. Concessions will be available, but attendees are welcome to bring their own food and drink. This week features the Reunion Band. More info: scpen.org/christophers-concerts or 850-433-0074.

Clean Water Paddle Series

6 p.m. Thursdays through May 16. Shaka Bar, 649 Pensacola Beach Blvd. Participants will paddle around Little Sabine Bay for up to one hour, then enjoy the sunset from The Shaka Bar. Environmental education will be provided before, during, and after the paddle by Healthy Gulf and others. Learn about seagrass, clean water, marine life, and how you can help to protect it all. Free. More info: 850-687-9968 or christian@healthygulf.org.

of Montreal

7 p.m. Thursday, April 25. Vinyl Music Hall, 2 S. Palafox St. of Montreal is an indie pop band from Athens, Georgia, identified as part of the Elephant 6 collective. Throughout its existence, the band's musical style has evolved considerably and drawn inspiration from 1960s psychedelic pop acts. Yip Deceiver will open the show. $20. For all ages. More info and ticket purchase: vinylmusichall.com.

FRIDAY

The annual Interstate Mullet Toss & Gulf Coast’s Greatest Beach Party hosted by the Flora-Bama Lounge gets going Friday. (Photo: Jody Link/online@pnj.com)

Interstate Mullet Toss and Gulf Coast's Greatest Beach Party

10 a.m. Friday through Sunday, April 26 through 28. Flora-Bama Lounge, Package and Oyster Bar, 17401 Perdido Key Drive. What started as just a reason to party has become one of the biggest beach parties on the coast. Those who participate in the Mullet Toss will throw a dead mullet over the state line of Florida and Alabama to see who gets the farthest. Hotel bookings are done months, if not years in advance for this event. People travel from across the globe to see what all the fuss is about. More info: florabama.com or 850-492-6838.

The 35th Annual Pensacola Crawfish Festival

Noon Friday, 10 a.m. Saturday and 11 a.m. Sunday, April 26 through 28. Vince Whibbs Sr. Community Maritime Park, 301 W. Main St. The Crawfish Festival will bring a taste of Louisiana right here to Pensacola Bay with 16,000 pounds of boiled crawfish, fresh from Louisiana, courtesy of Pensacola locals, Cordova Crawfish Company. The festival will also feature live entertainment, arts & crafts vendors, a children’s area, and the 13th annual Cat Country 98.7 Crawfish Eating Contest. Admission: $6; free for children 12 and younger. More info: fiestapensacola.org/pensacola-crawfish-festival.

Crown The Empire and We Came As Romans

6 p.m. Friday, April 26. Vinyl Music Hall, 2 S. Palafox St. Crown the Empire fuses electronic ambience with metal catharsis, creating a moody and dramatic sound that sets the band apart from its contemporaries. We Came as Romans will showcase their blend of post-hardcore and melodic screamo. Erra and Shvpes will open the show. $22 to $25. For all ages. More info and ticket purchase: vinylmusichall.com.

SATURDAY

2019 Deluna's Beach Games

6 a.m. Saturday, April 27. Flounder's Chowder House, 800 Quietwater Beach Road, Pensacola Beach. Pensacola Sports is excited to launch this new event which features a wide variety of sporting events including a sunrise run, open water swim, putt putt tournament, scavenger hunt, skateboard competition, and go-cart racing. The goal is to add events each year to make a fun, family-oriented sports festival. More info: pensacolasports.org or 850-434-2800.

The U.S. Finals (Cheer Finals)

9 a.m. Saturday and 8 a.m. Sunday, April 27 and 28. Pensacola Bay Center, 201 E. Gregory St. The U.S. Finals has grown into the single most successful multi-brand event in the country. It is an end-of-the-year series of seven events aimed at crowning true champions in all divisions and levels of cheer and dance, giving teams a chance to see where they rank against other teams in their respective divisions from coast to coast and around the world. Visit pensacolabaycenter.com for ticket information and details.

Be My Neighbor Day

10 a.m. Saturday, April 27. WSRE Jean & Paul Amos Performance Studio, Pensacola State College, 1000 College Blvd. A free family event spotlighting the neighborly values of Mister Rogers and featuring PBS KIDS stars: Daniel Tiger, Katerina Kittycat and Mr. Steve. Community organizations will be on hand indoors and outside with children's activity booths and useful information for parents. Free. More info: 850-484-1200 or wsre.org.

Paws on Palafox

10 a.m. Saturday, April 27. Plaza de Luna Park, downtown Palafox. Walk as an individual or a “pack” at Paws on Palafox. Bring your best canine pal and join the folks at the Pensacola Humane Society for a 3K fun walk. People and dogs of all ages are invited to wind through the streets of downtown Pensacola to help raise funds for shelter animals and the Barbara Grice Memorial Spay and Neuter Clinic. More info: Jennifer Bitner, 850-466-3945 or jennifer@pensacolahumane.org.

The Walk for Mommy and Me will take place from 10 a.m. Saturday at Carpenter’s Park in Milton. (Photo: Think Stock)

Walk for Mommy & Me

10 a.m. Saturday, April 27. Carpenter’s Park on Munson Highway in Milton. The walk around the park will feature booths with information of interest to parents, including nutrition and car seat safety, activities and games for children, the Crash Test Dummies and other local mascots. All registered participants will receive a free entry into a drawing for special prizes. More info: 850-983-5250 or santarosa.floridahealth.gov.

Florida's Flora: Nature Tour of Arcadia Mill

10:30 a.m. Saturdays in April. Arcadia Mill Archaeological Site, 5709 Mill Pond Lane, Milton. Guests of all ages will learn about how native plants were used in the past on the Florida’s Flora tour. This ticketed tour lasts approximately 45 minutes to an hour and takes place along the boardwalk and nature trails. Trail appropriate attire, bug spray, and sunscreen are recommended. Admission: $2 for kids; $4 for adults. More info: 850-626-3084.

Arcadia Kids Crafts

11 a.m. Saturday, April 27. Arcadia Mill Archaeological Site, 5709 Mill Pond Lane, Milton. Children will make a coffee filter Earth painting while learning about Earth Day. All materials will be provided. Each activity is estimated to be completed in 30 minutes. Participants must be accompanied by a parent, legal guardian, or adult. Free. More info: 850-626-3084 or historicpensacola.org.

Grillin’ in the Breeze

11 a.m. Saturday, April 27. Shoreline Park, 801 Shoreline Drive, Gulf Breeze. Taste grilled and smoked delicacies, cast your vote for the People’s Choice award, and bid on terrific silent auction items throughout the day. The Navarre Beach Marine Science Station’s Discovery Depot and Pensacola Mess Hall will be on-site with activities for all ages. Chef Bob Solarski will also be serving a special menu in the VIP tent. $10 in advance; $12 day of; VIP tickets are $35 in advance; $40 day of; free for children 10 and younger. More info: grillininthebreeze.com.

The Marine Corps League’s 18th Annual Vehicle & Cycle Show

11 a.m. Saturday, April 27. Five Flags Speedway, 7451 Pine Forest Road. The expanded line up for this year’s event includes cars, ATVs, trucks and motorcycles. The show will feature live music by Muskogee Ridge. Games will be available along with door prizes. Food and drink vendors will also be on hand and there will be a 50/50 drawing. $20 per entry. Free to the public. More info: pensacolamcleague.com.

Concert in the Park - Gypsy Spark Band

4 p.m. Saturday, April 27. Big Lagoon State Park, 12301 Gulf Beach Highway. The Gypsy Spark Band will tantalize the senses with both original and familiar tunes, crafted by front man Jimmy Lumpkin and Brenda Bledsoe. Free with paid park admission. More info: 850-492-1595 or gypsysparkband.com.

Pensacola Symphony Orchestra Presents: Concerto for Orchestra

7:30 p.m. Saturday, April 27. Saenger Theatre, 118 S. Palafox St. The 93rd season comes to close with a program inspired by folk music from around the world. Featuring the memorable opening roll of the timpani and the arresting proclamation of the piano, Grieg’s Piano Concerto will be played by Alessio Bax. Guest composer Gabriela Lena Frank joins us to share her own work, Apu: Tone Poem for Orchestra, inspired by Peruvian folk music. Continuing with this inspiration is Bartok’s Concerto for Orchestra, a piece with origins in traditional Hungarian folk music. Tickets start at $23. More info: 850-595-3880 or pensacolasaenger.com.

Big Deal Burlesque

8 p.m. Saturday, April 27. Vinyl Music Hall, 2 S. Palafox St. Big Deal Burlesque, New Orlean's own first ever touring burlesque show, is comprised of a rotational all-star cast of dancers, aerialists, musicians, pole performers and sideshow acts. The show features guests from across the country. Enjoy the best of New Orleans burlesque has to offer. $12 to $45. For ages 18 and older. More info and ticket purchase: vinylmusichall.com.

SUNDAY

The Pensacola Triathlon

6:15 a.m. Sunday, April 28. Maritime Park, 301 W. Main St. Start the race with a swim in Pensacola Bay, bike along the scenic out-and-back course, and run through Historic Pensacola neighborhoods and past cheering spectators. The event concludes with a festive waterfront awards party featuring music, food, and cold beer. More info: 850-435-9222.

St. Joseph Blues & Bar-B-Que

11 a.m. Sunday, April 28. St. Joseph Catholic Church, 140 W. Government St. In addition to the barbecue food line-up, this year’s event features a musical line-up of Biscuit Miller, Dedra Ruff And The All-Pros Band, Cat Daddy, Back Street Blues Band, Belmont Youth Band, Spearman Brewers, and Max McCain Band. Free. More info: 850-932-8584.

The Psychedelic Furs

7 p.m. Sunday, April 28. Vinyl Music Hall, 2 S. Palafox St. Led by front man and songwriter Richard Butler, the Furs won over fans and critics alike by combining poetic lyrics, innovative rhythms and melodies driven by an aggressive, punk desperation. Through it all, the band scored major hits with "Love My Way," "Pretty In Pink," "Heaven," "The Ghost In You," and "Heartbreak Beat." Royston Langdon will open the show. $30 to $32. For all ages. More info and ticket purchase: vinylmusichall.com.

Address: 101 E Romana St, Pensacola, FL 32502, USA

Title: St. Matthew's House graduates show what's possible after addiction recovery
Summary:
Nick Matson wakes up enthusiastic over what the day may bring.

Same for the next day, the next month.

His outlook is a stark contrast from two years ago. He expected to die from a heroin overdose.

The Naples native has come full circle from addiction to recovery. He owns a local moving company, Matson Movers.

“It makes me feel like, wow,” Matson, 25, said. “I did it. I actually started something and it’s working. I’m a business guy. It makes me feel accomplished.”

Nick Matson, right, laughs with his dad, Arthur Matson, while they eat breakfast at Nana's Diner in Golden Gate on Tuesday, April 9, 2019. Nick decided to quit drugs after overdosing in early 2017 and went through the Justin's Place Recovery Program at St. Matthew's House. Nick saw the need for a delivery service while working at the thrift stores run by St. Matthew's House in Naples, and he decided to start his own moving company with the help of his father. (Photo: Alex Driehaus/Naples Daily News USA TODAY NETWORK - FLORIDA)

Matson credits Justin’s Place Recovery Program at St. Matthew’s House, a year-long Christian-based substance abuse recovery program with boot camp-like rules. St. Matthew’s House also runs homeless shelters, a soup kitchen, and several businesses that graduates of the program help operate.

The program is highly structured to help people develop life skills — often for the first time — to be accountable and productive.

After a 28-day stay at Justin’s Place in East Naples, men spend six months at the remote Port LaBelle Inn and Conference Center, which St. Matthew’s House purchased in 2014. The capacity is 70 men.

While taking part in recovery sessions, they work in food service, the laundry room, maintenance or other capacities to support St. Matthew’s and the inn that is available for retreats.

More: Opioids on Florida Cabinet priority lists

Women stay at Jill’s Place Retreat Center, an 11-acre property with four residences in Alva for skills training and personal growth. The capacity is limited to 32 women year-round; only 25 percent of applicants can be served because of the limited capacity.

The next step for men is transitional housing at Wolfe Apartments in Golden Gate. Program participants work at one of the "social enterprise" businesses run by St. Matthew's House. That could be one of its thrift stores, the car wash, café or catering business. The goal is learning how to balance life and work.

The program has graduated 470 former substance abusers since it began in 2010. They are tracked for two years for sobriety and there is an 87 percent success rate, according to St. Matthew's House.

NEWSLETTERS Get the News Alerts newsletter delivered to your inbox We're sorry, but something went wrong Get alerted to the latest stories to stay on top of the news. Please try again soon, or contact Customer Service at 1-844-900-7105. Delivery: Varies Invalid email address Thank you! You're almost signed up for News Alerts Keep an eye out for an email to confirm your newsletter registration. More newsletters

Some graduates have started their own businesses, earned degrees and have careers with opportunities.

“They gave me my life back,” Matson said. “I was going to die if I didn’t get help. I just thought I was going to die a heroin addict.”

Stan Schoenewald, right, instructs Trish Conway, left, during a TRX, or total body resistance exercise, class at Kensington Country Club fitness center in Naples on Monday, April 15, 2019. Schoenewald, a recovering alcoholic, went through the Justin's Place Recovery Program at St. Matthew's House after attempting suicide in December 2014. With the help of a grant through St. Matthew's House, Schoenewald got certified as a personal trainer and now works at Kensington, Wyndemere Country Club, and the Greater Naples YMCA. (Photo: Alex Driehaus/Naples Daily News USA TODAY NETWORK - FLORIDA)

Stan Schoenewald, whose alcohol abuse led to kidney failure and dialysis for five months, is a fitness trainer at Kensington Country Club, Wyndemere Country Club and the Greater Naples YMCA.

He stayed two years at Wolfe Apartments as a caseworker after completing the program.

“The more I stayed, the more I learned,” Schoenewald, 40, said. “I realized it was not a quick fix.”

Jesenia Martinez, 41, wanted to die after losing her three kids because of drugs. She’s been off drugs for five years and is customer relations manager at Naples Nissan.

“I see St. Matthew’s House as a stepping stone that God used to pull me out of the darkness,” Martinez said.

Working the program

After graduating Gulf Coast High School in 2011, Matson worked in local restaurants where drugs were often plentiful.

“I didn’t have a purpose,” he said.

He used opioids, including Oxycontin, and progressed to shooting heroin.

“I started losing everything,” he said. “I ran my car on Alligator Alley going 85 mph into the canal.”

One night at his drug dealer’s place, he couldn’t get a vein. The dealer’s girlfriend injected him.

More: Collier mental health committee tasked with shaping new treatment center

He faintly recalls being shoved up against a wall and water spraying him. He realized later he was carried into the shower.

Matson woke up in a hospital bed. He had overdosed. His dealer had not wanted a dead man in his home and called an ambulance.

In the hospital bed, Matson had time to think. He checked himself into the recovery program.

“I realized I am not invincible,” he said.

He worked in the laundry room in LaBelle and liked how the men helped one another stick to the program.

After moving to Wolfe Apartments, he worked for two of the thrift stores run by St. Matthew's House in Naples. Customers kept asking about delivery service. That’s when he came up with idea of starting a moving business.

Nick Matson, right, and Kenny McAdams, left, move patio furniture being donated to Providence House, a Naples womens' shelter, from a home in Naples on Monday, April 8, 2019. McAdams and Matson are fellow graduates of the Justin's Place Recovery Program at St. Matthew's House, and McAdams is Matson's first full-time employee. (Photo: Alex Driehaus/Naples Daily News USA TODAY NETWORK - FLORIDA)

He pitched the idea to Vann Ellison, president and chief executive officer of St. Matthew’s House, who blessed it. He pitched it to his father, Arthur Matson, a retired marine law enforcement officer.

Through the thrift store manager, Matson learned of a box truck available for $17,000. The sum seemed insurmountable.

He and his father made the rounds to banks for a loan, but Matson lacked business experience. His father ultimately put up the money. Matson Movers launched in late 2017.

His father helped with the physical work in the early months. Word spread from thrift stores clerks and repeat customers.

“It all just fell into place,” Matson said. “Business is rolling. In the last four months, I have not had one losing week.”

He’s up at 4:30 a.m. weekdays to work out at Iron Tribe Fitness in North Naples. He’s muscular at 240 pounds, a far cry from when he weighed 160 pounds as an addict.

“I was a skeleton,” he said.

From left to right, Arthur Matson, Nick Matson, and Kenny McAdams eat breakfast at Nana's Diner in Golden Gate on Tuesday, April 9, 2019. The Matsons and McAdams eat breakfast at Nana's every morning before starting work for the day. (Photo: Alex Driehaus/Naples Daily News USA TODAY NETWORK - FLORIDA)

More: Mental health, drug addiction care needs discussed at Collier workshop

He goes to an AA meeting after working out and then to Nana’s Diner in Golden Gate to meet his father and his only employee, Kenny McAdams. He and his father prefer burgers at breakfast.

At jobs, Matson is upbeat and chats with customers. He knows customer service is critical for repeat business. He plans to expand from local moving to more distant moving jobs.

A Biblical verse from Galatians on the side of his truck says: “Don’t forget where you came from.”

It’s a reminder his good fortune could turn on a dime if he ever uses drugs again.

“I know I could lose everything in a second,” Matson said.

From booze to brawn

Schoenewald moved from Williamstown, New Jersey, to the Jersey Shore town of Sea Isle after high school. He worked in restaurants and fell into the party lifestyle at night.

Everybody did it. He got up every morning on time and worked hard. He moved up in the restaurant world. All seemed fine.

He landed a job as a sous chef in Atlantic City, a town he describes as the “devil’s playground.”

Drugs are everywhere. He made good money and spent it. He used cocaine and opioids. Even his high tolerance for Jameson Irish whiskey dumbfounded him. He kept functioning.

One morning after a big night, he woke to find the left side of his body distorted from swelling. He went to an emergency room. He was in kidney failure at the age of 25.

“They knew why, the alcohol and drugs,” Schoenewald said. “My body was shutting down.”

Stan Schoenewald teaches a TRX, or total body resistance exercise, class at Kensington Country Club fitness center in Naples on Monday, April 15, 2019. (Photo: Alex Driehaus/Naples Daily News USA TODAY NETWORK - FLORIDA)

He was put on dialysis. Doctors couldn’t say if it would be permanent. He stayed off alcohol. Five months later he was given a clean bill of health.

“I went back to the same place, the same people,” Schoenewald said. “A month later I said I will have a sip of whiskey and nothing happened. It probably took me two weeks before I was firing on all cylinders like before.”

He was miserable. After visiting his older brother in Fort Myers, he moved there. He got a job at a popular eatery and fell back into the party lifestyle.

More: The ‘heart’ of Texas: Author details 28-year life of addiction and crime

He got a girl pregnant and they married after their daughter was born. He got arrested for drunken driving.

In driving school, the instructor talked about the signs of alcoholism. The only one Schoenewald didn’t check off was drinking in the morning.

“I don’t know why in my head I decided I had to be the best alcoholic I could. It doesn’t make sense,” he said. “I started drinking in the morning. It took the edge off, so I started drinking all day.”

His wife kicked him out. He wasn’t allowed to see his daughter. He lost jobs. He was consuming a 1.75 liter bottle of Captain Morgan or Jameson daily.

“Now I was in my pity party,” Schoenewald said. “I felt sorry for myself. I felt the walls were caving in on me. I felt like an elephant was sitting on my chest.”

Suicide as a way out

He thought people in his life would be better without him. He tied a sheet around his neck and the other end to a rafter to strangle himself. He did not stand on a chair.

“I felt myself blacking out and all of a sudden I felt like I had a purpose but I didn’t know what it was,” he said.

It was the middle of the afternoon in December 2014. He was able to loosen the sheet. He prayed for help. He prayed for a commercial to come on television for an addiction recovery program.

Those commercials usually run in the wee hours of the night, but that day, within five minutes, a commercial for Passages Malibu recovery program or something similar, came on.

More: Gov. DeSantis announces task force to combat opioid crisis

He called and learned the program cost $40,000. The woman on the phone suggested he finance it. He hung up.

Schoenewald called his sister-in-law for help. She got him the number to Justin’s Place. When he learned the program lasts one year, his family urged him to go.

He started the program in January 2015. It took him a month to break out of his shell.

In LaBelle, he worked in the kitchen. He read the Bible and began to feel alive.

“Working the steps, you see people start changing, to get a glow about them,” he said.

Stan Schoenewald instructs Nanette Marsh during a TRX, or total body resistance exercise, class at Kensington Country Club fitness center in Naples on Monday, April 15, 2019. (Photo: Alex Driehaus/Naples Daily News USA TODAY NETWORK - FLORIDA)

He began running and built up his stamina. He helped get exercise equipment from the thrift stores to LaBelle.

At the Wolfe Apartments, he became an intern to help others and moved up to a caseworker position.

He applied for a $1,500 scholarship through a program at St. Matthew’s House to get certified as a personal trainer.

One day at Naples Church on Immokalee Road, he struck up a conversation with a woman next to him. She turned out to be the fitness director at Kensington Country Club. They stayed in touch. She hired him as an attendant at Kensington.

“God put all the right people in my path,” he said. “She plugged me into Wyndemere and at the YMCA.”

More: The opioid diaries: In Naples, a horse named Tacoma

He received two more scholarships from St. Matthew’s for spinning instructor certification and to teach classes.

He has run the Fort Myers Marathon, the Chicago and New York marathons and plans to run the Boston Marathon next year.

He’s up at 4:15 a.m. and reads the Bible before heading to Crunch gym.

“I’ve learned if I get up and do something for myself, I can give to people all day,” Schoenewald said.

Stan Schoenewald leads his class in stretches after a TRX, or total body resistance exercise, class at Kensington Country Club fitness center in Naples on Monday, April 15, 2019. (Photo: Alex Driehaus/Naples Daily News USA TODAY NETWORK - FLORIDA)

Gang life to car dealership

Martinez dropped out of school in Miami after sixth grade and joined a gang.

“The gang was my family,” she said. “I felt protected.”

She broke into homes and was around drugs all the time. She lived in the fast lane until a friend was shot and killed near where she lived. She was 17 and wanted out. She moved to Naples to live with her mother.

She held odd jobs and kept returning to Miami where she met a man and married. She had the first of her three kids with him at 21.

She wanted to make the marriage work and smoked crack with her husband until he became abusive. She left him and spent six months living at the Shelter for Abused Women in Naples. Her kids were 2, 3 and 4.

“I was starting from ground up,” she said. “I got a legitimate job as a car detailer.”

More: David Lawrence Center's Nancy Dauphinais speaks about opioid crisis

She struggled to make ends meet. She couch-hopped staying with friends and began smoking crack again. She sold drugs and stole food from stores to keep her kids fed.

A low point came when someone called the state Department of Children and Families and she lost custody of her children.

“I wanted to die,” Martinez said. Instead of focusing on getting her life in order she kept using. I chose the wrong way.”

She was looking at prison time after five arrests for petty theft. The judge gave her a break and seven months in jail.

"It was divine intervention," she said.

Jesenia Martinez poses for a portrait at Naples Nissan on Wednesday, April 17, 2019. Martinez's years-long drug habit got her kids taken away and caused her to spend seven months in jail. Shortly after her release she decided she wanted to get clean and ended up in a recovery program at St. Matthew's House, which helped her get her kids back and land a job at Naples Nissan where she works as a customer relations manager. (Photo: Alex Driehaus/Naples Daily News USA TODAY NETWORK - FLORIDA)

She didn’t know how to ask for help until one night shortly after her release.

“I was sitting in a dope dealer’s house in the middle of the night on a Sunday. I was getting high and started to get really anxious,” she said. “I stood up and handed my drugs to someone and said, ‘I have to go.’”

She walked to a convenience store and told the clerk she wanted to kill herself. The clerk called the Sheriff’s Office. The deputy who responded knew her.

“He looked at me and said, ‘Are you finally done?'" she said. "I said, ‘Yes.’ I didn’t really know how to ask for help.”

The deputy drove her to the David Lawrence Center, a mental health and addiction treatment center in Naples.

When someone mentioned Justin’s Place, it jarred a memory. She remembered running into a former drug user who had gone to Justin's Place. She remembered how good he looked. She was ready.

“I wanted to stop, I was just so tired,” Martinez said.

She stayed in the program one year. She established a relationship with God. She no longer believed she was destined, or deserved, to be homeless and an addict.

“The devil had no power over me anymore,” Martinez said. “I am grateful to St. Matthew’s House. It helped me because I wanted it to help me.”

She got her children back and lived in Wolfe Apartments. When she was ready to buy a car, she went to Naples Nissan, which is a supporter of St. Matthew’s House.

Martinez met the general manager of the dealership. She sent prospective customers to Nissan. The general manager convinced her to come work there. He put her in the service department, where she's been since June 2016.

Her children are grown and thriving. The eldest is at the University of Florida on a scholarship and wants to go to medical school.

Martinez’s job at the dealership is to address issues customers may have with the service department. She lets them vent — if they need it — before she convinces them she is there to solve their problem.

“I pray every morning before I get here,” Martinez said. “How can I not be grateful for my life today from where I came from?

Jesenia Martinez shows off her Alice in Wonderland-themed tattoo sleeve, which is still in progress, at Naples Nissan on Wednesday, April 17, 2019. Martinez says that her tattoos remind her of when her kids were growing up. She used to wake her kids up by singing the unbirthday song, and tried her best to make every day an adventure, even when they were homeless or were going through a tough time. (Photo: Alex Driehaus/Naples Daily News USA TODAY NETWORK - FLORIDA)

More: New Florida law cracks down on opioid prescriptions

Read or Share this story: https://www.naplesnews.com/story/news/local/2019/04/20/st-matthews-house-addiction-recovery-program-graduates-their-feet/3369142002/
Address: 1100 Immokalee Rd, Naples, FL 34110, USA

Title: Stuart doctor sentenced to two years in prison for healthcare fraud
Summary:
Buy Photo Office of Dr. Sheetal Kanar Kumar (Photo: PHOTO BY WILL GREENLEE)

FORT PIERCE — Notified earlier in the day that her medical license has been suspended, Sheetal Kanar Kumar was sentenced late Friday afternoon to two years in prison for healthcare fraud.

Two months ago, a federal court jury found the former obstetrician and gynecologist guilty of 23 of the 29 counts of scheming to commit fraud on health insurance claims made between January 2014 and July 2017 to Medicare, Medicaid and a handful of private insurers.

Though the maximum penalty for each charge was 10 years in prison and a $250,000 fine, federal sentencing guidelines called for a sentence of 38 months and a fine of $20,000 to $200,000.

MORE: Stuart doctor faces 26 counts of health care fraud

U.S. District Judge Kenneth Marra rebuffed efforts by Assistant U.S. Attorney Daniel Funk to increase the guidelines by adding enhancements based on allegations that Kumar used special skills as a doctor in filing the claims, obstructed prosecution by perjuring herself in her trial testimony and did not show acceptance or take responsibility for her crimes.

Buy Photo Office of Dr. Sheetal Kanar Kumar (Photo: PHOTO BY WILL GREENLEE)

Testifying at the sentencing hearing, Kumar, 48, pleaded with Marra for any punishment that would not take her away from her three teenage children, a 17-year-old girl and twin 14-year-old boys.

MORE: Federal jury finds Stuart doctor guilty of 23 of 29 counts of scheming to commit fraud on insurance claims

Her husband, Dr. Amitabh Kumar, a gastroenterology specialist who had been sharing office space and staff with his wife, found work in Albany, Georgia, and visits the family when he can.

“Before this trial, I had a feeling about myself that I was a good person who did good things,” Kanar Kumar told the judge. “That feeling is gone, and I want to do what I can to restore that feeling.

“As far as community service, I really need it,” she pleaded. “Punish me without punishing my kids.”

One of Kumar’s attorneys, Richard Kibbey of Stuart, told Marra the situation was a “dilemmatunity,” a concept he said he learned long ago from a college professor for a situation in which a dilemma could be turned into an opportunity.

Suggesting that Kumar had accumulated some “forgiveness chips” before these crimes, Kibbey said, “Some people need to be in prison for our safety, but why imprison someone just to imprison them” when that person could be contributing to society in some other way.

Kibbey proposed to Marra a 90-day sentence Kumar would serve during the summer when her children were not in school, following by a heavy dose of community service, perhaps 40 hours a week for three years.

In delivering his sentence, Marra said, “Tragic is an inadequate description of this case.”

Marra said people with children should not be treated differently in court from those without children.

“In my view, the fact that children may be adversely affected is not a reason to avoid incarceration,” he said.

Still, Marra went below the guidelines in giving Kumar a two-year sentence and $15,000 fine.

Though prosecutors wanted Kumar remanded into custody immediately, the judge agreed to Kibbey’s requests to allow Kumar to surrender to federal marshals by noon on June 24, so she could spend time preparing her children for her absence, and to ask that she be sent to a prison in Marianna or Tallahassee, where she moved with her children after her arrest.

Funk also said Kumar should be ordered to pay $637,177 in restitution, based on testimony by FBI analyst Jennifer Minton.

Kibbey and Kumar’s other attorney, Jason Wandner of Stuart, argued that amount included repayment for claims for which she was found not guilty.

Marra agreed with part of the defense argument and reduced the figure by about $65,000, but set a hearing for June 5 in West Palm Beach to resolve the restitution.

Address: 1939 SE Federal Hwy, Stuart, FL 34994, USA

Title: Grady wins District 2-3A tennis title as Leon, champion Chiles advance to regionals
Summary:
The Lions finished as district runner-up behind the Timberwolves, who captured their fifth consecutive district championship

Buy Photo Leon senior Jules Grady captured a District 2-3A title at No. 1 singles on Thursday at Tom Brown Park. (Photo: Brian Miller/Democrat)

Leon senior Jules Grady had learned her lesson.

If she was going to beat Chiles senior Gracie Wilson in the District 2-3A finals match Thursday morning at the No. 1 singles position, she was going to have to be patient.

Extremely patient.

Grady learned that lesson when she lost to Wilson 6-2, 6-4 at the city tournament, a few courts away at Tom Brown Park.

“I had to blend how I play and how she plays because she never misses,” Grady said. “When I lost to her at city’s, I was just playing my game and wasn’t making my aggressive shots. I just had to play consistent with her and make my shots.”

Buy Photo Chiles senior Gracie Wilson plays during the District 2-3A tennis tournament at Tom Brown Park on April 17 and 18, 2019. (Photo: Brian Miller/Democrat)

Grady, last year’s All-Big Bend Co-Player of the Year and 2018 city champ, had just beaten Wilson 8-6 the week before in a pro-set, handing Wilson her first local loss since her freshman year.

With high winds pushing struck balls around varying distances, Grady casually strolled towards each shot, hitting back and forth with Wilson with a relative nonchalance. Without angst, she played a waiting game instead of trying to power balls past her gritty competitor.

CITY TOURNAMENT: Chiles' Wilson, de Cardenas win city titles, but boys team crown still up for grabs

Grady's reward was a 6-4, 6-4 win and her first district title. She’s the first Leon girls district champion since Mary Phillips Smith in 2011.

“I was walking to balls,” Grady said. “When we had really intense points, it was exciting because most of the points were walking back and forth to balls. It was very different.”

On top of her individual achievement, Grady watched as Leon played without injured No. 3 Abby Birkmeier – her typical No. 1 doubles partner – yet the Lions snuck ahead of Niceville for the district runner-up spot. Leon will travel to Gulf Breeze for the first round of regionals.

“It was a group effort,” Grady said. “Our 4 and 5 won in the first round. We were a team.”

Buy Photo Leon senior Jules Grady captured a District 2-3A title at No. 1 singles on Thursday at Tom Brown Park. (Photo: Brian Miller/Democrat)

Niceville struggled with early evictions from the district bracket, including seeing its 1-seed at No. 4 singles get bounced in the quarterfinals following a first-round bye.

Despite shifting its lineup with Birkmeier out, Leon picked up points in several unexpected areas.

Buy Photo Leon's Carsyn Kenny plays during the District 2-3A tennis tournament at Tom Brown Park on April 17 and 18, 2019. (Photo: Brian Miller/Democrat)

“Katie Garland went up to 3 and won a match, and the girl she would have played at 4 she had lost to, but Grace (Netherton) ended up beating her,” Leon coach Kevin Record said. “Carsyn Dennis picked up a point at 2 against a girl she had just lost to. We picked up a point in every bracket. And Jules winning got us five points.”

TENNIS PREVIEW: Landscape among boys and girls as even as it has ever been

Record, however, experienced a reversal of expectation. He thought his Leon boys team – which recently beat Chiles 5-2 in a regular-season match to settle a tie at the city tournament – would be the one to get out of district.

With Blake Javanmardi and Will Bullen winning a finals match at No. 2 doubles, the Lions ended up tying Niceville for runner-up, then they lost in a tiebreaking pro-set dual match to finish in third. Chiles, which sent only No. 2 Brighton Jiang to the finals, was fourth.

Leon's boys tennis team of Will Bullen, Blake Javanmardi, Parker Kenny, Jack Long, Petar Leontikj and head coach Kevin Record captured the 2019 City Championship with a 5-2 tiebreaker win over Chiles. (Photo: Leon Athletics)

“It was weird, and I would be lying if I said I wasn’t disappointed the boys didn’t get out,” Record said. “It was a long tournament to go two days and then play a dual match.”

The dual was crucial at 3-4-5 singles. Jack Long and Bullen both won easily, but Petar Leontikj got up 3-1 before losing to a player who got hot at the right time.

RELATED: Perkins, Cicchetti help Maclay tennis pull off rare district sweep

“It was a good feeling to be back in the hunt,” Record said. “It has been a few years since I’ve been able to roam the courts. It felt like they were in the postseason. That was the wild-card game.”

Lincoln senior Kailey Williams made a slightly surprising run through the No. 4 singles bracket, winning as the 3-seed. After Leon’s Grace Netherton upset Chiles’ Harli Neshat in the quarterfinals, Williams beat Netherton 6-4, 6-4 and took down Fort Walton’s Emily Daldine 6-3, 6-2.

Buy Photo Lincoln senior Kailey Williams plays during the District 2-3A tennis tournament at Tom Brown Park on April 17 and 18, 2019. (Photo: Brian Miller/Democrat)

Chiles’ girls, meanwhile, captured their fifth consecutive district championship. In addition to Wilson reaching the No. 1 finals, the Timberwolves picked up big points from No. 2 singles winner Sofia Guerrero, No. 3 Amy Xia, and both No. 1 and No. 2 doubles.

The Timberwolves now begin their quest to reach a fourth consecutive state tournament.

“Our 1-2-3 are really strong and we knew we’d ride them,” Chiles head coach Mike Dross said. “While Harli’s loss was tough, it wasn’t a big deal. But she’s a really good doubles player and she did well with Amy there. My biggest takeaway was our players had no signs of quit. They fought the whole way and that’s what we’ve done all year.

“The way we’re playing now, I wouldn’t say we’re on cruise control, but I’m confident we can make it to state again as long as everyone stays in their lane and plays their role.”

Chiles' girls tennis team captured its fifth straight District 2-3A championship on Thursday at Tom Brown Park. From left: Timberwolves assistant coach Allen Long, Harli Neshat, Amy Xia, Gracie Wilson, Rasee Bhoola, Sofia Guerrero, Savanna Phelps, head coach Mike Dross. (Photo: Kim Wilson/Chiles Athletics)

District 2-3A tennis tournament

GIRLS TEAM RESULTS

GIRLS SINGLES
