Title: Local mom battling cancer posts Facebook plea for breast milk
Summary:
Local mom battling cancer posts Facebook plea for breast milk Video

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. (WFLA) - Jessica Purcell is one tough mama.

She's a captain in the United States Army. She's served overseas on mutiple deployments in places like Afghanistan and Qatar.

She's faced dangerous situations before.

But, it was her battle here at home with breast cancer where she found herself fighting for her life and the life of her newborn son.

"I just knew ultimately, this is God's will, God's way. Somehow, some way, it will, we can do this," she said, cradling her 5-week-old baby boy.

He is her miracle.

When Jessica was nine weeks pregnant, doctors gave her devastating news.

She was diagnosed with breast cancer.

For this St.Petersburg mom who served in the military, perserverance and positivity became her ammo in battling the disease.

"We got this, somehow it's going to work out," she said with a sigh and a smile. "Just keep the faith. Keep your hope. It's so mental."

Jessica would need that mental strength and toughness as she endured a mastectomy and 12 rounds of grueling chemotherapy, all while pregnant.

At the same time, she and her husband were also raising their little girl, nearly 2-years-old.

"Just going through chemo alone is hard, being pregnant is hard. But, going through both, I just, you would never imagine doing that," she told us.

She explained how terrfiying it was to face chemotherapy while carrying her son. She says she sought multiple opinions from top oncologists all over the country and coupled their findings with extensive research she performed on her own.

She says she was told if she didn't seek chemotherapy treatment, she would most likely not survive to see her son or raise her daughter.

She recalled the fear and cripipling anxiety she felt wondering what her future held.

Jessica relied on her faith, friends, familly and support groups comprised of other moms going through similar circumstances

Then, came the joyous moment.

She gave birth to a healthy baby boy in March.

But, because she couldn't breast feed, Jessica wanted to give her little guy a boost to his immune system.

A jump-start for baby Jameson.

So, she posted a plea on Facebook for breast milk.

"I'm like, 'oh my goodness,'" Jessica told us with a wide grin. "This is, you know I mean. I have offers coming from around the world now, just to ship from other countires. I literally thought just the girls in St. Pete, maybe Tampa, would be a stretch."

The mother of two says she's still in shock that her goal went global.

For now, she's focusing on feeding her son with donated breast milk from local moms and familiar faces. She says some moms have paid for extensive bloodwork when offering their milk, while others are close friends in which she has a history.

"It's wonderful, it's overwhelming. My freezer is full, I can actually feed my little guy," she said.

Jessica says she's pleasantly overhwhelmed with the love and support she's received worldwide.

It has warmed her heart and strengthened her mama bear spirit.

"I'm more excited than anything, I'm just so blessed," she told us. "My little guy, he's here, just a breath of fresh air."

Jessica has more final chemo treatment, then will soon begin radiation. She says her nurses at Moffitt Cancer Center keep her going, as does her moms' group.

"They're angels to me!"
Address: 200 S Parker St, Tampa, FL 33606, USA

Title: Teen with Down syndrome told she can't ride Ferris wheel because of her 'disabilities'
Summary:
Advertisement Teen with Down syndrome told she can't ride Ferris wheel because of her 'disabilities' Share Shares Copy Link Copy

A Kansas high school student says that she told she could not join in on a Ferris wheel ride during a school trip because she has Down syndrome.Kathryn Embry, 18, told WDAF she was discriminated against during a class trip to Scheels in Overland Park.Friends Emily Kramer and Morgan McGruder were stunned that Embry was turned away from the ride. They became friends through the girls' Blue Valley North soccer team,“She’s our manager, and she keeps the team in line," Kramer said. Kramer and McGruder decided to record a video of Embry explaining the situation and post it to Twitter, where it was retweeted hundreds of times.“I tried to go on the Ferris wheel, but they said I can’t because I have disabilities so I cannot ride," Kathryn said in the video. Embry's mother was disappointed to hear about the incident and got in touch with the Scheels manager.“The store manager at the time said he hadn’t heard about the incident, but he could confirm they had a policy that everybody needs to be able to understand and follow the rules," her mother Karen Embry said.Karen Embry argues that no one ever asked Kathryn if she understood the rules."The thing is, Kathryn has Down syndrome, so you can look at her and see that she has a disability," Karen Embry said. "But it says nothing about what her capabilities are. She can read the rules. She can follow the rules.”Kathryn was eventually allowed to ride the Ferris wheel with an adult chaperone, even though she is 18. “It made me really upset because I know that Kathryn is an amazing girl," McGruder said. “Just because someone might look different than someone else you shouldn’t assume their capabilities. Kathryn can do anything we can do."Ultimately, her supporters said it’s not about the ride.“It’s more than just the Ferris wheel," Kramer said. "It’s the fact that they looked at her and discriminated against her because of how she looked. She is our good luck charm, so we had to help fight back for her.”Karen Embry said the family would appreciate an apology and a change of policy. “We’re not here about a boycott and shut down a business that’s been very generous in our community," a statement said. "We’re about educating -- not just the community at large, but business -- about how even if it’s unintentional, it’s still illegal and it’s still wrong because it perpetuates stereotypes and it hurts a population, especially who are hitting this young adult stage.”The Blue Valley School District said in a written statement:“We are proud that Blue Valley employees have the best interests of our students at heart. The physical and emotional well-being of our students is always a top priority. We appreciate the efforts of our community partners to keep our kids safe through equitable practices.”
Address: Northcorp Business Park, Palm Beach Gardens, FL 33410, USA

Title: #MeToo Movement founder Tarana Burke to speak at FAMU Friday
Summary:
CLOSE Tarana Burke, founder of #MeToo movement, spoke at SUNY Broome Tuesday evening. Maggie Gilroy / Staff video

Tarana Burke speaks onstage during the 2018 Essence Festival presented by Coca-Cola at Ernest N. Morial Convention Center on July 6, 2018 in New Orleans, Louisiana. (Photo: Paras Griffin, Getty Images for Essence)

Tarana Burke believes in a world without sexual violence.

Burke is the woman who coined the term “me too” to let sexual violence victims, especially women and girls of color, know they’re not alone.

On Friday, Burke will speak at Florida A&M University as part of a tour at historic black colleges and universities.

After allegations of sexual harassment against Harvey Weinstein in October 2017, #MeToo became viral. Since then, the term has forged conversations about the silence and suffering of sexual violence survivors, and the powerful positions their perpetrators held.

Survivors are talking, listening and sharing. But Burke said there’s more work to be done.

“A big part of advocacy work and organizing work is imagination,” she said. “We have to imagine a world without sexual violence and the way that we actively move toward that is by shifting the culture that exists now that allows for sexual violence to flourish.”

At the last Sundance Film Festival, Burke coordinated a series of PSAs about sexual harassment.

She said a key to addressing the issue is through "systemic" campaigns, like anti-smoking campaigns, as well as comprehensive sexual education for youth to help them understand boundaries and consent to raise "a new generation of young people to understand that this is not OK."

Overall, Burke said, battling sexual violence has to be done through "healing and action."

"It’s multifaceted," she said. "We have to re-socialize ourselves, we have to socialize our children … we have to insert ourselves in pop culture in order to shift the dominant narrative around sexual violence."

The phrase "me too" came to her in 1997, when she was a summer camp counselor and a girl told her about how she'd been abused by a relative.

"I watched her walk away from me as she tried to recapture her secrets and tuck them back into their hiding place. I watched her put her mask back on and go back into the world like she was all alone and I couldn’t even bring myself to whisper … me too," Burke wrote on the Me Too movement's website.

A decade later, in 2006, Burke started Just Be., Inc, an organization to promote the well-being of young women of color.

"Sexual violence doesn’t discriminate. But ... statistics will show you there are fewer resources in communities of color, black communities," Burke said.

Since then, she's continued her efforts through the Me Too movement, putting together training for people to start "community healing circles" in their cities, giving TED talks and other speeches about the issue.

Once, on a flight out of Pittsburgh, Burke was sitting next to an 83-year-old woman who gave her a hug and said, "me too." The woman told Burke that she was abused as a child, but hushed the experience for her whole life.

"I never thought I’d be able to say anything out loud. But thank you for giving me that opportunity before I die to get it off of me," Burke recalled her saying.

"We have a lot of work to do," Burke added," and it’s going to be hard work and it’s going to be heart work."

#MeToo HBCU Tour Schedule

Strategic Planning Meeting

Where: Florida A&M University Grand Ballroom

When: Noon to 2 p.m., Friday

Campus leaders will be invited to meet and discuss the university's efforts to protect students, faculty and staff from sexual harassment.

Men's Workshop

Where: Multipurpose Room D

When: 4 to 5:30 p.m., Friday

Males Only: facilitators will conduct a workshop to discuss their role in protecting themselves and others.

Fireside Chat

Where: Grand Ballroom

When: 7 to 9 p.m. Friday

A community discussion with founder Tarana Burke, Yaba Blay and a celebrity guest.

Reach Nada Hassanein at nhassanein@tallahassee.com or on Twitter @nhassanein_.

Read or Share this story: https://www.tallahassee.com/story/news/2019/04/17/metoo-movement-tarana-burke-speak-famu-friday/3485310002/
Address: 277 N Magnolia Dr, Tallahassee, FL 32301, USA

Title: Mom demands children give their Build-A-Bears to daughter at birthday party
Summary:
- This is un-bear-able.

A mom was shocked by an unusual incident that allegedly unfolded at a child’s birthday party and turned to Reddit for advice.

The anonymous poster claimed on Reddit’s Parenting forum that she took her 6-year-old daughter to a classmate’s birthday party at Build-A-Bear Workshop over the weekend.

“The invitation said each kid (about 8 total) would get to make a Bear, and I just assumed they would get to take them home, since that is what happened at another BAB party I went to. Me and my husband even pitched in about 30 dollars as we know these things can get expensive,” the poster wrote on Reddit.

READ MORE ON FOXNEWS.COM

After the children spent time making their special animals and picking accessories, the group left the store and planned to go back to the birthday girl’s house for the rest of the party. However, as the kids left the workshop, the mom of the birthday girl announced each child would have to turn over their animal.

“All is well, we leave the store, then friends mom announces that the kids need to give all their animals to her daughter. Cue the upset and angry kids. They all disappointingly handed over their animals, and friend wasn’t even being nice about it either. Another little boy didn’t want to, and friend ripped it out of his hands. I probably should have said something, but I didn’t. The other parents seemed pretty baffled too,” she wrote.

The mom said she went to the party, but her daughter became upset watching as the birthday girl played with all her new animals.

After she returned home, the mom turned to Reddit asking if “this is totally normal and I should have expected this, or am I being an entitled parent?”

Those on Reddit were quick to respond, defending the mom as not being entitled.

“That is really weird!! I can't believe the parents made all the kids give away their bears,” one person commented.

“Agreed. Beyond strange. I would never in a million years think to have a party where the kids (and our guests) have to give away their item. So bizarre,” another wrote.

“Their daughter and family will forever be remembered for this. And NOT fondly,” another pointed out, concerned the birthday girl will now be disliked by her peers.

Though some tried to reason that maybe the parent throwing the party thought the bears would be gifts — but those attending the party should have been told in the invitation.

“I think it would have been less weird if they had said that up front like ‘Oh she wants a bear specially thought out by each of her friend’ to make it seem like they'll be special or something lol,” one person wrote.

In an update, the original poster explained that she talked to the mom of the party at the school pickup, but did not get a satisfying explanation.

The mom said she asked the mom throwing the party “why the kids didn’t get to keep their bears,” noting she “even pitched in a little bit of money, assuming the bears would go to the kids.

To which the mom allegedly responded, “Well I didn’t have enough money for each of the guests to make their own, that would get pretty expensive! If you want your money back I’ll see about getting it back to you. I don’t really see the problem though.”

Though the mom who wrote the post said she didn’t “push” the topic, she was frustrated that the mom didn’t “have enough money for all the kids” to get a bear, but had “enough [money] for her daughter to get like 8 bears.”

CHECK FOR UPDATES ON THIS STORY ON FOXNEWS.COM
Address: 35 Skyline Dr, Lake Mary, FL 32746, USA

Title: Former foster child testifies in sex abuse trial
Summary:
Man is accused of committing acts on girl who was 3 at the time

SARASOTA — Wearing a pink dress and braided hair, a young girl took the witness stand Tuesday and spoke in low, mumbling tones.

With her golden retriever therapy dog watching from the audience, the child repeated what she had told police investigators a year earlier — that her former foster father had approached her in a bedroom and put “his pee-pee” in her mouth.

Her testimony — spoken haltingly and quietly in a breathless circuit courtroom — is central to the case that the state is building against 64-year-old Gilberto Rios, a longtime foster father in North Port who is charged with sexual battery against the then-3-year-old girl.

In his defense, attorneys representing Rios used their opening arguments to ask the four-woman, four-man jury to keep in mind that Rios and his wife, Nereida, fostered hundreds of children over the past 25 years in Pennsylvania and Florida.

Attorney Jeffrey Young promised that caseworkers and other state employees would testify they were a “wonderful foster family.”

“Everybody seemed to be happy, they were caring for the children, they would get them to school, to doctor’s appointments, to Disney World,” Young said. “There’s no witnesses, nobody who said they saw anything; there’s no physical evidence.”

But the accusations for which Rios is being tried are not the first to surface.

In an article Tuesday, GateHouse Media detailed suspicions voiced by two parents and a former case manager that four more children were allegedly abused by Rios. One mother said she told the Department of Children & Families in 2016 that both of her daughters had been molested. But DCF could not substantiate her claims and continued placing children with Rios and his wife.

Tuesday afternoon, as the first witnesses took the stand, DCF announced it would review its policy on placing children with foster parents previously accused of abuse, even if unconfirmed.

“I, and all the employees of DCF, are appalled by the allegations in this case,” DCF Secretary Chad Poppell said in a statement Tuesday. “A foster care placement should be a safe place where we would be comfortable sending our own children.”

Rios, who appeared in a black suit jacket with a small oxygen tank, did not speak on the first day of his trial.

The investigation into his alleged abuse was triggered in 2018, when the now 7-year-old’s adoptive mother overheard her tell her older sister that she had once “bit” a man’s penis.

When questioned further, her daughter “shut down,” the mother testified. Three days later, on their way to therapy, the girl disclosed that the man in question was Rios. The mother called the abuse hotline the next day.

“She was placed there for safety and security, but it became a house of horrors,” Assistant State Attorney Brooke Kernan told the jury in her opening arguments.

Prior to the girl’s disclosure, family members also noticed the girl playing with Barbie dolls, stripping them naked, and simulating sex acts with them, according to testimony from the mother and an older sister.

The typically bubbly and cheerful young girl also displayed other worrisome behaviors, according to witnesses.

Guardian ad litem Marca Markwitz testified that while the girl seemed otherwise happy and well-cared for in the Rios home, she also had issues with potty training and smearing feces on the walls.

When Markwitz suggested the child go to therapy, Nereida Rios was resistant.

“I asked her didn’t she think she should see a therapist and Ms. Rios said no, we can handle it,” Markwitz said.

Markwitz also said she rarely, if ever, saw the couple’s two teenage children or their adopted son during visits.

Later in the week, jurors are expected to hear the testimony of a second former foster child who told investigators years earlier that she was also sexually abused by Rios while in his care.

The two children’s placements at the Rios home overlapped, according to testimony from child welfare workers.

Rios’ attorneys moved to block the testimony, raising concerns about inconsistencies in her story. But Judge Charles Roberts overruled their motion on grounds that the second child’s testimony had “striking and significant” similarities.

The trial is expected to end Thursday.
Address: 1777 Main St, Sarasota, FL 34236, USA

Title: New concern raised in lease of Camp McConnell land
Summary:
Winning bid held by former teacher investigated for inappropriate student contact

The man poised to run a 212-acre, year-round children’s camp on land now owned by Alachua County lost a teaching post after being accused of having an inappropriate relationship with a 16-year-old Marion County student, records show.

Jordan A. Richmond, a former West Port High School drama teacher, was investigated and reprimanded by Marion County Public Schools in 2016 after teachers and students raised concerns about his relationship with one of his students, causing him to lose his job.

Now, Richmond is president and founder of the Ocala-based nonprofit Basecamp Ventures and ranked first on the county’s shortlist to acquire Camp McConnell, a 212-acre campground near Micanopy, where the plan is to run a year-round camp with free and discounted services for Alachua County children.

Monday, Richmond denied having an inappropriate relationship with the female student and said all allegations were false.

“There was no findings of any sort,” he said. “Nothing ever happened.”

In February, Richmond’s nonprofit was selected to enter negotiations with the county to buy the camp with an opening bid of $500,000, roughly half what the county originally paid. The next day, The Sun reported the nonprofit had ties to state Sen. Keith Perry, R-Gainesville, who previously threatened to sue the county if he couldn’t purchase the land.

Perry’s ties were not disclosed prior to the selection and caused county officials to reopen the bidding process, worried that the process didn't appear transparent. Basecamp Ventures and Friendship Circle are the two entities vying for the campground, with Richmond’s company ranked as the No. 1 choice by county staff.

County officials are now looking to lease the property for 12 years at $100,000 each year, with an option to purchase after 12 years. The decision for who should run the camp is expected to be made at Thursday’s county commission meeting.

Details of Richmond’s past, however, could derail those plans, or so he fears. County officials said Monday they were unaware of the allegations surrounding Richmond and are investigating the matter.

“These are serious allegations that I’ve forwarded to our county manager and county attorney,” Commissioner Ken Cornell said. “I’ve asked our attorney to make sure that we get Mr. Richmond’s response to this in writing.”

According to a Marion County Public Schools 2016 investigation, witnesses said the 11th grade student and Richmond were often together when others weren’t, sometimes until 8 p.m. at the school or before others arrived in the morning. One teacher told investigators that the two were “very, very close.”

Another student, who worked closely with Richmond, said the female student wore Richmond’s wedding band and that Richmond used Twitter to talk to the girl. One tweet showed a picture of a beach where Richmond said “If only I could take (redaction) there.” The investigation redacted parts of the report that identified the girl. A second student told investigators of seeing the teacher and the girl text each other during class, as well as seeing them spend time in Richmond’s office with the door shut while other students were in the classroom. She was also in his classroom during times she should have been in other classes.

Richmond said he doesn’t wear a wedding ring, though he is married and has with four children, and said the two were rarely alone. He said the student helped him build sets for plays and spent time at rehearsals.

“There were students there all the time,” he said. “... I have been a child-care executive for over 25 years of my career … (The allegations) are based on hearsay and rumors, and nothing ever came of it.”

However, on May 1, 2016, a Sunday night, an Ocala police officer spotted Richmond and the girl, then 17, in a minivan behind an abandoned car dealership along Southwest College Road and State Road 200.

According to the incident report, the van began to drive away after spotting the patrol car but was then pulled over. The girl appeared to be crying and was discussing family issues with Richmond, the report said.

The two told police that they had just left a rehearsal at the school and that the girl texted Richmond to meet and talk in a private location. Richmond said he understood how the meeting appeared, but said he was simply trying to be supportive. He stated twice that he had no illegal intentions with the girl, the report said.

“I did not observe any sexual contact between either party upon initial contact,” the officer wrote in the report.

Richmond told school system investigators that the student requested they meet alone, through the student’s statements disputed that. He also said that he didn’t regret meeting with the student, but made a poor judgment in picking a location.

Investigators concluded Richmond used poor judgment, showed partiality and the confidence of his students, but did not confirm any romantic contact. He was never arrested or criminally charged in connection with the incident or investigation.

The student’s mother, Lisa Calderone, of Citrus County, said she heard from former West Port High School teachers that Richmond was looking to run a camp in Alachua County and thought officials should know about his past.

She wrote commissioners an email Monday morning detailing the relationship between Richmond and her daughter. Richmond said Monday that several of her claims in the email are false.

In a phone interview, Calderone said she didn’t have proof that the two had a sexual relationship and that her daughter wouldn’t talk about it, but that she always suspected it. She said her daughter eventually dropped out of school and moved to Los Angeles to work in adult films and that Richmond is at least partly to blame.

She said she previously tried to involve the police, but that her daughter’s reluctance to speak on the issue left them with little to go on.

“It’s alarming to me that he’d be working with children,” she said. “I’d assume he’d be mentoring these kids. It’s just heart-wrenching.”

Following the school district investigation, Richmond was told he wouldn’t be rehired, though Richmond said he wasn’t told it was because the investigation. He said the district reprimanded him for writing too many hall passes.

A week after being told he wouldn't be rehired, he applied for a job in Lake County and said he had never been investigated for misconduct or had his teaching contract non-renewed.

His response was flagged by the Florida Department of Education.

According to an April 2017 settlement agreement with the state, Richmond was reprimanded again, fined $1,000 and given three years of probation. The state, in a letter Richmond, said it didn't condone his actions and that he lessened the reputation of the profession. His teaching certification expired two months later and hasn’t been renewed.

In 2014, he served as executive director for Camp McConnell for five months, when it was run by the YMCA.

Some of the organizations that vouched for Richmond’s nonprofit in his county proposal include the University of Florida’s departments of sustainability and recreation sports, PACE Center for Girls, Florida Wildlife Care Center, Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation, the Gainesville Chamber of Commerce and CDS Family and Behavioral Health Service.

Commissioner Cornell said that Richmond should write letters to each of the organizations that vouched for him, so that they are aware of the allegations.

Richmond said Basecamp Ventures is ready to hit the ground running and he would hate if the allegations derailed that. Some of the services include free swimming lessons, scholarships, weekend retreats working with schools, hiking, having a conference center and leadership education.

“We’ve been doing this for a really long time and this program has the resources, staffing, team and experience,” he said. “We have a true desire and we are committed to Alachua County. We’re doing some tremendous things. This is a blip that didn’t lead to anything.”
Address: 2700 SW 13th St, Gainesville, FL 32608, USA

Title: New evidence released after man accused of killing family over $200K he spent on Bulgarian ‘cam girl’
Summary:
Hide Transcript Show Transcript

-- WHO JOINS US IN THE STUDIO. HE’S BEEN DIGGING THROUGH THESE DOCUMENTS. DAVE, WHAT HAVE WE JUST LEARNED? DAVE: WE’VE BEEN GOING THROUGH HOURS OF QUESTIONING, MUCH OF IT BEFORE GRANT AMATO WAS EVER ARRESTED IN JANUARY. HIS MOM, DAD AND BROTHER WERE FOUND SHOT TO DEATH IN THEIR CHULUOTA HOME. THE STATE SAYS AMATO HAD BEEN THROWN OUT OF THE HOUSE OVER CONTINUED SPENDING ON A PORN SITE WHERE HE’D DEVELOPED A RELATIONSHIP WITH A WOMAN FROM BULGARIA. HIS DEFENSE SAYS THERE’S NO PHYSICAL EVIDENCE TYING HIM TO THE CRIME. HERE’S A BIT OF THE QUESTIONING FROM THE DAY AFTER THE BODIE WERE DISCOVERED. DETECTIVE: YOU DON’T KNOW WHAT? YOU DON’T KNOW IF YOU FEEL BAD FOR DOING THIS TO YOUR FAMILY? GRANT: I MEAN, I’VE BEEN GETTING BLAMED FOR THE LAST HALF A YEAR FOR EVERYTHING AND I’VE BEEN TRYING TO MOVE IN A POSITIVE DIRECTION. EVERY DAY I’M REMINDED OF ALL THE TROUBLE THAT I’VE CAUSE I KEEP GETTING TOLD THE SAME THING OVER AND OVER AGAIN. THAT THERE IS NOTHING I CAN DO TO CHANGE IT. DETECTIVE: DO YOU REGRET DOING THAT TO EACH ONE OF YOUR FAMILY MEMBERS? GRANT: I DIDN’T DO THAT TO EACH ONE OF THEM. DAVE: THERE’S A LOT MORE TO GO THROUGH AND WE’LL CONTINUE TO REVIEW

Advertisement New evidence released after man accused of killing family over $200K he spent on Bulgarian ‘cam girl’ Share Shares Copy Link Copy

A Seminole County man facing murder charges in the deaths of three of his family members following an alleged fight over him sending $200,000 to a Bulgarian woman on an adult camera website maintained his innocence in interviews with detectives after he the bodies were found. Grant Amato, 29, is charged with killing his parents, Chad Amato, 59, Margaret Amato, 61, both of Chuluota, and brother Cody Amato, 31. Amato’s defense says there's no physical evidence tying him to the crime.Detective: "You don't know what? You don't know if you feel bad for doing this to your family?"Grant Amato: “I mean I've been getting blamed for the last half a year for everything and I've been trying to move in a positive direction. Every day I'm reminded of all the trouble that I've caused. I keep getting told the same thing over and over again.”Detective: “Do you regret doing that to each one of your family members?”Grant: “I didn't do that to each one of them.” According to an arrest affidavit, Grant Amato had been admitted to a south Florida rehab center for sex addiction treatment in December.His family ordered him to go to the rehab center after they found out he’d wired more than $200,000 of their money to a woman in Bulgaria.When Grant Amato returned from rehab his family ordered him not to have any communication with the woman in Bulgaria, but he said he continued speaking with the woman on Twitter.On the night of Jan. 24, Grant Amato’s father confronted him about the communication. Chad Amato and his wife, along with their 31-year-old son, were found dead the next morning.The bodies were found at the home in the Pickett Downs subdivision after an employer of one of the victims requested a welfare check when the man failed to show up for work.

Title: Man accused of killing girl, 6, and 2 women in Haines City due in court
Summary:
Man accused of killing girl, 6, and 2 women in Haines City due in court Video

HAINES CITY, Fla. (WFLA) – A man suspected of killing a 6-year-old girl and two other people at a home in Haines City on Friday has turned himself in. Ernst Cherizard, 38, is expected to appear before a judge Monday afternoon.

Cherizard was wanted in connection with the shooting deaths of Elizabelle Frenel, 6, her mother Eli Junia Normil, 23, and Normil's aunt, Nicole Guillume, 48.

Police say Ernst Cherizard, 38, shot Frenel and her mother, 23-year-old Eli Junia Normil at the Citrus Ridge Apartments shortly before 7:30 p.m Friday. Normil died and the child was left critically injured.

When Normil's relatives came to the apartment to check on her, Cherizard told them they were not there. Her aunt, 48-year-old Nicole Guillume, returned to the complex and a confrontation ensued. That's when Cherizard fired a handgun and killed Guillume before fleeing. His vehicle was last seen passing a Boyton Beach toll plaza shortly after midnight Saturday, according to police.

Police arrived at the scene and Frenel was rushed to an Orlando hospital, where she died the next day.

Police said Normil and Cherizard were in a relationship and have two children together, but Frenel was not his child.

In the early hours Saturday, Cherizard took to Facebook to acknowledge the crime and apologized to his children.

"Daddy is so sorry with all my heart cuz I can't believe this happened," he wrote in the post.
Address: 200 S Parker St, Tampa, FL 33606, USA

Title: Haines City triple shooting suspect turns himself in
Summary:
- The suspect in Friday's triple shooting in Haines City has turned himself in to police.

The Haines City Police Department said 38-year-old Ernst Cherizard turned himself in to authorities just after 2 p.m. Sunday.

Police said Cherizard shot his 23-year-old girlfriend, Eli Junia Normil, inside a Haines City apartment complex before turning the gun on Normil's 6-year-old daughter, Elizabelle Frenel. Police said the girl was shot three times; one of those shots was fired directly at the young girl's head. The girl died just before 11 p.m. on Saturday.

Cherizard also shot Normil's mother, 48-year-old Nicole Guillume, who showed up a short time later looking for her daughter, the family told FOX 13.

Cherizard fled the scene Friday night and his vehicle was spotted in South Florida at a Boynton Beach toll plaza just after midnight on Saturday.

Police said they teamed up with U.S. Marshals to find him; however, Cherizard turned himself in soon after.

"Because of Cherizard's cowardly actions -- and they are nothing short of cowardly -- a family now has to bury three members, including a young child who had her whole life in front of her," Chief Jim Elensky said. "Our team is doing everything we can to bring this person to justice and help provide

closure for this family through this absolutely horrific tragedy. Our thoughts are with them as we continue this investigation."

This is a developing story. Stay with FOX 13 for updates.
Address: 35 Skyline Dr, Lake Mary, FL 32746, USA

Title: Haines City police: 6-year-old girl injured in shooting dies; search continues for man
Summary:
HAINES CITY, Fla. - A 6-year-old girl who was injured in a shooting that left two women dead has died, according to the Haines City Police Department.

Haines City police said Elizabelle Frenel succumbed to her injuries and was pronounced dead at an Orlando hospital before 11 p.m. Saturday.

Eli Junia Normil, 23, and Nicole Guillume, 48, were identified by police as the two women killed.

Police said Ernst Cherizard, 38, remained at large Saturday after fleeing in a burgundy 2011 Nissan Altima with Florida tag GZN C82.

Normil and Cherizard were in a relationship and have two children together, police said.

Elizabelle is not Cherizard's child, police said. Guillume is Normil's aunt.

Police said the vehicle was last seen passing the Boyton Beach toll plaza shortly after midnight Saturday. Cherizard fled in the vehicle before 7:30 p.m. Friday.

The Haines City Police Department and other law agencies are working to find Cherizard. Anyone who comes across Cherizard is asked to call 911.

UPDATE: We’re sad to report that Elizabelle Frenel, 6, succumbed to her injuries and was pronounced dead at an Orlando hospital before 11 p.m. Saturday night.



Cherizard remains at large.



Our next update will be on Sunday. pic.twitter.com/DoYvqSw40K — Haines City Police Department (@HainesCityPD) April 14, 2019

The two adult women deceased in this case were identified earlier as Eli Junia Normil, 23, and Nicole Guillume, 48. pic.twitter.com/x4tTCC14wv — Haines City Police Department (@HainesCityPD) April 14, 2019

Copyright 2019 by WKMG ClickOrlando - All rights reserved.
Address: 4466 N John Young Pkwy, Orlando, FL 32804, USA

Title: Florida parents who didn't know girl was gone for 14 hours charged with neglect, authorities say
Summary:
The girl, believed to be 2, was found wandering in a park near PBIA on Friday night.

WEST PALM BEACH — Parents of a toddler allegedly said it took 14 hours to realize they had left her at a park. Now the suburban West Palm Beach couple is charged with child neglect and another seven of their children have been pulled from their home, authorities said Sunday.

Makenson Alexandre, 34, was booked Saturday afternoon at the Palm Beach County Jail and left early Sunday morning. Jolanda Larose Alexandre, 27 — her first name also is spelled Yolanda — was booked Saturday afternoon and left a few hours later. Both posted $3,000 bail.

Makensen said at midday Monday that he could not comment now but might later. He declined to give either his daughter's name or age.

According to the Palm Beach County Sheriff's Office, the girl, believed to be 2, was found wandering alone just before 8 p.m. Friday at Haverhill Park, on Belvedere Road, west of Palm Beach International Airport. She wore a pink short-sleeve shirt with "adorable" on the front, along with a white and gold-colored tutu and clear plastic shoes.

Deputies canvassed the area and reverse 911 calls were made in an effort to find the girl’s parents. The agency sent out a note for media outlets headlined, "Do you know who I am?"

Late Friday, authorities placed the child with the Florida Department of Children and Families.

At about 11:40 a.m. Saturday, the parents reported their daughter missing. Detectives went to their home in the Stacy Street apartments, near Belvedere and Haverhill, about a half mile north of the park. The parents said they had not realized until then that they didn't have the little girl.

DCF removed the other seven children from the home and the parents were arrested, PBSO said Sunday morning.

According to a sheriff's report, two women walking in the park had come across the child and called authorities. The wife told deputies she'd loaded the children in her SUV, picked up her husband at work and headed to the park, where he let the children play for about an hour. She said when she returned home, she thought she saw the 2-year-old playing outside before she went to sleep.

She said she awoke at about 8:30 a.m. Saturday and soon realized the toddler wasn't there. She said she asked the other children and they said the toddler hadn't slept with them.

She said she and the other children "began looking frantically for" the toddler, then called 911. The report said the mother "was crying and shaking and said she cannot believe that she left (name withheld) in the park. She said this is the first time anything like this has happened and her children have never gone missing before."

The mother said she usually checks on the children at bedtime but had not done so this time.

The father told investigators he also did not check on the children, either when leaving the park or when returning home about 7:15 p.m. He said he dressed and went to church, then came home around 11 p.m. and went to sleep. He also said he did not check on the children. He said he loaded the children in the SUV on Saturday morning to go back to the park and it wasn't until they nearly were there that he realized the toddler was missing.

Staff writers Joe Capozzi and Julius Whigham II contributed to this story.
Address: 501 W 11th St, Panama City, FL 32401, USA

Title: Edgewater cop suspended after being warned or disciplined 10 times
Summary:
Among the allegations made against Officer Andrew Spurlock is that he engaged in intimate contact with a woman in his squad car while on duty on a street corner.

An Edgewater police officer who is dating a city councilwoman will be suspended without pay for 12 days for being late for one work shift and napping during another.

It's just the latest disciplinary action against Officer Andrew Spurlock. All told, he's been disciplined or received a warning 10 times since 2017, records show. Among other things, Spurlock was reprimanded earlier this year following allegations he had intimate contact with a woman in his police vehicle while on duty.

"The Edgewater Police Department follows a progressive discipline model," Interim Police Chief Joe Mahoney wrote to The News-Journal in an email Thursday. "We ensure our officers are accountable for their actions."

As part of his suspension that begins next week, Spurlock is required to forfeit his badge and gun. He was hired by the Edgewater Police Department in August 2016 and is paid $35,921 annually.

Spurlock denied the accusation he had relations with a woman while in uniform, but the ensuing investigation still resulted in discipline and a loss of 12 hours of personal time off. He lost another 12 hours of personal time off for failing to call in sick for an overtime shift late last year.

Spurlock is dating City Councilwoman Megan O'Keefe.

His most recent mistakes resulted in a harsher punishment. He is not allowed to work or get paid for any of his scheduled shifts from April 22 through May 12, according to the city.

On Feb. 25, Sgt. Sara Pollard reported to Spurlock's supervisor that she caught him sleeping and snoring in his patrol vehicle in front of Boston Whaler when she showed up to relieve him. Spurlock told both his supervisor and the internal affairs investigator that he was "horsing around" with Pollard by pretending he was asleep. He was found in violation of two department policies as a result.

On March 11, Spurlock was scheduled to arrive at work at 6 a.m., but didn't show up until 6:50 a.m., according to a report. Spurlock said he was late because he set his alarm to P.M. instead of A.M. That allegation was sustained.

For those two infractions, Spurlock was suspended for a total of 144 work hours.

The one who came forward with three of the allegations against the embattled police officer in late 2018 was the estranged husband of O'Keefe, the city councilwoman who is dating Spurlock.

James O'Keefe's most serious accusation against Spurlock is that he performed a sex act on a woman while on duty and in uniform in his patrol car.

Spurlock was accused of meeting up with the woman one night in February 2018 at the intersection of 22nd Street and Hibiscus Drive. It was learned during the internal affairs investigation that Spurlock spent more than 92 minutes at that location, according to a report.

Spurlock told Soltz he never fondled the woman. Soltz stated in his report that Spurlock told him he parks at the intersection "a lot" to do paperwork. In the same report, Spurlock said he had no specific recollection of what he was doing at that street corner on that particular night.

The woman's story about that night differed from Spurlock's. The woman told Lt. Aaron Soltz, the internal affairs investigator, that she was with Spurlock. At one point, she had her back to him while he was seated in his car with his legs turned outward, the report stated. She also said she was standing between Spurlock's legs. That's when the officer slid his hand down the front of her pants and fondled her, according to the report.

[READ MORE: Edgewater's 'Family Affair' government leads to possible City Council violations]

James O'Keefe received Facebook messages from someone describing how Spurlock and the woman met, as well as "sexual encounters they had on and off duty," the report stated.

O'Keefe told his estranged wife about Spurlock's relationship with the other woman and she was later interviewed by Soltz. Megan O'Keefe told Soltz that Spurlock initially lied to her about the encounters he had with the woman, but he later admitted it, according to the report. O'Keefe said Spurlock told her their encounters occurred while he was off duty, Soltz stated.

Spurlock met the 44-year-old Edgewater woman during a traffic crash investigation. The two exchanged phone calls and met up several times, Soltz wrote. At one point, while Spurlock was at the woman's house, he played a prank on her teenage niece. He had the teen blow into a device and Spurlock told her she tested positive for "weed in her system," Soltz wrote in his report. Spurlock pulled out a pair of handcuffs, which caused the girl to get scared and cry, the report stated.

Spurlock contradicted some of those details, telling Soltz he showed the girl the handcuffs after she asked to see them and that she never cried, according to a summary of the investigation.

The allegation sustained against Spurlock was that he violated the officer's Code of Conduct by being inattentive to his duties. The allegation that his professional conduct was detrimental to the morale and reputation of the department was not sustained.

Megan O'Keefe was arrested in September 2018 on a domestic battery charge following allegations she scratched and struck her husband during an argument. The argument was over O'Keefe allegedly seeing someone else, according to an arrest report.

[READ MORE: Edgewater councilwoman arrested after scuffle with husband]

The State Attorney's Office decided not to prosecute the councilwoman.

James O'Keefe came forward two other times with complaints against Spurlock in late 2018. O'Keefe's attorney emailed then-Edgewater police chief David Acieri alleging that Spurlock "inflamed an already volatile situation" involving O'Keefe and his ex-wife.

O'Keefe said he was at his estranged wife's home the night of Sept. 29, 2018 with a police officer. He was there removing property from the house, which he had previously shared with his wife.

While he was at the house, Megan O'Keefe showed up. James O'Keefe accused Spurlock of notifying her about his presence there. This came two weeks or so after Megan O'Keefe's domestic battery arrest.

Spurlock and Megan O'Keefe denied the accusation that Spurlock tipped her off about her estranged husband being at her house. He was cleared of that allegation.

In November 2018, James O'Keefe also filed a complaint alleging Spurlock had interfered with a Florida Department of Children and Families investigation involving him and his estranged wife. The investigation revealed that Spurlock asked the DCF agent whether a case was ongoing, but didn't pressure her to disclose anything sensitive. That allegation also was unfounded.

A fourth internal affairs investigation resulted in a sustained allegation against Spurlock, one that didn't involve James O'Keefe. Soltz concluded Spurlock had failed to notify his supervisor that he was too sick to work an overtime shift in November.

DON'T MISS AN EPISODE, SUBSCRIBE: iTunes |Google Play
Address: 901 6th St, Daytona Beach, FL 32117, USA

Title: The week ahead is jazzy, funky and flat out Okilly Dokilly | Music Roundup
Summary:
There’s too much musical pork for just one fork this week, y’all. Check it:

Funky reggae fest

Move to the groove at the Gadsden Reggae & Blues Festival Friday and Saturday at 5F Farm Event Center, 8701 Salem Road near Havana. Reggae legends Marcia Griffiths, Pluto Shervington, The Abyssinians, Anthony Que and more join blues crews Chubby Carrier, Joey Gilmore, Lomax, The Heather Gillis Band and others in the lineup. Gates open at 9 a.m. each day. Two-day passes are $30 online, $45 at the gate; one-day passes are $20 online, $25 at the gate. RV hook-ups and primitive campsites are available on a limited basis for an extra fee; reservations required. Visit www.havanareggaefest.com.

Royal treatment

Khris Royal hits The Yard this weekend. (Photo: Natasha Jasperson)

New Orleans sax man/songwriter/bandleader Khris Royal has been mixing it up with his hometown big dogs — players like most of the Marsalis family and Alvin Batiste — since he started producing and writing music at the age of 14. He currently serves as the main (and only) horn man in George Porter Jr. & the Runnin’ Pardners and as a touring member of Rebelution. He brings his own band Dark Matter to impart some jazz and electro-infused funk from the Crescent City at 8 p.m. Friday at The Yard in Railroad Square Art Park. Tickets are $10. Visit https://www.facebook.com/yardatrailroad/.

‘New Renaissance’ woman

Buy Photo Elizabeth A. Baker calls herself a “New Renaissance Artist." (Photo: Democrat files)

Elizabeth A. Baker calls herself a “New Renaissance Artist,” but what does that mean? For one thing, it means her performances are born anew at each show, feeding off the energy of her audience and her own intuitive connection with the space in which she performs and the sounds that space generates. Baker’s mesmerizing performances break the fourth wall and draw the audience into the circle of sound, making the audience members her collaborators. She is touring to promote “Quadrivium,” her first album on Aerocade Music, which includes world premieres of works by composers Nathan Corder and Karlheinz Essl alongside performances with the Baker-Hess Duo. Baker performs with opener blacksunblackmoon at 7 p.m. Friday at Indianhead Factory, 1020 E. Indianhead Drive. There’s probably a cover charge. Call 850-510-3892 to find out.

Sunshine State of mind

Old school Florida bluesman and man-with-a-thousand-watt-smile Joey Gilmore brings vocalist Dottie Kelly along for a show at 9 p.m. Friday at Bradfordville Blues Club, 7152 Moses Lane. Gilmore’s limber voice lends itself to gut-bucket blues, sweet soul and sassy R&B, and with Kelly along for the ride, there will definitely be some vocal pyrotechnics. Get there by 8:30 p.m. if you want free drag blues dance lessons before the show. Tickets are $25 advance, $30 at the door. Visit www.bradfordvilleblues.com.

Shakin’ Kingsnakes

Local band Finn & the Kingsnakes celebrate a year of playing together at a release party for the debut CD “The Best Kind of Trouble” at 8 p.m. Friday at The Junction at Monroe, 2011 S. Monroe St. Band members include John Ratowski on lead guitar and vocals, Tiffiny Hewitt-Brown on guitar and vocals, Tim Hendrix on bass and vocals, and Howard Rich on drums. Cover is $5. Visit www.junctionatmonroe.com.

Orchestral maneuvers

The Big Bend Community Orchestra celebrates its 25th season with a concert featuring works by Gershwin, Shubert, Dvorak and Saint-Saens at 3:30 p.m. Saturday in TCC’s Turner Auditorium on Appleyard Drive. The orchestra was founded in 1994 and consists of more than 50 volunteer musicians — homemakers, professionals, music teachers, retirees and students. Founding member Ginny Densmore will be the featured soloist on a clarinet concerto by Weber, and other alumni will join the orchestra in this celebration. It’s free and there’s a reception following the performance. Visit bigbendcommunityorchestra.org.

More: It's 25 years and counting for the Big Bend Community Orchestra

Rave on, Raven

Raise hell on the dance floor when Reverend Raven and the Chain-Smoking Altar Boys bring hot blues harp ace Westside Andy along for a juke joint revival at 9 p.m. Saturday at Bradfordville Blues Club, 7152 Moses Lane. Raven and his crew play a gritty mix of Chicago electric blues and West Coast Swing. Prepare to meet your maker. Tickets are $20 advance, $25 at the door. Visit www.bradfordvilleblues.com.

Made in Mississippi

Roots music duo Libby Rae Watson and Wes Lee absorbed the blues from the ground up in their home state of Mississippi. Watson was mentored by the great Sam Chatmon, the last surviving member of th—e legendary Mississippi Sheiks. Watson and Lee blow in for a set or two at 8 p.m. Saturday at Blue Tavern, 1206 N. Monroe St. Cover is $10. Call 850-212-5204.

He’s the jazz man

Count Basie Orchestra leader and trumpet maestro Scotty Barnhart assembles the troops — including David Detwiler on sax, Bill Peterson on piano, Jose Serrano on bass and Felix Allen on drums — to jazz things up between 8 and 10 p.m. Saturday at Black Dog on the Square in Railroad Square Art Park. Cover is $5. 850-841-7778.

Yacht rock docks

Buy Photo Naugahyde Park dips into the well of '70s soft rock. (Photo: Democrat files)

The well of ‘70s soft rock is deep (some would say bottomless), and local band Naugahyde Park dips into it on the regular to add to its songbook of classic hits. The band has worked up some Alan Parsons tunes — “Sirius” and “Eye in the Sky” — and an Olivia Newton John nugget — “A Little More Love” — to add to set list staples like “Summer Breeze,” “The Chain” (featuring sizzling vocals by Rory Krivit), “Dancing Queen,” “The Things We Do for Love” and more for a show from 8 to 11 p.m. Saturday at the American Legion Hall at Lake Ella. Cover is $8. Call 850-222-3382.

Begonias in bloom

Grateful Dead tribute band Blue Begonias kick in the jams at 6:30 p.m. Saturday at Bowery Station in Apalachicola. The Begonias lineup is chock-full o’ talent, including Mickey Abraham, Chris Skene, Brian Durham, Reo Morris and David Mendelsohn. That’s a supergroup that can jam with the best of ‘em. Call 850-653-2211 for more information.

Preachin’ the blues

This week’s Lost Monday guest host is Reverend Robert, slide guitar champ and old school Delta blues disciple. The Rev will hold a service of song from 8 to 10 p.m. Monday at Blue Tavern, 1206 N. Monroe St. Cover is $2. Call 850-212-5204.

Free-range and feral

Avey Tare of Animal Collective plays a show Tuesday at The Wilbury. (Photo: COURTESY)

There are musical collectives, and then there’s Animal Collective, a truly fluid mingling of talents and influences anchored by founder David Portner, aka Avey Tare, a musician enchanted with the possibilities of pushing the sound envelope and expanding the sonic palette. With Animal Collective, Portner/Tare constructed dense and often dizzying musical collages. As a solo artist, he has explored more personal but no less challenging territory — his interior soundscapes, as it were. Portner/Tare’s latest solo release — “Cows on Hourglass Pond” — finds him layering electronic effects over pulsing rhythms, throbbing synths and manipulated vocals. It’s urgent and intimate and hypnotic. Step into Avey Tare’s world when he visits for a show with Geologist at 9:30 p.m. Tuesday at The Wilbury, 513 W. Gaines St. Tickets are $14 general public, free for FSU students. Visit https://www.facebook.com/events/285070572159757/.

Viva Brasil!

Celebrate International Day of Choro with Tallahassee’s on choro ensemble As Saudades from 8 to 10 p.m. Tuesday at Blue Tavern, 1206 N. Monroe St. It’s a day to pay homage to flautist-turned-saxophonist Pixinguinha, the father of modern choro music in Brazil. Cover is $2. Call 850-212-5204.

Hi diddly ho, neighborinos!

Buy Photo Okilly Dokilly plays its only North Florida show Thursday at The Wilbury. (Photo: Democrat files)

You might think that a band named Okilly Dokilly and comprised of five dudes sporting combed-back hair, dad ‘staches, wire-rimmed spectacles and green pullover sweaters — five dudes, in fact, who are the spittin’ images of dorkus maximus Ned Flanders from “The Simpsons” — is a joke. And it is. But it’s also a badass “Nedal” band that packs plenty of headbanging chunk in songs like “Godspeed Little Doodle” and “White Wine Spritzer.” The latter was played over the closing credits of the long-running animated TV show on April 7. Both tunes are from the Phoenix, Ariz., band’s 2016 debut album “Howdilly Doodilly.” The Neds — Head Ned, Shred Ned, Zed Ned, Dread Ned and Bed Ned — bring the thunder of the freshly released second opus “Howdilly Twodilly” to a thrash-fest with Bear Ghost, Unico and Feedlot in the band’s only North Florida show at 8:30 p.m. Thursday at The Wilbury, 513 W. Gaines St. Tickets are $14 advance, $16 day of show, with a $2 under-21 fee at the door. Visit www.ticketfly.com/purchase/event/1826461.

And the beat goes on . . .

Singer-songwriter Emily Gabriel eases you into the weekend on wings of song from 7 to 9 p.m. Friday at Black Dog on the Square in Railroad Square Art Park. No cover. Call 850-841-7778. . . . Make it funky with Darryl Steele & Friends — including fellow band members from former funk posse Work for Higher — at 8 p.m. Friday at Blue Tavern, 1206 N. Monroe St. Cover is $5. Call 850-212-5204. . . . Deja Blu delivers sweet harmonies at 8 p.m. Friday at Backwoods Bistro, 401 E. Tennessee St. No cover. Call 850-320-6345. . . . Three Billy Goats Gruff get salty from 7 to 10 p.m. Friday at Half Shell Dockside in Apalachicola. No cover. Call 850-653-1211. . . . Clever Girl plays covers chosen with sly wit and savvy at 8 p.m. Saturday at Waterworks, 1133 Thomasville Road. Cover is $5. Call 850-224-1887. . . . Three Billy Goats Gruff choogles on over to Carrabelle for a show at 8 p.m. Saturday at Fathoms Steam Room & Raw Bar. No cover. Call 850-697-9712. . . . If it’s Hump Day, it’s time for Happy Hour with Garnet & Soul from 5 to 7:30 p.m. Wednesday at The Yard in Railroad Square Art Park. No cover. Visit https://www.facebook.com/yardatrailroad/.

Address: 277 N Magnolia Dr, Tallahassee, FL 32301, USA

Title: After Beyoncé surprise album, Netflix 'Homecoming' documentary may feature familiar FAMU faces
Summary:
Before the much-anticipated Netflix documentary, “Homecoming: A Film By Beyoncé” was scheduled to start streaming at 3:01 a.m. Wednesday, Don P. Roberts wasn’t quite sure what to expect.

The Queen Bey dropped a surprise 40-track album Wednesday to accompany the documentary, wowing the world and her faithful Beehive of fans.

But the former Marching 100 drum major — chosen by the star’s team to help bring the authentic HBCU culture to her 2018 Coachella concert upon which the film is based — expects it to include glimpses of faces familiar to Florida A&M University alumni.

In a nod to the pop culture icon’s international status – and the total control she commands over her empire — Netflix remained mum on any advance details.

Earlier this month, it did release a trailer, a fast-moving tease of some of the scenes.

Included was snapshot of men wearing FAMU T-shirts, which already has made its way around social media.

USA Today reported it gives “glimpses at Queen Bey and her team's preparation for the performance, set to the words of Maya Angelou.”

More: Beyoncé reveals past pregnancy struggles and more can't miss moments from 'Homecoming'

"I want to be representative of my race: the human race," the late poet and activist can be heard saying. "I have a chance to show how kind we can be, how intelligent and generous we can be. I have a chance to teach and to love and to laugh. I know that when I finish doing what I'm sent here to do, I will be called home, and I will go home without any fear (or) trepidations wondering what's going to happen."

Special premier viewings were held Tuesday night at Howard University in Washington, D.C., and Texas Southern University in the star’s hometown of Houston.

Netflix's 'Homecoming' documentary has FAMU ties

The two-hour-plus film captures a behind-the-scenes look at Beyoncé’s groundbreaking 2018 performance at the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival in Indio, California.

In it, she exposed the world to homecoming culture at HBCUs, complete with dancers, a nod to Greek life, marching bands and drumlines.

Beyoncé’s affinity for HBCUs stems from her father, who graduated from Fisk University, a private HBCU in Nashville, Tennessee.

The Florida A&M influence was propelled when Beyoncé’s team requested the assistance of Roberts, a FAMU alum and former Marching 100 drum major, who is recognized as one of the country’s most respected music educators.

Florida A&M University graduate Don P. Roberts, is CEO of DRUMLine Live, and music supervisor for DeKalb County Schools in Georgia. (Photo: Special to the Democrat)

Roberts attended FAMU from 1980 to 1985, earning his degree in music education. One of his classmates was Shelby Chipman, current professor of music and director of marching and pep bands at the university.

Based in Atlanta, Roberts is CEO of DRUMLine Live, music supervisor for DeKalb County Schools and former band director at Southwest DeKalb High School.

Roberts gained national recognition as executive band consultant for the movie “Drumline,” where he was in charge of working with actors, creating the precision drills and more.

INDIO, CA - APRIL 14: Beyonce Knowles performs onstage during 2018 Coachella Valley Music And Arts Festival Weekend 1 at the Empire Polo Field on April 14, 2018 in Indio, California. (Photo by Kevin Winter/Getty Images for Coachella) (Photo: Getty Images for Coachella)

He also served as band consultant for the BET series “The Quad” which which was set on a fictitious black university campus in Atlanta.

DRUMLine Live is an international tour production, including alumni from Florida A&M, Tennessee State, Alabama State and other HBCUs.

Among its members are former FAMU musicians and dancers with campus troupes. Former Marching 100 drum major Slater Thorpe, serves as its show announcer, the same role he snagged for Beyoncé’s Coachella performance.

2018 Coachella performance: First black woman to headline, other achievements

It was Roberts who was sought after by Beyoncé’s team to help bring the HBCU experience to her Coachella production.

“None of us had a role in the 'Homecoming' Netflix special,” Roberts said. “However, I'm sure you will see most of them in the special.”

Roberts said DRUMLine Live was responsible for securing HBCU-experienced band members to blend in with the group already established by Beyoncé’s team for her performance at Coachella.

“Her musicians were incredible and so were the members of DRUMLine Live,” Roberts said. “They made an extraordinary team that made musical history together. We were not responsible for the steppers and dancers. I selected all members from DRUMLine Live and assisted her musical director with rehearsals. I think our greatest role was bringing true HBCU authenticity to Coachella.”

That was critical, Robert said.

“Going into the project, my biggest concern was being authentic to the HBCU culture,” he said. “I know the Beehive was tough, but I knew if we did not properly pay tribute to the HBCU culture, inclusive of marching band, sororities, and fraternities, we were gonna have to deal with the wrath and scorn of HBCU band heads and alumni worldwide.”

Beyonce surprises fans with Netflix 'Homecoming' (Photo: Netflix)

Fortune magazine reported Beyoncé — the first black woman to headline at Coachella — broke viewership records on YouTube, with her HBCU-themed set attracting 458,000 simultaneous global viewers at its peak, making it the most viewed Coachella performance ever.

Her performance included over 100 singers, dancers, and musicians.

“I applaud the Queen and her staff for taking such a huge risk, but also for flawlessly executing what some may have thought was an impossible task,” Roberts said. “She is now a part of HBCU music history forever. I think her impact will be felt in the future by the positive exposure it will bring to the HBCU culture.”

Contact senior writer Byron Dobson at bdobson@tallahassee.com or on Twitter @byrondobson.

FAMUans who performed with Beyonce at Coachella

Former Florida A&M musicians selected by Roberts to perform with Beyonce’ at Coachella in 2018 were:

Travord Rolle, Marching 100, Trombone

Brian Snell, Marching 100, Drum Major (Tallahassee)

Wayne Westley, Marching 100, Drum Major, Strikers

Tallie Brinson, Marching 100, Trombone, Strikers

Lomario Marchman, Marching 100, French horn

Issac Carter, Marching 100, Bass Drum

Brandon Cunningham, Marching 100, Trumpet, Strikers

Rashaad Horne, Marching 100, Cymbals, Strikers

Naderah Munajj, FAMU Mahogany Rehearsal Director

Jason Price, Marching 100, Snare Drum

Jarmal Terry, Marching 100, Trumpet, Strikers.

CLOSE Madeline Bryant and Aidan Faminoff, known affectionately as Beyonce Girl and Boy, met up after a quest to find each other using Snapchat's campus story feature. Courtesy Madeline Bryant

Title: Jonchuck found guilty of murder, sentenced to life
Summary:
CLEARWATER — A Florida jury on Tuesday found a man guilty of first-degree murder for dropping his 5-year-old daughter off a bridge four years ago, despite arguments from his attorneys that he was insane and thought his actions would actually save her. He was automatically sentenced to life in prison.

Jurors in Clearwater, deliberated for about seven hours over two days before convicting John Jonchuck, whom prosecutors portrayed as a vengeful man who planned to kill his daughter to keep her away from her mother and grandmother.

The Tampa Bay Times reported that no one from Jonchuck's family was in the courtroom when the verdict was announced. And no friends or relatives spoke on behalf of Phoebe or her father before the sentencing. Jonchuck, who was stoic when the verdict was read, hugged his attorneys and said, "Yes, your honor," when asked if he understood that the verdict carries an automatic life sentence. He was then fingerprinted and taken out of the courtroom by bailiffs.

Jonchuck's lawyers had asked the judge to delay sentencing for a week because they have some issues to check. But when they failed to provide a reason, Judge Chris Helinger proceeded with the sentencing.

"I am satisfied that justice was done," the newspaper quoted Pinellas-Pasco State Attorney Bernie McCabe as saying. "My immediate reaction is killing children doesn't make one a very sympathetic character."

The judge thanked jurors for their attention during the month-long trial. "There's no way I can express my appreciation for your service," she said. "I've never had a trial this long and I've been here about 12 years as a judge."

No one disputed that Jonchuck, now 29, dropped his daughter Phoebe 62 feet into Tampa Bay in January 2015, and that he had a long history of mental problems.

But prosecutors claimed his action was premeditated. Assistant state attorney Paul Bolan told jurors that Jonchuck was motivated by anger over worries that Phoebe's mother was going to take the girl away from him and his own mother's doting attention to her granddaughter when she had been inattentive to him growing up.

"It was rage that drove him to it on top of that bridge," Bolan said. "Did he know what he was doing, and did he know it was wrong? The answer is clearly yes."

But assistant public defender Jessica Manuele told jurors Jonchuck loved Phoebe more than anything else in the world and that there's no evidence he acted out of "unbridled anger."

His delusions led him to believe Phoebe was possessed and that the archangel, Michael, was coming, Manuele said. He poured salt outside her window to keep spirits away, she said.

At the moment he threw her off the bridge, "he thought he was protecting his daughter," Manuele said. "It will never make sense because it's insanity."

Twelve hours before Phoebe's death, Jonchuck's divorce lawyer, Genevieve Torres, called a state child protection hotline, fearing for the girl's safety, authorities said.

Torres told the Department of Children and Families operator that Jonchuck had driven to three churches in his pajamas with Phoebe in tow that morning, called Torres "God" and asked her to translate his stepmother's century-old Swedish Bible, which he carried and had become obsessed with. Jonchuck was also paranoid that Phoebe wasn't his child, Torres said.

But the operator thought the attorney was more worried about Jonchuck's safety than the girl's and did not report the call to authorities, they said.

Just after midnight the next day, Jonchuck's PT Cruiser raced past officer William Vickers, who was heading home from a shift in his patrol car. He started following Jonchuck, but never got close enough to read the license plate and didn't know Phoebe was inside, authorities have said.

As they reached the bridge's crest, Jonchuck stopped and got out. Vickers, fearing an ambush, stopped behind him, pulled his gun and yelled at Jonchuck to show his hands. He saw no weapon.

Jonchuck yelled at the officer, "You have no free will." He grabbed Phoebe from the back seat, held her over the side momentarily and then dropped her, according to police accounts.

Jonchuck drove off but was soon arrested. Vickers scrambled down a ladder to a dock below the bridge but couldn't see Phoebe in the dark water. A marine rescue boat was summoned, and her body was found hours later.
Address: 300 W Lime St, Lakeland, FL 33815, USA

Title: 'Stay with me, stay with me:' 911 calls released in Palm Coast teen's death
Summary:
FLAGLER COUNTY, Fla. - Calls placed to 911 moments after a Palm Coast teen was fatally shot were released Tuesday along with a push from the Flagler County Sheriff's Office for additional witnesses to the crime to come forward.

A friend of 18-year-old Curtis Israel Gray called 911 along with a witness who stepped outside and saw the teen bleeding in the parking lot of Palm Coast Laundry around 12:30 a.m. Saturday.

"My friend just got shot," Gray's friend said.

The friend said Gray was shot in the chest and was trying to stay conscious.

The other witness who called 911 told an operator that there was no exit wound on Gray's back.

"Stay with me, stay with me," someone can be heard telling Gray during that 911 call.

The friend said a man named Frank who lives in the P Section of Palm Coast was responsible for the shooting. He said that man fled in a dark-colored SUV with three other people in it.

"I don't know his last name, but I know it's a girl driving the truck, it's a white dude in the front and there's two other people in the back," the friend said.

Deputies said 17-year-old Marion Lee Gavins was arrested Sunday after he turned himself in to authorities. He's facing a first-degree murder charge.

Though an arrest has been made in connection with Gray's death, deputies said they are still seeking additional witnesses to the crime as well as investigating witness tampering claims after reports of threats of retaliation to those who are cooperating with law enforcement.

“Learn from the mistakes of others that violence is not going to solve your problems,” Flagler County Sheriff Rick Staly said. “Don’t let another life be ruined or lost to senseless violence.”

Deputies said anyone who threatens a witness could face charges.

Teresa Selgado, also known as Alex, is being sought in connection with the case, but she is not considered a suspect.

Anyone with information about the shooting or potential witness tampering is asked to call FCSO at 386-313-4911 or email TIPS@flaglersheriff.com.

A GoFundMe account has been established to help pay for Gray's funeral expenses.

Copyright 2019 by WKMG ClickOrlando - All rights reserved.
Address: 4466 N John Young Pkwy, Orlando, FL 32804, USA

Title: North Port foster dad accused of sexual abuse stands trial today
Summary:
Gilberto Rios and his wife have fostered 48 children since 2009

SARASOTA — A 64-year-old North Port foster parent stands trial today for the alleged sexual and physical abuse of a 3-year-old girl back in 2015.

Last year, the child reportedly told her adoptive mother that Gilberto Rios forced his penis into her mouth, triggering a police investigation.

In an interview with investigators in April 2018, the girl said Rios “took my hand and pulled me over there,” unzipped his pants, then told her to put her mouth on his penis, according to a transcript obtained from court files related to the case.

Afterwards, she ran to her room and locked the door, the child told investigators.

Rios, who has pleaded not guilty and opted for trial, has fostered 48 children with his wife since they became licensed foster parents in 2009, according to child welfare officials.

His wife, Nereida, has not been charged.

But the allegations of sexual and physical abuse are not the first to be made against the Rios family.

GateHouse Media has identified at least four more suspected victims through public records and court documents. None are being named to protect their privacy.

In 2016, a biological mother complained to the Department of Children & Families that her two daughters had been sexually and physically abused while in the couple's care. But DCF could not substantiate the complaint and continued to send vulnerable foster children to the couple for more than a year.

Then in 2018, suspicions of abuse surfaced again with regard to a young child whom Rios and his wife adopted. The boy began disclosing disturbing stories to caseworkers after his father’s arrest last year, according to a former case manager for the Safe Children Coalition.

And Monday, the adoptive mother of yet another child previously fostered by the Rios family said she also fears her daughter was sexually abused.

The Sarasota YMCA/Safe Children Coalition, the nonprofit agency contracted by the Department of Children and Families to manage the child welfare system in Sarasota County, did not answer questions about how many abuse allegations have been filed against Rios over the years or why he and his wife were allowed to continue fostering after the initial allegations were made in 2016.

In an email, Steve Hurwitz, the attorney for the agency, said simply that DCF handles child abuse investigations in Sarasota County.

He added that the Rios foster home was “closed” the day Rios was arrested in April 2018.

The Florida Department of Children and Families did not return multiple requests for comment.

Gilberto Rios’ defense attorney Jeffrey Young also declined to comment on the case Friday.

But before jury selection on Monday, he and fellow defense attorney Betsy Young argued that allegations by children, especially those who have been through other trauma, are susceptible to false memories and embellishment through repeated questioning.

A database of foster care placements obtained by GateHouse Media shows that Rios and his wife often fostered five or six children at a time and were licensed to accept traditional foster kids under the age of 5 as well as medically needy foster children. The records also show that the couple was paid an average of $1,512 per month from 2013 through 2017 for foster services.

The database may be closed to the public next year because of a bill making its way through the Florida Legislature that would make the names of all foster parents a secret.

DCF worked with legislators to craft the proposal after GateHouse Media and the Sarasota Herald-Tribune made a public records request last year asking for the names of all licensed foster parents in the state.

Rios will now stand trial in Sarasota County Circuit Court following an investigation that began in April 2018. That’s when the adoptive mother of one of his former foster children noticed the girl simulating oral sex with Barbie dolls.

When questioned, the girl said that she had once “bit” someone’s penis, according to court documents. Later, on her way to a therapy appointment, she revealed that person was Rios, police in North Port said.

According to police, the girl’s adoptive mother immediately reported the allegations to authorities, who interviewed the child on April 12, 2018.

Police arrested Rios later that night and charged him with sexual assault against a child. He bonded out on $200,000 the next day, court records show.

During the course of the investigation, North Port Police Department detective Shannon Fortuno also learned of a previous allegation made against Rios in 2016. Fortuno noted in court documents that investigators conducted a medical exam in that case, but did not conduct a forensic interview, “possibly due to the age of the child.”

In an interview Friday, the mother of that child said she believes both of her daughters — then 2 and 3 — were molested by Rios.

She started to suspect abuse after noticing her daughters showing up for visits with cuts and bruises on their lips and buttocks. Her 3-year-old later began bleeding from her vagina and developed a yeast infection, according to the mother, whose name is being withheld to protect her children’s identities.

When asked about the injuries, her daughter “said she couldn’t tell me because she would go to jail or not be able to go home to Mommy,” the mother said.

She added that child welfare officials ignored her requests to have her daughter forensically interviewed to determine the veracity of her statements.

“Everybody kept getting ignored,” she said. “Emails, calls — it was ignored.”

After Hurricane Irma, she moved her and her daughters out of the state.

“My (daughter) is not even potty trained because she’s terrified of the toilet from when she was dunked into the toilet by Mr. and Mrs. Rios,” she said. “If I try to cut (my daughter) an apple, she screams out, please don’t cut the baby.”

Since she made her report, child welfare officials in Sarasota placed at least 10 foster children with the Rios family, according to the database obtained by GateHouse.

A former case manager with the Safe Children Coalition who asked that her name be withheld because of fears of retribution said the state’s investigation into the alleged abuse was inconclusive.

Despite the uncertainty, she said officials often continue to send children to homes with previous abuse allegations because of the severe shortage of available foster homes.

“There’s been foster homes which were less than stellar that we’ve had concerns about and they keep using them because, ‘Oh, well, they take the hard kids,'" she said.

The former case manager said that’s also when concerns cropped up about the couple’s adopted son, who began disclosing stories to caseworkers about “how he would go to Daddy’s room and they would have candy and have special time together,” she said.

“We had serious concerns that the mother was grooming the child.”

But legal efforts to temporarily remove the adoptive son from the home were turned down by Judge Rochelle Curley last year, according to two sources familiar with the case. It is unknown whether the child remains in the home.

Other people who took in children previously fostered by Rios also expressed concerns, including one mother who adopted her daughter out of the system in 2017.

After more than two decades as a foster parent, specializing in children with medical needs, she said it was the worst case she’d ever seen. The 2-year-old girl could not walk, talk or eat on her own. She looked as if she’d never seen the sun. The child was underweight and vomited profusely.

The mother, whom GateHouse is not naming to protect her child’s identity, feared her daughter had been abused.

“She was just so terrified of public restrooms, our bathroom, any bathroom,” the mother said. “You could see the sheer terror in her eyes.”

She said it took years for the child to gain trust in her as a mother. During bath time, the little girl would cover her privates, and scream “please, Mommy, no.”

“I had to tell her 100 times a day, I will never hurt you,” she said. “I don’t know by whom, but I can guarantee you, that child was abused.”

The adoptive mother was surprised to learn from GateHouse Media reporters that her daughter spent six months under Rios’ care as an infant in 2015, before later spending time with at least four other temporary caregivers.

The state never contacted her about the allegations against Rios.

“They don’t do the responsible thing,” she said. “It’s all supposed to be what’s in the best interest of the child. But it’s not. It’s what’s in the best interest of the agency.”

“The system is so broken. It makes me want to cry. Our most vulnerable children are being preyed upon.”
Address: 1777 Main St, Sarasota, FL 34236, USA
