Address: 1 Gannett Plaza Ave, Melbourne, FL 32940, USA

Title: Port St. Lucie fire, 20 years later: How has the city changed since historic blaze?
Summary:
Share This Story Tweet Share Share Pin Email

Michael and Linda Boogaart sat in silence as they stared at a copy of the Port St. Lucie Tribune, now tattered and yellow with age.

The brick house belonging to Michael and Linda Boogaart on Urbino Avenue erupts into flames while a tree in front of the home remains largely unscathed on Thursday, April 15, 1999, in Port St. Lucie.

(Photo: ERIC HASERT/TCPALM)

Even though the image was grainy, the Boogaarts recognized immediately their Southwest Urbino Avenue home, the serpentine branches of a giant, 150-year-old oak tree enveloping the property in western Port St. Lucie.

Tears welled in their eyes.

Twenty years later, the Boogaarts, now residents of Jensen Beach, were seeing for the first time their home, completely engulfed in flames.

"That's our house," Michael said. "I've never seen that before. I've never seen the house on fire."

The Boogaarts' home was one of 43 destroyed April 15, 1999, by a wind-whipped fire that scorched 2,400 acres between Florida's Turnpike and Interstate 95, blasting through neighborhoods from Southwest Del Rio to Southwest Gatlin boulevards. About 100 other homes were damaged, according to news reports, and 25 boats, cars, sheds and recreational vehicles also were lost.

The firestorm caused $4.5 million in damage. Remarkably, no one died.

A destructive combination of high winds and extremely dry conditions — the drought index was 703 out of a possible 800 — fueled the fire. Firefighters had been battling blazes for weeks, including one the night before that state officials say most likely sparked the bigger fire.

At the time, the city had not yet expanded its water and sewer system west of the turnpike, so there were very few hydrants in the affected area. Firefighters were forced to pull water from the C-24 Canal as well as from residents' swimming pools. Also, the development boom in that part of the city was still about five years away, so many homes were in heavily wooded neighborhoods.

As a result of the fire, significant changes were made to Port St. Lucie's infrastructure — there are now thousands more hydrants throughout all 120 square miles of the city — to guarantee fire protection to the most populous city on the Treasure Coast.

Still, the indelible memories of that day resonate with the residents who lived in the fire zone as well as the emergency services officials who battled the blaze.

A resident runs past flames April 15, 1999, engulfing a wooded area at Southwest Dalton Avenue and Southwest Calder Street in Port St. Lucie.



(Photo: DEBORAH SILVER/TCPALM)

'It was like a gut-punch'

Linda Boogaart holds a teapot, part of a commemorative tea set from the marriage of Prince Charles and Princess Diana, recovered from the remains of their home. It still shows the damage and ashes of the fire that destroyed their home April 15, 1999, in Port St. Lucie.

(Photo: ERIC HASERT/TCPALM)

The Boogaarts learned their home was destroyed a few hours after being evacuated, while watching the local news with friends.

"I knew there was no other red brick house with a basketball hoop, it was like a gut-punch," said Michael, 52, who became an insurance agent after losing his home to the fire. "You realize you just lost everything. Literally, whatever you're wearing is what you have."

A few days later, they returned to sift through what remained, but other than a few pieces of china and a teapot commemorating the marriage of Prince Charles and Princess Diana, the fire had destroyed everything.

"You're seeing all this stuff and it's like a shadow of what you saw 24 hours earlier," Michael said.

It took a few years to sink in, admits Linda, 52, who teaches kindergarten at Felix A. Williams Elementary in Jensen Beach.

"I would go into the drawer to find something to cook with, and it wouldn't be there," she said. "It would be like, 'Well, I know I had that measuring cup,' and then, 'Oh no, we lost that.' "

The Boogaarts' son Zachary, now 21, was only 9 months old at the time of the fire. Carson, 18, was born three years later.

"At the time you think it's the end of the world, but it really isn't," Michael said. "Life is fragile. What this does is make you put less importance on stuff. We work so hard to have nice cars and a nice house, but what it boils down to is it's just stuff."

CLOSE The Boogaarts lived in Port St. Lucie during the April 15, 1999, brush fires. Twenty years later, Michael Boogaart reflects on that day when he lost his home. Eric Hasert, eric.hasert@tcpalm.com

Linda and Michael Boogaart are seen at their home March 12, 2019, in Jensen Beach. A brush fire April 15, 1999, destroyed their home and 42 others in Port St. Lucie. "It's just a part of life. Fortunately, my family was safe, that was the main thing," Michael said about the experience. "We had a good insurance policy, so we were able to rebuild ... We look back at that now, we're fine."



(Photo: ERIC HASERT/TCPALM)

Lessons learned

In response to the fires, the Port St. Lucie City Council voted to construct a fire loop, consisting of one water main and hydrants that would service the areas of Southwest Del Rio and Southwest California boulevards as well as along Southwest Savona and Southwest Darwin boulevards and Southwest Becker Road.

The mandate was to have the fire loop complete before the 2000 fire season, said Donna Rhoden, deputy director of utility systems for Port St. Lucie.

"If there were fires in those general vicinities, trucks could get to that fire loop and pull water from those hydrants there," she said.

Even though the inventory of hydrants had grown to 2,100 by 1999, the city had concentrated the expansion in the central city between the river and the turnpike, Rhoden said.

"There were very few hydrants west of the turnpike," she said. "The handful that existed were near the intersection of Gatlin and Port St. Lucie boulevards."

Today, there are 5,560 hydrants providing water service and fire protection to the city.

Over the past two decades, Port St. Lucie, now the eighth largest city in Florida, has doubled in size. To keep up, the Port St. Lucie Police Department has done the same.

There now are 238 officers on staff, according to Chief John Bolduc. In 1999, Bolduc estimates there were about 120.

[ Click on the map to watch a time lapse of development in Port St. Lucie. If you cannot see the graphic, refresh your browser or click here. ]

Bolduc's isn't the only department now better equipped to handle wildfires.

The St. Lucie County Fire District enhanced its wildfire training, which includes more prescribed-burn exercises to learn about fire behavior, and improved coordination and communication with the Florida Forest Service and other Treasure Coast fire districts, said Fire District Chief Nate Spera.

It also upgraded to 800-megahertz radios that can integrate almost instantly with, in particular, the Martin County Fire District.

"Of course, having accessible water everywhere makes a huge difference, too," Spera said.

In fact, the Luck Wildfire, a 70-acre blaze that forced the evacuation of 40 homes last March in the city's Southbend neighborhood, could have been much worse had there not been a hydrant within a few feet of the fire, Spera said.

"The direction that fire was going in, for the better part of the afternoon, was pointed at about three houses," Spera remembers. "Had we not had a hydrant right there, we would have lost at least two of them, I can promise you."

More: We prepare for hurricanes, but we also need to be ready for wildfires | Maureen Kenyon

'I've never seen fire behavior like that'

By the time Spera arrived at the intersection of Southwest Merrick Street and Southwest Gatlin Boulevard the afternoon of April 15, 1999, the wind began to shift.

The fire moved quickly, dropping ash a quarter mile ahead of it. The wind picked up everything that was burning, blowing it miles ahead of the fire.

Spera — who was off duty at the time and had driven to the scene in his own truck — remembers watching the 1998 Dodge Dakota catch fire and burn behind him as he retreated to the east in a brush truck.

Port St. Lucie Police Officer Brian Major offers comfort to a resident after her neighborhood near Southwest Deckard Street and Southwest Abingdon Avenue was evacuated on April 15, 1999, in Port St. Lucie. Dozens of homes were destroyed in the area that day.

(Photo: DEBORAH SILVER/TCPALM)

"I've never seen fire behavior like that, before or since," he said. "I've been a firefighter for 34 years and I've never seen it like that."

The fire jumped Southwest Gatlin Boulevard and the C-24 Canal.

Even though the major burning phase didn't surpass six hours, it was a tricky fire to get under control.

Houses were peppered throughout the western part of the city, blending in with patches of unattended parcels, overgrown with brush, pine trees, palmettos as well as the invasive Brazilian pepper tree, Spera said.

"Basically, those Brazilian peppers burned like mad," he said. "Every time you thought you got (the fire) down a little bit, a Brazilian pepper would pop up and it was like putting gasoline on a fire."

Today, through development, there isn't much open area for a fire to run, Spera said.

"There were houses back then that would have brush right up to a fence line," he said. "We couldn't even get behind the house because the vacant lot next door had not been cleared at all."

Ensuring there's a safe perimeter and defensible space around a home, for residents as well as for firefighters, is one of the most important ways to prepare for fire season, according to the Florida Forest Service.

[ For more tips on how to prevent wildfire, scroll to the bottom of the story. ]

A charred bicycle was one of only a few recognizable remains of a residence that was destroyed by fire April 15, 1999, on Urbino Avenue in Port St. Lucie.



(Photo: ERIC HASERT/TCPALM)

Current fire outlook

In 1999, from March 15 to April 14, six hundredths of an inch of rain fell at Treasure Coast International Airport, according to John Pendergrast, senior meteorologist and fire weather program leader at the National Weather Service, Melbourne.

"We're not seeing anything that's looking like a dry period like (1999)," he said.

The U.S. Monthly Drought Outlook through April.

(Photo: CLIMATE PREDICTION CENTER/NOAA)

The Climate Prediction Center, part of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, anticipates above-normal rainfall for the Florida peninsula through the spring.

"If that does indeed pan out, that's good news," Pendergrast said. "April is normally the driest month of the year in Central Florida." (Click on the photo to enlarge it.)

Weak El Niño conditions are likely through the spring, too. El Niño — a natural climate pattern where sea water in the central and eastern tropical Pacific Ocean is warmer than average — tends to bring increased rainfall at the start of the dry season, which typically starts in October.

Better rainfall chances mean lower chances for wildfires.

As of April 9, the Keetch-Byram Drought Index average in Indian River County was 436; in St. Lucie it was 393; and in Martin it was 343, below normal for this time of year, according to the Florida Forest Service.

The drought index ranges from 0 to 800, with 0 representing swamp-like conditions and 800 being a desert.

Wildfire activity in March was below average, compared to the past 10 years, with only two wildfires in Indian River County, one in St. Lucie and four in Martin, said Melissa Yunas, spokeswoman for the Florida Forest Service.

“All we need to do is just have two weeks without rainfall and we start running wildfires again. I don't want people to think we're out of the woods this year.” Melissa Yunas, Florida Forest Service

"All we need to do is just have two weeks without rainfall and we start running wildfires again," she said. "I don't want people to think we're out of the woods this year."

Current El Niño conditions also have allowed land managers, biologists, farmers, ranchers and citrus industry workers a larger window of opportunity to manage their land with the use of fire, Yunas said.

"We typically restrict burn authorizations when fire activity increases," she said.

In 1998, one year before the Port St. Lucie blaze, more than 10,000 firefighters battled 2,200 fires across the state. Because of those fires, Florida now has one of the most extensive and active prescribed burning programs in the country, Pendergrast said.

Prescribed fire is used to reduce hazardous fuel buildups, providing increased protection to people, homes and the forest, according to the Florida Forest Service.

In an average year, the service issues about 88,000 authorizations allowing landowners and agencies to burn an average of more than 2.1 million acres each year.

'One blessing after the next'

Shaelyn Nelson, who turns 20 on April 14, stands next to the stork, the only item her parents, Eileen and Bill, were able to salvage after the 1999 fire.

(Photo: CONTRIBUED PHOTO FROM EILEEN NELSON)

The only item Eileen and Bill Nelson could salvage from their home on Southwest Jennifer Terrace was a pink cardboard stork.

"Where (the stork) was, leaning on a palm tree, they were the only things untouched by the fire," said Eileen, 55. "It was a sign that showed she had a girl, she's healthy, she brought her home, she's safe."

Their daughter, Shaelyn, turns 20 on April 14.

One week earlier, the Nelsons were given three dates for Eileen's scheduled Cesarean section: April 12, April 14 or April 16.

"We picked April 14 because it was mid-week," Eileen remembers. "The scary part is, I could have been home during the fire."

The Nelsons — who lived about 3 miles northeast of where officials believe the fire started — were able to build a new home on the same lot. Then, one year later, Bill, who works for Pratt & Whitney, was transferred. The family moved to Vernon, Connecticut, where they still reside today.

"It was one blessing after the next," Eileen said. "Still, to this day, we say it was meant to be the way it happened."

[ If you're having troubling seeing the graphic, click here. ]

Maureen Kenyon is TCPalm's trends reporter, keeping Treasure Coast residents updated on hot topics and happenings. Do you have a story to tell? Want to start a conversation? Send an email to maureen.kenyon@tcpalm.com, call 772-221-4249 or follow her on Twitter @_MaureenKenyon_.
Address: 1939 SE Federal Hwy, Stuart, FL 34994, USA

Title: 2 children, 4 adults shot and wounded during baby shower in Chicago
Summary:
Advertisement 2 children, 4 adults shot and wounded during baby shower in Chicago Share Shares Copy Link Copy

Two men who opened fire on a crowd of people gathered for a baby shower, wounding six people, including two children, may have acted in retaliation for an earlier gang conflict, police said Sunday.Authorities have only “shards of information” about what happened at the family gathering in Chicago because witnesses are not cooperating, a police spokesman said, but investigators hope the serious nature of the children’s injuries will prompt someone to talk.“This is a very tragic incident. You have two young children, an 8-year-old and a 10-year-old, clinging to life,” Chicago police spokesman Anthony Guglielmi said.At least a dozen people were gathered outside a home decorated with balloons for the baby shower when two armed men approached on foot and began shooting about 6:30 p.m. Saturday, Guglielmi said.The gunmen fired multiple rounds and ran away down an alley, he said.An 8-year-old boy was shot in the chest and back, and a 10-year-old girl was shot in the leg. Both children were in critical but stable condition. Their names were not released.Also shot were four other people — three men ranging in age from 23 to 48 and a 29-year-old woman. The woman was hospitalized in critical condition, and the two younger men were in stable condition.The condition of the oldest man was unknown, and Guglielmi said it was unclear whether the woman who was hurt may have been the person who was pregnant.People rushed inside the house when the shooting began. Children who had been playing in the yard reportedly started piling atop one another as they tried to get through the door.“We were trying to pick the kids up, get the kids out of the way. They were going to get crushed,” Richard Nix, whose grandson was having the shower, told The Chicago Tribune. “It wasn’t nothing but kids in front of the house, sitting on the porch. They was just playing, and the shooting went off.”The shooting occurred in the West Englewood neighborhood of Chicago’s South Side, and investigators had indications it was in retaliation for a previous incident, the spokesman said.“It’s part of a larger conflict that’s going on in that area,” Guglielmi said.Another shooting occurred Sunday morning about three blocks from the home where the gunfire erupted, he said, but it was unclear whether there was any connection.Authorities have struggled to contain violence in Chicago, the nation’s third-largest city. Police said 561 homicides were committed in the city last year, a total that exceeded the number of killings in New York and Los Angeles combined.
Address: Northcorp Business Park, Palm Beach Gardens, FL 33410, USA

Title: Following Grammy win, Dan + Shay victorious at ACM Awards
Summary:
Keith Urban, Kacey Musgraves, Dan + Shay win at ACM Awards

Grammy-winning duo Dan + Shay solidified themselves as the hottest group in country music with multiple wins at the Academy of Country Music Awards, where Keith Urban was named entertainer of the year and Kacey Musgraves won three honors.

Urban won the top prize Sunday with his ninth nomination for the award, besting Chris Stapleton, Luke Bryan, Kenny Chesney and Jason Aldean, who held the title the last three years.

"Baby girl, I love you so much," Urban said, looking to his actress-wife, Nicole Kidman. "To the fans out there, you are amazing. You have no idea what you mean to me."

Urban also won entertainer of the year at the Country Music Association Awards in November — his first time winning the prize since 2005.

No women were nominated for the coveted ACM honor. Musgraves was the sole women up for album of the year.

She won twice when "Golden Hour" picked up top album — as an artist and co-producer of the project. She was also named female vocalist of the year.

Musgraves said the award "goes out to anyone woman, girl, or anybody really" who has been told "her perspective or style is too different."

"Just stay at it. It'll work out," said Musgraves, who won four Grammys earlier this year, including album of the year and best country album.

Other categories didn't feature many female nominees: Bebe Rexha was the only woman competing for song of the year with "Meant to Be," while Maddie & Tae was the sole female act up for duo of the year.

But both honors, along with single of the year, went to Dan + Shay.

"I think somebody got the cards mixed up tonight," Dan Smyers said onstage at the MGM Grand Garden Arena in Las Vegas. "This is all incredible. We are all winners tonight."

Smyers technically won five honors — picking up double wins in song of the year as artist and co-writer (shared with Jordan Reynolds and Nicolle Galyon) and single of the year as artist and co-producer (shared with Scott Hendricks). Shay Mooney didn't write or produce the song.

Even Thomas Rhett jokingly dedicated his male vocalist of the year trophy to Dan + Shay.

"I am going to give this to Dan + Shay so they can go home with four," he said.

Rhett also gave a shout-out to his wife who sat in the audience: "You are smoking hot tonight."

Rhett performed Sunday, while Dan + Shay hit the stage to sing "Keeping Score" alongside Kelly Clarkson, hitting impressive high notes. Chris Stapleton's performance was also a highlight. The singer-songwriter, who often performs with his wife, Morgane Stapleton, sang onstage as she held her hand over her stomach (she is pregnant).

Emmy-nominated "This Is Us" actress Chrissy Metz made her live singing debut and gave an emotional performance onstage, teary-eyed at the song's end. Metz sang "I'm Standing with You" from the upcoming film "Breakthrough," which she stars in. She was joined onstage by Carrie Underwood, Lauren Alaina, Mickey Guyton and Maddie & Tae — the performers all wore blue dresses and sang in unison.

Ashley McBryde, who won new female artist of the year, also was memorable: Nearly in tears, she strummed her guitar and beautifully sang "Girl Goin' Nowhere." The 35-year-old was nominated for best country album at the Grammys and recently earned a Daytime Emmy nomination for her performance on "CBS This Morning Saturday." McBryde shined again onstage when she joined Eric Church to sing "The Snake."

Jason Aldean kicked off the awards show with a fun performance featuring the hit-making duo Florida Georgia Line. Aldean earned the Dick Clark Artist of the Decade Award.

"More than anything — thank you to the country music fans (and) country radio, you guys have changed my life forever," he said. "This is one of the proudest nights of my life."

Reba McEntire, who hosted the show for the 16th time, told several jokes. When she mentioned the collaborative performances of the night — Khalid and Kane Brown and Brandi Carlile and Dierks Bentley, among others — she said she would perform with rap star Cardi B.

She said they could sing her song "There's No U and Oklahoma," then said: "And that's okurrr with me," earning laughs from the audience.
Address: 455 6th St NW, Winter Haven, FL 33881, USA

Title: FDLE issues Missing Child Alert for Marion County teen
Summary:
The Florida Department of Law Enforcement issued an alert for a missing 15-year-old girl.

Emily Berry was last seen Friday heading north on the 1500 block of Highway 441, according to the FDLE. Berry was wearing a gray Mossy Oak sweatshirt with white jeans and light pink shoes.

Anyone with information is asked to call the FDLE at 1-888-356-4774 or the Marion County Sheriff's Office at 352-732-9111 or 911.
Address: 1100 Fairfield Dr, West Palm Beach, FL 33407, USA

Title: Family of 3 seriously injured in fiery Pine Hills crash
Summary:
The Orange County Fire Rescue said investigators are on scene at a crash in the area of North Pine Hills Road and North Lane in Pine Hills.

ORLANDO, Fla. - Three family members were seriously injured Friday night in a crash in the Orlando neighborhood of Pine Hills and the driver of the other vehicle involved left the scene, according to troopers with the Florida Highway Patrol.

Troopers said the driver of a Honda Civic was at a stop sign at Fir Drive and Pine Hills Road around 10 p.m. when he failed to remain stopped and turned into the path of a Nissan Maxima.

The Nissan hit the rear door of the Honda, causing the Honda to strike the north side curb of Pine Hills road and catch fire, according to the crash report.

Troopers said the driver of the Nissan fled on foot. Their identity is unknown, according to the report.

The 43-year-old driver of the Honda was taken to Orlando Regional Medical Center in serious condition. His two passengers, a 9-year-old girl and 7-year-old boy were taken to Arnold Palmer Hospital also in serious condition. All three victims share the same last name, according to the crash report.

Troopers said the crash remains under investigation and charges are pending.

A section of North Pine Hills Road and North Lane were closed Friday night into Saturday, according to Orange County Fire Rescue.

Copyright 2019 by WKMG ClickOrlando - All rights reserved.
Address: 4466 N John Young Pkwy, Orlando, FL 32804, USA

Title: Students say knife-wielding attacker is straight A's student
Summary:
CORAL SPRINGS, Fla. - Two boys ages 16 and 17 allegedly fighting over a teenage girl at the parking lot of Coral Springs High School didn't make it home Friday. One ended up in jail and the other in the hospital.

Witnesses said the 16-year-old boy wielded the knife and stabbed the 17-year-old boy after students were dismissed at 3 p.m.

Those who know the attacker say he is a disciplined student who is not involved with gangs or anything of the sort.

"He is a really smart kid -- straight-A's," a student said.

Officers arrested the student on aggravated battery with a deadly weapon and paramedics took the other student, whose leg was injured, to the hospital.

Parents of Coral Springs High School students received a message form Vivian C. Suarez, the school's principal saying the students will be facing "appropriate disciplinary measures."

Copyright 2019 by WPLG Local10.com - All rights reserved.
Address: 3401 W Hallandale Beach Blvd, Pembroke Park, FL 33023, USA

Title: Mom to face charges after claiming man tried to abduct her daughter at shopping mall
Summary:
Mom to face charges after claiming man tried to abduct her daughter at shopping mall

A woman will be criminally charged for falsely reporting that an Egyptian man tried to kidnap her daughter from a West Virginia shopping mall, a police detective told The Associated Press on Friday.Barboursville Police Detective Greg Lucas said they are going to charge Santana Renee Adams with falsely reporting an emergency incident.The charge would be the latest turn in a sensational tale of a mother who used a gun to thwart an abduction that quickly unraveled amid inconsistencies in her story.Authorities on Thursday announced they were dropping charges against the man, Mohamed Fathy Hussein Zayan, a 54-year-old engineer from Alexandria, Egypt, who is in the area for work. He cried as he greeted family members upon his release from jail.Adams initially told police Zayan grabbed her 5-year-old daughter girl by the hair inside a clothing store and tried to pull her away but stopped when she produced a gun, authorities said. But the story started falling apart when no witnesses could be found and mall surveillance video showed inconsistencies in the woman's original statement.She later told investigators she may have overreacted and misinterpreted the man's intentions. Zayan doesn't speak English and police say he may have simply been patting the girl on the head.Adams couldn't immediately be reached for comment.

A woman will be criminally charged for falsely reporting that an Egyptian man tried to kidnap her daughter from a West Virginia shopping mall, a police detective told The Associated Press on Friday.



Barboursville Police Detective Greg Lucas said they are going to charge Santana Renee Adams with falsely reporting an emergency incident.

Advertisement Related Content Police: Mom says she might have misjudged man who touched child

The charge would be the latest turn in a sensational tale of a mother who used a gun to thwart an abduction that quickly unraveled amid inconsistencies in her story.

Authorities on Thursday announced they were dropping charges against the man, Mohamed Fathy Hussein Zayan, a 54-year-old engineer from Alexandria, Egypt, who is in the area for work. He cried as he greeted family members upon his release from jail.

Adams initially told police Zayan grabbed her 5-year-old daughter girl by the hair inside a clothing store and tried to pull her away but stopped when she produced a gun, authorities said. But the story started falling apart when no witnesses could be found and mall surveillance video showed inconsistencies in the woman's original statement.

She later told investigators she may have overreacted and misinterpreted the man's intentions. Zayan doesn't speak English and police say he may have simply been patting the girl on the head.

Adams couldn't immediately be reached for comment.

AlertMe
Address: Northcorp Business Park, Palm Beach Gardens, FL 33410, USA

Title: 21-month-old girl beats stage 4 cancer
Summary:
21-month-old girl beats stage 4 cancer Copyright 2019 Nexstar Broadcasting, Inc. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten, or redistributed. Molly Hughes, CNN image [ + - ] Video

BOWLING GREEN, Kentucky (WFLA/CNN) - The family of a brave 21-month-old girl in Kentucky is celebrating after the toddler beat stage 4 cancer.

Little Molly Hughes spent 130 nights in the hospital after she was diagnosed with neuroblastoma. Molly underwent 15 months of grueling cancer treatment and proved she is one tough little cookie.

"She would just bounce back after every treatment. I mean she would knock her down for few days and then she would be at playing again," said Molly’s mother Chelsea Hughes.

Molly’s family and friends rallied to support her during her cancer fight and #MollyStrong became their battle cry.

Now, Molly’s family and friends are celebrating their victory over the deadly disease. Molly’s mom will always remember the phone call that brought the good news.

"Just like, I fell to the ground after I got off the phone and I just hugged her for like five minutes,” said Hughes.

Molly’s mom says the power of prayer helped her daughter. “I believe that's what helped her get through all this. With all the prayers she's heard and which I can't thank everyone enough for.”

Now that she's beat cancer, Molly gets to enjoy the things she loves, like playing in the sunshine and swinging on tire swings.
Address: 200 S Parker St, Tampa, FL 33606, USA

Title: Young girls around world suffering from breast ironing abuse
Summary:
If you’ve never heard of breast ironing, you should know it’s as bad, if not worse, than it sounds, and it’s happening to young girls around the world. It's not a new practice, but it has just recently been recognized by the United Kingdom government as a form of child abuse.

What is breast ironing?

Breast ironing, which originates from West Africa, involves ironing a young girl’s chest with hot objects in order to delay the growth of her breasts, according to the BBC. In many cases, a girl will also be made to wear an extremely tight strap around her chest to suppress the growth of the breasts even more.

The practice can lead to tissue damage, abcesses, cysts, fever, infection and itching.

It can go on for months.

In fact, the United Nations estimates there could be up to 3.8 million girls around the world who have been exposed to breast ironing.

It has been documented as happening in African countries such as Cameroon, Chad, Benin, Guinea-Bissau and Togo, but the CAME Women and Girls Development Organization, which aims to improve the health and wellbeing of a variety of people from disadvantaged communities, is concerned breast ironing could be affecting at least 1,000 girls and women in the U.K.

You might ask why anyone would do this.

Cases of abuse

Margaret, one woman who suffered the form of abuse as a child, explained it’s not done with bad intentions. Instead, mothers believe they are protecting their daughters from sexual abuse, rape or getting unwanted attention from boys at too young an age.

A woman named Comfort told the BBC she still remembers running from her sister, who allegedly abused her by doing breast ironing on her when Comfort was 9.

“I remember screaming a lot,” Comfort said. “She’d say, ‘Get on the floor,’ and then she would rub the stone on my chest. Someone got hold of me and they just held me while she did it … She was saying to me, ‘Your breasts shouldn’t be growing at this time. You’re too young.’ When I think about it, I can literally still feel the pain.”

Margaret now runs a charity in London to help young girls who have been through breast ironing.

Impacts of breast ironing

“We have seen girls who have not developed breasts. We have seen girls who have difficulties breastfeeding because the breast milk is not flowing. We have seen girls who have developed cancer,” Margaret said.

Psychotherapist Leyla Hussein said the psychological impacts breast ironing have on a girl are far-reaching: post-traumatic stress, severe depression, body dysmorphia. She said a lot of the victims will struggle in relationships.

“What they’ve experienced is not a traditional practice … it’s actually violence,” Hussein said.

Stopping the abuse

The violence is still happening so frequently that British politician and former lawyer Nicky Morgan is trying to bring awareness so that teachers can identify when the abuse is happening to their students. Even though it has recently been recognized as a form of abuse, there is still no specific law banning it in the U.K.

Morgan said it should be “tackled, addressed, talked about and stopped,” and that those who work with girls and young women have a very important role to play.

“It’s going to be essential for schools, teachers, school nurses, family members, friends of the girls involved to blow the whistle when they know that such things have occurred,” said Lord Alex Carlile, who is a British barrister and crossbench member of the House of Lords. “It’s purposeless, it’s violent, it’s crude, it’s disgusting and it’s a crime.”

Now that breast ironing has been labeled a form of abuse, breast ironing victims and witnesses are being urged to come forward.

“When you don’t talk about something that seems so secretive, it just eats away in you. It just does,” Comfort said.

A former gynecological nurse, Angie Marriot, told the BBC the true scale of breast ironing has been concealed because of underreporting, and women are afraid to speak out because they fear they could be ousted from their communities.

“To say the least, it’s an abuse. It hurts. It dehumanizes you,” Marriot said. “You are not a human being.”

Graham Media Group 2019
Address: 3401 W Hallandale Beach Blvd, Pembroke Park, FL 33023, USA

Title: ECSO investigating video of Ransom Middle School student torturing bunny rabbit
Summary:
A white rabbit similar in appearance to the one that appeared to have been tortured in a video circulating on Facebook. (Photo: Cumberland Valley Animal Shelter)

The Escambia County Sheriff's Office is investigating reports of a Ransom Middle School student who was filmed allegedly torturing a bunny rabbit in a video that has spread on social media.

The video, which has more than 10,000 views on Facebook as of Friday morning, was discovered by the Ransom Middle School Resource Officer, who alerted the school district and the sheriff's office to its existence.

Maj. Andrew Hobbs with the Escambia County Sheriff's Office confirmed to the News Journal on Friday morning that authorities and school officials were aware of the video and are investigating the incident.

The disturbing Snapchat video, posted on Facebook, shows a girl sitting in a yard, repeatedly grabbing the small white bunny by its back and tossing it into the air. At one point, the bunny runs across the yard in an attempt to escape, and the girl runs after it, tackles it and carries it back into the yard.

She then holds it by its hind legs and throws it high into the air again.

Children can be heard laughing in the background.

Hobbs said the bunny did not die, but Escambia County Animal Control is involved in the investigation. The News Journal has reached out to the county for more information on the bunny's condition.

Hobbs said he believed the bunny was a family pet, but he wasn't sure.

Charges have not been filed as of Friday morning.

Escambia County School District Superintendent Malcolm Thomas said the incident did not happen on school grounds, and as such would not be considered a school discipline-related issue.

"There's no discipline from the school's perspective because this was not an incident that happened at school," Thomas said. "This becomes a wrongdoing that happened in the community that, in this case, law enforcement and animal cruelty agencies are investigating."

Thomas said he could not disclose the student's name or her grade due to student privacy issues.

"It was a terrible video," Thomas said. "But we have referred to the appropriate agencies and are letting them handle this."

Annie Blanks can be reached at ablanks@pnj.com or 850-435-8632.

Title: Girl at center of nationwide search found safe near Lake City
Summary:
After a nearly yearlong search for a kidnapped 10-year-old girl from Utah came to an end in North Florida, the child and her father will be reunited.

Since last summer, local and federal authorities in Utah and Nevada had been looking for Ariana Bozemen. Police in Enoch, Utah, said the girl was kidnapped by her biological mother, 34-year-old Dawn Closson, after the girl's father was granted sole custody of the child. No one could locate the two until early Wednesday morning when deputies said the two were located at an interstate rest area near Lake City following an anonymous tip.

Adrian Bozemen, Ariana's father, told News4Jax that he got a call about 2 a.m. Wednesday from police, letting him know his daughter had been found.

"He said, 'Adrian, we found her.' I said, 'What do you mean?'" Bozeman said. "I’m reaching for something not there, stumbling around the bedroom. My wife woke up next to me. She (was) looking at me with big eyes. I just couldn’t believe it."

Investigators in Utah said they contacted the Columbia County Sheriff's Office after they got a tip from an anonymous Florida resident who noticed something suspicious about the girl and her mother. Investigators said the tipster went online, saw news reports about the girl and called them. Columbia County deputies said they located the 10-year-old inside an SUV at a rest stop along Interstate 75 near Lake City.

"This is just a mindful and watchful resident that was able to help us bring this to justice and get the girl safely back," said Sgt. Isaac Akeroth, with the Enoch Police Department.

Also inside the vehicle was Closson (pictured), Closson’s boyfriend and several other children, authorities said.

Closson was arrested and booked into the Columbia County jail, online jail records show. Her boyfriend and the other children in the SUV were allowed to leave while Ariana was placed into protective custody by the Department of Children and Families. Her father said he chose to drive from Oklahoma, where he is stationed at an Air Force base, to Florida to pick her up so he can spend more time with her driving back home.

"I didn’t know what physical or mental state my daughter would be in, so I figure we would have no choice but to talk to each other. I get to learn more about her because she’s been gone for so long," Bozeman said. "I think I’m going to be cool about it. I think I’m going to break down. I think I’m going to be nervous. I’m going through all these different emotions. I want to be strong for her."

Currently, Closson is the only one facing charges but police in Utah said if they can prove her boyfriend was aware she illegally took the child, he could be facing charges, as well.

Bozeman and his daughter should be reunited by Thursday morning.

"I can’t stop thinking about seeing her face and hearing her voice," he said.

Copyright 2019 by WJXT News4Jax - All rights reserved.
Address: 4 Broadcast Pl, Jacksonville, FL 32207, USA

Title: ON THE MARKET: Price lowered on Florida home in movie 'My Girl'
Summary:
The Ledger will feature a unique property for sale at least once a week. Take a look at this week’s property, the historic Bartow home featured in the 1991 film "My Girl."

This beautiful Victorian home was where the movie classic "My Girl" was filmed. This home boasts 9,508 square feet of living space, 6 bedrooms and 8 bathrooms, including 5 Jacuzzi tubs in the main house. One of the bedrooms is located in a mother-in-law suite.

The property also includes a wrap-around porch, gazebo, in-ground swimming pool and 7 fireplaces along with central heat and air.

The historic home built in 1906 has 2 tankless water heaters. The commercial kitchen offers a Butler's pantry, 6-burner gas stove, stainless steel island and built-in double oven.

Included on the grounds is a carriage house and a 1-bedroom, 1-bath loft apartment along with a garage and storage units.

List of items conveying with the property upon request includes most furniture including baby grand piano.

The home was previously used as The Stanford Inn Bed & Breakfast.

Address: 555 E. Stanford St., Bartow, FL 33830

Description: This is your opportunity to live like a movie star! And at a price reduction of $25,000.

Listing price: $425,000.

Realtor: Leslie Yokshas, 863-221-5785, Keller Williams Realty of Winter Haven

This story originally published to theledger.com, and was shared to other Florida newspapers in the GateHouse Media network.

Title: Paralyzed man finds purpose in volunteering at Halifax Health and body building
Summary:
Eric Murphy, 47, recently rolled his wheelchair into the room of a new patient at Halifax Health's Inpatient Rehabilitation center.

"Hey man, how you doing?" he asked 75-year-old Richard Pajula, who was recovering from a bladder and intestine infection.

They launch into a conversation, bonding over their struggles getting in and out of the shower. Pajula also has multiple sclerosis, which often confines him to a wheelchair.

"It's great talking to someone who's not a doctor or a nurse," Pajula said, pointing to their wheelchairs. "We have a lot in common, so we just build each other up."

For Murphy, volunteer work at the hospital has given him a purpose he has worked to find since an ATV accident left him paralyzed from the waist down and unable to work in 2003.

"I love coming here," he said. "It makes me feel good about myself and I can give back now."

When he's not helping out patients at Halifax Health, he's now training to be a body builder. He will compete in the wheelchair division of an upcoming competition in August.

"I worked out a lot in high school, but that was for sports," Murphy said. "I never thought I would be a body builder and compete."

In 2003, Murphy was 32, lean and fit, and led an extremely active life in Massachusetts. He had played football in high school. But he developed a love for all-terrain vehicles which eventually led to racing them competitively on dirt tracks.

A freak accident put Murphy in a wheelchair. He wasn't even riding at the time. He was at a race, eating lunch, when a rogue rider slammed into his back.

"Somebody who wasn't a racer, somebody who shouldn't have been on a bike, hit me square in the back," Murphy said. "I was on (an ATV) that wasn't running with my helmet off. I was eating a McDonald's McChicken when I got hit. I don't even remember getting hit."

The impact broke Murphy's back in two places. His hip, pelvis and ribs were shattered. His face was split open as it hit the handlebars, knocking out his two front teeth.

Murphy spent three and a half weeks in the intensive care unit at Boston Memorial Hospital because he'd contracted pneumonia. He then had multiple surgeries, resulting in four months of inpatient rehabilitation.

The accident also led to personal challenges. His first wife left him.

"She left me with my biological son, and she left her oldest son from another relationship with me," Murphy said. "I took care of them, but they also took care of me. They are my angels."

Although his broken bones had healed, he was left with myriad medical issues, the worst being uncontrollable muscle spasms that sometimes knocked him out of his chair, causing him to bang his knees on the floor, tables and anything on the ground. The falls sometimes left deep gouges in his knees. Then those wounds wouldn't heal because of the lack of blood flow to his legs. It left him hospitalized seven times with sepsis — the body's sometimes deadly response to an infection with symptoms including fever, difficulty breathing, low blood pressure, fast heart rate and mental confusion.

"It literally drove me nuts," Murphy said. "I couldn't drive; I couldn't move. For 10 years, doctors couldn't control my spasms with medication."

His son Patrick Murphy, now 16, can't put a number on the amount of times the spasms have knocked his dad out of his chair.

"He's fallen to the ground a few times and I've had to scoop him up," Patrick said. "Him getting dressed was a lot harder."

Besides the muscle spasms and open wounds, Murphy developed arthritis in his hands from constant use and from hyper-extending them when he lifted himself in and out of his pick-up truck. His right leg also formed a large calcium deposit that now wraps around some veins and cannot be removed.

"The average person doesn't understand the struggles we face after the accident," Murphy said. "They just see that we are in the wheelchair."

"Growing up, I knew everything was a little more difficult for my dad," Patrick Murphy said. "It made me grow up faster because me and my brother had to help him."

Relief didn't come until Murphy and his sons moved to Port Orange three years ago.

"When I came here, I had all open wounds everywhere," he said. "You could see my knee joints and the bones. It took four to five months just to heal one cut."

His journey to Florida began when he connected with the "hot girl" from his high school, who is now his wife. She lived in Florida and reached out to him when she saw they had a mutual friend who was also in a wheelchair.

"I thought he was good looking," Sheryl Carrigan said. "He was full of compliments, very complimentary towards everything. He did that and he still tells me I'm beautiful everyday."

When Murphy came to Florida for the first time, he had just gotten out of the hospital from one of his many bouts with sepsis. He was instructed not to travel because he was so sick. He ignored his doctors warnings.

"It was the best decision I ever made," he said. "I came down for a seven-day date and never left."

Carrigan pushed Murphy to go to the doctor to get his open wounds treated and his muscle spasms under control.

"He was a mess, I was determined to get those damn knees taken care of. He had a lot of open wounds and I had to take him to wound care to get those treated," Carrigan said.

The turning point came 18 months ago. Dr. Carolyn Geis, board certified in inpatient rehabilitation at Halifax Health, installed an "Intrathecal Baclofen pump," which constantly administers medication to Murphy's spinal cord. The pump has nearly eliminated Murphy's spasms.

"Before he couldn't really do much, every little movement sent his body into a spasm" Geis said. "It's been a struggle for him. He's a remarkable guy to have been able to cope with things for so long."

Geis also connected him to the volunteer opportunity in Halifax Health's rehabilitation facility.

"He's able to share his struggles," Geis said. "He really needed something to give him purpose and meaning."

Murphy said his change in lifestyle has made a drastic difference not just in his life but also for his family.

"Now I get up with a smile on my face," Murphy said. "I'm a different person from six months ago."

In the guest bedroom of his three-bedroom home in Port Orange, Murphy has a Bowflex home gym system. During a reporter's visit, he rolled his wheelchair over to the base and wedged his wheels into a block of wood to keep him from moving. He grabbed the handlebar, pulling it to his core in a steady rhythm.

"I don't want to feel handicapped," Murphy said. "If I can't do it myself, I don't want to do it."

Murphy began his body building journey in January. He began volunteering at Halifax Health in October. He did so after Carrigan left him for a time in September 2018 because he wanted to stay home all day, and he became controlling of her free time.

"He would literally sit here in the house all day and wait for me to come home," said Carrigan. "I couldn't go out, I couldn't call or text anyone. He wanted me all to himself."

Carrigan didn't see a light at the end of the tunnel, so she left, hoping that her absence would be a wake up call for Murphy.

"He didn't have a life or want to do anything, so it was all on me until I left him," she said. "After I left, he went out and started at the hospital, he started counseling, and he started working out."

The two are back together now, but it took a lot of work on Murphy's part to become open to new things.

"I was a miserable asshole," Murphy said. "I'm glad she did that and pushed me to do things I wouldn't have done before."

Patrick is happy that his dad's quality of life has improved.

"He's more independent now. It's helped him a lot in a positive way," Patrick Murphy said. "It's changed his outcome on a lot of things. He's a lot less limited now."

Murphy wants to stay on the path he's on and continue to improve himself. He clearly enjoys his volunteer work at Halifax Health.

"I've come a long way and I can see the difference in myself," he said. "I have a life again, a purpose. This is a blessing to be here."

In February, Murphy reached another first. He went skydiving for the first time, something he and his son never imagined he would be able to do.

"It's pretty exciting; it's not something I ever thought I would see him do," Patrick Murphy said. "He always watched me do things. But now I get to watch him."

Title: Kacey Musgraves, Dan + Shay win big at ACM Awards
Summary:
Kacey Musgraves' Golden Hour" continued its winning streak: It won album of the year at the Grammys and repeated the win at the Academy of Country Music Awards on Sunday.

Musgraves said she had "some of the greatest memories of my entire life" while recording the album. She also thanked her sister, who was sitting in the audience at the MGM Grand Garden Arena in Las Vegas, for designing her album covers.

Musgraves' critically acclaimed "Golden Hour" won four Grammys, including album of the year and best country album. However, she didn't score a nomination for the top prize at the ACMs — entertainer of the year.

Instead, men make up the nominees exclusively for a second straight year with Chris Stapleton, Keith Urban, Kenny Chesney, Luke Bryan and Jason Aldean, who has held the title since 2015.

Musgraves was the sole female artist in the album of the year category.

Bebe Rexha was the only woman competing for song of the year thanks to the record-setting hit "Meant to Be," featuring Florida Georgia Line, while Maddie & Tae is the sole female act up for duo of the year.

But both honors, along with single of the year, went to Dan + Shay.

"I think somebody got the cards mixed up tonight," Dan Smyers said onstage. "This is all incredible. We are all winners tonight."

Smyers technically won five honors — picking up double wins in song of the year as artist and co-writer (shared with Jordan Reynolds and Nicolle Galyon) and single of the year as artist and co-producer (shared with Scott Hendricks). Shay Mooney didn't write or produce the song.

At the Grammys, Dan + Shay won best country duo/group performance for "Tequila," which peaked at No. 1 on Billboard's Hot country songs chart and No. 21 on the all-genre Hot 100 chart.

Even Thomas Rhett jokingly dedicated his male vocalist of the year trophy to Dan + Shay.

"I am going to five this to Dan + Shay so they can go home with four," he said.

Rhett also gave a shout-out to his wife who sat in the audience: "You are smoking hot tonight."

Rhett also performed Sunday, while Dan + Shay hit the stage to sing "Keeping Score" alongside Kelly Clarkson, hitting impressive high notes. Chris Stapleton's performance was also a highlight. The singer-songwriter, who often performs with his wife, Morgane Stapleton, sang onstage as she held her hand over her stomach (she is pregnant).

Ashley McBryde, who won new female artist of the year, also was memorable: Nearly in tears, she strummed her guitar and beautifully sang "Girl Goin' Nowhere." The 35-year-old was nominated for best country album at the Grammys and recently earned a Daytime Emmy nomination for her performance on "CBS This Morning Saturday." McBryde shined again onstage when she joined Eric Church to sing "The Snake."

Jason Aldean, the reigning entertainer of the year champion at the ACMs, kicked off the awards show with a fun performance featuring the hit-making duo Florida Georgia Line. FGL's Tyler Hubbard wore a denim outfit featuring the American flag as he sang onstage with band member Brian Kelley and Aldean.

Reba McEntire, who is hosting the show for the 16th time, told several jokes. When she mentioned the collaborative performances of the night — Khalid and Kane Brown and Brandi Carlile and Dierks Bentley, among others — she said she would perform with rap star Cardi B.

She said they could sing her song "There's No U and Oklahoma," then said: "And that's okurrr with me," earning laughs from the audience.
Address: 901 6th St, Daytona Beach, FL 32117, USA

Title: It's time to give the heave-ho to the Matlacha Mullet Toss: your say
Summary:
0407 Cartoon (Photo: Rick McKee, The Augusta Chronicle, GA)

Toss the Toss

A few years ago, I wrote a letter expressing my negative feelings regarding the Mullet Toss in Matlacha. It was published, and then letters berating me for my opinion followed.

On March 24, I read the letter of Donna Reynolds, stating that she felt the same way I did about the bad example this inhumane event sent to children. Today, I see a letter from Carol Taddeo saying she also found this event very disturbing.

I am happy to note that I have read every letter every day in between the publication of these two, and have not seen any defending this cruel, yearly event. Perhaps we can hope that enough people will give some thought to the message this throwing of a once living thing sends to our children and replace the creatures with bean bags, as suggested by Carol.

All living things have the right to be respected.

Linda Spies, Cape Coral

More: It's time for Lee County to reinstate full impact fees: your say

More light

I agree with recent letters naming darkness as contributing to the tragic death of a young schoolchild waiting for her bus early one morning last month.

Note that just two weeks before the young girl lost her life, we changed our clocks to daylight saving time, in effect making the mornings darker. Without that change, she would have been at her bus stop at about the time of sunrise, rather than an hour earlier, while it was still pitch dark.

I think the current movement to observe daylight saving time year-round is ill-advised. It makes more sense to go the other way: stay on standard time year-round. There would still be plenty of evening light in the summer, even with sunset an hour earlier.

Let’s give our kids more light, not less.

NEWSLETTERS Get the Florida Voices newsletter delivered to your inbox We're sorry, but something went wrong Florida Voices tells the stories of everyday Floridians, examining what issues matter most to them in the Sunshine State. Please try again soon, or contact Customer Service at 1-800-468-0233. Delivery: Fri Invalid email address Thank you! You're almost signed up for Florida Voices Keep an eye out for an email to confirm your newsletter registration. More newsletters

V. E. Delnore, Fort Myers

Money talks

There was a great cartoon (flooding in the Midwest) in the March 30 News-Press. Artist forgot the red hats. I am suggesting though that rural America (especially farmers) is sick of this mess. Face it, they made a mistake.

Likewise, USA TODAY must have made a big mistake, placing “Midwest reeling from bomb cyclones" and "Coal king as global carbon emissions rise”, next to each other on March 28.

They can’t be suggesting that climate change is associated with severe weather events? This places them in opposition to their climate change denier subscribers. Especially on a day when the president is in Florida telling about his help to restore the Everglades.

From where I am, it looks like Lake Okeechobee and the Everglades might both be underwater from sea level rise before this is accomplished. First, they must carry out this big plan to restore the financial viability of all the contractors involved in the big projects.

This sounds much just like how this problem started in the beginning – Lake Okeechobee and obstruction of the normal flow to the Everglades – making sure that big contractors and big farmers got their needs taken care of first.

Lewis Robinson, Fort Myers

More: Thank you, Gov. DeSantis, for quick action on smokable marijuana: your say

Find conscience

I remember the number of times some demagogue has rallied the people against someone who is not “us”. Each time they have assured the people that the end of America is on the doorstep. Every time the demon hordes have somehow metamorphosed into the people who built America.



Once again, we are asked to believe that another group of people bring crime and disease and aren’t our problem anyway. Once again, people who only want the dream that is America will need to starve and die while we huddle in fear.



Holocaust memorials all over our country will not let us forget that we turned our backs on millions of Jews who were headed to gas chambers. How many more times are we going to allow ourselves to be the playthings of demagogues who would use us for evil? Can we really throw a blanket over the Statue of Liberty and deny its place in our national conscience?

I hope we’ll tell the demagogues that we found our conscience and to take their foolishness on down the road.



Dean Crocker, Estero and Manchester, Maine

Title: Road rage shooting victim remembered as good family man
Summary:
Road rage shooting victim remembered as good family man Video

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. (WFLA) - He died in a violent road rage incident, but tonight, Quentin Hicks is being remembered among his friends and family, in an upbeat, positive way.

RELATED: 2 men in BMW convertible shot, 1 killed

RELATED: Arrest made in fatal road rage shooting in Historic Old Northeast

Hundreds gathered to say their goodbyes to Hicks on Saturday. The standing-room only sang, clapped, and raised their voices to celebrate a man dedicated to enjoying life.

His funeral was held at the Galilee Missionary Baptist Church in St. Petersburg.

Hicks was a father of five. He was also a grand-dad, a husband, and a brother to 9 siblings.

“Quinn liked everything. Especially anything involving family, friends, the community, the neighborhood. I met Quinn when I was 2 years old. We grew up in the neighborhood together,” said Toy Rich.

Those that knew him called him "Quinn."

Hicks died on March 27, when police say a man named William Shutt shot him during a road rage incident.

Detectives said Shutt was seen on surveillance video driving away from the scene after firing the shot that killed Quinn.

Hicks crashed into a tree four blocks away. He died, but his passenger survived.

Friends describe Quinn as a friendly, family man. They already miss him dearly.

“Quinn could go into any neighborhood in the city and have friends. As seen here today. Representative from all shapes, sizes, colors, Quinn was a friend of mine. We grew up together from pre-school,” said Kevin Wells.

People from all walks of life filled the sanctuary—all to remember a man known as a good cook who enjoyed fishing, the outdoors and most of all, family.

Jeremy Vaughn considered Quinn his own brother. Vaughn remembers a time when he was very sick.

“I said, man, you gotta help me with the baby. My girl was at work, ya know? Guess what he did? I woke up, he sitting there rocking the baby in his arms. This one right here,” said Vaughn as he held his young daughter.

Shutt is charged with first-degree murder, first-degree attempted murder and burglary. Police said Shutt did not know either victim.
Address: 200 S Parker St, Tampa, FL 33606, USA

Title: 19-year-old arrested for DUI manslaughter after deadly crash in North Port
Summary:
Copyright 2019 Nexstar Broadcasting, Inc. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten, or redistributed. Sarasota County Sheriff's Office

NORTH PORT, Fla. (WFLA) - A 17-year-old girl is dead and three others are in the hospital after rollover crash in North Port early Saturday morning.

Police responded to the intersection of Joewood Circle and Genip Court just after 2:30 a.m. when deputies arrived they discovered approximately 13 people were inside and on the roof of a 2010 Toyota SUV when the driver Stephanie Evrard,19, lost control and rolled the SUV over

Investigators established probable cause Evrard was operating the SUV under the influence and charged her with one count of DUI Manslaughter, and three counts of DUI with Personal Injury. Evrard is currently being booked into Sarasota County Jail.

At this time the victim's names will not be released. Anyone with information is asked to contact North Port Police at 941-429-7300

Out of respect for a grieving school community, drama performances scheduled for tonight and Sunday afternoon have been cancelled.

North Port High School will have counselors on site Sunday from noon – 3 p.m. and during school this coming week for any student needing support. In addition, students can speak to a counselor anonymously by texting “HERE4U” to the Crisis Text Line at 741741. This service is available to all students in Sarasota County 24/7.
Address: 200 S Parker St, Tampa, FL 33606, USA

Title: Chelsea Handler says Trump's 2016 win sent her to a shrink, hooked her on marijuana
Summary:
- Comedian and activist Chelsea Handler shared Friday that she had to seek out a psychiatrist after Donald Trump's victory in the 2016 presidential election.

Handler explained during an appearance on “Real Time with Bill Maher” that she went through a “midlife identity crisis” after Trump shocked the world by defeating Hillary Clinton for the nation's highest office, saying she never felt her life feel “so unhinged.”

“I had to pay a psychiatrist to listen to me b---- about Donald Trump for about the first three weeks,” Handler told Maher. “And then once when we got past that and got to the real stuff, I realized the parallel there was my world becoming unhinged when I was a little girl, my brother died when I was nine years old. I had never related the two, but for me, as I can imagine it must have been for so many people, it was an emotional trigger of everything being destabilized and I realized how spoiled and privileged I had been all my life and realize to be this upset and this on-a-ten every day and the outrage and the anger, I just wanted to f---ing fight people, you know? And I was like, ‘I have to go see a psychiatrist.’”

The liberal comedian also spoke about having “white guilt” and how she realized in therapy that she had believed she didn’t have “the right to be in pain” because she hadn't been raped or molested.

“I’m a more mindful citizen because of it and I woke up. I’m in an awakening,” Handler continued.

She also said Trump’s election win “led” her to smoking marijuana and pivoting away from alcohol, calling cannabis the “gateway drug to meditation.”

Get update on this story at FoxNews.com
Address: 35 Skyline Dr, Lake Mary, FL 32746, USA

Title: Father arrested rushing daughter to hospital; nurses raise jail bond
Summary:
CENTREVILLE, Ill. - A father rushing his choking daughter to the hospital was arrested for violating several traffic laws during the drive.

But the silver lining is that the hospital's nurses came to the rescue and bonded him out of jail Thursday.

KTVI reports Darius Hinkle does not have a driver's license, but put that all aside as he was trying to get his daughter to the hospital in Centreville (Ill.). Hinkle said the girl was choking on a penny.

Police officers from different agencies were trailing Hinkle the entire way, and arrested him once he arrived at the hospital.

The child's mother said she learned about the nurses' generosity when she arrived at the jail and learned they had collected money to pay the bond.

Title: Dispute about dog leads to fatal shooting in Miami Gardens, family member says
Summary:
A body is removed from a home on Northwest 17th Court in Miami Gardens.

MIAMI GARDENS, Fla. - Police are conducting a death investigation in Miami Gardens.

A body was removed from a home on Northwest 17th Court early Friday.

Miami Gardens police haven't confirmed how the person died, but the victim's granddaughter told Local 10 News that she was shot and killed in a dispute with strangers about the family dog.

The granddaughter said the family's Yorkshire terrier recently escaped and wandered into a neighbor's yard. She said the neighbor returned the dog, but two other people claimed the dog belonged to them.

An argument ensued and that's when, the girl said, her grandmother was shot in the head.

Copyright 2019 by WPLG Local10.com - All rights reserved.
Address: 3401 W Hallandale Beach Blvd, Pembroke Park, FL 33023, USA

Title: 7 men plead guilty to sexually abusing children, creating child porn
Summary:
7 men plead guilty to sexually abusing children, creating child porn Copyright 2019 Nexstar Broadcasting, Inc. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten, or redistributed. Copyright 2019 Nexstar Broadcasting, Inc. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten, or redistributed. Video

COLUMBUS, Ohio (WCMH) - Seven Ohio men have pleaded guilty to related crimes regarding child pornography and the sexual abuse of two 10-year-old children.

Four of the men were charged in a second superseding indictment returned by a federal grand jury in August 2018, for crimes related to producing child pornography and the repeated sexual abuse of a 10-year-old girl.

They include: William G. Weekley, 35, of Newark; Timothy F. Sullivan, 50, of Canal Winchester; Franklin Eugene Perry, 63, of Columbus; and Brian S. Perkins, 42, of Mt. Vernon.

Three other defendants were discovered in the course of the investigation that was initiated by the discovery of Weekley’s activities.

Those three men were each charged in separate cases on Aug. 23, 2018.

Grant Michalski, 29, of Columbus, was charged by criminal complaint.

A federal grand jury charged Eric Zevely, 34, of Columbus, to offenses related to the production of child pornography and sexual abuse of another 10-year-old girl.

Finally, in a fourth case, Jordan I. Makowski, 33, of Greenville, Ohio, was indicted by a federal grand jury for distributing and receiving child pornography.

Benjamin C. Glassman, United States Attorney for the Southern District of Ohio, Todd A. Wickerham, Special Agent in Charge, Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), Cincinnati Division, Ohio Attorney General Dave Yost, Steve Francis, Special Agent in Charge, Homeland Security Investigations (HSI), Franklin County Sheriff Dallas Baldwin, Westerville Acting Police Chief Charles Chandler and other members of the FBI Crimes Against Children Task Force announced the pleas entered into before Chief U.S. District Judge Edmund A. Sargus, Jr.

This investigation began when Ohio Bureau of Criminal Investigations Special Agent/FBI Task Force Officer Larry McCoy communicated undercover with Weekley online.

From that initial investigation into Weekley, investigators were able to discover the additional defendants.

According to court documents, the defendants made online contact with each other and others who shared, or whom they believed to share, their sexual interest in minors, incest and child pornography.

After making initial contact through Craigslist, Weekley – who pleaded guilty in U.S. District Court today – communicated with each of the other defendants on an ongoing basis through text and various other apps, including Wickr.

Weekley had regular access to a female child (Jane Doe), who was approximately 10 to 11 years old during the offenses detailed.

Weekley sexually abused the girl and created images and videos of the molestation, which he shared with others, including some of the co-defendants.

Weekley and Perry discussed sexually abusing the girl together and made plans for Perry to join Weekley in the sexual abuse of Jane Doe.

Perry encouraged Weekley to continue abusing the victim and did eventually sexually abuse the victim together with Weekley.

Likewise, Perkins and Sullivan requested that Weekley bring Jane Doe to meet them for the purpose of sexually abusing Jane Doe, but it is not believed that Perkins or Sullivan actually met with Weekley.

One of the conversations found on Weekley’s phone between him and Sullivan was initiated when Weekley responded to an online classified ad Sullivan posted entitled “I AM LOOKING TO PRIVATELY MEET AN INCEST FAMILY. Mom son brother sister.”

Weekley and Michalski messaged on Craigslist about interests in sexual topics like “family, forced” and “K9 and more.”

Zevely engaged in thousands of communications with numerous other individuals in response to ads placed on Craigslist, including with Weekley.

Investigators discovered Zevely sexually abused a different 10-year-old victim who was not Jane Doe. Zevely also engaged in communications about sexually abusing minors with both HSI and FBI undercover task force officers.

In a conversation on Kik messenger, Makowski sent several files containing child pornography to another individual.

Weekley pleaded guilty Thursday to three counts of production of child pornography (15 to 30 years in prison), one count of attempted coercion of a minor (10 years to life in prison) and two counts of distributing child pornography (five to 20 years in prison).

Sullivan pleaded guilty on Tuesday to attempted coercion or enticement of a minor to engage in illegal sexual activity (10 years to life in prison).

Perry pleaded guilty in January 2019 to coercion or enticement of a minor to engage in illegal sexual activity (10 years to life in prison).

Perkins, Zevely and Michalski all pleaded guilty in November 2018. Perkins and Michalski pleaded guilty to receipt of child pornography (five to 20 years in prison), and Zevely pleaded guilty to producing child pornography (15 to 30 years in prison).

Makowski pleaded guilty in February 2019 to distributing child pornography (five to 20 years in prison).

U.S. Attorney Glassman commended the investigation of this case by the FBI Crimes Against Children Task Force, the Franklin County Sheriff’s Office Internet Crimes Against Children Task Force, and Assistant United States Attorneys Heather A. Hill and S. Courter Shimeall, who are prosecuting the cases.
Address: 200 S Parker St, Tampa, FL 33606, USA

Title: Deputies: Woman who fatally struck girl didn't have driver's license, had expired visa
Summary:
0 Deputies: Woman who fatally struck girl didn't have driver's license, had expired visa

POLK COUNTY, Fla. - A 25-year-old Argentinean woman who fatally struck a 13-year-old girl Wednesday morning did not have a valid driver's license and was living in the United States on an expired visa, the Polk County Sheriff's Office said.

Deputies said Mariana Perez Borroto, of Kissimmee, was bicycling to Lake Marion Creek Middle School shortly after 7:45 a.m. when she was hit by a minivan being driven by Micaela Coronel on Homosassa Road.

Investigators said Borroto, who was critically injured, was flown to Orlando's Arnold Palmer Children's Hospital, where she died. She would have turned 14 in two weeks.

TRENDING NOW:

Coronel said she had been living in Kissimmee since October on a "visitor pass" and provided deputies an Argentinian identification card, but she did not have a valid driver's license in either country, deputies said.

Coronel said that about 80 percent of her windshield was covered in condensation when she struck Borroto, investigators said. They said she was driving her child to school when she crashed.

"She should have thought about the impact on her family before she operated that motor vehicle without a license, without cleaning the windshield," Sheriff Grady Judd said. "She was careless. She was negligent, and there's a 13-year-old child (who is) dead today."

Coronel was arrested on charges of operating a motor vehicle without a valid driver's license causing death.

Judd said she will be sentenced and deported should she be convicted.

Lake Marion Creek Middle School Principal Johna Jozwiak released the following statement:

"Our hearts are broken today. We are devastated by the loss of a very special member of our Lake Marion Creek Middle family. Mariana was a bright and sweet-natured girl who possessed a very polite and calm manner. She enjoyed studying history and loved spending her free time sketching in notebooks. We are devastated by this tragic news. Counselors are available at school for students and staff members. We have also rescheduled the rest of this week's Florida Standards Assessments testing to next week."

The crash remains under investigation.

"This suspect killed a 13 yr old middle schooler who was riding her bike to school this AM, while driving without a license. This senseless tragedy should never have occurred!" - Sheriff Judd



Click here to read the release: https://t.co/NBrf9WeVYT; pic.twitter.com/E4kvk8XTWI — Polk County Sheriff (@PolkCoSheriff) April 3, 2019

Coming up on @WFTV; the latest on the driver who’s accused of hitting & killing a 13 year old. The Polk County sheriff says Micaela Coronel can be sentenced to prison for up to 5 years & deportation to Argentina. She was driving without a valid license. pic.twitter.com/McI5Om5KAG — Johny Fernandez (@jfernandezwftv) April 4, 2019

Title: Dominick Hawkins found guilty of kidnapping, sexual battery on minor
Summary:
Copyright 2019 Nexstar Broadcasting, Inc. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten, or redistributed.

MANATEE COUNTY, Fla. (WFLA) - Dominick Hawkins has been found guilty of kidnapping and sexual battery on minor.

In 2013, prosecutors say Hawkins approached a 5-year-old girl at the Wayside Glen mobile home park in Bradenton.

Prosecutors say he offered to buy the girl candy.

The pair was captured on surveillance camera inside a convenience store.

“After she got the candy she wanted to go home, but the man told her he was having a party at his house,” said prosecutor Ashley Dusnik.

Instead, he lured her to an abandoned trailer.

Officials say after he assaulted her, he ran to a nearby bus, frantically trying to leave the area.

“She put her pants back on. Tried to exit the trailer, when she found she couldn’t go out the door, she crawled out a window,” said Dusnik.

He has been sentenced to life in prison.
Address: 200 S Parker St, Tampa, FL 33606, USA

Title: Police: 10-year-old girl dies after apparent road-rage shooting in Phoenix
Summary:
PHOENIX (FOX 10/AP) - Police say a 10-year-old girl has died after she and her father were both shot outside their home during a possible road-rage shooting in Phoenix on April 3.

According to a statement released by Sgt. Vince Lewis, a family of four was driving near 37th Avenue and Portland Street when they noticed a white Ford F-150 with dark-colored trim was following them.

As they turned onto Moreland Street where they lived, the truck continued following them. When they turned into their driveway, the truck stopped and the driver fired several gunshots at them.

“They were traveling westbound on Moreland and turned into their residence and that’s when the driver or someone from the pickup truck opened fire to the car," said Sgt. Lewis. "The father and daughter were struck by gunfire.”

A 30-year-old man driving the vehicle and his daughter, identified by police as Summerbell Brown, were both shot.

The mother and a second daughter who were also in the vehicle weren't injured.

Neighbors who did not want to go on camera say several shots were heard.

"Just knowing that all the family is there and for them to do that, it’s just sad," said one person.

Police say the suspect, identified as a 30-to-40-year-old man, remains on the loose.

Anyone with information should leave an anonymous tip by calling Silent Witness at 480-WITNESS. Spanish speakers can leave an anonymous tip by calling Testigo Silencioso at 480-TESTIGO.

Si tiene alguna información sobre este caso, llame a la línea de Testigo Silencioso (480-TESTIGO, 480-837-8446).

Silent Witness

http://www.silentwitness.org/

Title: Hobe Sound man charged with lewd or lascivious battery on a 14-year-old
Summary:
Zachary Stockman (Photo: MARTIN COUNTY SHERIFF'S OFFICE)

MARTIN COUNTY — An 18-year-old Hobe Sound man is accused of inappropriately touching a 14-year-old girl multiple times and giving her marijuana.

Zachary Stockman, of the 8300 block of Southeast Pinehaven Avenue, was arrested Tuesday on four counts of felony lewd or lascivious battery on a child younger than 15, one charge of delivering marijuana to a child and felony possession of LSD.

Deputies said in February they were called to the girl's home when her parents went to check on her and didn't find her in her room. The girl's parents told deputies they then called her, and she told them she was with Stockman.

More: Port St. Lucie High School student charged with sending photos, trying to meet minor for sex

The teen told deputies she met Stockman at a movie theater in Stuart and he had touched her inappropriately about four times. She also told deputies Stockman showed her Xanax and ecstasy and gave her marijuana that the two smoked together.

Deputies said based on what the girl told them, they obtained a search warrant for Stockman's home and found 56 Xanax pills and ecstasy.

Stockman was arrested and taken to the Martin County Jail, where he remained Thursday afternoon on $135,000 bail.

More: Stuart man accused of inappropriately touching teenage girl
