Address: 3401 W Hallandale Beach Blvd, Pembroke Park, FL 33023, USA

Title: Duck gets a leg up on surgery
Summary:
OCEAN CITY — Thanks to the nearly two-dozen people who have responded thus far to a GoFundMe campaign, a young duck hobbled by a broken femur will be getting needed surgery.

"I feel awesome!" said Jamie Wilson, owner of 9-month-old Big Girl, reacting to the donations which have pushed past her $800 goal.

Wilson got Big Girl — and another duck, named Sylvia — from a coworker in January. About a month later, Wilson noticed Big Girl limping. An initial veterinary visit found nothing wrong, but a second trip to another veterinarian indicated Big Girl likely had a hairline fracture of her left femur that became a full-fledged break.

Wilson covered initial veterinary expenses, totaling about $300, but couldn't cover surgery. After learning no local veterinarians or rescue groups would do the surgery on credit, and failing to qualify for veterinary insurance, Wilson turned to GoFundMe.

The campaign began sluggishly, but picked up after a Daily News story on Big Girl's plight. As of late Monday morning, donations totaled more than $900. Most donors gave between $5 and $25, but there were larger donations, including a $275 contribution.

Among the more generous donors, Wilson said, was an elderly homebound gentleman in Santa Rosa Beach who didn't have computer access, but sent his caretaker to Ocean City to find her. Wilson, who by that time had raised the needed $800, spoke with the man by phone, and he urged her to go ahead and take his donation.

"He was like, 'How about food? How about this? How about that?'" Wilson said.

Wilson has decided to keep the campaign going for a few more days, until she gets Big Girl's surgery scheduled at the Bayside Hospital for Animals in Fort Walton Beach. Wilson was working Monday to get the duck scheduled for the femur repair.

"I won't leave it open that much longer," she said Monday.

Meanwhile, on the GoFundMe page, online at gofundme.com/f/surgey-for-big-girl, Wilson wrote, "... (I)f you would like to make a donation we will use the additional funds for her follow-up appointments, bedding, food ... ."

"I can not express my gratitude for where we are now and we will be greatful (sic) for any additional assistance ... ," Wilson added.
Address: 2 Eglin Pkwy NE, Fort Walton Beach, FL 32548, USA

Title: Florida sheriff: Mom killed 11-year-old to keep her from having sex
Summary:
An Orange County Sheriff's Office arrest report said Rose Alcides Rivera first denied stabbing the girl but eventually admitted to killing her.

ORLANDO — A woman accused of stabbing her daughter to death told investigators she killed the 11-year-old to keep her from having sex, authorities in Florida said.

Rose Alcides Rivera, 28, pulled up to a hospital in Orlando asking for help for her daughter on Sunday morning, but the girl was already dead from multiple stab wounds, sheriff's investigators said. Then, they say Rivera pulled a knife on hospital workers before being arrested.

She later told investigators she killed her daughter to "prevent her from having sex" with men, authorities said. She is charged with first-degree murder in the death of Aleyda Rivera.

The mother told first responders "my baby is gone," the Orlando Sentinel reported. The child had 15 stab wounds to her back and a defensive wound on her right arm.

Orange County Sheriff's investigators said the incident started early Sunday when the mother took her daughter to the home of a man and accused him of having sex with the child. Witnesses told detectives the child denied having sex with anyone.

An arrest report said Rivera first denied stabbing the girl but eventually admitted to killing her. "Rivera stated she stabbed her daughter while in the car, and while stabbing her she was attempting to make her more comfortable," an investigator wrote in the report.

The mother told detectives she believes her daughter is in heaven.

According to the report, Rivera said she didn't see her daughter having sex with the man, nor did the girl tell her she was having sex.

Rivera had a superficial cut on her arm, which authorities believe was self-inflicted.

A lawyer wasn't listed for her on jail records.
Address: 2121 SW 19th Avenue Rd, Ocala, FL 34471, USA

Title: 'Our country is full': Trump says migrants straining immigration system
Summary:
Advertisement 'Our country is full': Trump says migrants straining immigration system Share Shares Copy Link Copy

Declaring "our country is full," President Donald Trump on Friday insisted the U.S. immigration system was overburdened and illegal crossings must be stopped as he inspected a refurbished section of fencing at the Mexican border.Trump, making a renewed push for border security as a central campaign issue for his 2020 re-election, participated in a briefing on immigration and border security in Calexico before viewing a 2-mile see-through steel-slat barrier that was a long-planned replacement for an older barrier — and not a new wall."There is indeed an emergency on our southern border," Trump said at the briefing, adding that there has been a sharp uptick in illegal crossings. "It's a colossal surge and it's overwhelming our immigration system, and we can't let that happen...We can't take you anymore. We can't take you. Our country is full."As Air Force One touched down in the state, California and 19 other states that are suing Trump over his emergency declaration to build a border wall requested a court order to stop money from being diverted to fund the project. But Trump, who ratcheted up his hardline immigration rhetoric in recent weeks, declared that his move, which included vetoing a congressional vote, was necessary.Also on Friday, House Democrats filed a lawsuit preventing Trump from spending more money than Congress has approved to erect barriers along the southwestern border. Congress approved just under $1.4 billion for work on border barricades. Trump has asserted he can use his powers as chief executive to transfer an additional $6.7 billion to wall construction.Trump, who earlier in the week threatened to shut down the border over the high numbers of migrants trying to enter the U.S., appeared to walk back his comments Thursday. He said Friday that it was because Mexico had gotten tougher in stopping an influx of immigrants from moving north."Mexico has been absolutely terrific for the last four days," the president said as he left the White House. "I never changed my mind at all. I may shut it down at some point."The president's visit came a day after he withdrew his nominee to lead U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement. Longtime border official Ron Vitiello appeared to be cruising toward confirmation, but Trump said Friday that he wanted to go in a "tougher direction."Trump, as he so often does, mixed fact with fiction when warning of the threat at the border. When complaining about the Flores legal settlement that governs treatment of migrant children and families, he blamed "Judge Flores, whoever you may be." But Flores was an unaccompanied 15-year-old girl from El Salvador.He also downplayed the claims of people seeking asylum at the border, declaring without evidence that many are gang members while comparing some of their efforts to find safety in the U.S. to special counsel Robert Mueller's investigation of Russian interference in the 2016 elections."It's a scam, it's a hoax," Trump said. "I know about hoaxes. I just went through a hoax."As the president showed off the renovated section of the barrier to reporters, a balloon depicting Trump as a baby floated further down the border. And as Trump landed in California, the state's governor ripped the president's push for Congress to pass legislation that would tighten asylum rules to make it harder for people to qualify."Since our founding, this country has been a place of refuge — a safe haven for people fleeing tyranny, oppression and violence. His words show a total disregard of the Constitution, our justice system, and what it means to be an American," said Democratic Gov. Gavin Newsom.Trump has been increasingly exasperated at his inability to halt the swelling number of migrants entering the U.S., including thousands who have been released after arriving because border officials have no space for them. Arrests along the southern border have skyrocketed in recent months, and border agents were on track to make 100,000 arrests or denials of entry in March, a 12-year high. More than half of those are families with children, who require extra care.The southern border is nearly 2,000 miles long and already has about 650 miles of different types of barriers, including short vehicle barricades and tall steel fences that go up to 30 feet high. Most of the fencing was built during George W. Bush's administration, and there have been updates and maintenance throughout other administrations.Trump has yet to complete any new mileage of fencing or other barriers anywhere on the border, though he declared Friday that at least 400 miles of the border barrier would be erected over the next two years. His administration so far has only replaced existing fencing. Construction for that small chunk of fencing cost about $18 million, began in February 2018 and was completed in October. Plans to replace that fence date back to 2009, during President Barack Obama's tenure.Administration officials had been studying ways to minimize the economic impact of a potential border closure in case Trump went through with his threat, including keeping trucking lanes open or closing only certain ports.But even absent that extraordinary step, delays at border stations have been mounting after some 2,000 border officers were reassigned from checking vehicles to deal with migrant crowds.After the border visit, Trump traveled to Los Angeles for a pair of fundraisers in the deeply liberal city. He then traveled to Las Vegas for another re-election fundraiser and an address to the Republican Jewish Coalition, which is backed by GOP mega-donor Sheldon Adelson. ___Lemire reported from New York. Associated Press writers Jill Colvin and Alan Fram contributed to this report from Washington.
Address: Northcorp Business Park, Palm Beach Gardens, FL 33410, USA

Title: Munchausen syndrome by proxy: What is the mental health problem used in Gypsy Rose case?
Summary:
Gypsy Rose Blanchard was forced by her mother to undergo unnecessary medical procedures and was later convicted in connection with her murder. (Photo: HBO)

Gypsy Rose Blanchard, a woman previously known by her community as a sick child with cancer, pleaded guilty to murdering her mother — a woman she says forced her to fake disabilities, like someone suffering from Munchausen syndrome by proxy may do.

Dee Dee Blanchard convinced her daughter she had leukemia, muscular dystrophy, epilepsy, asthma and poor vision. But, Gypsy was actually a healthy girl subject to multiple surgeries, medications and a wheelchair.

In 2015, Gypsy Rose Blanchard and a boyfriend she met online were charged with first-degree murder after Dee Dee Blanchard was found stabbed to death in her bed.

The shocking case is also the subject of Hulu's new drama, "The Act." HBO's documentary film "Mommy Dead and Dearest" focused on details of the case in 2017.

Here's what you should know about Munchausen syndrome by proxy:

What is Munchausen syndrome by proxy?

It's a mental disorder, also known as factitious disorder, that involves a parent exaggerating, inducing or making up illnesses for a child that is not actually sick. People may do this to gain sympathy, attention and money. It is a form of child abuse.

Marc Feldman, who has been studying Munchausen by proxy for over 25 years, said in a past interview that Munchausen by proxy survivors can struggle with discerning what's real and what's not, and they sometimes avoid getting medical care when they need it because they don't trust hospitals.

"Adult survivors of Munchausen by proxy, they almost invariably have post-traumatic stress disorder," Feldman said. "If not the full-blown disorder, at least symptoms like flashbacks."

More: Patricia Arquette: At 50, 'I didn't imagine I'd get good parts' like Hulu's 'The Act'

Do experts think Gypsy Blanchard's mom had it?

Feldman feels confident saying Gypsy Blanchard was a victim of Munchausen by proxy.

"Gypsy was infantilized and kept away from her peers," Feldman said. "She was little more than a tool for Dee Dee to navigate through the world the way she wanted to."

Feldman noted the length of time that Dee Dee Blanchard abused her daughter and her ability to dupe so many people.

"The length to which Dee Dee took it is remarkable," Feldman said. "Part of the agenda appears to be malingering, trying to get money out of the fraud ... But most of it seemed to be her pursuit of attention and control."

Where is Gypsy now?

Gypsy Blanchard is serving a 10-year sentence for her role in the death of her mother. In a 2018 interview, her stepmother Kristy Blanchard said she's doing "amazing" working toward earning her GED.

"There has been no long-term side effects from all the medication her mom had given her," Blanchard said at the time. "She has a clean bill of health, thank God — and I really only think what it has done was stunt her growth."

Contributing: Harrison Keegan, Springfield (Mo.) News-Leader. Follow Ashley May on Twitter: @AshleyMayTweets

Title: Man accused of slaughtering 400-pound pet pig named Princess that wandered into yard
Summary:
Advertisement Man accused of slaughtering 400-pound pet pig named Princess that wandered into yard Share Shares Copy Link Copy

A pet pig named Princess wandered away from her California home last month and met an ugly demise."It's just a really bizarre case," said Arcata police Lt. Todd Dockweiler.Princess wasn't one of those teacup pigs that you can carry around like a Chihuahua. She was a big girl, nearly 400 pounds, according to the Lost Coast Outpost.The fact that she wandered away wasn't out of the ordinary at all."Believe it or not, that's not a super uncommon call for us. We have a lot of loose livestock calls," said Dockweiler. "It is very common to have loose cows, loose horses, loose goats. it's still a neighborhood environment, but a lot of folks have a few acres."An officer responded and found Princess hanging out in someone's yard. The officer asked the property owner if he wouldn't mind keeping the pig in his yard until they could track down its owner, a practice Dockweiler says is common for these kinds of loose livestock issues.The neighbor happily obliged, and the officer went off to track down Princess's owner. Her owner was already looking for her, too, so she was easy to identify. But when the officer went back to retrieve Princess from the yard about an hour later, he stumbled upon something shocking: a butchering in progress."Obviously that was a bit of a shock to everyone involved. ... Given the stage of the butchering process he was in, he must have slaughtered the pig very shortly after the officer left," Dockweiler said.The man police say is responsible wasn't the homeowner but "a man who was known to them" who was on the property with the owner's permission.Thankfully, Princess's owner, identified as Carrie Hogan by the Lost Coast Outpost, wasn't there to see the gruesome scene for herself. But when she heard the news, she was devastated. Hogan told the local news site she bottle-fed Princess since she was a piglet and considered the pet a part of her family. According to Arcata police, slaughtering a pig that doesn't belong to you is a crime. Officers are expecting to forward a criminal charge to the district attorney's office after their investigation is complete."It's just not clear what the thought process was. He obviously knew the pig didn't belong to him and he didn't have the right to slaughter it."While Hogan considered Princess a family member, under the law, she's still considered livestock, so Dockweiler expects the suspect to be charged with "theft of livestock."Hogan told the Lost Coast Outpost she thinks the man responsible still has her pet's meat. She wants to get it back to keep him — or anyone else — from eating it."I think that the hardest part of this is knowing that there's somebody out there that's this kind of a savage," Hogan said.
Address: Northcorp Business Park, Palm Beach Gardens, FL 33410, USA

Title: Mother of murdered 7-year-old sponsors scholarship to prevent future child victims
Summary:
0 Mother of murdered 7-year-old sponsors scholarship to prevent future child victims

JACKSONVILLE, Fla. - The mother of a murdered local 7-year-old is sponsoring a scholarship so that no other child is victimized.

Friday would be Somer Thompson’s 17th birthday.

October will mark 10 years since she was abducted, sexually assaulted and murdered by a sexual predator who struck while she was walking to school.

TRENDING:

Diena Thompson, Somer's mother, said the new scholarship aims to give people the tools they need to identify and report these crimes.

“It’s to protect our children. It’s to protect our community,” Thompson said. “Our children are our most precious commodity and if we don’t start protecting them and trying to help them see the good and the evil in this world than I’m afraid the future could be disastrous for us.”

Somer Thompson was abducted and murdered by Jarred Harrell, who is serving a life sentence.

“Unfortunately, I have to miss my little girl because a monster came into my world and took her away,” Diena Thompson said.

The Somer Sunshine Scholarship is offering Darkness to Light Stewards of Children online training to anyone living in Baker, Clay, Duval, Nassau or St. Johns counties.

The training helps people learn how to prevent, recognize and react appropriately to sexual abuse.

Children’s Safe Passage, founded in response to Somer’s death, and the Somer Sunshine Foundation are providing it.

“I could possibly make a difference for somebody else and that’s what I’m going to do,” Diena Thompson said.

Thompson said if the scholarship can save even one child, it’s all worth it.

For people outside of Northeast Florida, they can access the training for $10.

Link to register: https://d2l.csod.com/selfreg/register.aspx?c=somer

Title: Kissimmee teen dies after car strikes her bicycle
Summary:
A minivan driven by a woman in the country on a "visitor pass" from Argentina and with no valid driver license struck and killed 13-year-old Mariana Perez Borroto on her way to school.

KISSIMMEE — Polk County Sheriff's Office deputies arrested 25-year-old Micaela Coronel of Kissimmee on charges of operating a motor vehicle without a valid driver license causing death, a third-degree felony, after she fatally struck 13-year-old Mariana Perez Borroto on Tuesday morning.

Coronel "failed to use care" when driving, hitting Borroto with her vehicle, according to PCSO reports.

According to the arrest affidavit, the crash occurred around 7:50 a.m.

Borroto, an 8th grader at Lake Marion Creek Middle School in Kissimmee/Poinciana, was riding her bicycle to school when she was hit by the Chrysler Town & Country minivan headed eastbound on Homosassa Road.

The teen was critically injured and airlifted to Arnold Palmer Children's Hospital in Orlando, where she later succumbed to her injuries, said the Sheriff's Office in a prepared media release Wednesday.

Coronel told deputies she's been in the country on a "visitor pass" from Argentina since October, and presented them with an Argentinian identification card, according to reports. She does not have a Florida driver license, and deputies determined through their investigation that she does not have a valid driver license at all.

Coronel told deputies that at the time of the crash, condensation covered approximately 80% of her windshield, obstructing her view while she was driving, according to reports.

Other factors that may have contributed to the crash are being investigated, said the Sheriff's Office. The investigation is ongoing.

The PCSO is checking with U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement to determine her status in the country, due to the fact that she's committed a felony, according to reports.

"This suspect should not have even been behind the wheel of a vehicle. This is an awful, senseless tragedy that should never have occurred," Sheriff Grady Judd said. "This beautiful child should be turning 14 years old in just two weeks, but for this suspect's illegal actions. Mariana's family and friends are in our prayers."

Johna Jozwiak, the principal at Lake Marion Creek Middle, said, "Our hearts are broken today. We are devastated by the loss of a very special member of our Lake Marion Creek Middle family. Mariana was a bright and sweet-natured girl who possessed a very polite and calm manner. She enjoyed studying history and loved spending her free time sketching in notebooks. We are devastated by this tragic news."

Counselors are available at school for students and staff members, said Jozwiak. The rest of this week's Florida Standards Assessments testing has been rescheduled to next week, she said.

Kathy Leigh Berkowitz can be reached at kberkowitz@theledger.com or at 863-802-7558. Follow her on Twitter @kberkowitzthel1.
Address: 455 6th St NW, Winter Haven, FL 33881, USA

Title: St.Pete man accused of kidnapping, beating teen, dropping her off at police headquarters
Summary:
Copyright 2019 Nexstar Broadcasting, Inc. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten, or redistributed. St. Petersburg Police

ST.PETERSBURG, Fla. (WFLA) - A St.Petersburg man is behind bars after deputies say he kidnapped a 16-year-old girl, had multiple women beat her up, and then dropped her off at the police headquarters saying she had stolen a car.

Mi'Keal Davis, 24 on April 1 allegedly exited his black Toyota Venza wearing a black mask armed with a handgun and chased the teen until he was able to strike her with his gun and forced her into her car.

According to detectives, Davis then took the teen to an unknown location where several unknown victims attacked her. Following the attack, Davis took the victim to St.Petersburg Police headquarters saying she had stolen a car the night prior.

The victim was treated at All Children's Hospital. Davis has been charged with Kidnapping.
Address: 200 S Parker St, Tampa, FL 33606, USA

Title: Police: Mom says she might have misjudged man who touched child
Summary:
Police: Mom says she might have misjudged man who touched child

Police in West Virginia say a woman now says she might have misinterpreted an incident when she reported that a man was trying to abduct her 5-year-old daughter at a mall.News outlets report the woman told police Monday that she stopped the man by pulling out a gun.Police said the prosecutor was working Tuesday to either release 54-year-old Mohamed Fathy Hussein Zayan of Alexandria, Egypt, or amend the charges.The criminal complaint said a woman was shopping at the Huntington Mall in Barboursville when a man grabbed her child by the hair. Police said Tuesday that inconsistencies were discovered, and the mother eventually said she might have misjudged the man’s actions and overreacted to his touching the child’s head.Jail records don’t indicate whether Zayan has an attorney.This is the original story reported from the Associated Press:Police in West Virginia say a man was trying to abduct a child at a mall when the mother stopped him by pulling out a gun.News outlets report 54-year-old Mohamed Fathy Hussein Zayan of Alexandria, Egypt, was arraigned Monday night in Cabell County Magistrate Court on a felony charge of attempted abduction.According to a criminal complaint, a woman was shopping with her 5-year-old daughter at the Huntington Mall in Barboursville when a man grabbed the girl by the hair and tried to pull her away. Police say the mother pulled out a gun and told the suspect to let go of the child. The man released the child and was later detained by mall security and Barboursville police near a food court.Zayan was being jailed on $200,000 cash bond. Jail records didn’t indicate whether he has an attorney.

Police in West Virginia say a woman now says she might have misinterpreted an incident when she reported that a man was trying to abduct her 5-year-old daughter at a mall.

News outlets report the woman told police Monday that she stopped the man by pulling out a gun.

Advertisement

Police said the prosecutor was working Tuesday to either release 54-year-old Mohamed Fathy Hussein Zayan of Alexandria, Egypt, or amend the charges.

The criminal complaint said a woman was shopping at the Huntington Mall in Barboursville when a man grabbed her child by the hair. Police said Tuesday that inconsistencies were discovered, and the mother eventually said she might have misjudged the man’s actions and overreacted to his touching the child’s head.

Jail records don’t indicate whether Zayan has an attorney.

This is the original story reported from the Associated Press:

Police in West Virginia say a man was trying to abduct a child at a mall when the mother stopped him by pulling out a gun.

News outlets report 54-year-old Mohamed Fathy Hussein Zayan of Alexandria, Egypt, was arraigned Monday night in Cabell County Magistrate Court on a felony charge of attempted abduction.

According to a criminal complaint, a woman was shopping with her 5-year-old daughter at the Huntington Mall in Barboursville when a man grabbed the girl by the hair and tried to pull her away. Police say the mother pulled out a gun and told the suspect to let go of the child. The man released the child and was later detained by mall security and Barboursville police near a food court.

Zayan was being jailed on $200,000 cash bond. Jail records didn’t indicate whether he has an attorney.

Title: 2 teens electrocuted trying to save dog in canal
Summary:
Advertisement 2 teens electrocuted trying to save dog in canal Share Shares Copy Link Copy

Two teenagers trying to rescue a dog from a canal died Monday when they grabbed hold of an electrically charged metal bridge, the Solano County Sheriff’s Office said.Three teenage boys, a teenage girl and a dog were walking alongside a Solano Irrigation District canal west of Interstate 80 in Dixon around 12:30 p.m. when, at some point, two of the teens and the dog walked across the bridge, which goes over the canal. “For unknown reasons, the dog jumped or fell from the bridge into the SID canal,” a news release from the sheriff’s office said. Two of the boys — identified by officials as 17-year-old Jacob Hourmouzus of Elk Grove and 17-year-old Jacob Schneider of Dixon — jumped into the canal to try to save the dog. As they grabbed the dog, the teens reached up to the metal bridge to try to keep from being pulled farther down the canal. “When doing so, witness reports state the two teenage boys appeared to have been electrocuted and unable to release their grip from the metal bridge,” the sheriff’s office said. The third teenage boy saw what was happening and jumped into the canal, which knocked the two other teens off the bridge. He was able to pull the two teens from the canal and onto the side of the levee. The teenage girl then called 911. Firefighters quickly arrived at the canal and started lifesaving efforts on the two boys. Both were rushed to a hospital in Vacaville, where they were pronounced dead. A Pacific Gas and Electric Co. crew went to the scene to deactivate power to the energized bridge so that it would be safe for investigators. Investigators with the sheriff’s office and the Solano County District Attorney’s Office are looking into the case and “will work with experts to determine how the bridge became energized and this incident occurred,” the release said. “Our thoughts and prayers go out to the families of everyone affected by this tragedy,” Solano County Sheriff Thomas Ferrara said in a statement. “The Solano County Sheriff’s Office will continue to search for answers as to how this incident happened.”The dog, named Ranger, was treated for its injuries, released to its family and was reportedly in good health as of Tuesday morning, officials said.
Address: Northcorp Business Park, Palm Beach Gardens, FL 33410, USA

Title: Lawsuit: Veterinarian used pet clinic medication to drug teen before rape
Summary:
Advertisement Lawsuit: Veterinarian used pet clinic medication to drug teen before rape Share Shares Copy Link Copy

A civil lawsuit filed against an embattled Santa Fe veterinarian sheds new light on the rape and sexual battery accusations against him in Louisiana.Todd Michael Glover, 36, is facing one charge of rape and three charges of sexual battery in Allen Parish, after he allegedly drugged and sexually assaulted a 17-year-old Galveston County girl and another underage girl during a trip to the neighboring state on Dec. 1, according to a lawsuit filed against Glover last week. Glover was arrested on the four charges Dec. 26 at his Hitchcock home. As the criminal case continues, one of the victims' families lodged a suit in Galveston County against Glover and his clinics, alleging that he used animal medication from his clinic to sedate the teenager and two other minors that night."Despite being aware of the fact that (the victim) could not legally or ethically consent to an exchange of sexual acts, Glover exploited and took advantage of (her)," the lawsuit alleges. "No person could reasonably believe that (she) could give valid consent for sexual contact."Glover's criminal attorney, Paul Darrow, could not immediately be reached for comment. He previously told Chron.com that Glover is innocent. An attorney for Glover on the civil suit was not listed.Glover has since had his veterinarian license suspended. In an order filed in January, authorities with the Texas Board of Veterinary Medical Examiners allege Glover did not keep proper records of several controlled substances used to treat pet ailments, including ketamine, tramadol and diazepam.He's also accused of prescribing Adderall to pets, including his own and pets of his employees, when it may not have been necessary, according to the order.Samantha Martinez, the lawyer representing the family on the civil suit, said Glover and the girl knew each other prior to the trip to Louisiana, although the type of connection was not immediately clear.
Address: Northcorp Business Park, Palm Beach Gardens, FL 33410, USA

Title: Oviedo restaurant launches social media campaign to reunite girl with stuffed animal
Summary:
The employees of a Seminole County restaurant are doing everything they can to reunite a misplaced stuffed animal with its rightful owner. A mother and daughter came into eat at the Dairy Queen on Hammock Road in Oviedo on Saturday, March 23, but they left the restaurant not realizing the stuffed dog they brought along was still at their table. They came back looking for it, but employees couldn’t find it at the time.Employees found the pick eared pooch while they were cleaning up later that day and after that they started a Facebook campaign to get the dog back to its owner. “I can't wait to be reunited with my owner. The people at Dairy Queen have been so nice to me, but I just can't wait to be back with my best friend,” one post said. Monday’s post has the puppy with a new friend. Someone to keep it company until they can find the rightful owner. “Your little puppy is in good hands and we'll take care of her until you can come and we'll get you some ice cream when you can,” another post said.

Title: Bradenton man on trial for allegedly luring 5-year-old with candy then raping her
Summary:
Bradenton man on trial for allegedly luring 5-year-old with candy then raping her Copyright 2019 Nexstar Broadcasting, Inc. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten, or redistributed. Video

MANATEE COUNTY, Fla. (WFLA) - A Bradenton man is on trial for a chilling crime that would terrify any parent.

Prosecutors say Dominick Hawkins lured a 5-year-old girl with candy and then raped her.

In June 2013, a 5-year-old girl was playing outside her grandmother's home at the Wayside Glen mobile home park in Bradenton.

Prosecutors say Dominick Hawkins, a homeless man, offered to buy her candy.

"They went hand in hand, down the road to a convenience store,” said prosecutor Ashley Dusnik.

The pair was captured on surveillance camera.

“After she got the candy she wanted to go home, but the man told her he was having a party at his house,” said Dusnik.

Instead, he lured her to an abandoned trailer.

"They went to what she thought was his house and she'll tell you that there was no furniture in the house, it just had some trash in the house and that when they got there, the man began to be mean to her. And [he] pushed her down on the ground and began to choke her and told her to shut up and be quiet,” said Dusnik.

Officials say after he assaulted her, he ran to a nearby bus, frantically trying to leave the area.

“She put her pants back on. Tried to exit the trailer, when she found she couldn’t go out the door, she crawled out a window,” said Dusnik.

Surveillance video shows the girl running home for help.

That little girl is now 11-years-old, and she will testify in front of the jury.

Hawkins' defense team says the convenience store owner recognized the pair as regular customers and nothing seemed amiss.

“The video does not depict a man who is holding a 5-year-old against her will, it shows a girl who won't leave Mr. Hawkins alone,” said defense attorney Charalampos Demosthenous.

If convicted, Hawkins will face life in prison.

The girl is expected to testify on Tuesday. The trial should wrap up by Friday.
Address: 200 S Parker St, Tampa, FL 33606, USA

Title: Benches, sidewalks, safety top concerns for local leaders after death of Cape Coral girl
Summary:
CLOSE Layla's family and friends hosted their own fundraiser called Lights for Layla. Andrea Melendez, Fort Myers News-Press

Local leaders discussed school bus stop safety Monday, following the death of an 8-year-old girl who was hit by a truck while waiting for the bus last week.

At the Cape Coral City Council meeting, a member of the Rotary Club of Cape Coral said the organization plans on working with other organizations and donors to install more benches at school bus stops in the city. Ed Bolter, a Rotarian and vice president of Lamar Advertising, said the club has the capability and resources to help make this project happen.

“I don't want to see another child hurt, much less tragically killed; it's too emotional for the whole city," Bolter said. "We need to get this done. So hopefully we can do it.”

Randi Romanoff, right, a co-founder of the non-profit organization "Lights for Layla", addresses the Cape Coral city council Monday afternoon, 4/1/19, during a public meeting. The group was organized after Layla Aiken was killed by a car last Monday morning while waiting for the school bus near her home. (Photo: Ricardo Rolon/The News-Press USA TODAY NETWORK - FLORIDA)

Layla Aiken was killed last week when a pickup struck her while she was waiting at a school bus stop with her twin brothers. Police recovered a truck they believe is involved and identified a person of interest, but have yet to make an arrest.

More: Lights for Layla: local agencies raising money for LED lights on student backpacks after girl's death at school bus stop

And: Cape Coral community gathers to support grieving family of 8-year-old killed in hit-and-run

Melissa Shollack fights back tears remembering Layla Aiken, who was killed last month while waiting at a school bus stop. Shollack addressed the Cape Coral city council Monday afternoon, 4/1/19, during a public meeting. She was concerned about student safety while waiting at school bus stops. (Photo: Ricardo Rolon/The News-Press USA TODAY NETWORK - FLORIDA)

Bolter said he has discussed the project with a Fort Myers company that will donate precast slabs on which the benches will go, which would allow the benches to be more easily moved.

Cape Coral Traffic Engineer Bill Corbett said there have been 16,000 school bus stop changes countywide during the current school year, for various reasons, including the presence of registered sex offenders and students moving. He said there are roughly 7,000 school bus stops in Lee County with 1,671, or about 24%, located in Cape Coral.

He said 673 of Cape Coral's stops are semipermanent, meaning they remain the same year-after-year. To date, all semipermanent bus stops with pickups or drop-offs during dark hours have street lights, he said.

Erin Diaz adjusts the microphone for her son Colin, 10, who was addressing the Cape Coral city council Monday afternoon, 4/1/19, during a public meeting. (Photo: Ricardo Rolon/The News-Press USA TODAY NETWORK - FLORIDA)

Previously: Cape Coral mourns 8-year-old girl killed in hit-and-run: 'Help us lay this angel to rest.'

Also: Cape Coral, Lee County School District to analyze bus stop safety after student deaths

Consultant and former mayor Joe Mazurkiewicz said the city manager included him in the discussions because of his experience helping to deploy LeeTran benches. He said the Chamber of Commerce, Cape Coral Construction Industry Association and other organizations have reached out with their willingness to join in the effort.

District 5 Council Member David Stokes pledged to sponsor a bench.

“With this many folks supporting … we can take a big bite out of this fairly quickly,” Mazurkiewicz said.

District 7 Council Member Jessica Cosden requested that the city have a dedicated sidewalks budget that includes money from the general fund this budget season or sooner. She said the sidewalks budget now is all grant-funded.

"We're too big of a city not to do that,” Cosden said.

Sidewalks in Cape Coral Trouble scrolling? Move your finger or cursor to the right side of the screen. This map of sidewalks was created using data from Cape Coral's Open Data Portal. This data is based primarily on aerial imagery from 2014 and is updated periodically, but the accuracy of the data may vary.

Graphic by Janie Haseman / The News-Press

Several meeting attendees — many of whom wore "#LightsForLayla" T-shirts, and some of whom were students themselves — urged City Council members to take action with emotional pleas.

Randi Romanov, a friend of Lalya's mother and one of the Lights for Layla organizers, said everyone was at fault for allowing the girl's death to happen.

“How many more of our children need to die before this community does something? I’m going to answer that for you; the answer is none.”

Mayor Joe Coviello said he was sure the city could find safety solutions without "economics" getting in the way.

Members of the Cape Coral city council listen to public input Monday afternoon, 4/1/19. (Photo: Ricardo Rolon/The News-Press USA TODAY NETWORK - FLORIDA)

"We'll find funding for this kind of a program," Coviello said. "As the (city gets) built out, things like sidewalks more street lighting, go hand-in-hand."

The Lee County School Board and local law enforcement leaders held a meeting earlier in the day to talk about school safety issues, including school bus stop safety.

Superintendent Greg Adkins said the school district and the city of Cape Coral plan to form a team to look at the issue. Adkins said he also wants to have similar discussions with Lehigh, the city of Fort Myers and the county.

"I think countywide we have to work within our different cities and municipalities to try to address this issue more broadly," Adkins said. "That's when you talk about ... sidewalks or safer bus stop areas. This is something I think is going to be a collaborative effort moving forward.

"And let's face it ... there are reports out there that have shown that Lee County is one of the more dangerous communities in our country as it relates to pedestrian and bicycle safety," Adkins said. "That impact students walking to school and riding to school on their bicycles."

NEWSLETTERS Get the Breaking News newsletter delivered to your inbox We're sorry, but something went wrong Urgent developments you should know now, not later. Please try again soon, or contact Customer Service at 1-800-468-0233. Delivery: varies Invalid email address Thank you! You're almost signed up for Breaking News Keep an eye out for an email to confirm your newsletter registration. More newsletters

The school district is also partnering with the Lee County Sheriff's Office and Big Mama and the Wild Bunch at FM radio station B103.9 to raise $100,000 for flashing LED lights that will go on students' backpacks by the next school year.

School bus stop safety tips

Stand at least three giant steps or six feet away from the street when waiting on a bus.

Do not sit near the street at a bus stop.

Do not run or play at a bus stop.

Wear bright-colored clothing that makes it easy for drivers to see you.

Pay attention to your surroundings.

Parents and guardians should visit bus stops.

If you drop something near a bus, ask the bus driver for help.

Do not approach a bus until it has stopped and the doors are open.

Address: 2442 Dr Martin Luther King Jr Blvd, Fort Myers, FL 33901, USA

Title: Dericka Lindsay case: Final defendant in death of girl sat on by cousin cleared for trial
Summary:
Buy Photo Grace Joan Smith appears before Circuit Court Judge Jan Shackelford at a hearing in February. Smith was committed to a state hospital until she was competent enough to understand the criminal proceedings against her. The judge has since ruled that Smith has recovered enough to stand trial for her alleged role in the murder of her 9-year-old adopted daughter. (Photo: Tony Giberson/tgiberson@pnj.com)

Just weeks after she was deemed not competent for trial and sent to a state psychiatric hospital, a Pensacola woman has recovered enough to stand trial for her alleged role in the murder of her 9-year-old adopted daughter.

Grace Joan Smith, 71, is one of three people charged in the 2017 death of Dericka Lindsay, a child who suffocated when her cousin sat on her as a form of discipline. Both of Smith's co-defendants have already been convicted and sentenced to state prison, but Smith's trial was delayed when doctors determined she suffered delirium that prevented her from understanding court proceedings.

Smith was committed to the Florida State Hospital in Chattahoochee, where she received several weeks of competency training from medial staff. In a follow-up hearing Monday morning in Pensacola, a judge ruled Smith has regained her competency and the trial can move forward.

Competency, for court purposes, describes a defendant's ability to follow court proceedings, understand their rights and assist their attorney.

Smith was in poor physical health when she was initially arrested, and according to doctors, her mental health began to degrade as she was in jail awaiting trial. In a Feb. 21 competency hearing, officials said Smith suffered delirium, lost 200 pounds, spent most of her time in bed, frequently declined meals and medication, and refused to let nurses turn her to alleviate bed sores.

At the February hearing, Judge Jan Shackelford deemed Smith not competent and approved her transfer to Chattahoochee. Part of the judge's stated reasoning was that state medical personnel had the ability to compel Smith to comply with her treatment.

Smith has shown marked improvement under state care, according to officials, with Shackleford noting in the follow-up hearing Monday that Smith had been more "participatory and interactive" at the hospital than she was at court.

After finding Smith competent, the judge set a tentative trial date for mid-May.

Want more news like this? Click here to subscribe to pnj.com.

Prosecutors claim Smith and her husband, James, were having trouble maintaining discipline over Dericka. On the day of Dericka's death, her cousin, Veronica Green Posey, came over to help the Smiths get the 9-year-old under control. The approximately 320-pound Posey ended up killing Dericka when she sat on the girl's torso for several minutes.

Posey was convicted of felony murder and sentenced to life in prison. James Smith pleaded no contest to aggravated manslaughter and was sentenced to a decade in prison.

Kevin Robinson can be reached at krobinson4@pnj.com or 850-435-8527.

Read or Share this story: https://www.pnj.com/story/news/2019/04/01/dericka-lindsay-adopted-mom-stand-trial-death-girl-sat-cousin/3331408002/
Address: 101 E Romana St, Pensacola, FL 32502, USA

Title: Man caught in shower with young girl
Summary:
A man is facing lewd and lascivious charges after getting caught in the shower with a young girl. According to the Palm Beach County Sheriff's Office, the girl's mother made the shocking discovery.

Deputies arrested 20-year-old Pablo Perez Lopez on three counts of lewd and lascivious battery and one count of lewd and lascivious molestation on a victim older than 12 but younger than 16.

The girl told investigators she and Perez Lopez began getting close and that she started to fall in love with him. She said she initiated the idea of the two having sex in the shower. While standing nude in the shower, the girl said her mother opened the bathroom door and found Perez Lopez pulling his pants up. The girl later admitted to investigators she and Perez Lopez had sex approximately three times starting in February.

Perez Lopez is due in court Monday morning.
Address: 1100 Fairfield Dr, West Palm Beach, FL 33407, USA

Title: Aunt of girl severely injured from abuse shares dangers
Summary:
JACKSONVILLE, Fla. - It's easy to think child abuse happens to some other family in some other neighborhood. In reality, it happens multiple times every day.

Florida's child abuse hotline averages 77 calls from Northeast Florida each day. Those calls are about children neglected, beaten or worse.

A woman whose 2-year-old niece, Rosie, suffered such head trauma she was paralyzed shared her family's painful story of abuse with the hope it will prevent another child from suffering the same fate.

"At some point, someone took their hands and smashed in her ears on both sides of her head," said Rosie's aunt, Mandy Rhoden. "I didn't think she was going to make it."

Rhoden was speechless when she saw her niece for the first time in the hospital. The 2-year-old had suffered such severe trauma she had a stroke.

"She was paralyzed on the left side," Rhoden was speechless when she saw her niece for the first time in the hospital. The 2-year-old had suffered such severe trauma she had a stroke.

Video of Rosie in the hospital shows her whole body quivering from a seizure from the brain damage. The white of her left eye was blood-red.

A diagram showed all of the bruises on her little body.

"There were so many bruises on her body, they couldn't even count them all," Rhoden said.

Rhoden had been trying for months to get her sister -- Rosie's mom -- to give her custody of the girl. Instead, the mom turned the child over to a friend.

"He said she fell out of her car seat and she hit her head on the ground, and that's what caused her stroke," Rhoden said.

Jeremy Leonard is now charged with child abuse. The officers who arrested him reported finding a hole in a wall of his home about 3 feet from the ground. That's about the height of Rosie.

After the injury, it took weeks for Rosie to move her left hand and months more for her to learn how to walk again.

Now 4, Rosie is in a much happier, safer place, but she still has to wear a brace around her ankle to walk.

Rhoden has adopted her, along with another niece who was born with fetal alcohol syndrome.

She understands that raising children is hard.

"It is not easy for me. I am a single parent. I have a full-time job. I have two children and Rosie has all these therapies and doctors' appointments. Do I get frustrated? Yes. But never with them."

She hopes that sharing Rosie's story will remind anyone who cares for a child to stop before doing something that will change your life and a child's life forever.

"Don't let your last resort be abusing a child that has not done anything to deserve the abuse you are dishing out to him," Rhoden said. "You need to step away, take a few minutes to gather yourself and remember what you are there for. You're there to be their parent."

Doctors at Wolfson Children's Hospital have become concerned about the number of child abuse cases they've treated recently, especially among babies.

Experts suggest putting yourself in time out before you get so angry or so frustrated that you lash out at a child.

If you suspect abuse or neglect, you are urged to report the situation online at reportabuse.dcf.state.fl.us or call 1-800-962-2873.

Copyright 2019 by WJXT News4Jax - All rights reserved.
Address: 4 Broadcast Pl, Jacksonville, FL 32207, USA

Title: Melbourne nurse celebrating wedding anniversary saves child from near-drowning
Summary:
CLOSE Keith Cunningham, with the American Red Cross, demonstrates proper method of CPR. The Kentucky General Assembly recently passed a bill that requires all state public high school students to be trained in CPR. The Courier Journal

It's a scene no one wants to see.

A little girl is pulled from a pool — blue in color and unresponsive.

Sadly, that was what happened recently at the Rosen Shingle Creek hotel in Orlando.

Fortunately, Laura Dalton, a registered nurse at Health First’s Holmes Regional Medical Center in Melbourne, was there celebrating her 13th wedding anniversary.

“I see this lady holding this little girl, and she’s just blue,” Dalton said. “Your skills just take over.”

She described the next several minutes as an “out-of-body experience,” as her instinct kicked in and she began performing chest compressions on the small child, whom she estimated to be about 4 years old.

Dalton thinks she did about 10 rounds of cardiopulmonary resuscitation, or CPR, before the preschool-age child began coughing up water and hacking.

“By the time paramedics arrived, she was crying and wanted her mom and dad,” Dalton said.

Far out: Surfers help near-drowning victim at Pineda Beach

More: Toddler tumbles into Melbourne swimming pool, nearly drowns

Drowning in Indialantic: Grandfather from Michigan dies after being pulled from rough surf

The child was rushed to a nearby children’s hospital in Orlando where officials said she recovered.

With Florida leading the nation in the number of drowning deaths of children ages 1 to 4, CPR is something that could potentially help everyone, even if it is one of those things we hope we’ll never have to use.

Dalton does think about the fact that had no one else been present who was trained in CPR, the outcome could have been tragic.

Dalton being there must have been fate.

The weekend getaway was a surprise anniversary treat from her mother-in-law just days earlier, Dalton said. With her husband in the military and expected to deploy in May, the trip became an incredible gift not just for the couple, their two children and extended family, but also for this tiny guest and her loved ones.

“I’m so grateful that I happened to be right by this little girl when she needed help,” Dalton said. “It just goes to show how important a skill CPR is — and it’s something anyone can learn and use to save a life.”

Paulson is the Marketing & Communications Editor for Health First.

Laura Dalton, a registered nurse at Health First’s Holmes Regional Medical Center in Melbourne, recently saved a child at an Orlando-area hotel by using CPR. (Photo: Provided)

CPR training

Cardio pulmonary resuscitation or CPR training is regularly offered through Health First. In addition to CPR training, infant and child CPR classes are held monthly at the Health First Training Center in Melbourne. For more information, call 321-434-1960 or email training@health-first.org.

Address: 1 Gannett Plaza Ave, Melbourne, FL 32940, USA

Title: Teenage girl dead after car crashes into Altamonte Springs apartment complex
Summary:
- A deadly crash in Altamonte Springs sent one car barreling into an apartment complex.

The crash happened overnight Friday on Montgomery Road. Investigators say that a teenage girl was killed in the crash. The other car involved ended up slamming into the Sunny Village apartments.

Residents say that this is not the first time a car has crashed into their building. Courtney Passalacqua said that "apparently the people who lived here prior to us moved out because the same situation happened. They need to put some barrier between the road and these apartments because, as we see, it's lethal."

No one inside the apartment unit was hurt. The other driver, who survived, was taken to the hospital and is expected to be okay.
Address: 35 Skyline Dr, Lake Mary, FL 32746, USA

Title: Volusia schools look to cut down on high rate of suspensions
Summary:
A third-grade student walked into Christopher Sherriff’s classroom at Palm Terrace Elementary and threw herself into a chair. She was distraught, slumped down so far she was in danger of spilling onto the floor. She held her face in her hands and began to cry.

Sherriff folded himself into an identical tiny plastic chair beside her and slowly extracted the problem: After not doing well on a recent test, she was angry at her “stupid” teacher.

At many schools, a child leaving a classroom without permission and calling her teacher stupid would mean a one-way ticket to the principal’s office and, possibly, a suspension.

But as the Volusia County school district pushes to improve its state grade to an A, its track record of disciplining students stands out — and not in a good way. Over the last school year, 91 of every 1,000 students in Volusia were suspended. That's 78 percent higher than the state average of 51 students in every 1,000. No large, A-rated district in Florida had a higher rate of out-of-school suspensions or chronic absenteeism than Volusia. Flagler County had a rate of 68 suspended students per 1,000.

So Sherriff's focus wasn't on discipline; he sought to help the girl identify what she was feeling and how to deal with it constructively.

He calmly explained once, then again in a different way, that she was feeling more disappointed in herself than angry at her teacher. Her teacher wasn’t out to get her. The best way to deal with those feelings would be to work hard and improve on the next test.

Eventually, she perked up. She sat by herself and shuffled her feet while she considered his point. Then she went back to class with a plan to talk to her teacher one-on-one about what happened.

This is what a win looks like in Volusia County schools, where last year only 10 of Florida’s 67 school districts had a higher rate of out-of-school suspensions. That means more kids piling up absences instead of prepping for the exams the state uses to measure student performance and grade the school district’s effectiveness.

Now, Volusia is prioritizing social and emotional learning. Sherriff is an example of the teachers on assignment in middle and select elementary schools who were hired to impart lessons that go beyond reading and math to help children identify and respond to emotions that can cause problems if they don’t have them under control.

“It doesn’t take a rocket scientist to understand the more kids are out of school, the less likely they are to make academic progress,” said Cindy Fisher, who helps oversee discipline for Volusia schools and summed up what nearly everyone The News-Journal interviewed for this story said.

FAITH — an outside group of religious organizations in Volusia devoted to social justice — called on the School Board to reduce the amount of out-of-school suspensions by 50 percent by 2021. The group believes that a culture change encouraged by district leadership is what's needed. It’s hosting an action assembly at 6:30 p.m. Monday in Daytona’s Peabody Auditorium to further discuss the issue.

For about a year Volusia has made a coordinated push to cut down on the number of suspensions and keep kids in class. By offering more preventative measures, like social-emotional learning and restorative discipline practices, and generally turning to suspensions as a last resort, district officials hope the numbers will trend down this year.

“We do recognize that number (of suspensions) was high,” said Superintendent Tom Russell, who added it’s a question of school culture. “Is our culture going to be doing our very best to keep students in class? Or do you have just a very, very strict discipline code? You’re desperately trying to find the medium.”

The problem

On days she’s suspended, 7-year-old Kassie Larsh watches TV. She plays with her dogs, Chloe and Slater. She runs errands with her grandma and her cousin.

What’s meant to be a punishment feels more like a vacation for the second-grader at Forest Lake Elementary in Deltona, who giggles when she explains her routine on those days.

“To her, it has no bearing,” said her mom, Krissy, echoing the parents of other young students who have been punished in this way. “She doesn’t even understand why she’s being suspended, and she thinks it’s great.”

Because student records are confidential, school officials are unable to comment about Kassie's suspensions. Her mom said she's been suspended from school for seven days so far this year, a punishment that also results in the loss of privileges at home like watching TV and using a tablet. Each suspension occurred because Kassie, who has a behavioral disability, hit another student. At many schools, violence is one of the non-negotiables that can lead to a suspension.

“She’s getting the suspensions, and then she’s getting the letters for chronic absenteeism,” she said.

These are the documents schools send home with students who are in danger of being labeled chronically absent, or missing 10 percent of the entire school year. “We are concerned that these absences may affect Kassandra’s educational progress toward graduation,” the letters read.

Kassie’s experience illustrates part of Volusia’s problem: How can you discipline students to curb bad behavior without compromising their academic progress or anyone’s safety?

Volusia has erred on the side of safety, turning out students from the classroom at a higher rate than other large counties like Miami-Dade, Hillsborough and Orange. The number of Volusia students suspended in 2017-2018 totaled about 5,700, just under 10 percent of the student population. The number of total out-of-school suspensions — which counts each time a student is suspended — was just under 11,000. (That's a figure the state doesn't track, so it's difficult to make comparisons with other districts.)

Another problem with school discipline that's been widely documented across the country is that it disproportionately affects black students. Volusia is no different. Although black students make up less than one-fifth of Volusia's student population, they account for about one-third of suspensions. White students are two-thirds of the population, but constitute less than half of suspensions.

Nicholas Gage, an assistant professor at the University of Florida and an expert on positive behavioral interventions for children, explained there is a national movement to reduce the number of out-of-school suspensions in districts.

“There is an ever-growing and mounting evidence base suggesting that suspensions have really negative outcomes on students, particularly out-of-school suspensions,” Gage said. “Removing students from a classroom reduces their access to general curriculum, and they are less likely to be successful.”

Earlier this year, a News-Journal analysis of state data showed Volusia lags behind Florida’s seven A-rated large districts in areas that impact student performance: It has lower teacher pay and experience, gets less of the state funding allocation, has a lower median household income, and has a higher rate of students living in poverty.

[READ MORE: Volusia County schools aim for an A, but face obstacles Florida doesn't count]

Compared with those same seven school districts, Volusia also had the highest number of out-of-school suspensions last year and the highest rate of chronic absenteeism.

Although middle schools had the most out-of-school suspensions, the chronic absenteeism rate at the elementary level rivaled that of the middle schools. Last year, the majority of Volusia's elementary schools were C-rated by the state.

“It’s hard for me to wrap by brain around how we send kids in elementary school home,” Gage said. “The direct instruction that early elementary kids get is their primary form of instruction.”

Volusia officials know this, and they're pushing to improve, especially at the elementary level. Teachers are expecting to get new math and language arts textbooks by the beginning of next year after five years without the basic materials. The district is also adding 30 minutes onto the elementary school day, to give those students even more access to instructional time.

[READ MORE: Unlike Volusia, top-rated school districts have textbooks for elementary schools]

[READ MORE: District looks to improve low grades at Volusia elementary schools]

Even as that’s all happening, Volusia has been changing the way it handles discipline and, in effect, its priorities — nearly unnoticed by anyone who isn’t experiencing it every day.

The response

A class of eighth-graders at Hinson Middle School recently sat in a circle and took turns answering questions posed by their teacher. What was your favorite family vacation? What are two of your pet peeves? What’s the last book you read?

Sometimes the entire class burst into laughter at someone’s sarcastic answer and they chattered over each other. Other times the honesty and vulnerability of the answers left everyone quiet for a couple of seconds.

Asked what they would change if they could go back in time, one student spoke about wanting to repair his relationship with his father before his death. Immediately afterward, another student said she wished she hadn’t spilled bleach on her carpet.

The exercise for middle schoolers, who traditionally have the highest rate of suspensions, was designed to teach them the classroom is a safe place, they’re all on the same team and that listening is often more important than having something to say.

It’s another example of the social and emotional learning taking place in Volusia. Seven teachers on assignment cover all 14 of Volusia’s middle schools, and four elementary schools have a full-time teacher in place to gradually teach kids how to better control their emotions.

“We teach them how to do math, we teach them how to read, but we don’t teach them how to get along with other people or how to resolve a conflict in an appropriate way,” Sherriff said. “And those are arguably more important than (for example) learning science. Because not everyone is going to use science when they’re an adult, but everyone is going to have conflict when they’re an adult.”

The teachers on assignment like Sherriff work with small groups of students, as well as helping other teachers incorporate social and emotional learning practices in the classroom. Some schools ask elementary students to chart their emotions on grids on their desks so teachers can gauge their needs. Others seek to build relationships among students so the class feels like a team.

It’s all in an effort to introduce once more a holistic approach to a child’s education. After years of being laser-focused on academic rigor and curriculum instruction — when every minute of the school day is planned and designed to give students more instruction and access to curriculum — social and emotional learning is, at its core, about instructors slowing down and getting to know the students they’re teaching.

“The teachers, the ones who it’s really clicked with, are seeing they can’t just come in and be a giver of curriculum, more or less,” said Greg Iorio, the dean of student relationships at Hinson Middle.

The results

After one year of implementing these practices, preliminary results suggest its working. At Palm Terrace where Sherriff works, for example, the elementary had seen 82 out-of-school suspensions through February for this school year. For the same period in the previous school year, Palm Terrace had 224 suspensions.

At the middle school level, which had 300 out-of-school suspensions for each 1,000 students in the past three years, there's been a 17 percent drop in discipline referrals compared with this time last year.

Russell promised at a March School Board meeting to present the latest district data soon. But no matter what the numbers show, there’s more in the pipeline for Volusia.

For now, there aren't any concrete plans to put more SEL teachers on assignments at more schools, said SEL specialist Justin Lipomi in an email.

The reviews from stakeholders are good, however, and he said his office will be advocating at a meeting later this month for the district to use federal funding to expand the program.

"Expansion is a top priority for us," Lipomi said.

In an effort to come up with more innovative ways to lower the number of suspensions, the district also started a task force in December called “Rethinking Discipline.” The group of mostly administrators will continue to meet to think of better ways to deal with students who act out.

“The bottom line is we want as many kids in school as possible,” Russell said. “We have worked to put in programs and create positions to help to that end, and we’re going to continue … (to create) a classroom culture where learning is encouraged and takes place every day.

“To me, that’s what you want.”
Address: 901 6th St, Daytona Beach, FL 32117, USA

Title: Police now say 1 died at scene of overnight Cove shooting, 3 injured; shooter still on the loose
Summary:
Panama City Police have identified absconded sex offender Michael Harrison Hunt as a person of interest, according to public information officer Caitlin Lawrence. Police have been looking for Hunt this week, as he has an active warrant for failure to appear April 1 on charges of "Unlawful sexual activity with certain minors" and aggravated assault, according to court records. According to an arrest complaint Hunt was already a registered sex offender.

PANAMA CITY —One of the people involved Thursday night in a Cove shooting actually died at the scene on Allen Avenue Thursday night, Panama City police are now saying, while three more remain hospitalized with life-threatening injuries.

The names of the victims have not been released, but police are searching for absconded sex offender Michael Harrison Hunt as a person of interest, according to public information officer Caitlin Lawrence. The truck he was believed to have been driving has been found abandoned in Bay County, Lawrence said.

Police have been looking for Hunt since Monday when he was deemed as a failure to appear on charges of "Unlawful sexual activity with certain minors" and aggravated assault, according to court records. According to an arrest complaint Hunt was already a registered sex offender.

Thursday shooting happened at about 10:30 p.m. in the 100 block of Allen Avenue, near the corner with Cherry Street. Two homes there were marked by crime scene tape Friday and it was unknown if the victims were associated with both homes.

According to a press release received at 12:21 p.m. today, "one victim succumbed to their injuries at the scene. The other three victims were transported to a local hospital for treatment. They all remain in serious condition at this time."

The department is saying that this is "not a random act" and they do not believe there is an immediate threat of danger to people living in the Cove or the rest of the city.

Hunt is described as a black male, 5'09'' tall and around 210 pounds. Hunt is known to operate a black 2015 Ford Explorer with Florida tag ETCT72 and his last known registered address in the 2100 block of E. 5th Street.

People with information on his location are asked to call the police.

Information from police has been slow in coming; one nearby school that heard about it on the Internet sent this message, which some parents who shared it with The News Herald: "Due to a shooting in the Cove neighborhood, school time this morning is postponed. Parents are asked to keep children at home until the suspect is captured. There is a lockdown location for all students at school today.”

One man who drove by the scene but asked that his name not be used said he was particularly concerned and trying to get information because he had heard the suspect was also wanted for child sex charge, but he didn't know if that was true.

Police have now said it is, and according to courthouse records Hunt was arrested Sept. 12 by the Bay County Sheriff's Office and charged with "Unlawful Sexual Activity with Certain Minors."

That investigation, according to court records, began with a Sept. 11 call to Panama City police involving Hunt "displaying a firearm during a verbal altercation." According to an arrest complaint, a man confronted Hunt "about having sexual contact with a neighbor's daughter." The complaint said Hunt went to his vehicle and lifted his shirt, "exposing a handgun he had tucked into the right side of his waist band."

Hunt allegedly told the man, "This can be taken care of right now," according to the complaint.

As police investigated that incident, it led to the discovery that Hunt was involved in sex acts with a minor that occurred outside the city, which started an investigation by the Bay County Sheriff's Office.

A Bay County Sheriff's Office arrest complaint said the girl in that case told them she had sex with Hunt. Hunt, in an interview, admitted to knowing the victim, denied having sex with her and admitted to knowing she was underage.

After his arrest on those charges in September, Hunt made bond but failed to appear in court April 1.

This is a developing story and will be updated.
Address: 501 W 11th St, Panama City, FL 32401, USA

Title: CCSO: Collier man arrested, accused of using social media to extort lewd photos from minors
Summary:
CLOSE This is a six-month review of the most-read crime stories in Collier County on naplesnews.com from September 2018 to February 2019. Vonna Keomanyvong, vonna.keomanyvong@naplesnews.com; 239-213-5380

A Collier County man was arrested Wednesday and accused of hacking into Snapchat accounts and extorting lewd photos from eight teens, according to the Collier County Sheriff’s Office.

Jorge L. Ingunza Jr., 21, was charged with possession of child pornography, two counts of transmitting child pornography, four counts of extortion and six counts of accessing a computer or electronic device without authorization.

The eight victims, including six in Collier County and two in Colorado, range in age from 13 to 18, according to the sheriff’s office.

Detectives said evidence indicates there are numerous other unidentified victims, according to a news release from CCSO.

More: Copeland man pleads not guilty to killing his father aboard fishing vessel

Jorge L. Ingunza Jr. (Photo: Collier County Sheriff's Office)

Some of these victims may not want to come forward out of fear they will be in trouble for having lewd photos of themselves, however the victims will not face charges and law enforcement wants to help them, according to CCSO.

The victims in Colorado told authorities they are aware of more than 20 other victims who are all afraid of repercussions for coming forward, according to Ingunza’s arrest report.

Since mid-December 2018, CCSO has received tips from local victims, the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children and law enforcement in Colorado about someone hacking into minors' Snapchat accounts, according to CCSO.

Snapchat is a popular messaging app that allows users to share photos and videos that disappear in a few seconds. Users can also post content that will stay visible for 24 hours.

More: Three main suspects in state-led massage parlor sting in Collier, Lee enter guilty pleas

Ingunza accessed the victim’s Snapchat accounts by tricking them into providing their usernames and passwords or by using an already-compromised account belonging to a friend of the victim, according to the sheriff’s office.

NEWSLETTERS Get the News Alerts newsletter delivered to your inbox We're sorry, but something went wrong Get alerted to the latest stories to stay on top of the news. Please try again soon, or contact Customer Service at 1-844-900-7105. Delivery: Varies Invalid email address Thank you! You're almost signed up for News Alerts Keep an eye out for an email to confirm your newsletter registration. More newsletters

Ingunza then took over the victim’s accounts, changing their backup e-mails, phone numbers and passwords, according to CCSO.

He downloaded the lewd images and videos and then sent them back to the victim on Instagram, according to CCSO.

Detectives said Ingunza threatened to post the images publicly on social media if the victims didn’t send him more lewd images.

More: Grand jury indicts Golden Gate Estates man on first-degree murder count

During an exchange with one victim, Ingunza called himself a “sociopath” and said he was having “fun,” according to his arrest report.

Ingunza used many fake Instagram accounts, including one called Lizziedoggy15, and accounts he had hacked from other victims, according to CCSO.

Investigators determined the internet activity was occurring at Ingunza’s home on Emperor Lane in southeastern Collier County, according to the sheriff’s office.

On Wednesday, Special Crimes Bureau detectives and SWAT members found Ingunza at home with his mother.

Detectives said they found photographs of one of the victims on Ingunza’s iPhone X and numerous emails from Snapchat about password changes for various accounts, according to Ingunza’s arrest report.

More: Police: Naples homicide suspect called victim's son, admitted to the crime

Folders, possibly named after each victim, were found on Ingunza’s iPhone X with lewd photos of the victims, according to his arrest report.

Anyone who believes they may be a victim or has information about the Ingunza case is asked to contact the Collier County Sheriff’s Office at 239-252-9300 or to remain anonymous call Crime Stoppers at 1-800-780-8477 (TIPS).

CLOSE Here are three ways to submit a tip to Crime Stoppers. Wochit

STAYING SAFE

Use software to monitor children's online activity.

Know what apps your children are using and how they work. Keep the computer in a family room rather than a child’s bedroom.

Enforce social media apps' age requirements and learn children's online dialect.

Avoid posting public photos of children online.

Remember people online may not be who they seem. Someone claiming to be a 12-year-old girl could be a 40-year-old male predator.

If you become aware of child pornography while online, immediately report it to the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children’s CyberTipline at 1-800-843-5678 or www.cybertipline.com.

Source: CCSO

Read or Share this story: https://www.naplesnews.com/story/news/crime/2019/04/04/jorge-ingunza-jr-accused-using-social-media-extort-lewd-nude-photos-minors-collier-sheriffs-office/3365638002/
Address: 1100 Immokalee Rd, Naples, FL 34110, USA

Title: Mistrial in case of man accused of threatening to kill U.S. Rep. Brian Mast's kids
Summary:
Laurence Key (Photo: CONTRIBUTED PHOTO BY ST. LUCIE COUNTY SHERIFF'S OFFICE)

MARTIN COUNTY — A mistrial was declared Thursday in a federal case involving a Stuart man arrested last year after allegations he threatened to kill U.S. Rep. Brian Mast's children over Trump administration immigration policies, according to records and the U.S. Attorney’s Office.

The trial against Laurence Key, 68, charged with one count of communicating a threat to kidnap or injure a person, began Monday in Miami, but there was a hung jury and a mistrial was declared, according to records and Sarah Schall, U.S. Attorney's Office spokeswoman.

Key first was arrested by FBI agents June 18, hours after an intern in Mast’s office in Washington, D.C., reported a man later identified as Key threatened to kidnap and kill Mast's children, a girl and two boys. Mast now has a daughter and three sons.

More: Grand jury indicts man on charges he threatened to kidnap, kill Rep. Brian Mast's children

Key “said something to the effect that he was going to separate the Congressman from his children by kidnapping and killing the children and said it will not be possible to find him,” records state.

Officials ultimately tracked the call to Key’s home in Stuart.

A Martin County Sheriff’s detective and an FBI agent spoke to Key there.

According to a transcript of an interview there, Key told investigators he’d been “calling all day to everybody.”

“Telling people that they are wrong not to oppose this Nazi regime. It's just like Germany in 1930,” Key said.

Key said he had not been drinking or taking drugs.

NEWSLETTERS Get the News Alerts newsletter delivered to your inbox We're sorry, but something went wrong Get alerted to the latest stories to stay on top of the news. Please try again soon, or contact Customer Service at 1-844-331-0264. Delivery: Varies Invalid email address Thank you! You're almost signed up for News Alerts Keep an eye out for an email to confirm your newsletter registration. More newsletters

Asked what he said during the Mast call, Key said, “I told him that what he's doing is wrong and that he's not — that he needs to have some kind of incentive to know how those people felt and he deserves to have — he deserves to be separated from his children.”

More:Stuart man charged with threatening Rep. Brian Mast's children over Trump policy

It's not the first time Key has gotten into trouble over politics.

Shortly before the 2004 presidential election, Martin County deputies spotted Key pulling up Bush-Cheney signs, tearing them up and putting them in his vehicle, according to arrest records.

A jury found Key guilty of petty theft and criminal mischief and he spent six months on probation after paying $1,259 in fines.

Mast, a Republican from Florida's 18th district, stretching from northern Palm Beach County to Martin and St. Lucie counties, did not take a public stance on the Trump administration's former policy of separating migrant children from their families.

President Donald Trump signed an executive order reversing the policy two days after Key's arrest.
