Title: State rests in Bargo resentencing trial
Summary:
Forensics expert and medical examiner among Thursday's witnesses; defense starts presenting its case on Friday

Prosecutors on Thursday rested their case in the resentencing trial of Michael Shane Bargo.

Assistant State Attorneys Amy Berndt and Robin Arnold took turns questioning more than 10 witnesses, including sheriff's deputies, forensic specialists, a firearm examiner, medical officials, and those who talked with Bargo about killing 15-year-old Seath Jackson.

James Williams Sr. said Bargo told him he had killed someone and burned his body. He said Bargo told him how many times he shot the victim and details on how and when the murder occurred.

One of Bargo's lawyers, Candance Hawthorne, quizzed Williams about her client's state of mind and asked his impression of Bargo. Williams said at first he did not believe Bargo and was trying to figure out what Bargo told him. He said he never contacted law enforcement, and said Bargo told him the reason he killed the person was because the victim had raped a girl who was close to him.

Bargo, along with co-defendants Amber Wright, Kyle Hooper, Charlie Ely and Justin Soto, have been convicted of Seath’s murder. The co-defendants were sentenced to life in prison, but Bargo was sentenced to death.



In October 2016, the Florida Supreme Court ruled that juries must unanimously recommend death sentences. Bargo’s jury voted 10-2 for death. In June 2017, the Florida Supreme Court granted Bargo resentencing.

Crystal Anderson testified that Bargo told her he was in trouble and had done something crazy. She said he told her he had killed someone and she thought he was not being serious. Anderson said Bargo went into details about shooting the victim eight times, including twice in the face, and burning the boy's body after beating him.

Anderson said she never said anything to anyone because she was scared. When Bargo was arrested in Starke, she said she did not read anything about the murder on social media or any news outlets.

Hawthorne asked Anderson about Bargo's mood. She said when she first met Bargo, she considered him a happy-go-lucky person. But when he was in Starke with them, he was acting sad and depressed as if something was bothering him. Anderson said Bargo told her he did it, meaning the crime.

James Williams Sr. said when Bargo told him about the killing, he told him to turn himself in. Williams said he was shocked.

After his arrest in Starke, Bargo was transferred to the Marion County Jail. There, a fellow inmate, William Faulker, testified Bargo freely told him that the person he killed had raped a girlfriend and he killed him, making reference to Seath. Faulker said he never told anyone about that conversation until three weeks later, when he was released.

In the morning session, Arnold questioned Mike Proctor, the man who gave Bargo the firearm that was used to shoot Seath.

Proctor told Arnold he called the Marion County Sheriff's Office to report that bit of information because it was "the right thing to do."

The .22-caliber weapon, together with the box it came in, was given to Bargo in exchange for yard work Bargo did, Proctor said.

Following Proctor's time on the witness stand, sheriff's official Lisa Berg testified about locating Seath's remains and outlined the careful steps taken to preserve the evidence. During this testimony, Seath's mother, Sonia Jackson, left the courtroom.

Seath's body was burned in a burn pit and the remains were placed in buckets. Dr. Michael Warren, retired director of the University of Florida CA Pound Human Identification Laboratory, testified about how those remains were analyzed and determined to be Seath's.

Dr. Kyle Shaw of the Medical Examiner's Office in Leesburg was able to review the evidence, both from the scene and at his office. He told the jury how he concluded that Seath died from a gunshot wound and blunt force trauma.

Hawthorne asked Shaw if he could determine which came first: the gunshot or the blunt force trauma. Shaw said he could not and said a combination of the two caused the teen's death.

Maria Pagan, a firearms examiner, talked about testing the gun used to shoot the teen.

The defense is expected to present its case to jurors starting Friday.

Contact Austin L. Miller at 867-4118, austin.miller@starbanner.com or @almillerosb
Address: 2121 SW 19th Avenue Rd, Ocala, FL 34471, USA

Title: Ex-officer who had sex while child was dying in car gets 20 years
Summary:
A former Mississippi Gulf Coast police officer is headed to prison for the death of her 3-year-old daughter, who was left in a patrol car while her mom had sex with a police supervisor.

Ex-Long Beach police Officer Cassie Barker was sentenced Monday to 20 years in prison in the 2016 death of Cheyenne Hyer. The 29-year-old pregnant woman pleaded guilty to manslaughter in a plea bargain after being indicted on a charge of second-degree murder.

Cheyenne was strapped in her car seat in the patrol car for four hours while Barker was with her then-supervisor. The car's air was turned on, but it wasn't blowing cold. Cheyenne was unresponsive and had a temperature of 107 degrees when Barker returned.

Ryan Hyer, the child's father, who lives in Jacksonville, read an impact statement on Monday during Baker's sentencing hearing in a Mississippi courtroom. He described to News4Jax on Tuesday how the tragic death of his daughter has impacted him.

"This was very difficult. I've been waiting for two and a half years for this to be over with," Hyer said. "It doesn't bring my daughter back, but I can start moving forward now that justice has been served."

The father is suing Long Beach Police Department, which is the agency Barker worked for, and he's suing the Mississippi Department of Child Protection Services for the wrongful death of his child. Hyer said Barker was arrested months before his daughter's death for leaving the young girl in the car while going into a store.

"She was arrested, (the) state took my daughter, and (the) police chief went and got her out of jail. Within 24 hours, she had my daughter back and I was never notified," Hyer said.

Barker is not eligible for parole.
Address: 4 Broadcast Pl, Jacksonville, FL 32207, USA

Title: Tallahassee man facing multiple child sex charges
Summary:
A Tallahassee man is facing multiple child sex charges after investigators say he used food and sweets to coerce a young girl into lewd acts.

James R. Daniels III was charged Monday with three counts of lewd and lascivious molestation, two counts of lewd and lascivious exhibition, lewd and lascivious battery, soliciting a child and child abuse. The 40-year-old is being held in the Leon County Detention Facility.

James R. Daniels III was charged Monday with three counts of lewd and lascivious molestation, two counts of lewd and lascivious exhibition, lewd and lascivious battery, soliciting a child and child abuse. The 40-year-old is being held in the Leon County Detention Facility. (Photo: Leon County Detention Facility)

The victim told investigators that over three years, Daniels masturbated in front of and grinded on her multiple times. She detailed several occasions in which Daniels coerced her into touching him sexually and pulling her into his lap while he was naked and touching her while she slept, despite her objections.

“The victim remembers the defendant bribing her with food and sweets,” Tallahassee Police investigators wrote in arrest documents. “He would offer her ice cream, candy or cookies. He would tell her, ‘I’ll give you this candy if you let me do this to you.’”

Daniels has an extensive Leon County criminal history that includes drug charges, aggravated battery and burglary. He was arrested after a meeting with his probation officer Monday.

Contact Karl Etters at ketters@tallahassee.com or @KarlEtters on Twitter

Title: In search of owner: Lost stuffed animal post goes viral
Summary:
- At a Dairy Queen in Oviedo, ice cream cones are swirled to perfection, with the help of a pink-spotted dog sitting nearby.

The dog, nicknamed by the restaurant “Lovely,” is a stuffed animal looking for her long lost owner. The store’s manager, Ryan Allen, is now looking for the dog’s owner, a little girl who left "Lovely" behind by accident.

“When you're a kid, your stuffed animal is like their pets or their best friend. It’s defiantly heartbreaking to know that there's some child out there that's missing their loved one,”he said. “They ate ice cream and she left it on the bench, and then they left.”

The store, taking to their Facebook page, saying “We know there is probably a sad kid out there missing their friend. Trying to find the owner of this super cute pup."

That could have been the end of it, but the posts didn't stop there.

“Day two: still haven't found my person, but the people watching me have lots of ice cream. Miss my kid though, waiting patiently for you to come back for me. #lostlovely.”

That post shared over 1,000 times.

“I mean if free cone day only got six shares and this little puppy dog got a thousand, that says a lot,” the store posted the following day, which it continued to do, throughout the week.

"Day four: got to play outside today, reminded me of the times we went to the park together. Not a moment passes by without the thoughts of you in my mind. "

It’s now day five, and still no owner. The family, believed to be from Florida, stopped in last week but missed the manager and couldn’t find "Lovely." Allen said he’s hoping they come back.



“If they stopped here once...hopefully they'll stop in again.”
Address: 35 Skyline Dr, Lake Mary, FL 32746, USA

Title: Deputies: Man smoked pot, drank, then drove around with 2-year-old
Summary:
ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla - A St. Augustine man was arrested after he smoked marijuana, took shots of alcohol and drove around with his 2-year-old stepdaughter, according to the St. Johns County Sheriff's Office.

William Patrick Schultz, 36, was arrested Sunday evening on charges of DUI, child neglect and a probation violation, an arrest report shows. As of Monday, he was held in the St. Johns County Jail on no bond.

According to the Sheriff's Office, Schultz's eyes were bloodshot and he smelled of alcohol. He told a deputy that he smokes medical marijuana and had last smoked around noontime. The report showed Schultz was pulled over around 6:44 p.m.

When asked, Schultz told a deputy he had drank a few shots of "99 proof," the Sheriff's Office said. He then requested not to perform a field sobriety test saying, "I know I'm going to fail."

According to the arrest report, Schultz's blood alcohol concentration level registered .240 during a breathalyzer test.

Investigators said the young girl's biological mother was called to the scene to take custody of the child and retrieve her car, which Schultz was driving.

Copyright 2019 by WJXT News4Jax - All rights reserved.
Address: 4 Broadcast Pl, Jacksonville, FL 32207, USA

Title: Mother claims son's head stomped at Jacksonville day care
Summary:
JACKSONVILLE, Fla. - A Jacksonville mother is calling for a state investigation into a Northside day care after her 8-year-old boy was hospitalized with a head injury.

The mother, whom we’ll refer to in this story as Jenny, said she was picking up her son Friday from Brighter Futures Learning Center on Lem Turner Road when she witnessed the unthinkable.

“I see a boy just stomping him in the face,” she told News4Jax on Monday. “Punching him and stomping him and stomping him, so immediately I went berserk.”

Jenny said her son was having an asthma attack and complaining of head pain, so she drove him to UF Health Jacksonville, where he was given breathing treatments and diagnosed with a head injury.

On Monday, News4Jax stopped by the Brighter Futures location to speak with the owner. She disputed the mother’s version of events, saying there was only a minor tussle over a game of basketball.

Jenny isn’t convinced, though. She has filed reports with the Jacksonville Sheriff’s Office and the Department of Children and Families. News4Jax has requested copies of those reports.

“Just imagine you being a mom and you see this big kid stomping your kid in the head,” she said. “A little girl (in South Carolina) just died from that. You know what I’m saying? That’s unacceptable.”

The case she’s referring to is that of Raniya Wright, a fifth grade student from Waltersboro, South Carolina, who died March 27 -- two days after the 10-year-old was injured in a fight at school.

Jenny said her son wasn’t bruised or bleeding after Friday’s incident, but she noted that he was diagnosed with a mild concussion and had an asthma attack in the car afterward.

“I was so mad,” she said. “I’m so angry about that because, even if she couldn’t see, you should have enough people out there watching (the children).”

Copyright 2019 by WJXT News4Jax - All rights reserved.

Title: 61-year-old grandma delivers healthy baby girl for her son and his husband
Summary:
Image copyright 2019 Getty Images. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten, or redistributed. KNUTSFORD, UNITED KINGDOM - APRIL 03: (FILE) In this file photograph taken on March 20, 2007, a two-week-old boy finds his feet in his new world. H(Photo by Christopher Furlong/Getty Images)

Image copyright 2019 Getty Images. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten, or redistributed. KNUTSFORD, UNITED KINGDOM - APRIL 03: (FILE) In this file photograph taken on March 20, 2007, a two-week-old boy finds his feet in his new world. H(Photo by Christopher Furlong/Getty Images)

OMAHA, Ne. (WOI) - Most grandmothers have a special bond with their grandchildren, but one grandmother from Gretna, NE has an even greater bond. She carried the baby for nine months as a surrogate for her son and his husband.

61-year-old Cecile Eledge delivered five pounds,13-ounce Uma Louise Dougherty-Eledge on Monday, March 25.

When her son Matthew and his husband Elliot Dougherty wanted to expand their family, she volunteered. “There was no moment of hesitation. It was natural instinct.” Cecile Eledge said.

With her age in consideration, Cecile undertook several medical tests before doctors determined her health allowed her to be the surrogate. Dougherty's sister donated the egg and Matthew donated the sperm.

“We are thankful with how the whole process worked,” said Matthew Eledge. “We are really grateful that both Uma and her grandma are here, happy and healthy. For the time being, we’re just going to relax and enjoy this moment.”
Address: 200 S Parker St, Tampa, FL 33606, USA

Title: Man fakes burglary accused of stealing Girl Scout money
Summary:
PORTLAND, OR. (WFLA/CNN) - An Oregon man accused of making up a robbery story to cover the theft of his daughter's Girl Scout cookie money appeared in court Friday.

Brian Couture,40, is charged with initiating a false report and improper use of an emergency reporting system.

Police say he called 911 on March 6 and reported that he'd struggled with someone who'd broken in. When police arrived, they found Couture unresponsive.

He was hospitalized but eventually acknowledged that he staged the scene and made up a story, according to police.

He was arrested March 18.

In court Friday Couture pleaded not guilty a spokeswoman for the Girl Scouts confirmed that Couture has a daughter who is a member of the organization and that there is around $740 missing from cookie sales connected to the case.

They are reportedly working on a repayment plan.
Address: 200 S Parker St, Tampa, FL 33606, USA

Title: UPDATED: Police now say 1 died at scene of overnight Cove shooting, 3 injured; shooter still on the loose
Summary:
Panama City Police have identified absconded sex offender Michael Harrison Hunt as a person of interest, according to public information officer Caitlin Lawrence. Police have been looking for Hunt this week, as he has an active warrant for failure to appear April 1 on charges of "Unlawful sexual activity with certain minors" and aggravated assault, according to court records. According to an arrest complaint Hunt was already a registered sex offender.

PANAMA CITY —One of the people involved Thursday night in a Cove shooting actually died at the scene on Allen Avenue Thursday night, Panama City police are now saying, while three more remain hospitalized with life-threatening injuries.

The names of the victims have not been released, but police are searching for absconded sex offender Michael Harrison Hunt as a person of interest, according to public information officer Caitlin Lawrence. The truck he was believed to have been driving has been found abandoned in Bay County, Lawrence said.

Police have been looking for Hunt since Monday when he failed to appear April 1 on charges of "Unlawful sexual activity with certain minors" and aggravated assault, according to court records. According to an arrest complaint Hunt was already a registered sex offender.

Thursday night's shooting happened at about 10:30 p.m. in the 100 block of Allen Avenue, near the corner with Cherry Street. Two homes there were marked by crime scene tape Friday and it was unknown if the victims were associated with both homes.

According to a press release received at 12:21 p.m. today, "one victim succumbed to their injuries at the scene. The other three victims were transported to a local hospital for treatment. They all remain in serious condition at this time."

The department is saying that this is "not a random act" and they do not believe there is an immediate threat of danger to people living in the Cove or the rest of the city.

Hunt is described as a black male, 5'09'' tall and around 210 pounds. Hunt is known to operate a black 2015 Ford Explorer with Florida tag ETCT72 and his last known registered address in the 2100 block of E. 5th Street.

People with information on his location are asked to call the police.

Information from police has been slow in coming; one nearby school that heard about it on the Internet sent this message, which some parents who shared it with The News Herald: "Due to a shooting in the Cove neighborhood, school time this morning is postponed. Parents are asked to keep children at home until the suspect is captured. There is a lockdown location for all students at school today.”

One man who drove by the scene but asked that his name not be used said he was particularly concerned and trying to get information because he had heard the suspect was also wanted for child sex charge, but he didn't know if that was true.

Police have now said it is, and according to courthouse records Hunt was arrested Sept. 12 by the Bay County Sheriff's Office and charged with "Unlawful Sexual Activity with Certain Minors."

That investigation, according to court records, began with a Sept. 11 call to Panama City police involving Hunt "displaying a firearm during a verbal altercation." According to an arrest complaint, a man confronted Hunt "about having sexual contact with a neighbor's daughter." The complaint said Hunt went to his vehicle and lifted his shirt, "exposing a handgun he had tucked into the right side of his waist band."

Hunt allegedly told the man, "This can be taken care of right now," according to the complaint.

As police investigated that incident, it led to the discovery that Hunt was involved in sex acts with a minor that occurred outside the city, which started an investigation by the Bay County Sheriff's Office.

A Bay County Sheriff's Office arrest complaint said the girl in that case told them she had sex with Hunt. Hunt, in an interview, admitted to knowing the victim, denied having sex with her and admitted to knowing she was underage.

After his arrest on those charges in September, Hunt made bond but failed to appear in court April 1.

This is a developing story and will be updated.
Address: 501 W 11th St, Panama City, FL 32401, USA

Title: Competitive streak earns Felicity Fonseca spot at Trailblazer Series in California
Summary:
PORT ST. LUCIE — For 13-year-old Felicity Fonseca, the hour spent at the Barwis Gym at First Data Field on any given Monday night is a price she’s willing to pay to follow her dream.

Buy Photo Felicity Fonseca lifts weights at the Barwis Gym at First Data Field. Felicity plays for Girls Travel Baseball out of Miami and the Vipers Baseball Club, a travel club based in West Palm Beach comprised primarily of boys. (Photo: AIMEE FORD FOSTER/SPECIAL TO TCPALM)

Weights, medicine balls, sprints, each drill done with precision and intent as she works to mold her ability and body into the perfect baseball machine. And even though the climb will be steep for Fonseca, a seventh-grade student at Somerset College Preparatory Academy in Port St. Lucie, she is already making a mark.

From April 11 to 14, Fonseca will be one of 96 girls 11 to 13 years old participating in the Trailblazer Series at Major League Baseball’s Compton Youth Academy in California. The event, co-sponsored by MLB and USA Baseball, features competitive play, instruction and other education opportunities for the players whose expenses are entirely paid by MLB.

This is the third year for the series. It is also the third year that Fonseca, who plays for Girls Travel Baseball out of Miami and the Vipers Baseball Club, a travel club based in West Palm Beach comprised primarily of boys, has been invited to attend.

“Basically, they take the top 100 baseball girls and you play a huge tournament,” she said. “You just show them what you got.”

Buy Photo Felicity Fonseca (Photo: AIMEE FORD FOSTER/SPECIAL TO TCPALM)

Fonseca, still shy of 5 feet tall, is a left-handed first baseman who also pitches — fastball, curveball, slider, changeup — and can play the outfield. She recently joined the Vipers, and in her first week was named the starting first baseman for the 13-under team and stepped in as the lead-off hitter. She practices twice a week with the Vipers, swims four times a week with the River Rats Swim Team, attends the Barwis Gym three times a week, and plays random weekends with GTB, which is a national team based in Miami that travels the country playing in tournaments against boys teams.

“I think the GTB is the most rewarding thing I do because those girls are more talented,” Fonseca said. “Playing with those girls is great.”

Fonseca intends to play high school baseball and dreams of college ball and beyond.

“I want to go past college, past the women’s national team,” she said.

Fonseca fell in love with the game nine years ago, after her parents Gus and Ana relocated the family from New Jersey to Port St. Lucie and attended their first spring training session.

“We went to every practice that spring and every minor league game that season,” said Gus Fonseca, who often plays chauffeur for his daughter. He and Ana also have 9-year-old twin boys Seth and Tyler. “Part of the reason was players like Angel Pagan and (Mike) Pelfrey, they would start talking baseball with her, what did she think of the game, what could they have done better. She started thinking about the game at a young age. And she loved it.”

Felicity Fonseca said she doesn’t remember much about those days, “but my parents tell the stories.”

NEWSLETTERS Get the Outdoors with Ed Killer newsletter delivered to your inbox We're sorry, but something went wrong A weekly newsletter featuring upcoming fishing, boating and hunting events in Florida, outdoors features stories and tips. Please try again soon, or contact Customer Service at 1-844-331-0264. Delivery: Fri Invalid email address Thank you! You're almost signed up for Outdoors with Ed Killer Keep an eye out for an email to confirm your newsletter registration. More newsletters

For her, the best part of baseball is “how competitive is it, as a girl playing against boys.”

“I like battling,” she continued. “I like pitching.

“Speed and jumping are my strengths. I bat lead-off, so I have to be fast. I get on base a lot.”

Her father has clearly enjoyed watching her grow in the sport.

“We were in Brazil for three years and she didn’t play much,” Gus Fonseca said. “As soon as we came back, she got involved and we got a hold of the national team. She’s had some cool experiences. We went to the (World Baseball Classic) and the girls got to go on the field.”
Address: 1939 SE Federal Hwy, Stuart, FL 34994, USA

Title: Fort Myers Film Festival: Harry Connick trumpeter plays live show after doc screening
Summary:
CLOSE Dan Miller and Lew Del Gatto have been playing jazz together for years. They perform every Thursday with their quartet at Fort Myers' The Barrel Room. Charles Runnells, crunnells@news-press.com

Cameron Washington remembers the exact moment he first heard Leroy Jones’ trumpet. He was listening to Harry Connick Junior’s 1991 big-band album “Blue Light, Red Light.”

Then Washington got to the last song, “Just Kiss Me.”

And his mind was blown.

“I heard Leroy Jones, and I said, ‘Oh my God, who is that trumpet player?’” the filmmaker recalls. “He was blazing up a storm. I’ve never heard anything like it.”

New Orleans trumpeter Leroy Jones in a scene from the documentary "A Man and His Trumpet: The Leroy Jones Story" (Photo: Special to The News-Press)

Washington ended up buying every album he could find featuring Jones, and that fandom eventually led to some unexpected places — including meeting Jones one day in New Orleans, becoming friends and eventually following the trumpeter around for two years with video cameras.

The resulting 2018 documentary, “A Man and His Trumpet: The Leroy Jones Story,” has been playing U.S. film festivals, and it recently won the Louisiana Endowment for the Humanities Award For Documentary Film for 2019. Now it’s opening the Fort Myers Film Festival next week.

Jones, 61, says he’s flattered that anyone would take such a deep interest in his life. But he admits he’s not quite used to being a movie star.

“It’s surreal to me, man,” he says and laughs. “It’s really weird seeing yourself as the main character in a film.”

New Orleans trumpeter Leroy Jones is the subject of the documentary "A Man and His Trumpet: The Leroy Jones Story." (Photo: Special to The News-Press)

Jones has had a busy career, playing in New Orleans bands and parades and also recording and touring with Connick from 1990-2007.

Jones is still friends with many members of Connick’s band, including Fort Myers trumpeter Dan Miller. Miller and another famous local musician — saxophonist and former “Saturday Night Live” music arranger Lew Del Gato — will join Jones for a jazz concert after the Wednesday, April 10, film screening at Sidney & Berne Davis Art Center in downtown Fort Myers.

More: Dan Miller and Lew Del Gatto play all that jazz at The Barrel Room

More: Live Music in SWFL: Bad Bunny, Night Ranger, Village People, Joe Diffie, Mickey Dolenz, Pop Evil, etc.

Jones doesn’t know quite what they’ll play yet, but he says it’s bound to be a fun night of bop, swing and traditional jazz. “It’s some seasoned cats, man!”

Film fest attendees are in for a treat, Washington says. No one sounds or plays like Jones — including in the trumpeter’s hometown of New Orleans.

“You’re in a city with a thousand trumpet players, and everybody knows it’s Leroy the second he starts playing,” Washington says. “He’s just got this sound and this connection with his trumpet.”

New Orleans trumpeter Leroy Jones is the subject of the documentary "A Man and His Trumpet: The Leroy Jones Story." (Photo: Special to The News-Press)

“A Man and His Trumpet: The Leroy Jones Story” will screen at 7 p.m. at Davis Art Center, followed by an after party and the concert. Tickets are $25 for the film only, or $150 for the film, concert and after party.

That’s not all that's happening at the Fort Myers Film Festival, of course. The ninth-annual event will bring independent feature-length films, documentaries, shorts and more to several Fort Myers locations.

Here are seven more must-see picks from festival founder Eric Raddatz:

“Marcos Doesn’t Live Here Anymore” (9 a.m. April 11 at Davis Art Center): Director David Sutherland’s documentary follows a decorated U.S. Marine veteran who’s fighting to reunite her family after her husband gets deported. Meanwhile, her husband — alone in Mexico — works as a soccer referee, struggles with depression and fights the urge to cross the border illegally. The film will be shown April 15 on the PBS show “Frontline.”

NEWSLETTERS Get the SWFL Eats newsletter delivered to your inbox We're sorry, but something went wrong Restaurant reviews, foodie news, cooking tips, Q&As, and dining updates. Please try again soon, or contact Customer Service at 1-800-468-0233. Delivery: Invalid email address Thank you! You're almost signed up for SWFL Eats Keep an eye out for an email to confirm your newsletter registration. More newsletters

“Wherever we stand politically, we need to address and give voice to how political decisions reverberate into all of our lives, some for good and some for bad,” Raddatz says. “It’s moving and telling and a must-watch here, or on PBS when it comes out.”

Fantasy and science fiction Ursula K. Le Guin, who died in 2018, is the subject of the documentary “Worlds of Ursula K. Le Guin." (Photo: Benjamin Brink, AP)

“Worlds of Ursula K. Le Guin” (5:30 p.m. Thursday, April 11 at Davis Art Center): Arwen Curry’s documentary about the beloved science fiction and fantasy writer, who died in 2018. The film looks at her life and legacy with appearances by famous authors such as Neil Gaiman, Michael Chabon and Margaret Atwood.

Some readers consider Le Guin to be a forerunner to modern feminism, thanks partly to her exploration of gender identity, equality and fluidity, Raddatz says. Other just think she was a great — albeit eccentric — writer.

“Ursula K. Le Guin was brilliant, but a really, really different person than most and truly unique as a female science fiction writer in the 60s,” Raddatz says. “The documentary follows her for years, exploring the reasons for her being who she was.”

“Eliades Ochoa From Cuba To The World” (6:30 p.m. Thursday, April 11 at the Alliance for the Arts): A documentary about the life and success of Cuban singer/guitarist Eliades Ochoa, a poor country musician who later found international fame as a member of the Buena Vista Social Club.

“This documentary tackles what it’s like to be true to your style of original music,” Raddatz says. “Most musicians see the need to be original, but Eliades Ochoa, the founder of the group, gives us a unique story on what it is like to be you as a legendary musician.”

“The Great Train Robbery” (8 p.m. Thursday, April 11 at Edison & Ford Winter Estates): The classic 1903 silent film gets a live piano accompaniment for this outdoor screening overlooking the Caloosahatchee River behind the former winter home of inventor Thomas Edison. The 12-minute Western was written, produced, and directed by Edwin S. Porter, a former cameraman at Edison Studios.

Cuban singer/guitarist Eliades Ochoa (Photo: Pucciariello Max)

“Fly Like a Girl” (6 p.m. Friday, April 12 at IMAG): Director Katie McEntire Wiatt’s documentary about young girls and women pursuing aviation in a field dominated by men.

“Some may say films like this help empower women, but the power is already there,” Raddatz says. “This documentary explores those today who are female and flying high and young girls who are inspired to change the statistics.”

“Long Time Coming: A 1955 Baseball Story” (6:15 p.m. Friday, April 12 at Davis Art Center): Jon Strong’s documentary about racial segregation and two teams of 12-year-old boys stepping onto a baseball field for Florida's 1955 Little League State Championship. It was one of the first integrated Little League games in the South.

The film will be introduced by Glenn Miller, a former The News-Press sports reporter and the current president of the Southwest Florida Historical Society.

“We follow the lives of folks who played the first interracial Little League game in Florida,” Raddatz says. “The humanity of the sport proved greater than the racism so prevalent, proving we are really just alike when we are playing our nation’s greatest sport.”

“Surviving Lunch” (8 p.m. Saturday, April 13 at Davis Art Center): In this drama, a teen moves to Florida after a violent event tears her life apart. Then she sees a bully in the school lunchroom and begins a dangerous quest to stop him.

Raddatz says the film comes along at just the right time in the United States, where Parkland and other school shootings have become commonplace. “Our story takes place in a time where we can’t help but to think, discuss and react to the safety of our children today. The movie is brilliant.”

Title: NTSB releases report for Winter Haven plane crash
Summary:
- The National Transportation Safety Board released a preliminary report revealing new details about a plane crash into a house in Winter Haven.

The initial crash happened in late February at a home on Idylridge Way, just south of the Winter Haven Airport. Polk County Sheriff Grady Judd said 64-year-old instructor pilot James Wagner, of Lakeland, and 33-year-old student pilot Timothy Sheehy, of Bozeman, Montana, were on board when the plane took off from the Winter Haven Airport.

The two were scheduled to perform simulated engine failure training when the plane crashed into a family’s home. Wagner died in the crash, but Judd said Sheehy was able to climb out of the wreckage on his own. He suffered minor injuries.

A 17-year-old girl was in one of the bedrooms and became pinned and trapped after the crash. At first, her injuries were reported as minor; however, the new report states her injuries were serious. The report also states that, so far, investigators have not found any mechanical errors within the plane.

Captain Robert Katz, a commercial pilot and certified flight instructor, said the crash could have been avoided. He explained that, when simulating engine failure, pilots should always be away from homes and fly at a higher altitude than the pair were flying, when they crashed.

“To simulate that low to the ground is a dangerous choice because you’re not giving yourself a lot of room to work with if the recovery doesn’t go as planned,” said Katz.

A full crash report should be available in the next 18 months.
Address: 35 Skyline Dr, Lake Mary, FL 32746, USA

Title: Man charged with murder after assaulting 4-year-old with Down Syndrome for interrupting: Sheriff
Summary:
- A Rancho Cucamonga man has been charged with murder after he allegedly assaulted a 4-year-old girl with Down Syndrome for interrupting him, ultimately resulting in her death, authorities said.

Adam Hughes, 24, was charged with first-degree murder in the death of 4-year-old Kylee Willis.

According to investigators, Huges was watching his girlfriend's children on Tuesday night, when, at some point, Willis angered Hughes by interrupting him. Authorities said Hughes assaulted Willis and then put her to bed.

Several hours later, Hughes noticed the child was non-responsive and that her fingers and lips had turned blue. Authorities said the then called his girlfriend, Corrine Blake, for help.

Blake called 911 at approximately 7:56 p.m. Tuesday. Paramedics arrived and transported the 4-year-old to San Antonio Medical Center for treatment. Willis was then flown to the Loma Linda University Medical Center for treatment for severe head trauma. Authorities said the child was on life support for several days and on March 29, 2019, she died as a result of the injuries caused by Hughes.

On March 27, 2019, both Hughes and Blake were arrested and booked for willful cruelty to a child. Blake was released the following day after posting bail. On March 29, 2019, after Willis' death, Hughes charged with her murder.

Hughes is being held without bond and his next court date is April 2 at the Rancho Cucamonga Superior Court.
Address: 35 Skyline Dr, Lake Mary, FL 32746, USA

Title: Strong rip currents keep lifeguards busy along coast
Summary:
DAYTONA BEACH — Lifeguards rescued more than 100 people from rough surf along a stretch of beaches on Florida's Atlantic coast.

Volusia County ocean rescue Capt. Mike Berard told The Daytona Beach News-Journal that lifeguards rescued 48 people on Saturday and at least 55 on Sunday. Those rescued included a 7-year-old girl washed out into the water by strong rip currents.

He said the child and another child in nearby New Smyrna Beach were taken to hospitals as a precaution.

Berard said the rip currents were "pretty bad" over the weekend as spring break crowds flocked to the beaches.
Address: 455 6th St NW, Winter Haven, FL 33881, USA

Title: Man arrested for overdosing, dropping child in Port Richey
Summary:
Copyright 2019 Nexstar Broadcasting, Inc. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten, or redistributed.

PORT RICHEY, Fla. (WFLA) - A Pasco County man is facing a child neglect charge after deputies say he overdosed while caring for two young girls.

According to an arrest report, 37-year-old Scott Duguette was caring for a 1-year-old and a 7-year-old on Friday night in Port Richey when he injected dilaudid and overdosed. Deputies say he had one of the children in his lap and dropped the girl when he fell over.

The 7-year-old child told deputies she ran outside because she was scared Duguette was dead, the arrest report says. Deputies say his neighbors had to give him two doses of Narcan to revive him.

Duguette later admitted to injecting dilaudid and smoking marijuana while taking care of the children, according to the arrest report. Deputies say he does not have a prescription for the medication and has overdosed on it before.
Address: 200 S Parker St, Tampa, FL 33606, USA

Title: Adoptable pet: Meet Mirielle
Summary:
Mirielle is a full figured, spayed female tabby cat thatis recovering from neck wounds. (Photo: Animal Service Center)

It's a good thing that kitties have nine lives! Mirielle (A180603) is a full figured, spayed female 3(ish)-year-old tabby cat that came to us with horrifying wounds on her neck.

She wasn't talking about how she got them (Chemical burn? Too tight collar?) but we knew she needed treatment. She spent some time in a foster home where she was getting all the TLC she deserves.

Her foster mom says that she's expressive, loves to be with people, runs to greet you - but loves her "alone time" too. She's confident, tolerant of her medical treatments and laid back. She is now back at the shelter hanging out in a staff member's office waiting for her perfect person to come along. She's healing very well, and she is guaranteed to make someone very happy!

If you are interested in meeting this special girl, come on in and ask for her at the front desk.

Mirielle’s adoption fee would be $20 which includes her spay surgery, vaccines, and microchip + registration.

Animal Service Center, 1125 Easterwood Drive (Tom Brown Park); 850-891-2950

www.talgov.com/animals. Open: Tuesday-Friday (10:30-6:30), Saturday (10-5) Sunday (1-5); Closed Mondays.

Title: Woman with two wombs gives birth to twins 26 days after first baby
Summary:
Copyright by WFLA - All rights reserved

TAMPA (WFLA) - A 20-year-old woman with two uteruses unexpectedly gave birth to twins nearly a month after she gave birth to a baby boy.

According to CNN, a Bangladeshi woman identified as Arifa Sultana had twins 26 days after she gave birth to her first child at Ad-Din Hospital in Dhaka.

Sultana has uterus didelphys, a condition meaning she has two uteruses.

Her first baby and her set of twins were conceived and grown in separate uteruses. Doctors say she did not get an ultrasound before the first delivery, so it was missed.

Doctors were able to perform a C-section to safely deliver the twins, a girl, and a boy.

All three children and their mother are all fine.
Address: 200 S Parker St, Tampa, FL 33606, USA

Title: More than 100 rescued from Volusia County surf over weekend
Summary:
More than a hundred people were saved from the surf along Volusia County beaches over the weekend. That included a young girl dragged out by rip currents in Daytona Beach on Sunday.

According to Capt. Mike Berard, of Volusia County Beach Safety Ocean Rescue, rip currents kept lifeguards busy rescuing 48 people Saturday and at least 55 on Sunday.

Of the dozens of rescues made Sunday, the more serious incident involved a 7-year-old girl washed away from shore near the Lennox Avenue approach in Daytona, Berard said.

That child and another juvenile in New Smyrna Beach were transported to hospitals as a precaution, he said.

"The rip currents were pretty bad over the weekend," Berard said late Sunday afternoon.

The National Weather Service in Melbourne issued a rip current statement on Sunday for parts of east Florida that included a Volusia County warning about high risk for swimmers.

Weather officials said the greatest risk of rip currents started at 7 a.m. Sunday and continued into late afternoon toward dusk because of tidal effects.

Address: 901 6th St, Daytona Beach, FL 32117, USA

Title: Cape Coral community gathers to support grieving family of 8-year-old killed in hit-and-run
Summary:
Hundreds of Lee County residents gathered Saturday to support a family grieving the loss of a little girl.

The event, called Lights for Layla, was held at the Cape Assembly church at 717 Skyline Blvd. in Cape Coral. The event offered bounce houses, face painting, food trucks, raffle prizes, a DJ and more, and raised funds that will support added safety measures at school bus stops.

Layla Aiken, 8, was killed when a pickup truck struck her while she was waiting at a school bus stop with her twin brothers Monday. Police recovered a truck they believe is involved and identified a person of interest, but have yet to make an arrest.

Randi Romanov, left, hugs her friend Kathleen Aiken after Aiken arrived at the Lights for Layla fundraiser on Saturday, March 30, 2019, in Cape Coral. Romanov helped organize the event to raise money and awarness for safer bus stops after AikenÕs daughter Layla was killed when she was hit by a truck at her bus stop. (Photo: Amanda Inscore/The News-Press USA TODAY NETWORK - FLORIDA)

More: Cape Coral police seize truck, eye person of interest in hit-and-run that killed 8-year-old girl

More: Cape Coral, Lee County School District to analyze bus stop safety after student deaths

"We need better safety measures for these poor kids that are standing out there when it's dark outside," said Angelique Pilcher, her 7-year-old daughter painting a canvas at one of the stations nearby.

Pilcher, 36, said she wanted to show her support because the incident hit so close to home. Her daughter is only one year younger than Layla was, and the family lives about two miles away from the school bus stop where she was hit, at the intersection of Northeast 3rd Avenue and Northeast 19th Terrace.

"So I think you kind of put yourself in that mother's place, and just imagine it being your child," she said. "It's very hard to think of that. There's not much we can do because we didn't know the family, and there's always thoughts and prayers but we wanted to actually do something to try to help a little bit. We are their neighbors."

The group of organizers behind the event are pushing for increased safety measures at school bus stops.

They started a fundraiser on Facebook after Layla's death, which has raised almost $65,000. That money will help the family pay for the funeral, but will also be used to advocate for safety measures such as lights, benches, and perhaps even monitors stationed at school bus stops in the mornings, according to organizer Lacey Williams.

"This was happening too often, and we just knew that we could do something more," Williams said. "We were able to help Layla's family, and now we can help other families too."

NEWSLETTERS Get the Breaking News newsletter delivered to your inbox We're sorry, but something went wrong Urgent developments you should know now, not later. Please try again soon, or contact Customer Service at 1-800-468-0233. Delivery: varies Invalid email address Thank you! You're almost signed up for Breaking News Keep an eye out for an email to confirm your newsletter registration. More newsletters

The group will meet with Cape Coral city officials this week, she said. They first will advocate for stationary school bus stops, because they currently operate on a rotating schedule and change from year to year, she said.

"If we can at least get the bus stops stable, then we can put up lights, benches, things like that to make it a little bit safer," she said. "Unfortunately right now, especially with the time change, it's pitch dark when these kids are at the bus stop. We've got to do something."

The Lee County School District is evaluating the safety of the school bus stops, and partnering with the Lee County Sheriff's Office and Big Mama and the Wild Bunch at FM radio station B103.9 to raise $100,000 for flashing LED lights that will go on students' backpacks by the next school year.

More: Lights for Layla: local agencies raising money for LED lights on student backpacks after girl's death at school bus stop

"It's turned into a really major thing, all in honor of a beautiful little girl," Williams said. "Hopefully nobody else's children will have to go through this."

Layla was a sweet little girl who loved unicorns, and was her mom's only daughter, Williams said. The girl's mother, Kathleen Aiken, showed up at the fundraiser with her two sons to thank the community and to let the boys see the community support firsthand.

Williams helped make shirts that read #LightsForLayla, which were sold at the fundraiser. Layla's twin brothers arrived shortly before 2 p.m., wearing the shirts, which draped nearly to their knees.

Aiken waded through a sea of hugs, encouraging words and tears. Family friends presented her with a wooden cross that read "In loving memory of Layla Aiken" and "Buggy Layla Rocks." Aiken called Layla her "little buggy girl" as a nickname.

One woman, who appeared to be a close friend, sat on a curb, silently crying as she waited for her turn to comfort Aiken. A musician who was hired to play an acoustic guitar at the event played the song 'Stand By Me' by Ben. E King as they embraced, swaying in place.

Aiken said the tremendous show of support from the community helped her and her grieving sons, who witnessed their sister's death.

"Layla was very social, and she loved everyone and she loved being the center of attention," Aiken said. "She would have loved this."

Aiken spoke softly of her daughter, her voice broken.

"Obviously the thing I want most is my daughter back. But if I can't have that, this change makes it so what happened to her wasn't in vain," she said. "If I can protect everyone else's babies because there wasn't anyone there to protect mine."

Title: Deputies: Jailhouse call is 1 of hundreds made to home of 11-year-old
Summary:
MIDDLEBURG, Fla. - A jailhouse phone call reveals one of the conversations that deputies said a Middleburg woman had with a man charged with sexual battery on an 11-year-old girl before the woman was arrested on charges of child abuse and witness tampering.

Jason Evans, 39, is charged with capital sexual battery and lewd and lascivious conduct. As of Friday, he was held in the Clay County Jail on no bond. When he was arrested on March 14, records showed he was held on a $1 million bond.

ORIGINAL STORY: Woman accused of abusing 11-year-old after deputies hear jailhouse calls

Investigators said following the assault, the 11-year-old gave birth to a child.

According to the Clay County Sheriff's Office, Evans made hundreds of calls from jail to the home of Danielle Mayhorn, 36, who cared for the 11-year-old. Following those recorded phone calls, Mayhorn was arrested.

By law, Evans was not supposed to have contact with the young girl, but deputies said Mayhorn made that possible by allowing him to talk to child when he called from the jail. News4Jax obtained a portion of those phone calls on Friday, which appear to be from a conversation about legal representation.

Evans: “I’m going to be embarrassed to see her. I was on the other side of the fence before.”



Mayhorn: “She is going to be your best bet. She pulled up your record and said, 'This is the first time he’s ever been in trouble.' I said, 'Yes.'”



Evans: “An attorney I got now says that doesn’t matter.”



Mayhorn: "Yes. He’s looking at it now as a [expletive] paycheck.”

There were about 700 recorded calls between Evans and Mayhorn, deputies said.

Address: 4 Broadcast Pl, Jacksonville, FL 32207, USA

Title: Man gets life in prison for 1997 sex attack on girl in Daytona Beach
Summary:
Robert Haar in a mugshot from a 1995 arrest in Hillsborough County on grand theft of a motor vehicle charges.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. - A man was sentenced Friday to life in prison after being found guilty in a sex attack of a 14-year-old girl in Daytona Beach in 1997.

Robert Haar, 44, was sentenced to life in prison without the possibility of parole.

The case, which involved three men, was cold until the teen's DNA was entered into a national database nearly 20 years after the attack.

"This young lady had to live through it because of your actions, sir," Circuit Judge Matt Foxman said. "For that reason, I’m going to sentence you to the term of your natural life in a Florida state prison without the possibility of parole."

Haar was arrested in 2017 in Wisconsin and was found guilty on one of two counts of sexual battery with special circumstances.

"This was a little girl who was in the woods running into three strange men with a van and no windows. That’s a start of a horror movie," Foxman said.

The assistant state attorney told the judge Haar hasn't had a clean record in the past couple of years, including a crime involving his daughter.

"The court also received a letter from Mr. Haar's daughter regarding other sexual allegations that she’s made against Mr. Haar in recent years," Andrew Urbanak said.

Haar was also declared as a sexual predator in the state of Florida.

Copyright 2019 by WKMG ClickOrlando - All rights reserved.
Address: 4466 N John Young Pkwy, Orlando, FL 32804, USA

Title: Amber Alert issued for 2-year-old who could be headed to Florida
Summary:
MILWAUKEE - Milwaukee police issued an Amber Alert for a 2-year-old Milwaukee girl who could be headed to Florida.

Authorities say she could be with a man considered armed and dangerous.

Noelani J Robinson is believed to be with 34-year-old Dariaz L. Higgins. Police say he is also known as Dariaz Taylor or Dariaz Lewis.

Police do not know where in Florida he could be headed, but noted Florida and Las Vegas ties.

Authorities say Higgins was last seen driving a black SUV, but have not been able to provide any more information. Higgins is accused of not returning Robinson to her mother as planned around 1:30 p.m. Monday.

If anyone sees Higgins or the child, call 911 immediately.

Title: Body of missing woman from Avon Park found in lake near Vero Beach Outlets mall
Summary:
Khadijah Anderson (Photo: PHOTO CONTRIBUTED BY HIGHLANDS COUNTY SHERIFF'S OFFICE)

INDIAN RIVER COUNTY — Desire Nance will remember her little sister, Khadijah Anderson as a sweet girl.

"I'm not just saying she was sweet because I'm her big sister," Nance said. "My siblings kind of get on my nerves sometimes, but not her; she was a good girl."

Anderson's body was found Saturday afternoon in a lake west of Vero Beach after the 24-year-old was reported missing from Avon Park on March 25.

Indian River County Sheriff's Office spokesman Maj. Eric Flowers said deputies were searching near Vero Beach Outlets mall, 1824 94th Drive, when they found Anderson's car.

More: Mother of murder victim urges Gifford community to 'take shackles off their mouths'

After searching the area, they found Anderson's body in Keg Lake near the mall.

Flowers said Monday there were no signs of trauma or foul play.

"Nothing leads us to believe that anyone was involved (with Anderson's death)," he said.

Anderson's body was taken to the Treasure Coast Medical Examiner's Office for an autopsy. The Indian River County Sheriff's Office is investigating the incident as a suspicious death.

Nance said Anderson loved to sing and had dreams of becoming a nurse.

"She really didn't do what most adults did like party and hang out," Nance said. "We would do that sometimes because I would pull teeth to get her to do it, but most of the time she was just a hard worker. She was always going to work and making sure all of her things were in order."

More: 1 Sebastian teen found, another reported missing

Nance said Anderson worked part time with Comfort Keepers, an in-home care provider company, and enjoyed helping people.

"She just has a sweet spirit; her clients at her job loved her, and she was only with them for a short amount of time," she said.

Desire Nance (left) and her sister (Khadijah Anderson.) Anderson was found in a lake in Vero Beach Saturday afternoon. Deputies are investigating the incident as a suspicious death. (Photo: COURTESY OF DESIRE NANCE)

Nance said she first realized her little sister was missing when Comfort Keepers called her and asked if something had happened to Anderson because she missed work.

"She is dependable," she said. "I know out of all of my siblings, if I can't depend on anyone else, I can depend on her (Anderson) to do what she says she's going to do and hold her responsible for it."

More: Gifford 'drug den' included machine guns, altar, cash, officials said

The day before Anderson went missing, Nance said her sister had gotten out of a relationship and called her to talk about it. Nance said she encouraged her sister to come visit her to cheer her up after her shift at work the next day and Nance never saw Anderson again.

"She just had gotten her diploma, she just payed her car off, we were signing up for school; it just doesn't make sense," Nance said. "I really want to know what happened because I really need to know."

Anyone with information was asked to call Detective Vincent Forest of the Highlands County Sheriff's Office at 863-402-7358.

Title: Snook lead the catch list and trout action is improving
Summary:
CLOSE Wicked windy weather stirred up fishing patterns, but all should be well by the weekend. Ed Killer, ed.killer@tcpalm.com

Indian River County

Joe Cramer of Grant aboard his boat Island Girl fished in the vicinity of Incentive with Capt. Bruce Alcock out of Capt Hiram's Resort in Sebastian over the weekend. At about 330 feet of water, the two boats found a nice color change and blue water. Trolling north the two boats combined to catch about 15 dolphin up to about 27 pounds making for a nice day for both boats. Inshore, there are plenty of rodbenders in the Indian River Lagoon right now. Jacks, ladyfish, small sharks, pompano, trout and redfish are all biting on the flats taking jigs.

St. Lucie County

Capt. Mark Dravo of Y-B Normal charters in Fort Pierce has been steering his anglers to catches of snook, trout and redfish in the shallows around the mangrove shorelines. There has been better fishing in Snapper Cut and St. Lucie Cut, and as the tide comes up, on the flats in front of St. Lucie Village just off the ends of the docks. Use topwater plugs early in the morning at first light. Then switch over to artificial shrimp or soft plastic jigs with curly tails for best bites. Offshore, the seas have been a little big for bottom fishing. Dolphin fishing should be improving. When seas allow, expect a good mangrove snapper bite in 60 to 90 feet of water on live bottom.

Buy Photo The Florida Oceanographic Society's 8th annual Game Fish and Fish Games Youth Fishing Clinic on Sunday, March 31, 2019, at the Florida Oceanographic Society Coastal Center in Stuart. The free clinic for children ages 8-14 brought together 60 participants to go through seven activity stations to learn about casting, knot tying, cast netting, lures and tackle, fish filleting, and fish identification, along with proper fishing techniques and ethics, with the help from members of the Stuart Rod and Reel Club. (Photo: ERIC HASERT/TCPALM)

Martin County

Capt. Marshall Busha of DayMaker Inshore Charters has been doing very well on catch and release fishing for snook for his clients. During a four-hour trip Sunday, Busha put his clients on 28 snook, keeping one slot fish for the frying pan. Tripletail fishing has been pretty good, too. Also, reader Grayson Drexel caught a nice sheepshead in the trough at Stuart Beach using a live shrimp as bait. Few anglers think of catching sheepshead at a sandy beach rather than around a barnacle-encrusted bridge piling.

Lake Okeechobee

Bass fishing remains consistent with the warm weather. Wild shiners are the best bait for chances to catch big fish and big numbers of fish. Anglers who prefer to use artificial lures are finding the best program is to start with topwater frogs or popper-style plugs, spinnerbaits or flat-sided crank baits. Worms and flukes work better later in the day. Bluegill and shellcracker fishing has been steady, too.

Title: Man used machete to kill wife, daughter in Miami Gardens, police say
Summary:
Police are continuing to search for a man they said killed his wife and 10-year-old daughter with a machete over the weekend in Miami Gardens.

Police said Noel Chambers, 57, killed his young daughter, Shayla Chambers, and wife, Lorrice Harris, Saturday night at their apartment in the 600 block of Northwest 177th Street before trying to kill his adult daughter.

"For someone to get a machete and chop somebody up like that -- your own wife, your own daughter, and try to kill your other daughter -- a 10-year-old. This could have been anybody's sister, anybody's daughter. A 10-year-old lying in bed," Harris' older daughter, Ashlee Anderson, said at a news conference Monday.

According to authorities, Saturday was Harris' birthday and was also the day she told her husband she was leaving him.

Police investigated a tip Monday afternoon from someone who claimed to have spotted Noel Chambers going into an abandoned building off Northwest Seventh Avenue, near Top Golf.

Sky 10 was above the area shortly before 5 pm. as officers swarmed the location, but it doesn't appear that Noel Chambers has yet been found.

Relatives said they believed Noel Chambers was still in Miami Gardens.

"This is not a human. This is a monster, and we need to get this monster off the street," Anderson said.

A crisis response team, meanwhile, was placed at Norwood Elementary School in Miami Gardens Monday morning, where Shayla was a student.

"Wow. That's unthinkable for a parent to do that to their family," Janeka Butler, whose child attends Norwood Elementary School, said.

Parents at the school were shocked to find out about the deadly attack.

Hearing infuriating and devastating reports of the murder of a 10-year-old child during a domestic dispute. This is so wholly unnatural and inexcusable. I pray for this child's soul and that peace is found after death, that this innocent child did not experience in life. #Enough

-- Alberto M. Carvalho (@MiamiSup) March 31, 2019

Police said they found Shayla's body in a bedroom and her mother was found dead on the porch. They said Noel Chambers' adult daughter, Shanalee Chambers, was outside the apartment, alive but injured.

She was taken to a hospital in critical, but stable condition.

Officer Carlos Austin, a spokesman for the Miami Gardens Police Department, said it was the most horrific crime scene that he has seen in his 17 years of law enforcement.

"Hopefully they catch him," Melissa Thomas, whose child attends Norwood Elementary, said. "Sad for the family, the little girl. Because the child is innocent regardless of the circumstances, whatever is going on between the parents and child is always innocent."

A crisis response team is at Shayla's school to help students and staff members process their grief.

"I'm glad that they were quick to respond to that because the students are going to need some kind of outlet to kind of express themselves," Butler said.

Anyone with information about Noel Chambers' whereabouts is asked to contact Detective H. Schneider at 305-474-1710 or Miami-Dade Crime Stoppers at 305-471-TIPS.
Address: 3401 W Hallandale Beach Blvd, Pembroke Park, FL 33023, USA

Title: Let's fix bus stop issue in Lee County; no more children can die: your say
Summary:
0331 Cartoon (Photo: Rick McKee, The Augusta Chronicle, GA)

Dark danger

How many more children must die? The 8-year-old girl killed March 25 was waiting for her school bus at 6:20 a.m. Sunrise was at 7:26 (https://www.timeanddate.com/sun/usa/cape-coral).

In other words, more than an hour too late for this child. We can and should hold the hit-and-run driver accountable for his/her part in this tragedy. But what about the school system that has children walking dark roads and waiting on dark roadsides before daylight?

Perhaps, and I emphasize perhaps, there are good reasons why school hours are what they are. Whatever those reasons might be, are they more important than children's safety? Are they worth a child's life?



Ed Dilgen, Fort Myers

More: Founders showcased their brilliance with Electoral College: your say

Too early

The local news says that the recent death of the 8 year old while she was waiting at her bus stop at 6:20 a.m. school officials state that they don't have responsibility until the student boards the bus. I disagree; the school board is responsible for the start times of school and if they were not so early, that student would not have been there at that dark early hour. What is wrong with this picture?

Alaina Meister, St. James City

Waste of time

Where have the nonproductive hours, days, months, years gone? Congress, the House and the Senate, owe the American people a considerable amount of time.

Instead of chasing their tails over the 2016 election they should have been working on health care, Immigration and the country's broken-down infrastructure. But no, they had to have hearings upon hearings and endless interviews and indictments.

What a waste of time. We did not send them to Washington to run around in circles and let the media dictate to them. They were sent their to take care of our country's business. God help us.

Gary Olson, North Fort Myers

Vote counts?

A letter writer claims that the move to eliminate the Electoral College from the presidential voting process is pushed by Democrats who are angry that Trump beat Clinton in 2016.

NEWSLETTERS Get the Florida Voices newsletter delivered to your inbox We're sorry, but something went wrong Florida Voices tells the stories of everyday Floridians, examining what issues matter most to them in the Sunshine State. Please try again soon, or contact Customer Service at 1-800-468-0233. Delivery: Fri Invalid email address Thank you! You're almost signed up for Florida Voices Keep an eye out for an email to confirm your newsletter registration. More newsletters

Trump didn't beat Clinton. The archaic Electoral College beat Clinton:

Clinton: 65,844,594; Trump: 62,979,616.

Clinton: 48.2% of the popular vote; Trump: 46.1% of the popular vote.

Either the Electoral College goes or it becomes a federal crime to tell citizens that their vote counts.

C. A. Farrington, south Fort Myers

Two questions

I totally disagree with guest columnist Kimberly Wallace's article appearing in the March 24 News Press, "The Montessori's difference in raising your child."

Please absorb the words "your child." I am just an 81-year-old husband, father, godfather and grandfather with only a high school diploma who has been a cop for 38 years and I need to ask the Wallace two questions.

1. For the child's sake and benefit and not the parent's who should raise your child?

2. If your gift from God was able to speak and you asked them would they like to be dumped off at Montessori's so strangers could raise them or would they rather be raised by their mother and father at home?

The article states that the Wallaces were overjoyed with excitement about having a little girl. They are missing the excitement when their daughter starts crawling, walking, talking and saying the magic word mommy. Unfortunately the word mommy will take longer because mommy dumped her off at Montessori's.

The article further states that the Wallaces did a lot of research on day care but they should have spent their time researching the best way to raise their child in today's world.

Albert Joseph, Fort Myers

More: Trump's not only qualified to be president, he's the best since Reagan: your say

History lesson

A recent Mailbag contributor may need a history lesson. The first time Bill Clinton got elected president he received only 43% of the vote. The other 57% of the vote went to Bush and Perot.

R.B. Macchia, Sanibel

Title: Artist uses science, imagination to transform seaweed into island maps
Summary:
Artist uses science, imagination to transform seaweed into island maps

Debe Loughlin uses science and her imagination to transform seaweed into art.Loughlin, a self-described island girl, uses a photographic printing process called cyanotype to create maps of islands that come straight from her imagination.To make the maps, Loughlin puts a piece of seaweed on special photographic paper.As the paper develops under light, it changes color, leaving an impression where the seaweed was placed.Loughlin then brings her ideas to life."So, I start to figure out where there might be quicksand on the island, or maybe there’s an old boat that’s sunken off the island somewhere," Loughlin said. "I create these things in my head."Loughlin's maps are fictional but come from her love of island life."I’m from one of the islands in Casco Bay, and so I’m kind of very island-bound in my heart, and that’s what comes out in my work," she said.

Debe Loughlin uses science and her imagination to transform seaweed into art.

Advertisement

Loughlin, a self-described island girl, uses a photographic printing process called cyanotype to create maps of islands that come straight from her imagination.

To make the maps, Loughlin puts a piece of seaweed on special photographic paper.

As the paper develops under light, it changes color, leaving an impression where the seaweed was placed.

Loughlin then brings her ideas to life.

"So, I start to figure out where there might be quicksand on the island, or maybe there’s an old boat that’s sunken off the island somewhere," Loughlin said. "I create these things in my head."

Loughlin's maps are fictional but come from her love of island life.

"I’m from one of the islands in Casco Bay, and so I’m kind of very island-bound in my heart, and that’s what comes out in my work," she said.

Title: Dog 'frightened, confused' after being abandoned at Orange City park
Summary:
Do you recognize this sweet girl? Volusia County officials said she was left tied to a picnic table at Valentine Park on Wednesday, March 27, 2019. (Image: Volusia County Animal Services)

ORANGE CITY, Fla. - A senior female dog was rescued Wednesday after being left tied to a picnic table at an Orange City park, Volusia County Animal Services officials said.

Witnesses said a woman in a newer model motor home dropped the tan-colored pup off at the Valentine Park pavilion around 9 a.m. She left a blanket and water for the dog before driving away. Officials said it's unclear if she was the dog’s owner.

The dog was wearing a black padded nylon harness with two leashes -- one yellow and one orange -- hooked together.

The abandoned dog was "frightened and confused" when Volusia County Animal control officers were called to collect her at the park on West French Avenue.

Animal control officers retrieved the dog and brought her to the Southeast Volusia Humane Society, where she will be cared for until she is reclaimed or adopted.

Anyone with information on the dog is asked to call Volusia County Animal Services at 386-248-1790.

Title: Two teenagers killed in high-speed crash in Deltona
Summary:
Two teenagers killed in high-speed crash in Deltona

Two teenagers are dead after a high-speed crash occurred in Deltona on Thursday, deputies confirmed.Authorities said 17-year-old Zachary Hollenback was driving east on Saxon Boulevard at a high rate of speed when he lost control of the vehicle. Hollenback's car crossed into the westbound lanes and struck a Nissan Maxima, officials said.Chester Turck, 17, a passenger in Hollenback's vehicle, died in the crash.Authorities said Hollenback was taken to Central Florida Hospital in Sanford in critical condition. Officials said Hollenback died Friday afternoon.The driver of the Nissan was treated at Central Florida Regional Hospital and then released. Her passenger, a 13-year-old girl, was not injured.Authorities said there were no signs that anyone was impaired before the crash.

Two teenagers are dead after a high-speed crash occurred in Deltona on Thursday, deputies confirmed.

Title: Girl asks if dad can sing at Grand Floridian & rest is Disney magic
Summary:
Girl asks if dad can sing 'Ave Maria' at Grand Floridian & rest is Disney magic Video

ORLANDO, Fla. (WFLA) - A family tradition turns into a viral moment when a man started singing at the Grand Floridian in Walt Disney World last week.

Justin Gigliello traveled with his family from Connecticut to Disney World. They were having lunch at the resort and he was telling his daughter Lyla how he used to go to the Grand Floridian with his parents to listen to the pianist play in the lobby. So, his daughter wanted to do the same thing.

Justin said he danced with his daughter for a couple of songs and then she went up to the pianist and told him that her dad plays and sings. The pianist went along and asked what song? She said “Ave Maria,” and the rest is Disney and Internet magic.

Copyright 2019 Nexstar Broadcasting, Inc. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten, or redistributed. Courtesy: Justin Gigliello

Copyright 2019 Nexstar Broadcasting, Inc. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten, or redistributed. Courtesy: Justin Gigliello

Reactions on Facebook were how the look on Lyla’s face while he is signing is priceless, and we agree.

Justin started singing when he was 15. “I used to sing as a kid with my dad. He used to play Beatles and Frank Sinatra records at home but I didn’t start taking lessons until 15.”

His parents signed him up with an opera coach and he fell in love with it. He ended up going to school at the Boston Conservatory.

Bravo Justin!

Title: Winter Garden arrested for soliciting nude photo of teen, deputies say
Summary:
- The Polk County Sheriff's Office has arrested a man they said solicited a nude photo from a 14-year-old girl from Davenport.

Joao Meira, 32, is charged with using a computer to solicit a child and unlawful use of a 2-way communication device.

Deputies say they launched an investigation in November after receiving a tip from the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children.

The victim reportedly confirmed to investigators that she had talked with Meira through Facebook Messenger and that he asked for a nude photo, which she provided to him. She said she was just 13-years-old at the time that the photo was taken.

The victim also received a photo from Meira showing his face and genitals, deputies say.

A total of 22 images were reported, many of them showing a young girl wearing a bikini, underwear, and bra and one image showing a girl a girl partially nude.

"At this time, we are only aware of one victim," said Sheriff Grady Judd in a statement. "The investigation is ongoing to see if there are more images of this girl, or any other children. But even if there is only the one image, it's one too many. No man, no matter how old, should be asking little girls for nude pictures."

Meira was taken to the Polk County Jail.

Title: St. Augustine man charged with sexual battery on girl younger than 16
Summary:
ST. JOHNS COUNTY, Fla. - A 27-year-old St. Augustine man has been charged with lewd or lascivious battery on a child older than 12 and younger than 16 years old.

Daniel Rodriguez was taken into custody by St. Johns County deputies around 2:30 a.m. Monday.

Investigators said they found Rodriguez and the victim asleep in the backseat of his car which was parked at the end of St. Johns Parkway.

Deputies said the victim said she and Rodriguez had an on-going sexual relationship for about three months.

She said he would entice her to sneak out of the house and the two would go to the area to have sex several times during that time.

Detectives said Rodriguez admitted to having sex with the underage girl and was booked into the St. Johns County jail with bond set at $75,000.

Title: Quacker is a little quacked up, needs help
Summary:
OCEAN CITY — At first glance, she seems to have it all — a nice place to live (private swimming pool included), plenty of good food, even a roommate named Sylvia.

But appearances can be deceiving. And when Big Girl rises to make her way across her Navy Street living quarters, it's immediately apparent that for her, for now, life isn't all ... well, all it's quacked up to be.

One of her orange legs and webbed feet works fine, but the other doesn't. So when the 9-month old duck wants to go anywhere, her right leg and foot claw at the ground, forcing her to use her extended right wing for leverage to move. Getting to the pool — actually a small pond in one corner of the pen she shares with Sylvia — is an even bigger ordeal.

"If she really wants to go down there, she'll flap her right wing and use her left leg," explained Jamie Wilson, who back in January took in Big Girl and Sylvia from a co-worker who didn't have room for the two young ducks.

"When she said she had ducks, I said, 'I've got land. What does it take to raise a duck? You make sure it has water, food, and a pond."

Until, that is, one of your ducks develops a mysterious limp. Then, raising a duck becomes a whirlwind of visits to veterinarians, and a frantic search for money to fund a needed operation.

About a month after Wilson brought the duck home to the sturdy pen built by Pope — a timber frame covered with stretched-tight chicken wire — she noticed that Big Girl, for some reason, had developed a limp. An initial trip to a local veterinarian revealed no reason for the limp, but when Big Girl's condition worsened, Wilson sought a second opinion.

An X-ray by a second veterinarian revealed that Big Girl had a broken right femur. Surgery to fix the bone, which would involve inserting a pin in Big Girl's right leg to hold the bone together to heal, carries a price tag of $810. That's money Wilson just doesn't have right now, after spending $300 to get Big Girl's problem diagnosed. She's tried to find a veterinarian or animal rescue group that will let her pay off the operation over time, but hasn't been successful.

"They all said they've been burnt before," Wilson said.

In the meantime, Big Girl's right leg and foot have become gnarled, and there's a chance that, if the money isn't available soon, Big Girl might be beyond healing.

"It's going on three weeks now," Wilson said, "and sometimes, you can't get the bones back together."

It's not like Wilson hasn't tried to get the money.

"I had a yard sale, and raised $25," she said, almost apologetically.

She's also applied — unsuccessfully — to CareCredit and Scratchpay, two veterinary financing services.

And, Wilson has turned online, to GoFundMe. But, results at her campaign page, "Surgery for Big Girl," (https://www.gofundme.com/surgey-for-big-girl), have been lackluster. As of Wednesday, contributions totaled just $175.

"There's how many people in America?" Wilson asked rhetorically while feeding Big Girl on Wednesday afternoon, clearly frustrated that more people haven't stepped up to help.

For now, Wilson is taking some solace in the fact that one of her veterinarians told her that ducks are among nature's most resilient and adaptable creatures, and Big Girl might learn to live with a broken or misshapen leg.

"... They're really good at adapting to disability," Wilson said. "I've found videos where they can live with just one leg," Wilson said.

But then again, if it comes to that, amputation would cost just about as much as the femur repair surgery, she said.

Which down the road, depending on how Big Girl does if she doesn't get the femur surgery, might leave just one option.

"If, at any point, she seems totally distressed, I would have her put to sleep," Wilson said.
Address: 2 Eglin Pkwy NE, Fort Walton Beach, FL 32548, USA

Title: Teen girl groped while on school trip to Disney, deputies say
Summary:
ORANGE COUNTY, Fla. - A teenage girl who was on a class trip to Disney's Animal Kingdom was inappropriately touched while visiting the park, according to the Orange County Sheriff's Office.

Deputies said the 16-year-old girl told a chaperone that she and her other female friends were walking to the school's bus on Friday when a man in a blue shirt groped her as he was walking by the group.

The victim was crying and visibly shaken after the incident, the report said. The man was gone from the area by the time the chaperone was made aware of what happened.

Deputies said the chaperone reported the incident to Disney security the next day and they in turn reported it to the Orange County Sheriff's Office.

The victim, who attends school in Alabama, did not wish to file a formal report.

The man has not been identified.
