Title: Actor Bailey Chase of 'Longmire,' 'Buffy the Vampire Slayer,' 'Ugly Betty' grew up in Florida
Summary:
Actor and Naples native Bailey Chase co-stars in a new Netflix Original movie, "Walk Ride Rodeo." (Photo: Photo courtesy of Greg Peters)

Bailey Chase for years has played the character viewers often dislike.

The Naples native and father of three says he's enjoying his new roles including the new Netflix Original "Walk. Ride. Rodeo." that premiered earlier this month.

Chase, 46, gained prominence for his acting from 2012 to 2017 on the western crime series "Longmire," in which he played the role of an ambitious Wyoming sheriff's deputy, Branch Connally.

“More than anything, the arc that I got to do on 'Longmire,' that character Branch, he hit all the notes," Chase said in a recent telephone interview.

"It gave me a confidence as an actor that I could do anything, I could play good. I could play bad. And by portraying these newer characters, that’s how I connect with the audience more. Then they start rooting for you.”

More: Actor Burt Reynolds had a long connection to FSU and football

More: Steve Carell of 'The Office' will star in Netflix 'Space Force' series

More: 7 benefits of a FLORIDA TODAY digital subscription

In his latest role, Chase plays Cory Snyder, the real-life father of Amberley Snyder, a successful rodeo barrel racer who returns to the sport after a car crash.

Bailey and his wife Amy have three children: twin 2-year-olds (a boy and a girl) and a 4-year-old daughter who was born in Santa Fe, New Mexico, when Chase was still shooting "Longmire."

“For me as a dad, to play that role, as an actor, you go to those places where I’m imagining my girl in a hospital bed and in a wheelchair," Bailey said.

“Since 'Longmire' and becoming a dad, I feel like I can play anything.”

Happy Mother’s Day to all the amazing Mama’s out there (miss you Mom) and to my beautiful wife for these 3 little backseat drivers ❤️🚌 pic.twitter.com/dln0pQr4cT — Bailey Chase (@Bailey_Chase) May 13, 2018

He grew up in Naples, living in the seaside town from age 4 through his freshman year at Naples High School. He transferred to the Bolles School in Jacksonville where he played football and baseball and graduated from the private school before heading to Duke University in Durham, North Carolina.

After graduating from Duke with a bachelor's degree in sports psychology, Chase said, he decided to fulfill "a boyhood dream" and headed to Los Angeles instead of New York.

"I came out here, being a Florida boy," Chase said. "The climate was a little bit better. I was living at the beach, waiting tables and going to acting class.”

He eventually traveled overseas to become a student at the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art (LAMDA), to study Shakespeare.

When he returned to the U.S., he landed a role on "Buffy The Vampire Slayer," a television series that ran from 1997 to 2003. For the next few years, Chase portrayed Chris Robert Hughes on the soap opera "As The World Turns."

He co-starred as "Becks" Scott in the ABC comedy-drama "Ugly Betty," which ran from 2006 to 2010, and on the TNT series "Saving Grace" that was ran between 2007 and 2010.

But his most notable role came in 2012, when he began on "Longmire" that began on the A&E channel and, later, Netflix. Actor Robert Taylor starred as Walt Longmire, a stoic, rugged, no-nonsense sheriff who revealed his Australian accent away from the camera, Chase said.

"He’s a good dude," Chase said of Taylor. "It was a strong cast. We were all distinctly different.”

Bailey Chase, from left, Laura San Giacomo, Bokeem Woodbine, Leon Rippy, Holly Hunter, Gregory Norman Cruz and Kenneth Johnson appear in the TNT network television program "Saving Grace." (Gannett News Service, Frank Ockenfels/TNT/File) (Photo: FRANK OCKENFELS, GNS)

Longmire" also co-starred actress Kate Sackhoff and actors Lou Diamond Phillips and Gerald McRaney, known for his TV roles on "Major Dad" and "Simon & Simon" that Chase said he grew up watching.

Upcoming work for Chase include a role this summer on season 4 of "Queen of the South," a crime drama on the USA Network. Chase said he's been flying to New Orleans for filming and returning home to LA every weekend.

All he said he could reveal about his character is that he's "a jazz musician with a dark past."

Chase said he still has family in Florida, including a brother who's a builder based in Ocala. He hasn't been in Naples for more than a decade but hopes to visit again one day.

“Growing up down there, I couldn’t wait to get out," he said of Naples.

"But once I got into my 20s and my 30s, I always enjoyed coming back home. Naples will always be home. It's so humid; it just has a feel and a smell. It’s very nostalgic for me.”

Actor Bailey Chase, who grew up in Naples, stars in a new Netflix Original film "Walk Ride Rodeo" that premiered March 8, 2019. (Photo: Photo courtesy of Greg Peters with Netflix)

Address: 1 Gannett Plaza Ave, Melbourne, FL 32940, USA

Title: FLAGLER PREP ROUNDUP: Pirates earn diamond split with Father Lopez
Summary:
Chad Taylor drove in four runs during three separate rallies Friday night and Nathan Quinn handcuffed the Green Wave batters for six innings to give the Pirates a 7-1 win and a split of the season series in district games last week.

Matanzas knocked out eight hits in the game, including a fifth-inning double by Andrew Butler, who also scored twice. Sean Sparling singled and scored a run and Joseph Alvarado was 2-for-3 with a run scored for the Pirates.

Quinn benefitted from timely hitting and his own ability to throw strikes. He fanned 12 over the course of six innings and gave up a paltry three hits. A third-inning single by the Wave’s Grayson Chastain drove in the visitors’ lone run.

Cameron Quintana pitched one inning of scoreless relief for the Pirates.

Father Lopez 8, Matanzas 2: In the opening game of the series March 26, the Green Wave touched Matanzas starter Eric Libby for seven hits and seven runs, only four earned, over five complete innings. The Pirates avoided a shutout in the top of the seventh trailing 8-0 when Alvarado hit an RBi double and Kyle Perry drove in another run on a fielder’s choice ground out.

TRACK AND FIELD

ERAU Spikes Classic: Three Flagler Palm Coast competitors won events and two relay teams held first place over the weekend at the ERAU Spikes Classic at Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University in Daytona Beach.

The Bulldogs boys’ team got wins from Ken’Deric Morton in the 300 hurdles in 39.93 seconds and Nikita Roumianstev in the high jump with a top performance of 5-5¾. Tallin Coates took second in the 110 hurdles in 15.56 seconds and FPC placed in seven other individual events. The team got a win in the 4x400 relay in a time of 3:28.69 with Ryan Clark, Morton, Jason Chum and Jones running the race.

Triple jumper Prosperity Wright was the only girl on the FPC team to win an individual event when she jumped 36 feet 8½ inches and teammate Dyman Howard jumped 34-9 for second in the event. The two were joined by Susann Kaufmann and Tara Tallaksen for first in the 4x100 relay, timed at 49.55 seconds.

Kaufmann, Otyana Clayton and Talleksen gave FPC a 4-7-8 finish in the 100 meter dash with Kaufmann’s 12.85 leading that effort. Jahlia McCaskell placed third in the 300 hurdles at 47/10 seconds and fourth in the 100 hurdles at 17.10 seconds. Jada Williams took sixth in the 1,600 meter run in 5:46.78 and Haley Olsen was eighth in the 3,200 in 14:17.90.

FPC’s boys team took third in two events with De’Shaun Hugee throwing 131-9 in the discus and Clark running the 400 in 52.42 seconds. Morton took fourth in the 400 meters in 22.50, Chum was fourth in the 800 at 2:07.21, Curt Gray also was fourth in the triple jump in 41-11¾ and Brandon Eatman fourth in the shot put in 39-2¼. Diego Carrascosa was sixth in the 1,600 meters at 4:49.48.

PEPSI RELAYS

Miley, Paul lead Bulldogs: Jacob Miley and Nelson Paul gave Flagler Palm Coast a pair of fifth-place finishes over the weekend at the annual relay event at the University of Florida featuring collegiate teams and elite high school performers from across the state.

Miley ran his top time of the year in the 800 meters in a time of 1:53.26 for fifth place, a split-second behind Bolles runner Chase Rivera in the battle for fourth. The race was won by Piper’s Sukell Foucha in 1:51.19. FPC’s Shawn Gordon just missed a medal finish with a 1:58.03 for 10th place while five other Bulldogs, Darrell Thomas, Wes Magnell, JT Dahlberg, Nathan Farrell and Gus Healy also competed in the half mile event.

The Bulldogs also got a fifth-place showing from Paul in the shot put, when he had one of his top throws of the year at 53-6½. FPC’s 4x800 relay team had a top place in third with a time of 7:58.18. Farrell was 11th in the 110 hurdles (14.57) and Verneal Henshaw was a finalist in the discus in 15th place at 133-2.

TENNIS

FPC boys win 4 of 7 in finals: Brothers Eric and Daniel Berenblit along with teammate Matt Pokorny gave Flagler Palm Coast wins in four of seven finals matches as well as the overall singles and doubles championship at the Five Star Conference championships Wednesday and Thursday last week in Daytona Beach.

Eric Berenblit won the No. 1 singles title with a 6-0, 6-1 victory over Spruce Creek’s Luke Paschal in the championship finals. His younger brother, Daniel, won No. 2 singles with a 6-2, 6-1 win over Creek’s Andre Cronje. Pokorny took the No. 3 singles title match 6-2, 6-2 over Daniel Cronje. The Berenblit brothers won the No. 1 doubles match in a pivotal match, as Spruce Creek won NO. 4 and No. 5 singles and No. 2 doubles.

WEIGHTLIFTING

Region 4-2A championships: Matanzas lifters Will Lam and Skyler Michaud-Williams and Flagler Palm Coast’s Dominique Bennett won individual titles Friday night in the Region 4-2A championships to earn automatic berths in the upcoming state tournament at Panama City Beach.

Lam won the 169-pound title with a 645-pound combined lift that was one of the top efforts at the meet, including lifters in three higher classifications. Lam did 355 pounds on his bench press and 290 in the clean and jerk.

Michaud-Williams won the 219-pound class with a 635 combined lift that included a 340 on the bench and 295 in the clean and jerk.

Bennett was champion in the lightest weight classification, 119, when he did a 185-170—355 finish on hisbest attempts. Spruce Creek led the tournament at FPC with four of 10 weight class champions and Winter Springs had two champions.

-- Andy Mikula
Address: 901 6th St, Daytona Beach, FL 32117, USA

Title: NTSB: ‘No mechanical malfunction’ when plane crashed into Winter Haven home
Summary:
Hide Transcript Show Transcript

WEBVTT A PLANE CRASHES INTO A LOCAL HOME, KILLING THE PILOT AND INJURING TWO OTHER PEOPLE. SUMMER: AND TONIGHT WE’RE HEARING FROM NEIGHBORS WHO WATCHED WHILE IT WAS ALL HAPPENING. WESH 2’S MICHELLE MEREDITH SHOWS US THE CONFUSION AND CHAOS THAT UNFOLDED, WHICH CAN BE HEARD IN NEWLY RELEASED 911 CALLS. >> WELL AS I WAS WALKING INTO MY HOUSE YOU JUST HEARD THIS LOUD EXPLOSION AND I WAS LIKE HOLY MERCY, WHAT IS THAT? MICHELLE: IT WAS A PLANE. CRASHING INTO THEIR NEIGHBOR’S HOUSE, INSIDE THE HOUSE WAS A MOTHER, HER 21-YEAR-OLD SON AND 17-YEAR-OLD DAUGHTER. THE DAUGHTER WAS PINNED TO A WALL. AS YOU HEAR IN THIS DRAMATIC 911 CALL, THAT’S WHEN THE CHAOS AND PANIC STARTED. >> HOW MANY PEOPLE ARE INJURED? MICHELLE: NEIGHBORS AND FAMILY MEMBERS ARE SCRAMBLING TO FIGURE OUT WHAT THEY ARE DEALING WITH, INCLUDING THE 911 OPERATOR. >> I NEED EVERYBODY TO GET OUT OF THE HOUSE. MICHELLE: THE SMALL PLANE HAD JUST TAKEN OFF FROM A WINTER HAVEN AIRPORT, LOST POWER, THEN NOSEDIVED INTO THE HOME. INSIDE THE PLANE WAS A STUDENT PILOT 33-YEAR-OLD TIMOTHY SHEEHY , WHO SURVIVED. HIS INSTRUCTOR, 64-YEAR-OLD JAMES WAGNER, DID NOT. >> WE’VE GOT SOME HELP ON THE WAY, OK? >> TELL THEM TO HURRY UP, THE LADY DOES NOT HAVE LONG, SHE’S HURT REAL

Advertisement NTSB: ‘No mechanical malfunction’ when plane crashed into Winter Haven home Share Shares Copy Link Copy

The National Transportation Safety Board has released a new report detailing what caused a plane to crash into a Winter Haven home earlier this year.The preliminary report by the NTSB found said no mechanical problems were found during an initial review of the engine and fuselage.Pilot and flight instructor James Wagner died after the plane crashed into a home on Feb 23. Timothy Sheehy, of Montana, survived with minor injuries. A 17-year-old girl who was in the home at the time of the crash was also hurt. According to the NTSB aviation accident preliminary report, the twin engine seaplane, a STOL Aircraft Corp UC-1 amphibious airplane, took off from Winter Haven Regional Airport at 12:43 p.m. Sheehy told the NTSB that Wagner advised him before takeoff that he would introduce a simulated engine failure. After reaching 200-300 feet, Wagner reduced throttle on the left engine. A witness on the ground, operating a fuel truck, also provided information that the left engine propeller was not spinning when the plane began to turn.Sheehy told the NTSB that the engine restart procedure was unsuccessful and attempts to make an emergency water landing nearby were unsuccessful. The plane crashed into the house, briefly trapping the 17-year-old, Carmelle Ngalamulume, who was rescued by neighbors.Neighbor Moses Saint Hillaire told WFLA-TV "Half of her body is through the wall and the other half was in her room. We promise, we (were) not going to leave you.” Saint Hillaire continued, “I told her I said listen, if anything happens, if the plane catch on fire, I'm sorry, I'm gonna have to pull you out. Cause I'd rather pull you out and you be injured than you know, you catch on fire.”Her mother, Emerance Ngalamulume, and brother, Joel Ngalamulume, were inside as well but were not harmed. Children playing in the driveway also were not hurt.The NTSB conducted a test run of the left engine, and the report notes, “the engine started immediately, accelerated smoothly, and ran continuously at all selected power settings without interruption.” It further reads, “No evidence of preimpact mechanical malfunction was noted during the examination of the recovered airframe and engines.”According to the report, the plane had its 100-hour inspection the same day as the crash.NTSB spokesman Eric Weiss told WESH 2 News, “This report represents an initial review of the evidence collected at the scene. No probable cause will be determined until we release a final report.”Wagner was considered an accomplished pilot and instructor, in particular with seaplanes. His most recent FAA first-class medical certificate was issued January 25, and he reported 15,000 total hours of flight experience on that date.

Title: Ocala Scouts, now including girls, enjoy Pinewood Derby
Summary:
Classic event is a chance for kids and family members to work together.

Imagination supplied the spark and gravity provided the fuel on Saturday as Cub Scouts ranging from kindergarten age to the fourth grade rolled their hand-crafted wooden model cars down a four-lane inclined track while surrounded by cheering family and friends at the annual Scouts BSA North Florida Council/Marion District Pinewood Derby.

The top three winners in each of five categories will go to the regional finals on May 4 at Bass Pro Shop in Gainesville.

This year's competition, held at St. Paul's United Methodist Church, included the first participation in the races by girls in Marion County Cub Scout packs.

Steve Hickman, cubmaster of Tiger Pack 18, said girls were admitted into Scouts BSA as of February 2018, and five of the 57 racers at Saturday's event were girls. Hickman referred to the "inclusive environment" at the event and praised it as a "full family experience."

Annabelle Cruce, 7, of Tiger Pack 18, raced a pink "Unicorn Fantasy" car and took third place in the Tiger division, making her the first female scout to place in the local Pinewood Derby. She will advance to Gainesville.

She was adamant that the pink paint made her car go faster, but she also "took a weight off."

The track used at the event Saturday was made of metal rather than wood. The competition had computerized scoring and a clock.

Teresa Lanning, committee chair with Boy Scout Troop 692 and Cub Scout Pack 692 and scoutmaster of the six-member Scouts BSA Girl Troop 692, said during the event that she has "the first female scout in the area who received the Arrow of Light award and crossed over to Scouts BSA Girl Troop 692."

"Two other girls have earned their Arrow of Light and will be crossing over soon from their Cub Scout pack," Lanning said.

Marion District Pinewood Derby Chair Bill Holland said the event is aimed at fostering qualities like leadership and sportsmanship. Holland's wife, Robin, and their son, Casey, 11, have participated in five prior races, and a shelf at their home holds past entries including one called "Sting Like A Bee."

Cub Scouts assemble their own scale cars, which may be no heavier than 5 ounces, Hickman stated. Entrants focus on weight placement, axles and alignment.

Hickman said this was also the inaugural year for kindergartners to race in the Lions division.

The cars are often a joint venture involving scout and parents; as they grow older, many scouts complete their own cars.

Keileb Negron, 9, took first place in the third grade Bears division. His parents, Jackeline Negron and Tony Duarte, cheered him on as he bested the other entries with his "Golden Dasher" car.

Daniel and Gina Gentry were at the derby with their sons Anthony, 9, racing in his fourth event, and Daniel III, 12, who raced in four prior derbys and is now a Scout. Anthony took third place in the Webelos, or fourth grade, division.

Jeremy Harrell enjoyed an afternoon of racing with his stepson Ethan, 6.

Truman Magley, senior Marion district executive, said the district now has about 30 female scouts in three troops. He said the Pinewood Derby is a chance for "scout and parents to work together to develop skills."

Ryan and Jessica Pilch came to the races with their daughter, Vivian, 8, and son, Ethan, 5, both in Scouts USA. Ethan finished second in the Lions or kindergartner division.

Vivian said she was drawn to scouting by archery, and she likes outdoor activity.

"Girls can camp, too," she said.
Address: 2121 SW 19th Avenue Rd, Ocala, FL 34471, USA

Title: Scholar Athlete of the Month: Aneeshea Cason
Summary:
Aneeshea Cason is WPBF 25’s Scholar Athlete of the Month. She’s not only valedictorian of her class, graduating two years early, but also the first ever girl at Seminole Ridge High School to score more than 1,000 points during her basketball career. According to Coach Maria Hudson, "There were game nights where Shea would come into our pregame room and would be studying or taking classes online right before a game and would go out there and give 14,15,16 points and be locked in." Aneeshea described her play to WPBF’s Sandra Shaw. "I would kinda get banged up a little bit so I could get to the foul line when I needed to.”Beyond basketball, she’s excited about pursuing a career as a pediatric cardiothoracic surgeon. She wants to take this path because she suffered from a heart murmur as a child. She already has a head start with college credits, as well. Principal James Campbell says Aneeshea has taken 40 classes that will qualify her for college credits.

Title: Leesburg men shot at children walking home, used racial slurs, police say
Summary:
James Reidnauer, 31, and Brent Van Besien, 33, are accused of calling two Leesburg children racial slurs and shooting at them.

LEESBURG, Fla. - A Lake County mother can be heard in a 911 call telling her children to stay down and away from the windows after two white men called the siblings racial slurs and shot at them sending them running home.

The 12-year-old girl and 16-year-old boy were walking home on Goose Prairie Road March 17 from the BP gas station and cut through the area near a church when the victims said James Reidnauer, 31, and Brent Van Besien, 33, confronted them.

The area where the victims were walking was near the Lisbon Church of God where Lake County students are picked up and dropped off by the school bus, the victims' mother said in the 911 call.

"They tried to block them in before with their truck," she said.

The siblings said Reidnauer asked, "What are you doing?" to which the 16-year-old said "just walking home with his sister."

At which point Reidenauer again asked "What are you doing?" and Van Besisen called the 16-year-old a racial slur before both men fired their guns at the children, according to the arrest report.

The siblings ran home and in the 911 call from their mother it's clear they were running out of fear. Police who responded said neither child was injured but "both were visibly frightened."

[WARNING GRAPHIC LANGUAGE IN 911 CALL BELOW]

In the 911 call the mother tells her children they shouldn't have even responded to the men's questions, "You don’t ever speak you just run."

When deputies spoke with the suspects, both men said they had confronted two "meth heads" and Reidnauer fired "a warning shot into the ground to prevent them from breaking into the house." Van Besien, who is a convicted felon, said only Reidnauer fired the shot. Deputies said they found bullet casings from a Smith and Wesson 9 mm.

Both men described the victims as a "brown guy" and a "white girl" who were in their 20s or 30s, according to the report. Deputies said Van Besien "then changed his story saying he never actually got a good look at the people because he was quite a distance away."

Reidnauer and Van Besien are both charged with two counts of aggravated assault with a firearm during a hate crime. Van Beisen faces additional charges of possession of a firearm by a convicted felon.

Lake County Jail records show both suspects were booked into the jail March 18 and have not posted bond.

As a dispatcher tried to calm the mother telling her to take deep breaths. She responded "We have to get out of this neighborhood."

"They weren’t doing anything," she said. "All they did was walk home from the store."

Title: People born in this month are the smartest, study finds
Summary:
If you were born in September, apparently you are smarter than people born in any other month, and now, you have a study to back you up.

A published study in the National Bureau of Economic Research shows a clear association between your smarts and the month in which you were born.

If you were born in any other month, read on, because we have some news that may soothe your concerns.

The study, named School Starting Age and Cognitive Development, analyzed cognitive development in 1.2 million school children between the ages of 6 and 15 in Florida.

There is a bit of a caveat. The determination that those born in September had a higher grade average was likely because they were among the oldest when starting school, the study found.

Because many states require students going into kindergarten to be 5 years old before Sept. 1, those children begin school the following year, just on the verge of being 6 years old.

The study, Marie Claire reported, showed the age difference can have an impact on development. In addition, those born in August — who would be the youngest in their class — had the lowest grade average, seemingly backing up the theory.

For those not born in September, there’s no need to fret! The study also revealed that all other children will eventually catch up to their older counterparts.

Title: Lights for Layla: local agencies raising money for LED lights on student backpacks after girl's death at school bus stop
Summary:
Layla Aiken, 8, was killed in a hit-and-run while waiting at her school bus stop. (Photo: Special to the News-Press)

Lee County students who wait for school buses in the dark morning hours will be able to adorn their backpacks with flashing LED lights starting next year.

Local agencies are partnering to raise money for the new safety protocols after the death of 8-year-old Layla Aikens, who was hit by a pickup truck while waiting at her bus stop with her brothers Monday morning.

The Lee County School District is partnering with the Lee County Sheriff's Office and Big Momma and the Wild Bunch at FM radio station B103.9 to raise $100,000 for flashing LED lights that every student can attach to their backpacks, according to a school district news release.

Lee County School District Superintendent Greg Adkins (center) and Lee County Sheriff Carmine Marceno (right) talk with Big Momma of B103.9 about Lights for Layla, a school safety fundraiser after a girl was killed while waiting at her bus stop Monday. (Photo: The Lee County School District)

More: Cape Coral mourns 8-year-old girl killed in hit-and-run: 'Help us lay this angel to rest.'

More: Cape Coral, Lee County School District to analyze bus stop safety after student deaths

"The safety of our students is always our highest priority," said Superintendent Greg Adkins. "With the community's support, we can raise the money to provide every bus rider a bright, flashing light they can attach to their bag or backpack so they can be even more visible while waiting for their bus in the morning."

The sheriff's office and the school district will commit $20,000 and $10,000 respectively. The sheriff's office will also establish a nonprofit called "Compassionate Cops" to manage the donations and help purchase the lights.

“We will devote all of the time, effort and resources necessary to protect the students of Lee County," said Sheriff Carmine Marceno. "I can't think of anything more important. And we will continue to work closely with the school district to ensure the safety of our students."

A note from mom is attached to a photograph of 8-year-old Layla Aiken at a memorial site. Layla was killed by a hit-and-run driver Monday morning. (Photo: Ricardo Rolon/The News-Press USA TODAY NETWORK - FLORIDA)

More: Fort Myers man identified as victim in Sunday hit-and-run on Palm Beach Boulevard

More: Fundraisers for 8-year-old killed in hit-and-run garnering community support

At the moment, only checks sent to the Lee County Sheriff’s Office with Lights for Layla written in the memo line can be accepted as donations.

Once the nonprofit is established, information about making donations online will be posted on the sheriff’s office Facebook page and the school district's Facebook page. It is anticipated the lights will be purchased this summer and distributed to students before the start of the next school year in August.

Meanwhile, Layla's family and friends will host their own fundraiser called Lights for Layla Saturday at the Cape Assembly church from 1 to 3 p.m. The event will raise money for awareness for increased safety for children at bus stops, and will offer bounce houses, face painting, a DJ, balloon animals, food vendors, and more, according to an event flyer.

Authorities have seized the pickup truck involved in the deadly crash and have identified a person of interest, but have not yet charged or arrested anyone.

Title: No bond set for Stuart man accused of touching girl inappropriately multiple times
Summary:
German Garcia-Lopez (Photo: MARTIN COUNTY SHERIFF'S OFFICE)

STUART— A 19-year-old man from Stuart is accused of inappropriately touching a teenage girl multiple times.

German Garcia-Lopez, of the 3000 block of Southeast Evergreen Avenue in Stuart, was arrested Wednesday on five counts of lewd and lascivious battery on a person under the age of 16.

More: No bond for St. Lucie County man in child pornography case

The girl told deputies Garcia-Lopez asked her to send him inappropriate pictures of herself. After getting a search warrant, deputies said they found the pictures on Garcia-Lopez's cellphone.

Garcia-Lopez told deputies he didn't know how old the girl was before he touched her, but thought she was about 14.

He was taken to the Martin County Jail. No bond had been set as of Thursday morning.

(WFLA) - An AMBER Alert has been issued for a 1-year-old girl who was abducted in Georgia and is believed to be in extreme danger.

Authorities say Baylee Sue Peeples, 1, was abducted by Robert Joseph Peeples, 39, in Jefferson, Georgia.

Baylee is believed to be in extreme danger, according to the Georgia Bureau of Investigation. She was last seen wearing a pink shirt that has hearts on it and says “Always Amazing.” She was also wearing a pink and black jacket that had the word “Love” on it.

Baylee has blonde hair and blue eyes and weighs 25 pounds.

Robert Peeples is driving a white 1993 GMC Vandura with Georgia license tag RIK1620. Robert Peeples is 5 feet 10 inches tall and weighs 187 pounds.

If you have any information about the whereabouts of Baylee or Robert Peeples call 911.

Title: Fifth grader dies after elementary school fight
Summary:
WALTERBORO, S.C. - Authorities say a fifth grader in South Carolina has died from injuries she suffered in a fight at her elementary school earlier this week.

Colleton County Sheriff's spokeswoman Shalane Lowes said the girl died at a Charleston hospital Wednesday.

Colleton County School District officials say the girl was hurt Monday during a fight at Forest Hills Elementary School in Walterboro. Authorities haven't detailed how the girl was injured or what the fight was about.

The school district said in a statement one student was suspended as the investigation into the fight continues. Colleton County deputies said they are also investigating the fight.

The coroner's office didn't immediately release the girl's name or her cause of death.

Title: Report: 10-year-old girl ﻿dies after fight in South Carolina school classroom
Summary:
Authorities say a fifth-grader in South Carolina has died from injuries she suffered in a classroom fight at her elementary school earlier this week.Colleton County Sheriff’s spokeswoman Shalane Lowes said the girl died at a Charleston hospital Wednesday.According to WCSC, a post on the Colleton County School District's Facebook page confirmed the tragic news.“We are devastated by this news, and we want our communities to keep their thoughts and prayers with the student’s family at this time,” it read. Colleton County School District officials say the girl was hurt Monday during a fight at Forest Hills Elementary School in Walterboro. Authorities haven’t detailed how the girl was injured or what the fight was about.The school district said in a statement one student was suspended as the investigation into the fight continues. Colleton County deputies said they are also investigating the fight. Colleton County Coroner Richard Harvey confirmed to WCSC that the girl killed in the fight was 10-year-old Raniya Wright but did not release a cause of death. A GoFundMe page created to support her family has raised more than $10,000.The district's crisis team has been on campus since the incident. “What is most important right now is making sure our students, staff and teachers are getting the support that they need,” district spokesman Sean Gruber said.After the fight, a teacher who wished to remain unidentified told WISC she does not feel that the district's children are safe."My child had personally went through it on two different occasions, to, at one point, she had to switch schools and at one point it was not handled properly. As a parent, I wouldn't say I was satisfied," the woman said. She said she has reported incidents of bullying in her classroom several times this year."I immediately stop it when I see it. If I notice it as a continuous thing, I report it," she continued. "Being an educator, I think our students should be put first in all situations."

Colleton County School District officials say the girl was hurt Monday during a fight at Forest Hills Elementary School in Walterboro. Authorities haven’t detailed how the girl was injured or what the fight was about.

The school district said in a statement one student was suspended as the investigation into the fight continues. Colleton County deputies said they are also investigating the fight.

Colleton County Coroner Richard Harvey confirmed to WCSC that the girl killed in the fight was 10-year-old Raniya Wright but did not release a cause of death. A GoFundMe page created to support her family has raised more than $10,000.

“What is most important right now is making sure our students, staff and teachers are getting the support that they need,” district spokesman Sean Gruber said.

Title: Prosecutor: Pastor encouraged other ministers to have sex with 'groomed' teenager
Summary:
Advertisement Prosecutor: Pastor encouraged other ministers to have sex with 'groomed' teenager Share Shares Copy Link Copy

A minister who promised a woman he’d take care of her daughter began having sex with the teenager daily and later encouraged two other pastors to have sex with her as well, federal prosecutors said Monday.Anthony Haynes could face up to life in prison if he’s convicted of child sex trafficking and other charges. The two other Toledo-area pastors charged in the investigation have pleaded guilty and are awaiting sentencing.Prosecutors said during the opening of Haynes’ trial that he first had sex with the girl when she was 14. They said the evidence against him includes text messages, photos, voice mails and DNA evidence from his church where the girl said they often had sex.Haynes’ attorney told jurors that the allegations are shocking, but there’s not enough evidence to prove the trafficking and conspiracy charges he faces.Attorney Pete Wagner also said Haynes may have had a questionable relationship with the girl, but he didn’t coordinate or take part in trafficking her to the other ministers. He also said there was no paying for sex.Prosecutors say the girl had a difficult childhood and was sexually abused by a relative.Haynes pledged in front of his congregation to protect her and serve as a father figure, but he began grooming her for sex when she turned 14 and first forced her to perform sex acts in front of him, said Michael Freeman, an assistant U.S. attorney.They had sex day after day, often at a motel or his church, the Greater Life Christian Center in Toledo, and Haynes would give her cash, Freeman said.After about a year, Haynes introduced her to Kenneth Butler, another pastor, and he also began having sex with her, Freeman said.Sometimes, the two men joked about the arrangement, prosecutors said. One text shown in court that prosecutors say was sent by Butler to the girl said: “You better be nice and naked when I get there.”Prosecutors said the girl next met Cordell Jenkins, a minister who founded his own church in Toledo and built a large following until it closed after his arrest.The FBI has said in court documents that Jenkins had sex with two girls at his home, church office and a motel and often recorded the acts with his phone.Haynes, prosecutors said, encouraged the relationship with Jenkins.In addition to the charges against the men, Haynes’ wife and stepdaughter are accused of abducting the girl at gunpoint in January and warning her not to testify at his trial.Court documents say the pair forced the teenager from her apartment, choked her with a cord and told her to take back statements she made to investigators. Attorneys for Haynes’ wife and stepdaughter have declined to comment.Just before her husband went on trial, his wife appeared Monday in the same courtroom where the judge overseeing the case turned down her request to be released.
Address: Northcorp Business Park, Palm Beach Gardens, FL 33410, USA

Title: More than $60K raised for family of Cape Coral girl killed in hit-and-run crash
Summary:
CLOSE It was a dangerous year on Lee and Collier roads in 2018. Megan Kearney, mkearney@news-press.com

Well-wishers have raised more than $60,000 for the family of an 8-year-old girl who was killed in a hit and run Monday morning in Cape Coral.

A total of $61,009 was donated as of Wednesday morning from two online fundraisers for Layla Aiken — one on Facebook, which garnered $54,364 and one on GoFundMe, which garnered $6,645.

Josh Jasilewicz, a lineman for an electric company, came to pay his respects Tuesday afternoon and delivered a teddy bear to the memorial site for Layla Aiken visible on the corner of NE 3rd Avenue and NE 19th Terrace in Cape Coral. Layla Aiken was killed while waiting for her school bus Monday morning. (Photo: Ricardo Rolon/The News-Press USA TODAY NETWORK - FLORIDA)

The fundraiser pages are rife with messages of support for Layla's family. "Our hearts ache over your loss... our thoughts are with you during this difficult time," one contributor wrote. Another said "RIP, sweet girl."

Layla was sitting with her older twin brothers on the edge of the roadway on the northeast corner of Northeast 19th Terrace around 6:20 a.m. Monday when a truck traveling south on NE 3rd Avenue struck and rolled over her.

More: What we know: Cape Coral girl hit and killed at bus stop

More: Cape Coral police seize truck, eye person of interest in hit-and-run that killed 8-year-old girl

CONSIDER SUBSCRIBING TODAY: Help support local journalism

Layla Aiken, 8, was killed in a hit-and-run while waiting at her school bus stop. (Photo: Special to the News-Press)

Police said the driver took off away from the scene, and Layla was taken to the hospital, where she died.

Police said Tuesday that they seized the red truck they believe is involved in the hit and run, and have developed a person of interest in the case. Investigators are not releasing details about the person's identity "as the investigation is still in its infancy," a news release said.

Community members are also paying tribute to Layla through a roadside memorial, with supporters leaving notes, pictures, flowers and mementos.

A memorial including notes, flowers, balloons and plush animals, is now visible on the corner of NE 3rd Avenue and NE 19th Terrace in Cape Coral Tuesday afternoon at the site were Layla Aiken was killed while waiting for her school bus. (Photo: Ricardo Rolon/The News-Press USA TODAY NETWORK - FLORIDA)

The Cape Coral Police Department is still investigating the case and is working with the state attorney's office.

"The lead investigator and other Cape Coral Police personnel are working diligently to resolve this tragic case with the correct disposition based on the totality of the investigation as soon as possible," a Tuesday news release said.

Police said they have been collecting surveillance video from the area. If you believe you have video or other information about this case, you can contact the Cape Coral Police Department at 239-574-3223 or submit an anonymous tip here. You can also text a tip to CRIMES (274637) by including "CCPD+" before your message.

Title: Ocala man accused of having sex with 13-year-old girl may have other victims
Summary:
OCALA, Fla. - A 22-year-old Ocala man previously accused of molesting a minor has been arrested again on allegations he had sex with a 13-year-old girl.

Deputies with the Marion County Sheriff's Office said Jonathan Erick Doody II was arrested Tuesday after the girl told investigators Doody had sex with her several times last summer.

[MORE: Florida man claims to be 'Insta famous,’ lures, rapes Texas girl, police say | Real estate agent raped woman who was house hunting, police say]

Authorities said the girl decided to report the alleged incidents after learning Doody was charged with lewd and lascivious behavior on a victim 12-16 years of age in January, after being accused of molesting a 15-year-old girl.

While reporting the alleged incidents, the 13-year-old girl gave investigators detailed accounts of the alleged sexual encounters and was able to describe Doody's bedroom in great detail, deputies said.

Doody denied the allegations and told investigators the girl had never been to his house, according to the Sheriff's Office.

Following his arrest Tuesday, Doody faces two counts of lewd and lascivious battery on victims 12-16 years of age, records show.

Due to information learned throughout the investigation, detectives believe there may be additional victims. Anyone with information about other potential victims is asked to call the Marion County Sheriff's Office at 352-368-3508.

Title: Florida Book Awards announces winners for 2018 publications
Summary:
The Phillip and Dana Zimmerman Gold Medal for Florida Nonfiction was awarded to Gilbert King for “Beneath a Ruthless Sun: A True Story of Violence, Race, and Justice Lost & Found.” (Photo: Special to the Democrat)

With its 13th annual competition now complete, the Florida Book Awards has announced winners for books published in 2018. More than 200 eligible publications were submitted across 11 categories of competition.

The Florida Book Awards, coordinated by the Florida State University Libraries, is the nation’s most comprehensive state book awards program. It was established in 2006 to celebrate the best Florida literature. Authors must be full-time Florida residents, except in the Florida nonfiction and visual arts categories, where the subject matter must focus on Florida.

The Gwen P. Reichert Gold Medal for Children’s Literature, now in its fourth year, was awarded to Miami resident Silvia Lopez for “Just Right Family: An Adoption Story,” published by Albert Whitman & Company. This $1,000 cash award is in memory of Gwen P. Reichert and serves as a lasting tribute to her accomplishments as a rare book collector, nurturer of authors and educator of children.

Also awarded were the Richard E. Rice Gold Medal Award for Visual Arts to Richard Shieldhouse for “William Morgan: Evolution of an Architect” (University Press of Florida) and the Phillip and Dana Zimmerman Gold Medal for Florida Nonfiction to Gilbert King for “Beneath a Ruthless Sun: A True Story of Violence, Race, and Justice Lost & Found” (Penguin Random House). These two category winners each receive a $500 cash award.

The winning authors from across the state will be honored April 11 at the Abitz Family Dinner, the annual awards banquet, at the Mission San Luis in Tallahassee. The public is invited to attend. Please contact Jenni McKnight at floridabookawards.com or 850- 644-6323.

Here are the Florida Book Awards 2018 Winners by Category:

Younger Children's Literature

GOLD: Silvia Lopez, Miami, “Just Right Family: An Adoption Story” (Albert Whitman & Company)

SILVER: Margaret Cardillo, Miami, “Just Being Jackie” (HarperCollins)

BRONZE: Rob Sanders, Brandon, “Peaceful Fights for Equal Rights” (Simon & Schuster)

Older Children's Literature

GOLD: Ryan Calejo, Miami, “Charlie Hernádez & the League of Shadows” (Simon & Schuster)

SILVER: Jennifer Swanson, Jacksonville, “Astronaut-Aquanaut: How Space Science and Sea Science Interact” (National Geographic Partners)



Florida Nonfiction

GOLD: Gilbert King, “Beneath a Ruthless Sun: A True Story of Violence, Race, and Justice Lost & Found” (RiverHead Books)

SILVER: Jim Ross, editor, Ocala, “In Season: Stories of Discovery, Loss, Home, and Places in Between” (University Press of Florida)

BRONZE: Bruce Horovitz, Jacksonville, “Gamble Rogers: A Troubadour's Life” (University Press of Florida)



General Fiction

GOLD: Kimberly Lojewski, Ocala, “Worm Fiddling Nocturne in the Key of a Broken Heart” (Burrow Press)

SILVER: Ron Cooper, Ocala, “All My Sins Remembered” (Goliad Press)

BRONZE: Gale Massey, St. Petersburg, “The Girl from Blind River” (Crooked Lane)



General Nonfiction

GOLD: Dawn Davies, Fort Lauderdale, “Mothers of Sparta” (Flatiron Books)

SILVER: Kevin Begos, Apalachicola, “Tasting the Past: The Science of Flavor & the Search for the Origins of Wine” (Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill)

BRONZE: Luis Martínez-Fernández, Orlando, “Key to the New World: A History of Early Colonial Cuba” (University Press of Florida)



Poetry

GOLD: Erica Dawson, Tampa, “When Rap Spoke Straight to God” (Tin House Books)

SILVER: D.M. Aderibigbe, Tallahassee, “How the End First Showed” (University of Wisconsin Press)

BRONZE: Erin Hoover, Tallahassee, “Barnburner” (Elixir Press)

Popular Fiction

GOLD: Michael Jordan, Longboat Key, “Company of Demons” (Greenleaf Book Group Press)

SILVER: Veronica H. Hart, Ormond Beach, “The Knife” (Paranormalice Press)

BRONZE: Tom Lowe, Windermere, “The Jefferson Prophecy” (Kingsbridge Entertainment)

Spanish Language

GOLD: Hernán Vera Álvarez, Miami, “La librería del mal salvaje” (Suburbano Ediciones)

SILVER: Glenda Galán, Miami, “Ventanas: Entrevistas de Glenda Galán a escritores latinoamericanos” (Grupo Editorial)

BRONZE: Félix Anesio, Miami, “Los cuervos y la infamia” (Betania)

Visual Arts

GOLD: Richard Shieldhouse, Jacksonville, “William Morgan: Evolution of an Architect” (University Press of Florida)

SILVER: Sharon Koskoff, Delray Beach, “Murals of the Palm Beaches” (Acadia Publishing)

BRONZE: Andre Frattino, Gainesville, “A Land Remembered: A Graphic Novel” (Pineapple Press)

Young Adult

GOLD: Tara Lynn Masih, St. Augustine, “My Real Name Is Hanna” (Mandel Vilar Press)

SILVER: Kristina Neihouse, Key West, “Knowing When to Leave” (SeaStory Press)

Submissions for the 2018 awards were read by juries of three members, who were nominated by co-sponsoring organizations from across the state. Jurors are authorized to select up to three medalists (one gold winner, one silver runner-up and one bronze medalist) in each of the 11 categories; jurors are also authorized to make no selections in a given year.

The Florida State University Libraries coordinate the Florida Book Awards with assistance from co-sponsors, including the the State Library and Archives of Florida; the Florida Humanities Council and the Florida Library Association.

Learn more about the Florida Book Awards at floridabookawards.lib.fsu.edu.

Title: Florida deputies find missing infant with parents
Summary:
Copyright 2019 Nexstar Broadcasting, Inc. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten, or redistributed. (Photo: Florida Department of Law Enforcement)

EDGEWATER, Fla. (AP) - Two parents wanted for disappearing with their 4-month-old daughter against a court order were arrested at a central Florida shopping mall.

The Volusia County Sheriff's Office says Chloe Wall and Elliot Singleton were found on Saturday with their daughter, Skylah Singleton, at an Orlando mall, more than 60 miles from where they had disappeared.

The sheriff's office says the parents had warrants charging them with concealing the location of a child contrary to a court order.

Deputies says Wall was arrested Tuesday on drug possession charges and Singleton also was arrested for resisting arrest without violence.

Child welfare officials conducted an investigation and concluded that Skylah should be taken into custody.

Deputies say the family didn't cooperate, and when the parents were released from jail, they disappeared with Skylah.
Address: 200 S Parker St, Tampa, FL 33606, USA

Title: Florida deputies say missing infant taken by parents
Summary:
Deputies in Florida are searching for the parents of a 4-month-old girl who authorities say illegally took their daughter following their release from jail on drug and resisting charges.

The Volusia County Sheriff's Office said Saturday that they were searching for Skylah Singleton who they believe was taken by one or both of her parents, 18-year-old Chloe Wall and 26-year-old Elliot Singleton.

Deputies says Wall was arrested Tuesday on drug possession charges and Singleton also was arrested for resisting arrest without violence.



The Florida Department of Children and Families conducted an investigation and concluded that Skylah should be taken into custody.

Deputies say the family didn't cooperate and when the parents were released from jail on Tuesday they disappeared with Skylah.

Title: Inside South Florida: “Legally Blonde” Comes to Town
Summary:
Please enable Javascript to watch this video

Women, unite! It’s the ultimate theatrical tribute to girl power as Legally Blonde: The Musical makes a South Florida stop this Saturday at the South Miami-Dade Cultural Arts Center. There are two shows: 3 pm and 8 pm. It’s based off the hugely successful movie that starred Reese Witherspoon and you can follow Elle Woods, sorority girl turned Harvard lawyer, as she confronts stereotypes, sexism, cheating boyfriends and manipulative mentors.

Throughout the show, no one has faith in Elle, but she manages to surprise them all when she defies expectations while staying true to herself. There’s great music, a great message, and of course, Elle’s adorable dog Bruiser. What could be better than that?

For tickets and more information, head to smdcac.org.

Title: Pirates earn diamond split with Father Lopez
Summary:
Chad Taylor drove in four runs during three separate rallies Friday night and Nathan Quinn handcuffed the Green Wave batters for six innings to give the Pirates a 7-1 win and a split of the season series in district games last week.

Matanzas knocked out eight hits in the game, including a fifth-inning double by Andrew Butler, who also scored twice. Sean Sparling singled and scored a run and Joseph Alvarado was 2-for-3 with a run scored for the Pirates.

Quinn benefitted from timely hitting and his own ability to throw strikes. He fanned 12 over the course of six innings and gave up a paltry three hits. A third-inning single by the Wave’s Grayson Chastain drove in the visitors’ lone run.

Cameron Quintana pitched one inning of scoreless relief for the Pirates.

Father Lopez 8, Matanzas 2: In the opening game of the series March 26, the Green Wave touched Matanzas starter Eric Libby for seven hits and seven runs, only four earned, over five complete innings. The Pirates avoided a shutout in the top of the seventh trailing 8-0 when Alvarado hit an RBi double and Kyle Perry drove in another run on a fielder’s choice ground out.

TRACK AND FIELD

ERAU Spikes Classic: Three Flagler Palm Coast competitors won events and two relay teams held first place over the weekend at the ERAU Spikes Classic at Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University in Daytona Beach.

The Bulldogs boys’ team got wins from Ken’Deric Morton in the 300 hurdles in 39.93 seconds and Nikita Roumianstev in the high jump with a top performance of 5-5¾. Tallin Coates took second in the 110 hurdles in 15.56 seconds and FPC placed in seven other individual events. The team got a win in the 4x400 relay in a time of 3:28.69 with Ryan Clark, Morton, Jason Chum and Jones running the race.

Triple jumper Prosperity Wright was the only girl on the FPC team to win an individual event when she jumped 36 feet 8½ inches and teammate Dyman Howard jumped 34-9 for second in the event. The two were joined by Susann Kaufmann and Tara Tallaksen for first in the 4x100 relay, timed at 49.55 seconds.

Kaufmann, Otyana Clayton and Talleksen gave FPC a 4-7-8 finish in the 100 meter dash with Kaufmann’s 12.85 leading that effort. Jahlia McCaskell placed third in the 300 hurdles at 47/10 seconds and fourth in the 100 hurdles at 17.10 seconds. Jada Williams took sixth in the 1,600 meter run in 5:46.78 and Haley Olsen was eighth in the 3,200 in 14:17.90.

FPC’s boys team took third in two events with De’Shaun Hugee throwing 131-9 in the discus and Clark running the 400 in 52.42 seconds. Morton took fourth in the 400 meters in 22.50, Chum was fourth in the 800 at 2:07.21, Curt Gray also was fourth in the triple jump in 41-11¾ and Brandon Eatman fourth in the shot put in 39-2¼. Diego Carrascosa was sixth in the 1,600 meters at 4:49.48.

PEPSI RELAYS

Miley, Paul lead Bulldogs: Jacob Miley and Nelson Paul gave Flagler Palm Coast a pair of fifth-place finishes over the weekend at the annual relay event at the University of Florida featuring collegiate teams and elite high school performers from across the state.

Miley ran his top time of the year in the 800 meters in a time of 1:53.26 for fifth place, a split-second behind Bolles runner Chase Rivera in the battle for fourth. The race was won by Piper’s Sukell Foucha in 1:51.19. FPC’s Shawn Gordon just missed a medal finish with a 1:58.03 for 10th place while five other Bulldogs, Darrell Thomas, Wes Magnell, JT Dahlberg, Nathan Farrell and Gus Healy also competed in the half mile event.

The Bulldogs also got a fifth-place showing from Paul in the shot put, when he had one of his top throws of the year at 53-6½. FPC’s 4x800 relay team had a top place in third with a time of 7:58.18. Farrell was 11th in the 110 hurdles (14.57) and Verneal Henshaw was a finalist in the discus in 15th place at 133-2.

TENNIS

FPC boys win 4 of 7 in finals: Brothers Eric and Daniel Berenblit along with teammate Matt Pokorny gave Flagler Palm Coast wins in four of seven finals matches as well as the overall singles and doubles championship at the Five Star Conference championships Wednesday and Thursday last week in Daytona Beach.

Eric Berenblit won the No. 1 singles title with a 6-0, 6-1 victory over Spruce Creek’s Luke Paschal in the championship finals. His younger brother, Daniel, won No. 2 singles with a 6-2, 6-1 win over Creek’s Andre Cronje. Pokorny took the No. 3 singles title match 6-2, 6-2 over Daniel Cronje. The Berenblit brothers won the No. 1 doubles match in a pivotal match, as Spruce Creek won NO. 4 and No. 5 singles and No. 2 doubles.

WEIGHTLIFTING

Region 4-2A championships: Matanzas lifters Will Lam and Skyler Michaud-Williams and Flagler Palm Coast’s Dominique Bennett won individual titles Friday night in the Region 4-2A championships to earn automatic berths in the upcoming state tournament at Panama City Beach.

Lam won the 169-pound title with a 645-pound combined lift that was one of the top efforts at the meet, including lifters in three higher classifications. Lam did 355 pounds on his bench press and 290 in the clean and jerk.

Michaud-Williams won the 219-pound class with a 635 combined lift that included a 340 on the bench and 295 in the clean and jerk.

Bennett was champion in the lightest weight classification, 119, when he did a 185-170—355 finish on hisbest attempts. Spruce Creek led the tournament at FPC with four of 10 weight class champions and Winter Springs had two champions.

-- Andy Mikula
Address: 901 6th St, Daytona Beach, FL 32117, USA

Title: Face the fear of fundraising with focus on mission |Notes on Nonprofits
Summary:
Buy Photo Alyce Lee Stansbury (Photo: Democrat files)

For many board members, asking for money is their biggest fear and most daunting board responsibility. For Executive Directors, fundraising without board involvement is a frustrating, unrelenting challenge. Given the unpredictability of public funding, changing legislative and funder priorities, and shifting donor interests, it is a good time to revisit my previous column on facing the fear of fundraising.



It might surprise people to know I haven’t always loved asking for money. As a child, the only fundraising I was good at was selling Girl Scout cookies. I’ve always contended this is because thin mints practically sell themselves! To be successful, all I had to do was show up in my uniform, circle the neighborhood with my red wagon full of cookies, and ring the doorbell.

People knew instantly why I was there and quickly scanned my wagon to see if I had their favorite variety. At one point in my cookie career, I was the top salesperson for my troop. As I look back on this, I realize how similar that process is to the fundraising I help my clients do now. Half the job is showing up, being credible, and putting your worthy cause in front of someone who knows and believes in your product.

Facing the twin fears of rejection and failure are what most people dread most about fundraising. A great deal of my work is teaching people how to face these fears by finding their niche in the fund development process, being an advocate for the mission, and remembering they are not asking for themselves but for a worthy cause. This includes learning how to listen to what’s important to donors as part of earning the right to ask.

For me, asking for a gift is a privilege and an opportunity to change or save a life. I’m also a big believer that practice is the best teacher. There’s no substitute for asking and learning how to get better with every ask.

According to Leading with Intent: A National Index of Nonprofit Board Practices, 60% of CEOs and 58% of board chairs identify fundraising as one of the most important areas for board improvement. This statistic mirrors my experience as a fundraising professional, consultant, and board member.

Over the past 25 years, I’ve known board and staff members in all types and sizes of nonprofits who have bemoaned the task of fundraising. As a consultant, I received a call from a prospective client who began the conversation with a heavy sigh and in a despondent, defeated tone, said, “I’ve put this off as long as possible” because they didn’t want to fundraise but needed to learn. I’ve also seen nonprofit staff and volunteers face down their fear of fundraising and move past it, many with amazing success.

Although I’m a huge fan of what fundraising can do to change lives, I’ve never thought it was easy. Because it isn’t. And I’ve had more than my share of fearful moments, shaky asks, rejections, and outright disasters. In spite of this, I don’t believe fundraising is the drudgery some people think it is.

Hank Russo penned my favorite definition of fundraising: the gentle art of teaching people the joy of giving. It is not cold calling or arm twisting. Fundraising is talking with people about something they care about and giving them a meaningful opportunity to act on that feeling.

The best fundraisers I know are passionate advocates for the mission and helping donors accomplish their goals and dreams by making a gift. As author and blogger Jeff Brooks says, fundraisers have to speak to a donor’s dreams, and I agree.

Perhaps my cookie sales did more to lay the ground work for my life’s work than I thought. With or without cookie selling experience, I’m a firm believer most board and staff members can be successful fundraisers. I agree with grassroots fundraising author Kim Klein who says, “What you believe in has to be bigger than what you’re afraid of.”

It starts with showing up, listening to what donors are interested in, and when there’s a match, putting your worthy cause in front of them and asking. And remember, if you’re not asking, someone else is.

Alyce Lee Stansbury, CFRE is President of Stansbury Consulting. Kelly Otte,, MPA, is Executive Director of PACE Center for Girls Leon. They can be reached at notesonnonprofits@gmail.com.

Address: 277 N Magnolia Dr, Tallahassee, FL 32301, USA

Title: Marion County marks 175 years with celebratory festival Saturday
Summary:
The celebration at the McPherson Government Complex in Ocala featured music, food, speeches and celebrants in period clothing to commemorate the March 25, 1844, signing that formed Marion County from parts of Alachua, Mosquito (now Orange) and Hillsborough counties.

Marion County celebrated the 175th anniversary its founding on Saturday, with a celebration at the McPherson Government Complex in Ocala.

The celebration commemorated the signing on March 25, 1844, by Richard Keith Call, territorial governor, of legislation authorizing the formation of Marion County from parts of Alachua, Mosquito (now Orange) and Hillsborough counties. A year later, Florida was admitted to the union.

Settlers had agitated for the formation of Marion County because the nearest county seat was at Newnansville, now the town of Alachua, and the journey there was over 50 miles of all-but-impassable sand trails, Darrell G. Riley wrote in “Marion County History,” a 1997 Star-Banner special section.

“Not many people know we became a county a year before Florida became a state,” said Sheriff Billy Woods, dressed in 1840s-style clothing astride his horse, Bull, as he greeted attendees.

Michelle Stone, chairwoman of the Marion County Commission, opened the program with a welcome featuring local elected officials, among them State Sen. Dennis Baxley, R-Ocala.

“You’re building a great Florida future for those who come behind us,” Baxley told the audience. “We’re making history, recognizing that we stand on the shoulders of those who came before.”

But while the overall tone of Saturday’s event was celebratory, a roster of speakers giving 15-minute talks in the County Commission auditorium did not shy away from the harsher realities of county history.

Morrey Deen, a former Ocala chief of police, described a complicated and bloody series of events in the late 18th and early 19th centuries that brought Creek Indians and runaway African-American slaves to central Florida, evoking images of Spanish gunrunners, Andrew Jackson and bounty hunters hired by slave owners. He told of the Treaty of Moultrie Creek between the U.S. government and Native American tribal leaders that created a 4-million-acre Indian reservation that stretched from north of Ocala to south of Lakeland. Deen also recounted the aftermath of the Seminole Wars, in which the government relocated Seminole Indians from Florida to Oklahoma.

“The shame of it is, you know what we did?” Deen said. “(The U.S. government later) pushed them out of Oklahoma because we had the great land rush.”

Cynthia Wilson-Graham presented a talk on Paradise Park, the attraction on the Silver River, alongside Silver Springs, for African-American tourists. Wilson-Graham, author of “Remembering Paradise Park: Tourism and Segregation at Silver Springs,” noted that Silver Springs had a black workforce in the days of segregation that was barred from visiting the park as tourists.

“They could work there, they could garden, they could take guests on the boat rides, but they could not mingle with the guests,” she said.

Wilson-Graham said that until the desegregation of Silver Springs in 1969, both parks were marketed nationally to tourists and Paradise Park was home to large Labor Day celebrations and annual gatherings of Boy Scouts and Girl Scouts.

“The guests that went to Silver Springs had somewhere to stay,” Wilson-Graham said. “They could be accommodated in different hotels and motels, but for the guests of Paradise Park, they had maybe one or two hotels here. They had to basically, go and stay at houses with other people.”

Outside, Saturday’s event included festival-like touches like musical entertainment, food trucks and booths staffed by representatives of local government agencies, companies and nonprofit organizations.

Karin Ahrman of Ocala worked a booth for the Marion County chapter of Harley’s Dream, a nonprofit organization dedicated to banning commercial dog breeding enterprises known as “puppy mills.”

“The traffic’s been pretty good,” Ahrman said at about noon. “We’ve handed out about 150 temporary tattoos for children, 100 pet food lids and I don’t know how many of our bracelets.

“(Turnout) isn’t as big as I thought, but it’s starting to get crowded,” she said.

In the lobby of the commission auditorium, organizers displayed the contents for a time capsule to be opened in 25 years for the county bicentennial, including: badges contributed by local first-responder agencies; an anniversary proclamation from the Dunnellon City Council; and a shell casing found at the Ocklawaha site of the 1935 shootout between the Barker-Karpis gang and FBI agents that killed Ma Barker and her son, Fred, donated by George Albright, county tax collector.

At the close of the celebration, Brandon Kalloo, a public information officer with the county, said traffic counters were still tabulating figures but estimated the day’s attendance at “several thousand.”

Festivities were to conclude with night fireworks at the Marion County Veterans’ Park.
Address: 2121 SW 19th Avenue Rd, Ocala, FL 34471, USA

Title: EDUCATION BRIEFS: Girl's Night, Math and more
Summary:
GCSC hosts 'Girls' Night'

PANAMA CITY — Gulf Coast State College, Bay District Schools and local industry partners are hosting “Girls’ Night,” an event designed to provide middle school girls in the community with the opportunity to learn about STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering and Math) careers. They will be able to explore GCSC’s Advanced Technology Center and participate in fun, hands-on activities in Engineering, 3D Printing, Unmanned Vehicle Systems (UVS), Cybersecurity, Computer Science and Digital Design. Refreshments will also be provided.

The event will be on from 5:15–7:30 p.m. on April 18, in GCSC’s Advanced Technology Center. The event is free for girls in sixth through eighth grades, but space is limited. To reserve a spot, visit https://bit.ly/2UHxYKE. For details, contact Katie McCurdy at 850-767-4539 or Terry Holdnak at 850-767-5299.

FSU PC hosts 'Magnificent Math'

PANAMA CITY — The public is encouraged to engage in fun, hands-on activities at Magnificent Math, from noon to 3:30 p.m. on Sunday, March 31, in the St. Joe Lecture Hall at FSU Panama City. Students, teachers and professors will "play" with visitors of all ages to discover the fun of math and how it is used in their daily lives. For more details, contact Ginger Littleton at 850-770-2152 or glittleton@pc.fsu.edu.

32nd Annual Math Bowl

NICEVILLE — High school teams from across Northwest Florida competed in the 32nd annual Math Bowl at Northwest Florida State College on March 8. After a daylong competition consisting of written exams and ciphering matches, an awards ceremony was held for the event’s team and individual winners.

Team winners: Class X: first South Walton, second Chipley, third Seacoast; Class Y: first Collegiate High School at NWF State College, second Gulf Breeze, third Pensacola Catholic; Class Z: first: Rickards, second: Lincoln, third: Niceville.

Individual winners: Class X: first Mark Fisher (South Walton), second Leo Pan (Chipley), third Isabella Sniadecki (South Walton); Class Y: first Teertho Bhattacharya (Collegiate High), second Eric Fowler (Collegiate High), Yen Nguyen (Pensacola Catholic); Class Z: first Dylan Epstein-Gross (Rickards), second Rayyan Darji (Rickards), third Rohan Davidi (Rickards).

In addition to trophies for individual and team winners, the highest scoring student from each class and school were also given $10 gift cards to assorted restaurants.
Address: 501 W 11th St, Panama City, FL 32401, USA

Title: How is Meghan Markle winding down her pregnancy?
Summary:
If all goes according to plan, Meghan Markle and Prince Harry, the Duke and Duchess of Sussex, will welcome their first child likely in the next month or so.

The royal couple never released a firm due date, but most reports agree that the baby is likely expected in late April.

So, how is Markle, a glowing mom-to-be, keeping busy these days?

A source close to the couple spoke with Elle about that very topic, saying Markle is feeling great. She will continue working just a bit longer before taking a well-deserved break from royal engagements.

“The Duchess of Sussex is winding down her schedule by end of March,” the article says. “Though sources say she may do one more public engagement before the baby is due, Meghan has been holding several meetings privately related to her humanitarian work. Meghan had one such meeting last week.”

The royal couple also will move, which doesn’t sound very appealing toward the end of a pregnancy, although it seems as though this was beyond Markle and Prince Harry’s control.

The pair is slated to leave Kensington Palace -- which is also the estate where Prince William, Kate Middleton and their three children live -- and move into Frogmore Cottage.

Royal commentator Emily Andrews, of The Sun, tweeted about the Frogmore Cottage delays earlier in the week.

Update on #frogmorecottage: Harry & Meghan were due to move in this week just gone, but their move has been delayed by three weeks or so. The renovation work has been huge to turn this mini-mansion back into a family home so it’s no real surprise that builders fell behind 1/4 — Emily Andrews (@byEmilyAndrews) March 24, 2019

"Harry and Meghan kept changing their minds on design aspects, putting the builders back (like all homeowners ever -- they want it to be perfect!)," Andrews also said, according to published reports.

Elle reports that Frogmore Cottage is a 10-bedroom house given to the couple by the queen. The home “has more space for children” and Markle and Prince Harry even had their second wedding reception there, with the wedding ceremony itself nearby at Windsor Castle.

------

Related:

Odds are, new royal baby's name could be Diana if it's a girl | What title will Harry and Meghan's baby hold? | Could Meghan Markle ever be queen of England?

Graham Media Group 2019
Address: 4 Broadcast Pl, Jacksonville, FL 32207, USA

Title: Former Wakulla teacher gets 20 years in prison for child porn
Summary:
A former Wakulla County charter school music teacher was sentenced to 20 years in prison for taking and sharing sexual photos and maintaining lewd contact with a 13-year-old student.

Nicholas Hughes, 34, was sentenced to 20 years in prison in U.S. District Court Friday for taking and sharing sexual photos and maintaining lewd contact with a 13-year-old student. (Photo: Wakulla County Jail)

Nicholas Hughes was sentenced in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Florida Friday. He was convicted of enticement of a minor, production and possession of child pornography on Jan. 4.

Throughout the 2016-2017 school year Hughes, then a teacher at Coast Charter Schools in St. Marks, and the girl had various sexual encounters. They communicated via social media, cell phone and texts and send pornographic photos back and forth.

Hughes was arrested at his home in Leon County in Nov. 2017. Investigators seized a laptop, camera and cellphone used to transmit the images and communicate.

In his announcement of the sentence, U.S. Attorney Lawrence Keefe said Hughes violated the trust placed in educators.

“Children see their teachers as role models and mentors, and in this tragic case, the defendant took advantage of that trust,” Keefe said in a statement. “Together with our federal, state, and local law enforcement partners, we will pursue child predators and bring them to justice.”

Contact Karl Etters at ketters@tallahassee.com or @KarlEtters on Twitter

Title: Missing Palm Bay teen found in South Carolina; mother arrested, police say
Summary:
CLOSE Tips on what to do when someone you care about goes missing. Video by Jordan Fenster/lohud Wochit

An Amber Alert for a Palm Bay teenager was canceled Thursday after the girl was found in South Carolina, police said.

Two people were arrested in connection with her disappearance.

Sophia Diaz, 15, was reported missing overnight from the 2800 block of College View Drive in Melbourne.

She was safe in police custody Thursday morning after being located at an RV park in Fair Play, South Carolina, a small town about 45 miles southwest of Greenville.

"Detectives from the Special Victims Unit worked throughout the night following investigative leads and working with FDLE and FBI to locate the victim," Palm Bay police said in a news release.

Police said Karis Diaz (left) and Curtis Clemons were arrested in connection with Sophia's disappearance. (Photo: CONTRIBUTED PHOTOS BY FLORIDA DEPARTMENT OF LAW ENFORCEMENT)

Sophia's mother, 37-year-old Karis Diaz and 33-year-old Curtis Clemons were arrested on felony charges of interference with child custody.

They will be extradited back to Brevard County to appear in court.

Title: FWB family lovingly remembers daughter
Summary:
FORT WALTON BEACH — She obsessed over unicorns, acted like a comedian and earned straight A's in fourth grade at Kenwood Elementary School.



The family of 10-year-old Skyla Morgan Schindler, or “Skyla Boo” as they called her, had the life she loved taken from her when she collided with a tree skiing at Breckenridge Ski Resort near Denver on Thursday, March 21. Her family annually took skiing trips.



One of the fondest memories the family has of their bubbly little girl involves unicorns. Skyla often said she was a unicorn. She and her dad would laugh and laugh about the rainbow-colored soap at the car wash. They pretended it was actually unicorn poop and the reason their car turned out so shiny.



A spitting image of her mother, Skyla was outgoing, smart, adventurous, bold, had a huge heart and was all smiles, the family said.



She also loved being outdoors on the water with her family. Additionally, she enjoyed playing softball as a catcher and outfielder.



Besides unicorns, the family recalled her other favorite things were the color purple and eating chicken caesar salad.



In an email to the Daily News, the family invited the community to join them as they plan on “celebrating Skyla’s amazing life and outgoing personality” at a memorial in her honor at 6:30 p.m. Saturday at The Gulf on the Okaloosa Island.
Address: 2 Eglin Pkwy NE, Fort Walton Beach, FL 32548, USA

Title: Baby's body found buried in flower pot at cemetery
Summary:
Copyright 2019 Nexstar Broadcasting, Inc. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten, or redistributed. File photo. (Photo by Matthew Lloyd/Getty Images)

(WFLA) - Texas authorities are working to identify the remains of an infant who was found buried inside of a flower pot at a cemetery.

Carrollton police said the remains of a newborn girl were discovered by a caretaker at Perry Cemetery on March 3 as they were removing soil from a flower pot that seemed "out of place."

The girl is said to have been born somewhere between 34 weeks gestation and full term. She weighed about 6 pounds and still had her umbilical cord attached. Her race is not yet known.

It's unclear whether she was born alive.

Investigators suspect the girl's body was placed in cemetery sometime between Wednesday, Feb. 27 and Saturday, March 2.

Those with information about the child are being asked to contact Detective Jennifer Cackler at 972-466-3324, or by email at Jennifer.Cackler@CityofCarrollton.com.
Address: 200 S Parker St, Tampa, FL 33606, USA

Title: Police officer jailed on child rape charge
Summary:
JACKSONVILLE — Authorities said a Florida police officer faces rape charges after an image of a nude girl was found on his cellphone.

Jacksonville Undersheriff Pat Ivey said 39-year-old Officer Matthew Harper Butler was charged Tuesday with capital sexual battery of a victim under 12 years old. He remains in jail and bond was set at $1 million.

The Florida Times-Union reported the agency's integrity unit received a tip on Friday about the cellphone image.

Butler is a nine-year veteran of the department. No other information about the girl or Butler's relationship to her was released.

On Sunday, sheriff's officials arrested another Jacksonville officer on aggravated assault charges for threatening his girlfriend and two other women with a gun.

An attorney for Butler wasn't listed on jail records.
Address: 300 W Lime St, Lakeland, FL 33815, USA

Title: Cape Coral, Lee County School District to analyze bus stop safety after student deaths
Summary:
CLOSE It was a dangerous year on Lee and Collier roads in 2018. Megan Kearney, mkearney@news-press.com

Cape Coral plans to work with the Lee County School District to address bus stop safety, after an 8-year-old girl was killed waiting at a bus stop on Monday in Cape Coral.

Layla Aiken was the second student pedestrian killed in Lee County this year, after 12-year-old Alana Tamplin was killed in January by a driver near her home in North Fort Myers.

In a news release sent Wednesday afternoon, the City of Cape Coral's Public Information Specialist said the city has formed a partnership with Lee County School District staff to analyze best practices for students at bus stops.

"Traffic safety solutions, education, volunteer programs, review of best practices nationwide, and the timeframe and costs to implement any changes will be considered," the release reads.

More: Fundraisers for 8-year-old killed in hit-and-run garnering community support

Meanwhile, fundraising for Layla's family is growing. Well-wishers have raised more than $60,000 for her family.

A total of $61,009 was donated as of Wednesday morning from two online fundraisers for Layla — one on Facebook, which garnered $54,364 and one on GoFundMe, which garnered $6,645.

Josh Jasilewicz, a lineman for an electric company, came to pay his respects Tuesday afternoon and delivered a teddy bear to the memorial site for Layla Aiken visible on the corner of NE 3rd Avenue and NE 19th Terrace in Cape Coral. Layla Aiken was killed while waiting for her school bus Monday morning. (Photo: Ricardo Rolon/The News-Press USA TODAY NETWORK - FLORIDA)

The fundraiser pages are rife with messages of support for Layla's family. "Our hearts ache over your loss... our thoughts are with you during this difficult time," one contributor wrote. Another said "RIP, sweet girl."

Layla was sitting with her older twin brothers on the edge of the roadway on the northeast corner of Northeast 19th Terrace around 6:20 a.m. Monday when a truck traveling south on NE 3rd Avenue struck and rolled over her.

More: What we know: Cape Coral girl hit and killed at bus stop

More: Cape Coral police seize truck, eye person of interest in hit-and-run that killed 8-year-old girl

CONSIDER SUBSCRIBING TODAY: Help support local journalism

Layla Aiken, 8, was killed in a hit-and-run while waiting at her school bus stop. (Photo: Special to the News-Press)

Police said the driver took off away from the scene, and Layla was taken to the hospital, where she died.

Police said Tuesday that they seized the red truck they believe is involved in the hit and run, and have developed a person of interest in the case. Investigators are not releasing details about the person's identity "as the investigation is still in its infancy," a news release said.

Community members are also paying tribute to Layla through a roadside memorial, with supporters leaving notes, pictures, flowers and mementos.

A memorial including notes, flowers, balloons and plush animals, is now visible on the corner of NE 3rd Avenue and NE 19th Terrace in Cape Coral Tuesday afternoon at the site were Layla Aiken was killed while waiting for her school bus. (Photo: Ricardo Rolon/The News-Press USA TODAY NETWORK - FLORIDA)

The Cape Coral Police Department is still investigating the case and is working with the state attorney's office.

"The lead investigator and other Cape Coral Police personnel are working diligently to resolve this tragic case with the correct disposition based on the totality of the investigation as soon as possible," a Tuesday news release said.

Police said they have been collecting surveillance video from the area. If you believe you have video or other information about this case, you can contact the Cape Coral Police Department at 239-574-3223 or submit an anonymous tip here. You can also text a tip to CRIMES (274637) by including "CCPD+" before your message.
