Title: Melbourne nurse saves girl's life while staying at Orlando hotel
Summary:
As hotel guests watched in a state of panic when a young girl was pulled from an Orlando resort pool, a Melbourne nurse said she stayed calm and focused to help save the girl's life.

Nurse Laura Dalton, of Holmes Regional Medical Center, said she was celebrating her wedding anniversary at the Rosen Shingle Creek Resort Saturday when a 4-year-old girl nearly drowned.

"The child was lifeless," Dalton said.

Dalton said the girl was blue when she began performing CPR. After about 10 rounds of CPR, the child was resuscitated.

#GoodNews: @Health_First nurse performs CPR saving the life of a 4-year-old who nearly drowned in a hotel pool. Our interview with nurse Laura Dalton on @news6wkmg at 6 and 7 #GettingResults pic.twitter.com/qYdELHP2Ny

-- James Sparvero (@News6James) March 26, 2019


"Your skills just take over," Dalton said.

The lifesaving encounter could not have happened without help from Dalton's family. Two days earlier, Dalton's mother-in-law surprised her with the resort stay as an anniversary gift.

Dalton said she's thought many times since the incident that if she were not there, the girl may have died.

"The whole time I was doing CPR, I just was praying to God so I do feel like it was all in God's hands for that little girl to make it," Dalton said.

It was the first time in her eight years as a nurse she had to perform CPR, Dalton said.

Dalton said the child was likely an international tourist because she did not speak English and she did not get the chance to speak with the girl's parents.

In a gesture of appreciation, the hotel treated Dalton and her family to free meals and the hotel promised her a free stay in the future.

Dalton hopes this story encourages more people to learn CPR and to teach their children how to swim.
Address: 4466 N John Young Pkwy, Orlando, FL 32804, USA

Title: Man accused of having sex with 13-year-old girl
Summary:
- Marion County deputies arrested a 22-year-old man accused of having sex with a 13-year-old girl.

Deputies arrested Jonathan Doody II, after they say the teenage victim came forward saying she and Doody has sex several times in the summer of 2018.

The victim told deputies that she learned Doody had been arrsted in January for lewd and lascivious molestation on a 15-year-old victim, prompting her to come forward.

Deputies say Doody denied having sex with the 13-year-old, saying she had never been to his house before.

Detectives believe their could be more victims in this case. Anyone with information is asked to call Detective Pinder at 352-368-3508.

Title: Police searching for 14-year-old girl missing out of Haines City
Summary:
- 14-year-old Mercedes McLeod is missing out of Haines City, the city's police department said.

The Haines City Police Department posted on Facebook that Mercedes was last seen at about 7 p.m. on Monday leaving her grandmother's house in the Randa Ridge subdivision.

Mercedes was reported missing by her grandmother, who told police that Mercedes was planning to attend a party in Lakeland on Monday night but was not allowed to go. Officers said that they went to the location of the party, but she was not there.

The grandmother also reportedly police that Mercedes has run away on two prior occasions. She is not thought to be endangered at this time and she does not take any medication.

Mercedes is described by police as 5'2'' and about 120 pounds. She was last seen wearing black and white shorts with a gray jacket.

Anyone with any information on Mercedes' whereabouts is asked to call police at 863-421-3636.

This story was written out of Orlando, Florida.

Title: Pembroke Pines man accused of molesting girl over course of 10 years
Summary:
Wayne Lincoln Chin, 57, is accused of molesting and raping a girl over the course of 10 years.

PEMBROKE PINES, Fla. - A Pembroke Pines man was arrested Monday on accusations that he molested and raped a girl numerous times over the course of 10 years.

According to an arrest report, the incidents began in 1998 when the alleged victim was 4 years old and continued until she was 14.

Pembroke Pines police said the victim, now 25, told detectives that Wayne Lincoln Chin, 57, started the abuse by touching her breasts and vagina under her clothing while telling her, "Just relax."

Police said he later began digitally penetrating her and eventually forced her to engage in oral sex and intercourse.

According to the arrest report, it has been five years since the victim last communicated with Chin.

Police said multiple controlled calls were placed with the accuser and Chin, in which Chin admitted to engaging in sex acts with her, bragged about taking her virginity and told her he loved and missed her.

Authorities said Chin asked the victim to meet him this week to engage in sex acts.

Chin was taken into custody Monday on charges of sexual assault on a minor and lewd and lascivious molestation of a minor.

Police said Chin claimed he only engaged in sex acts with the victim when she was an adult, however authorities said he contradicted himself multiple times during questioning and told detectives, "How can you arrest me for something I did 20 years ago?"

Police said he also claimed, "I did not rape her. I just lay in her bed and sleep with her."

Chin is being held at the Broward County Jail.

Police said they received unconfirmed information that Chin previously worked as a soccer coach in Pembroke Pines during the late 1990s and early 2000s.

"If accurate, he would have had contact with several juveniles during said timeframe," the Police Department said in a news release. "Due to the nature of this incident, the possibility exists that there may be additional victims related to this crime."

Anyone who believes they or their child were victimized by Chin is asked to call the Pembroke Pines Police Department or Broward Crime Stoppers at 954-493-8477.

Copyright 2019 by WPLG Local10.com - All rights reserved.
Address: 3401 W Hallandale Beach Blvd, Pembroke Park, FL 33023, USA

Title: Tallahassee man charged with rape of girl
Summary:
A man who twice skirted Department of Children and Families sexual abuse investigations is now facing criminal charges of sexual assault with a minor.

Jason Bembry, 38, faces charges of capital sexual battery and lewd and lascivious battery in connection with what investigators say was the repeated rape a 14-year-old girl. He is being held without bail in the Leon County Detention Facility.

She reported to Tallahassee Police investigators that Bembry began sexually assaulting her when she was in fifth grade.

Jason Bembry, 38, faces charges of capital sexual battery and lewd and lascivious battery in connection with what investigators say was the repeated rape a 14-year-old girl. He is being held without bail in the Leon County Detention Facility. (Photo: Leon County Detention Center)

She said on multiple occasions Bembry raped her after contacting her on social media. He also threatened to blackmail the girl by telling her mother about the social media posts.

Bembry was accused in two different cases, in Dade and Broward counties, of having sex with minors in 2010. The claims that Bembry was having sex with a 9 year-old and had been having sex with another minor since age 12 were unsubstantiated.

Title: Family members indicted in deaths of girl, boy found buried
Summary:
Effingham County Sheriff's Office booking photos of a father, stepmother and three other family members indicted in the deaths of a 14-year-old sister and brother.

GUYTON, Ga. - Five relatives charged in the death of a Georgia girl now faces charges in the death of her brother as well.

The Savannah Morning News reported their father, 50-year-old Elwyn Crocker Sr., their stepmother and three others are each indicted on two charges of felony murder, child cruelty and concealing a death.

Effingham County sheriff's investigators say a tip led authorities in December to the bodies of 14-year-olds Mary Crocker and Elwyn Crocker Jr, which were buried in their father's yard. Both had been homeschooled and never reported missing.

The indictment issued last week alleges that like his sister, Elwyn had been beaten, starved and kept in a dog crate.

Authorities said all five defendants were moved out of the Effingham County to separate jail locations for their safety.

The defendants are set to be arraigned next month.

Summary:
Copyright 2019 Nexstar Broadcasting, Inc. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten, or redistributed.

HIGH SPRINGS, Fla. (WESH) - A 2-year-old boy in Alachua County was mauled to death by two dogs Friday at his family’s home.

Officials with the Alachua County Sheriff’s Office said the attack happened around 10:30 a.m. at a home on Northwest 210th Avenue in High Springs.

Deputies said a woman was hospitalized with traumatic injuries. The boy was pronounced dead at the house.

Related Content:

Clearwater woman cleared over baby girl's dog mauling death

Title: Men shouted racial slurs before shooting at children in Lake County, police say
Summary:
Men shouted racial slurs before shooting at children in Lake County, police say

Two men are facing hate crime charges after deputies said they yelled racial slurs and then fired shots at two children near Leesburg. Officials with the Lake County Sheriff’s Office said James Reidnauer and Brent van Besein fired shots at a 16-year-old boy and 12-year-old girl as they were walking home from a convenience store. According to an arrest affidavit, it started when the children took a shortcut on their way home from the store. Reidnauer asked what they were doing and the boy responded that they were just walking home. The children said Reidnauer then fired a shot into the ground and van Besien used a racial slur and fired a shotgun near where they were standing. The kids ran home and told their mother, who called the police. Reidnauer told deputies he had fired a warning shot at “two meth heads walking through the area because they were acting suspiciously.” Both men denied using racial slurs. They are facing hate crime charges of aggravated battery with a firearm. Nobody was hurt.

Title: Man turns the tables on pair of crooks trying to invade his home
Summary:
A South Florida man turned the tables on a pair of crooks early Thursday morning after they tried to storm into his home in northwest Miami-Dade.

"I felt like if I was to die right there they would kill my grandmother and great-grandmother, Lord forbid -- God forbid," Pherrick Thomas said.

Thomas told Local 10 News that someone knocked on his back door at 2 a.m. Thursday.

He said he opened the door to find a girl he knew standing there. Soon after, he was greeted with a gun by another man.

"We were talking, trying to catch up. It was 2 in the morning, and the next thing you know a man with a rifle ran up talking about, 'Give me everything,'" Thomas said.

A struggle unfolded at the home on Northwest 85th Street, where Thomas lives with his grandmother and great-grandmother.

The two elderly women tried to defend themselves from the man and woman invading their home.
Thomas said his grandmother fought back with a brick while he took the man's gun.

"I turned the rifle around just in time," he said. "I had enough strength from seeing them hit my grandmother to actually shoot the man."

Thomas said an officer patrolling around the corner heard the shots and responded immediately.

The two suspects left in a car but were later captured by police, authorities said.

The unidentified man was taken to Jackson Memorial Hospital to be treated for his gunshot wound and the woman was taken into custody.

Thomas sustained a few scratches and a gash above his eye during the incident.

"They wasn't strong enough," he said. "The devil wasn't strong enough."
Address: 3401 W Hallandale Beach Blvd, Pembroke Park, FL 33023, USA

Title: Missing Palm Bay teen found in South Carolina; 2 arrested, police say
Summary:
CLOSE Tips on what to do when someone you care about goes missing. Video by Jordan Fenster/lohud Wochit

An Amber Alert for a Palm Bay teenager was canceled Thursday after the girl was found in South Carolina, police said.

Two people were arrested in connection with her disappearance.

Sophia Diaz, 15, was reported missing overnight from the 2800 block of College View Drive in Melbourne.

She was safe in police custody Thursday morning after being located in Fair Play, South Carolina, a small town about 45 miles southwest of Greenville.

Investigators believed Sophia had been abducted by her mother, 37-year-old Karis Diaz, and 33-year-old Curtis Clemons, Palm Bay police said early Thursday.

Diaz and Clemons were charged with felony interference with child custody, police said.

A 14-YEAR-OLD SAYS SHE HAD SEX WITH THE 22-YEAR-OLD TWICE WHEN SHE WAS 13. ONCE IN HIS BEDROOM, AND AGAIN IN A WOODED AREA NEAR HIS HOME. ARREST DOCUMENTS SHOW THE GIRL IS ABLE TO DESCRIBE WHAT THE INSIDE OF DOODY’S BEDROOM LOOKS LIKE, AND SHE MENTIONED SEEING AN ALIEN POSTER WITH A CAPTION READING, "TAKE ME TO YOUR DRUG DEALER." DETECTIVES THEN WENT TO THE OCALA MAN’S HOME TO ASK HIM ABOUT THE ALLEGATIONS LAST TUESDAY. DOODY DENIED HAVING SEX WITH THE UNDERAGE GIRL, AND SAYS HE NEVER EVEN LET HER INSIDE HIS HOME. HOWEVER, HE DID ADMIT HE OWNS AN ALIEN POSTER WITH THE SAME CAPTION THE VICTIM DESCRIBED. INVESTIGATORS DECIDE THE VICTIM’S STORY IS ACCURATE ENOUGH TO ARREST DOODY ON TUESDAY. HE FACES TWO LEWD BATTERY ON A 12-TO-16-YEAR-OLD CHARGES. DEPUTIES SAY THE GIRL FIRST CAME FORWARD AFTER HEARING ABOUT DOODY BEING ARRESTED IN JANUARY. AN ARREST REPORT SHOWS A 15-YEAR-OLD ALSO CLAIMS SHE HAD SEX WITH HIM IN LATE DECEMBER. IN THE REPORT, THIS VICTIM SAYS SHE TOLD DOODY HER TRUE AGE. THE 22-YEAR-OLD ADMITTED TO HAVING SEXUAL INTERCOURSE WITH THE UNDERAGE GIRL, BUT PROSECUTORS DROPPED THE CHARGES IN THAT CASE THE STATE ATTORNEY’S OFFICE HAS NOT OUGHT BACK TO US ABOUT WHY CHARGES FROM JANUARY WERE DROPPED. Title: Man accused of molesting girl for 10 years
Summary:
A man who possibly worked as a soccer coach in South Florida is accused of molesting a girl for ten years, starting when she was four years old.

Pembroke Pines Police arrested 57-year-old Wayne Lincoln Chin on charges of sexual assault and lewd and lascivious behavior.

Investigators said the alleged victim is now an adult who came forward to report the molestation that she claimed happened between 1998 and 2008.

Police said Chin may have once worked as a soccer coach in Pembroke Pines during the late 1990s or early 2000s. They have not been able to confirm the information. However, If confirmed, authorities fear there may be more victims. Any one with information is being asked to call police at 954-431-2200.

Title: FHP: 3 children among 7 injured when SUV strikes tree, overturns
Summary:
ALACHUA COUNTY, Fla. - Three children and four adults were injured, including one critically, in a single-vehicle crash early Monday afternoon in Alachua County, the Florida Highway Patrol said.

According to the Highway Patrol, a Ford Escape was traveling north on County Road 225 about 12:15 p.m. when, for unknown reasons, the SUV went off the road, struck a tree and overturned, ejecting three passengers.

Troopers said the driver, a 33-year-old woman, and five passengers -- a 36-year-old woman, a 22-year-old man, a 9-year-old boy, a 12-year-old girl and a 10-year-old girl -- were taken to UF Health Shands Hospital in Gainesville with serious injuries. A sixth passenger, an 18-year-old woman, was taken to the hospital with critical injuries.

According to the FHP report, only the driver and the 12-year-old girl were wearing seat belts.

All seven people in the SUV were from Starke, the FHP report shows.

The Highway Patrol said it continues to investigate and charges are pending.

Officials with the Alachua County Sheriff’s Office said the attack happened around 10:30 a.m. at a home on Northwest 210th Avenue in High Springs.

Title: Running with brushes: Naples Art Association hits 65 years in full stride
Summary:
Just eight days before her death in 1954, the colorful, intense artist Frida Kahlo splashed a title on her last painting, a symbolic array of plump watermelons: "Viva la Vida." Live the life.

It could have been the charter for the nascent organization being forged far away in Florida. That same year, 37 artists, an impressive number in the small fishing and vacation spot of Naples, banded together as the Naples Art Association. Their mission: to promote local art, show it and even teach it in Collier County schools until it became an approved part of the curriculum.

Annie Hagstrom, right, talks to instructor Diane Reed Eiler, left, about her painting during an oil and acrylic painting class at the Naples Art Association in Naples on Wednesday, March 27, 2019. (Photo: Alex Driehaus/Naples Daily News USA TODAY NETWORK - FLORIDA)

Those founding artists succeeded beyond their wildest dreams:

Naples Art Association now offers three annual shows that turn Fifth Avenue South into a sea of nearly 250 American artists and six local "Art in the Park" shows during visitor season. (The last one until autumn is next Saturday, April 6; see the information box.)

Some 925 children painted and sprayed, chiseled, rolled and spun art last summer at the association's annual ARTScool in its 585 Park Street building. Another 325 did the same at four outlying schools in a premiere "ARTScool to You." This year 500 children will learn art in five summer schools.

Adult learning now embraces 200 classes annually. They span cold-wax painting — creating ripples and bubbles in a finish — to pottery, blown glass, portrait painting, pastels and the artful slabs of palette knife technique.

Monthly and bimonthly exhibitions offer local art and juried works such as are in the current Florida Artists Group Annual Statewide Exhibition. Up next will be Camera USA, a local favorite that brings in a slew of outstanding works from around the U.S.

Art Hub session brings artists together, and exhibitor talks let the public hear what is on individual artists' minds and in their hearts. Dinner with the Artist pairs a chef and a working artist to share their processes and their personal stories to small dinner groups.

The organization celebrates 65 years of "living the life" in its annual "For the Love of Art" fundraiser Saturday, April 6. There's a Great Gatsby-Roaring Twenties theme, appropriate for an organization that plans to roar into its second 65 years.

Barbara Richardson starts a painting during an oil and acrylic painting class at the Naples Art Association in Naples on Wednesday, March 27, 2019. Richardson says she has taken almost a dozen classes through the Naples Art Association over the past few years. (Photo: Alex Driehaus/Naples Daily News USA TODAY NETWORK - FLORIDA)

Executive Director Aimee Schlehr is excited about its Ozlike message: All art on the building's exterior will be covered "to represent a world without art," she said. But supporters will open the doors on a colorful festival of artists at work, music and food, representing Naples the way the association sees its potential.

More: Must-sees: Empty Bowls, We & wilderness in Naples photo show

More: Shutterbugs: Naples Art Association's 'Camera USA' brings snap with crackle and pop

Naples is a city for art

There's no organization required for artists to effuse about Southwest Florida as a place for creating art. But creating it well and making a career selling it is elusive. The Naples Art Association has hewed a clear path to opportunities since Schlehr became director 10 years ago.

"We have been trying to focus more on providing our local and regional artists the platform on which to exhibit and providing them the professional development they need to succeed as business people," she said.

"A lot of times people really don’t understand artists are business people. We provide them a platform, so they can build their career and move on. It's similar to a lawyer coming out of school, who needs to go into a big firm to get the experience before they move out on their own."

The association has stepped up its monthly curated exhibitions of local art in the small side gallery, once the members' gallery, but now Gallery 104. For a $40 entry fee you can submit your art; if you're an Art Association donor, it's a $15 fee. And there are no promises, warned Jack O' Brien, curator for the association.

Angela Anderson, left, leads a palette knife painting class at the Naples Art Association in Naples on Wednesday, March 27, 2019. (Photo: Alex Driehaus/Naples Daily News USA TODAY NETWORK - FLORIDA)

More: Nature's children: Green is the color for Naples art this month

More: Locals offer ‘Food and Family’ stories at ‘Storytellers’ event; the next one is April 17

"People like a competition. You like being able to say 'I competed against my peers and won a spot,'" he pointed out. And for those who lose, "It forces you to analyze what you're doing."

O'Brien's chief concern about the Naples Art Association galleries, which have three shows up at any given time is "How do we let people know what we're doing when we're doing so much and so quickly?"

The quality and quantity is known well enough for its work with students, but the county is growing exponentially, and the Naples Art Association needs to reach all its population, Schlehr said.

Board President Robert Walpole echoes that: "The big challenge for an organization like the Naples Art Association, is how we can expand a brand. Growing that brand to present opportunities to creative people requires knowledge of the brand."

Aimee Schlehr, CEO and executive director of the Naples Art Association, poses for a portrait in her office in Naples on Wednesday, March 27, 2019. (Photo: Alex Driehaus/Naples Daily News USA TODAY NETWORK - FLORIDA)

Further, Schlehr acknowledged, cultivating sponsorships for its local art programs takes a lot more education itself:

"To get a sponsor to underwrite an exhibition for professional development, they really have to understand and appreciate what opportunities it's providing for these artists," she said.

With every success comes a challenge.

The Naples Art Center has filled its space is a subtlety. To reach Schlehr's office visitors walk through the center's kitchen. She shares it with the center's storage roo.

A set of shelves holds linens and utensils for receptions and for the evenings the center is rented out, one of its income-producing elements. Nestled against her desk are boxes of Nature Valley granola bars waiting on an arts festival

"This building wasn't built for storage," Schlehr said, chuckling. "There's only so much a tri-fold will hide."

She gave up a corner office on the other side of the building to enlarge its nine adjacent staff cubicles — so staff can store more of their own supplies in those.

With adult classes in the midst of their first season at the North Collier Regional Park, the center is also looking to launch them at the Eagle Lakes Community Park, too. It's a matter of getting the information to east and south Naples, Schlehr said.

ARTScool will take over the Girl Scout house next to its Park Street quarters and will probably max out its 1,010-student limit this year. In the association's dreams is a satellite office that can administer this growing number of off-campus classes.

O'Brien has created gallery space on every wall of its four rotundas that has enabled the center to share local exhibitions with art people might never see otherwise, such as the "Andy Warhol Portfolios" that brought a more thoughtful look at the pop artist's philosophy.

Aimee Schlehr, CEO and executive director of the Naples Art Association, poses for a portrait in her office in Naples on Wednesday, March 27, 2019. (Photo: Alex Driehaus/Naples Daily News USA TODAY NETWORK - FLORIDA)

"The Photographic Landscape" contrasted the black-and-white work of Florida's famous photographer, Clyde Butcher, with Western nature photographer T.K. Hill. And the Hewitt collection exhibition of African-American art brought some of its more famous names — Jacob Lawrence, Romare Bearden, Elizabeth Catlett and former Naples resident Jonathan Green.

To bring some of the import of the exhibitions to viewers, he has begun "Tea with the Curator" to share perspectives on what's in the center. People may have to take the elevator to the second floor to see everything now. But O'Brien likes the fact that it takes people past the ongoing classes and through the library.

"It's a campus environment that you wouldn't discover if you didn't come up here," he explained.

Still, the center is making tentative steps for a capital campaign to find more space as well as to update its 20-year-old building, which is in need of resealed windows, updated bathrooms and a better showcase for its popular gift shop, which specializes in locally and regionally produced items.

"My dream would be to find office space for the staff, move the gift shop over to where the office staff and put a little coffee shop in there," Schlehr said.

"We don't want to open a restaurant. We don’t want to compete with our great partners who offer dining downtown. But we do have students who stay here all day. We do have peep who come through the building, and they love to sit on the back deck. Some coffee and Danish would be nice."

That's still in the future, she added. This coming weekend, Naples Art Association plans to celebrate its first 65 years and look forward to the next 65, exemplifying Kahlo's exhortation to "live the life."

"The future is bright here," Schlehr said happily.

Naples Art Association events

What: Art in the Park, a monthly show and sale of area art and artisan work, this month with Bark in the Park with the Humane Society, a developing artist booth for students from FGCU and Naples Area High Schools and a make and take art project for kids

When: 10 a.m.-4 p.m. Saturday, April 6

Where: Cambier Park, 755 8th Ave S, Naples

Admission: Free

Information: 239-262-6517 or naplesart.org

***

What: For the Love of Art, annual fundraiser, this year with a "Great Gatsby" theme, celebrating 65 years for the organization and feature working artists, music and food

When: 7-11 p.m. Saturday, April 6

Where: Naples Art Association, 585 Park St., Naples

Title: K-9 Kilo saved in the line of duty thanks to 7-year-old with big heart
Summary:
ST. AUGUSTINE BEACH, Fla. - The outcome could have been devastating for a St. Augustine Beach Police K-9 and his handler. But, luckily crisis was averted -- thanks to a 7-year-old girl making sure police dogs are safe in the line of duty.

Last month, K-9 Kilo and his handler Cpl. Bruce Cline where on duty at VyStar in St. Augustine Beach. Kilo was taking a rest inside their police vehicle in the parking lot of the bank as Bruce worked his security detail inside.

The pair have been partners -- and inseparable -- for two years, vowing to serve and protect their community and each other.

"I was giving (Kilo) a break inside the vehicle, where he gets to kind of unwind and relax. I have a sensor that gives me feedback to my phone," Bruce explained to News4Jax anchor Joy Purdy. "I monitor that temperature whenever (Kilo's) in the vehicle. I can see that that temperature was going up."

What Bruce didn't know as he was looking at his phone, the air conditioner blowing cool air to Kilo malfunctioned, so the temperature inside the police vehicle was climbing.

He immediately went to Kilo, realized the AC wasn't working properly and brought his K9 partner back inside the bank with him for the rest of the day.

"I had the AC on and it malfunctioned. This is actually how the canines die in these cars, without these heat alarms," Bruce told Joy.

According to the Officer Down Memorial Page, 17 K-9s have died nationwide since 2016 as a result of heat exhaustion inside their handlers vehicles.

With the heat alarm and the app that goes with it, not only can Bruce monitor the temperature inside his police vehicle whenever he wants to check it, the app will also alert him when the vehicle's inside temperature exceeds the set limit.

He receives text alerts and automated phone calls, while other components of the total alarm system automatically turn on a cooling fan set up in one of the rear windows, and sets off the vehicle's horn and flashing lights.

"An alert is also sent to other people (designated) on my contact list," Bruce said.

That's the backup in case he's in a location where phone service is limited or if he were to miss an app alert.

"There's a huge misconception that (K-9 officers) are being cruel by leaving out dogs in there," Bruce told Joy while shaking his head. "(Kilo) is always paying attention to movement and smells, so sometimes that's the only break that he gets, is to be in there."

"I'm fortunate to be able to have one of these heat alarms installed in my vehicle," he added.

Bruce has the heat sensor because of 7-year-old Emma Johnson and her mom Debbie. The mother-daughter duo started the nonprofit K9s United to buy specific, life-saving supplies and tools that police K-9 units across the country need.

WATCH: How K9s United got started

It was from money raised during K9s United's annual charity run that allowed Emma and Debbie to purchase and donate the heat sensor that saved Kilo's life.

"So you're back at home with Kilo, you and Kilo hanging out, and you're thinking what just happened?" Joy asked Bruce.

"The next day, afterwards, I kinda realized, I'm so blessed. I'm extremely fortunate," he answered. "I would have been devastated. He's my buddy. This is my dream job."

"Being a cop is one thing, but having a bond that we have and being able to work hand-in-hand with, it’s an absolute dream," Bruce added.

Bruce says right after the donated heat sensor saved the day, he let everyone know.

"When I got the text, my heart sank at first, and then it was, like, 'Oh, but (Kilo's) okay!" said Debbie.

Joy asked Emma if she understands exactly how she helped protect Kilo. The soft-spoken girl smiled and nodded her head, "Yes."

Joy then asked how it makes her feel, and she summed it up perfectly in one word:

"Happy!" Emma exclaimed.

"I remember the text I got from Corporal Cline like it was yesterday," St. Augustine Beach Police Chief Robert Chadwick said to Joy. "This is his life, this is his family member -- and one of ours -- so we had an actual save, based on adding these extra features."

Debbie says with proof a car heat alarm can save a K9's life, she and Emma have a new focus for their mission -- raising money to specifically buy heat alarms for law enforcement canines locally and nationwide. You can donate specifically to the campaign to help equip K9 units with heat alarms on the charity's website at K9sUnited.org.

Kilo is a community superstar

K-9 Kilo joined the St. Augustine Beach Police Department two years ago as an expert at detecting drugs and finding missing people.

The 4-year-old German Shepherd is not only an important asset on the force, he's actually kind of a superstar with members of the community.

Posts on Facebook about the four-legged officer have reached more than 21,000 people. One particular post involving Kilo and boxes of Girl Scout Cookies received more than 650 likes (and that number keeps going up).

"He's become a community partner," Chief Hardwick told Joy. "He's become truly a focal point of our agency."

Copyright 2019 by WJXT News4Jax - All rights reserved.
Address: 4 Broadcast Pl, Jacksonville, FL 32207, USA

Title: Police officer accused of sex with child held on $1 million bond
Summary:
JACKSONVILLE, Fla. - Veteran police Officer Matthew Butler wore a red jumpsuit Wednesday when he faced a judge for the first time on a charge of capital sexual battery on a child under 12. He was ordered held on $1 million bond pending an arraignment April 17.

The nine-year veteran officer was arrested Tuesday The Jacksonville Sheriff's Office began investigating the 39-year-old officer last Friday after getting a tip he was in possession of an inappropriate photo of a young girl on a digital device.

Police haven't said Butler’s relationship to the victim and said they are checking all of Butler’s electronic devices to see if there could be any more victims.

News4Jax has requested the arrest warrant that should provide more details of the accusations.

He was booked into the Duval County jail just after 6 p.m. Tuesday. Jail inmates dressed in red are considered either high-profile prisoners, an escape risk or a suicide risk.

The person who answered the door at Butler's listed address Tuesday night did not wish to comment. A neighbor described his arrest as surreal.

"It's just the biggest shock to me of anything I’ve ever heard," neighbor Donald Johnson said.

Undersheriff Pat Ivey said the JSO was taking the unusual step of releasing an employee's booking photo due to the nature of the crime. Ivey said JSO would begin the process of firing the 39-year-old officer, but because he is a civil service employee, they have to go through a process for that to happen.

Police said it believes the Florida Department of Children and Families is involved in the case. DCF has not returned a request for comment.

Butler's arrest comes four days after the arrest of a veteran police officer. Rodney Bryant, 32, was charged with three counts of aggravated assault with a deadly weapon.

According to the Sheriff's Office, Bryant was arrested after an argument with his girlfriend and another woman that began at a Southside gentlemen's club. As they drove away, police said Bryant pulled over, retrieved a gun from the trunk of the car and pointed the firearm at the women.

Copyright 2019 by WJXT News4Jax - All rights reserved.
Address: 4 Broadcast Pl, Jacksonville, FL 32207, USA

Title: Former DoD employee sentenced to 10 years in child enticement case
Summary:
JACKSONVILLE, Fla. - A former Department of Defense employee was sentenced Tuesday to 10 years in federal prison after he pleaded guilty last year to federal charges that he tried to entice a child into meeting for sex, authorities said.

Mohammad Abdul Malek, 68, of St. Marys, Georgia, pleaded guilty Oct. 30 to a count of attempted enticement and coercion of a minor, according to the U.S. Attorney’s Office for Florida’s Middle District.

According to his plea agreement, Malek exchanged emails and texts with someone he thought was a 13-year-old girl in August. He asked for photos and said he wanted to teach her about “making love.”

In reality, the person he was communicating with was an undercover detective. When Malek traveled to Jacksonville to meet up with the “child” Aug. 26, he was arrested by the Jacksonville Sheriff’s Office.

This case was brought as part of Project Safe Childhood, a nationwide campaign by the Justice Department aimed at curbing the spread of child sexual exploitation and abuse.

Copyright 2019 by WJXT News4Jax - All rights reserved.

Summary:
There’s a lot to look back on in history for March 26. Here are a couple of notable moments.1979: Leaders of Israel and Egypt signed a peace treaty at the White House. The prime minister of Israel declared, “No more bloodshed,” calling for peace forever while the Egyptian leader called it a “historic turning point of great significance for all peace-loving nations.” 1997: Several bodies of Heaven's Gate cult members are found inside a mansion in California. The group is believed to have taken part in a mass suicide. 1917: The Seattle Metropolitans became the first U.S. team to win hockey's Stanley Cup. 1964: Barbra Streisand stars in “Funny Girl” as it hits Broadway for the first time. 1944: Legendary singer Diana Ross turns 75 today. The Detroit native was part of the hit group The Supremes, who released iconic songs such as “You can’t hurry love,” and “Stop! In the name of love.” She went on to have a solo career as well, releasing more hits like “Ain’t no mountain high enough,” and “I’m coming out.” She is a notable actress and producer, as well.Learn more about historic March 26 moments in the video player above.

Title: Cape Coral police seize truck, develop person of interest in hit-and-run that killed 8-year-old girl
Summary:
CLOSE It was a dangerous year on Lee and Collier roads in 2018. Megan Kearney, mkearney@news-press.com

The Cape Coral Police Department released new details Tuesday in the investigation of an 8-year-old girl who was killed Monday morning while waiting at her school bus stop.

Police said they seized the red pickup truck they believe was involved in the fatal hit-and-run as evidence, and they have developed a person of interest in the case. Police are not releasing details about the person's identity "as the investigation is still in its infancy," a news release said.

Police said the truck was traveling south on NE 3rd Avenue approaching the intersection with NE 19th Terrace while Layla Aiken was sitting on the edge of the roadway on the northeast corner of the intersection, waiting for her school bus.

"For an unknown reason," the truck made a sharp left turn traveling eastbound on NE 19th Terrace before the front of the truck struck and rolled over Layla, police said. The truck left the scene eastbound on 19th Terrace toward Andalusia Boulevard "without rendering aid or providing information."

More: Police identify 8-year-old who died in Cape Coral hit-and-run Monday morning

More: Fort Myers man identified as victim in Sunday hit-and-run on Palm Beach Boulevard

More: Hit-and-run victim is third pedestrian fatality on Palm Beach Boulevard in two weeks

Layla was taken to the hospital, where she died Monday. Police responded to the crash at Northeast 3rd Avenue and Northeast 19th Terrace at about 6:20 a.m.

According to the Lee County school district, the bus pickup was at 6:55 a.m., and the transportation department sent a safety team out to inspect the stop.

"The lead investigator and other Cape Coral Police personnel are working diligently to resolve this tragic case with the correct disposition based on the totality of the investigation as soon as possible," the news release said. The police department is also working with the State Attorney's Office on this investigation.

NEWSLETTERS Get the Breaking News newsletter delivered to your inbox We're sorry, but something went wrong Urgent developments you should know now, not later. Please try again soon, or contact Customer Service at 1-800-468-0233. Delivery: varies Invalid email address Thank you! You're almost signed up for Breaking News Keep an eye out for an email to confirm your newsletter registration. More newsletters

According to city data, there are no sidewalks on or near the road where Layla was hit.

Sidewalks in Cape Coral This map of sidewalks was created using data from Cape Coral's Open Data Portal. This data is based primarily on aerial imagery from 2014 and is updated periodically, but the accuracy of the data may vary.

Graphic by Janie Haseman / The News-Press

Fundraiser for the family

A fundraiser created on Facebook started by Layla's family friends had raised more than $34,000 as of Tuesday morning. The fundraiser details say Layla was waiting at the bus stop with her brothers.

"Her family is heartbroken and completely unprepared for such a devestating (sp) loss and we, as their friends, would like to help ease their burden any way we can," the fundraiser says. "Please help us lay this angel to rest."

The fundraiser page said more than 1,000 people donated as of Tuesday morning, and the page received dozens of comments from people expressing their condolences to Layla's family.

Do you have information?

Police said they have been collecting surveillance video from the area. If you believe you have video or other information about this case, you can contact the Cape Coral Police Department at 239-574-3223 or submit an anonymous tip here. You can also text a tip to CRIMES (274637) by including "CCPD+" before your message.

If you have any information, please contact the Cape Coral Police Department at 239-574-3223. You can also submit an anonymous tip. Go to capecops.com/tips or text a tip- text CCPD+"Your Message" to CRIMES (274637). You can call Crimestoppers at 1-800-780-TIPS. Please use this Case Report # 19-005966.

Title: Owner of lost military doll identified after viral Facebook post
Summary:
Heather Parsons and Dina Morley’s mission has been accomplished.Less than an hour after a post went viral on KMBC-TV’s Facebook page and was shared more than 4,000 times across the country, the owner of a missing Huggs To Go Daddy military doll that was found Friday afternoon at Kansas City International Airport has been identified.“A woman reached out to Dina via Facebook and said she knew who it belonged to and they’re coordinating a pickup time and place on Tuesday.” Parsons said. “Without KMBC 9, this wouldn’t have happened so quickly. We’re so excited to return the doll to this little girl.”The doll, in green and brown camouflage, shows a picture on its head of a girl and a man.Dina Morley, who works at Southwest Airlines, said a customer found it on the floor."I kept it at valet services for a few days, hoping somebody would call about it or come back for it, but nobody did," she said.She and Heather Parsons said they thought the photo is of a daughter and her father.The two turned to the news and social media to help get the doll back to where it belongs.

Heather Parsons and Dina Morley’s mission has been accomplished.



Less than an hour after a post went viral on KMBC-TV’s Facebook page and was shared more than 4,000 times across the country, the owner of a missing Huggs To Go Daddy military doll that was found Friday afternoon at Kansas City International Airport has been identified.

“A woman reached out to Dina via Facebook and said she knew who it belonged to and they’re coordinating a pickup time and place on Tuesday.” Parsons said. “Without KMBC 9, this wouldn’t have happened so quickly. We’re so excited to return the doll to this little girl.”

The doll, in green and brown camouflage, shows a picture on its head of a girl and a man.



Dina Morley, who works at Southwest Airlines, said a customer found it on the floor.



"I kept it at valet services for a few days, hoping somebody would call about it or come back for it, but nobody did," she said.

The two turned to the news and social media to help get the doll back to where it belongs.

Title: Police: Parents 'didn't realize' they left toddler alone in park for more than 14 hours
Summary:
Police: Parents 'didn't realize' they left toddler alone in park for more than 14 hours

The parents of a toddler left at a park in West Palm Beach, Florida, have been charged. The Palm Beach County Sheriff's Office reached out on social media about 8 a.m. Saturday to try and identify the girl and track down her parents. They explained she was found wandering alone in Haverhill Park. "Does anyone know who the parents are of this beautiful little girl?" they tweeted. A few hours later, authorities said the girl's parents reported her missing. "They both stated they did not realize they left their child at the park Friday, March 22, 2019, around 7 p.m. and she had been missing for more than fourteen hours," police posted on Facebook. Jolanda Larose Alexandre, 38, and Makenson Alexandre, 34, of West Palm Beach, were arrested and charged with child neglect. DCF responded to the home and removed seven other children from the home.

Title: Opening arguments to begin in murder trial of father of slain girl
Summary:
PINELLAS COUNTY, FL - (WFLA) - Opening arguments are expected to begin Monday in a high-profile murder trial in Pinellas County after years of delay.

For the first time, a jury will see evidence centered on John Jonchuck.

He's the man accused of throwing his little girl to her death off of the Dick Misner Bridge near the Sunshine Skyway back in 2015.

Five-year-old Phoebe was killed four years ago and now a jury, which was seated Friday will begin hearing evidence that will ultimately lead to a decision on her father’s fate.

The jury is comprised of nine men and seven women.

The trial is expected to last up to four weeks.

Jonchuck was being treated at a mental health facility up until recently. The judge warned the jury that he is medicated and they must not let his present condition in court or side effects from the medications affect their decision making process.

If found guilty, he could get life in prison, but if the jury decides he's innocent, he'll stay in a mental institution.

State prosecutors will not seek death penalty in this case.
Address: 200 S Parker St, Tampa, FL 33606, USA

Title: Parents accused of child neglect after daughter left alone at park
Summary:
WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. - The parents of a young girl who was left alone for hours at a West Palm Beach park Friday are facing charges of child neglect, authorities said.

Jolana Alexandre, 27, and Makenson Alexandre, 34, were arrested Saturday.

Believed to be around 2 years old, the girl was found alone in Haverhill Park. Deputies searched for a parent or a guardian in the surrounding area, but found no one. Deputies also checked with 911 dispatchers and found that no one had reported the girl missing.

More than 14 hours later, one of her parents contacted authorities to claim her. The Florida Department of Children and Families is currently caring for the girl. The department also removed the couple's other seven children from the home.

The Alexandres told deputies that they did not realize they left the girl at the park.

Title: Disney's 'Frozen' at Hertz Arena: Snow comes to Southwest Florida for ice-skating show
Summary:
CLOSE After "Frozen" hit theaters in 2013, it quickly became an instant classic, delighting not only diehard Disney fans but also casual moviegoers, before going on to become the highest-grossing animated movie of all time. And on Tuesday, the studio officially announced the release date for the long-anticipated sequel. Expectant fans can mark their calendars, as Elsa and Anna will be making their return to the silver screen on November 29th of 2019. While many of the details remain secret for the time being, it seems as if most of the original Frozen original cast members are expected to return, including Idina Menzel, Kristen Bell, and Josh Gad, as well as directors Jennifer Lee and Chris Buck.

Even in sunny Florida, it snows whenever Elsa works her magic. This is “Frozen,” after all.

“Fort Myers is warm right now, but we’ll see what happens when Elsa gets there,” says skater/actor Morgan Bell, who plays Elsa’s sister Anna in the Disney ice-skating show. “She’ll make it snow.”

Anna in "Disney on Ice presents Frozen." The role is now played by Morgan Bell (not pictured). (Photo: Special to The News-Press)

Not just a little snow, either. We’re talking a full-on snow storm in Hertz Arena — courtesy of an army of snow machines scattered around the venue. It’s the real deal: Cold, wet and everywhere.

Many Southwest Florida audiences, of course, have never seen snow before — real or man-made. And kids lose their minds when they see the stuff, Bell says.

“To see the audience get excited about that is pretty cool,” she says. “They’re always reaching out and feeling it.”

Elsa works her magic in "Disney on Ice presents Frozen." (Photo: Special to The News-Press)

More: Celtic Woman celebrates Irish music at Mann Hall in Fort Myers

More: St. Patrick's Day events in Fort Myers, Cape Coral, Bonita Springs, Naples, etc.

That’s not the only jaw-dropping spectacle audiences will see when “Disney On Ice presents Frozen” visits Estero this weekend. There’s the fearsome snow monster Marshmallow, for example. And an ice castle. And lots of Elsa’s powerful winter magic.

Except for the snow machines, though, Bell won’t discuss how all those things come to life. That’d ruin it for the kids.

“It’s all part of the Disney magic,” she says.

But here’s what she WILL say about the popular touring show: It’s exciting and fun and sticks closely to the story from the 2013 movie hit “Frozen.” All the songs are there, including “Let It Go” and “Do You Want to Build a Snowman?”

Morgan Bell plays Anna in “Disney On Ice presents Frozen” (Photo: Special to The News-Press)

And so are all the popular characters: Royal sisters Anna and Elsa, loveable snowman Olaf, rugged mountain man Kristoff, the reindeer Sven and even that fearsome ice monster (his name is Marshmallow).

“It was kind of a dream to play Anna on this show,” Bell says. “It’s a really amazing story, and it’s been a lot of fun for me.”

Bell remembers seeing the movie with her cousin when it first came out. She especially loved Anna — a character who was miles away from the typical Disney princess.

“Anna is so unique,” Bell says. “She’s relatable to a lot of people. She’s quirky and little bit unorthodox, and to bring that out on the ice has been a lot of fun.”

Bell loves seeing kids show up for the ice-skating show in costume and scream out characters’ names when they appear: “Anna!” “Elsa!” “Olaf!” “Kristoff!”

“To see little girls dressed as Anna and Elsa in the audience and to know you’re helping families make memories is pretty special,” Bell says.

Anna and Elsa in "Disney on Ice presents Frozen." Current cast not pictured. (Photo: Tim Pannell)

She especially loves the show’s underlying message about sisterhood and the importance of family.

“For little girls, it’s a great message, really” Bell says. “The focus is more on family love versus a girl needing a man to come and save her. It’s more focused on that love between sisters and that bond and how important it is.”

Tickets for “Disney on Ice presents Frozen” are $15-$100 (plus $20 for parking).

Hertz Arena is located 11000 Everblades Parkway in Estero, just off the intersection of I-75 and Corkscrew Road. For more information, call 948-7825 or visit hertzarena.com.

Connect with this reporter: Charles Runnells (Facebook), @charlesrunnells (Twitter), @crunnells1 (Instagram)

Address: 1100 Immokalee Rd, Naples, FL 34110, USA

Title: FSU website alerts to autism signs
Summary:
Your baby delights you but he’s causing you concern. Why is it so hard to get him to look at you? Why doesn’t he gesture as much as other babies you know?

Your relatives say you worry too much. They blame your parenting for the child’s frequent tantrums. Still, you wonder: “Could my baby have autism? And why isn’t there an easier way to find out?”

Amy Wetherby, one of the country’s pioneers in Autism Spectrum Disorder research, regularly hears those questions, and she has been working for decades to provide reliable, user-friendly tools for parents. This week, she and her team at the Florida State University College of Medicine’s Autism Institute are unveiling their latest breakthrough - Baby Navigator.

Early diagnosis and intervention are critical to help children with autism reach their potential. Parents can start interventions right away at home to support the growth of their child’s social communication skills.

“This is a culmination of our research,” said Wetherby, distinguished research professor and director of the institute. “Now what we really want to do is disseminate what we’ve learned.

“Baby Navigator is for parents to easily access the online resources that we’ve developed. Baby Navigator has two purposes: to provide information on early development and to provide information about early signs of Autism Spectrum Disorder.”

Hardly anyone — often not even the family pediatrician — wants to be the one to raise the possibility of a child’s developmental delay or disorder. Parents need to know the signs.

“It’s been more than a decade since the American Academy of Pediatrics recommended screening all children for autism at 18 and 24 months,” Wetherby said. “But the reality is very few doctors do that. And the screening tool that’s widely used is not very accurate at younger ages.”

Baby Navigator reflects the National Institutes of Health-funded research that Wetherby’s team has done on early detection of autism. It also incorporates the online courses and tools developed with funding from the Florida Legislature. And thanks to an anonymous donor, much of that information is becoming available on various PBS stations. Parents can access photo illustrations, video clips and a screening tool for children 9-18 months of age, and register for parenting classes, all online for free.

Wetherby’s favorite part of Baby Navigator is the new Autism Navigator Lookbook — 16 Early Signs of Autism by 16 Months. It’s loaded with photos so everyone can see what to look for in toddlers.

“We’re trying to lead the nation,” she said. “We have new milestones we want to teach everybody that are much more precise. They’re about social communication growth. We have pictures. We have videos. We’ve taken our growth charts down to six months.

“Way before they’re learning to read, they’re learning to communicate. That’s the foundation. Our goal is for most or all children with autism to have enough skills to thrive in general education kindergarten. It’s cost-saving and is the best learning environment. From there, they have a much better chance of graduating from high school and getting a job or going to college.”

The research at the FSU Autism Institute is reaching families, doctors and medical students across Florida and beyond. Laura Iyampillai in West Palm Beach has seen Wetherby’s tools work miracles.

Early on, she noticed her daughter didn’t communicate like other babies. In addition, she could barely take her out of the house without a meltdown. Onlookers blamed her parenting skills. Even though her pediatrician listened to her and referred her very early for intervention, the intervention system was not prepared. The interventionist ignored all of Iyampillai’s observations and said day care and $100-an-hour consultants would solve the problems.

But her speech-language-pathologist friend had heard of Wetherby. Finally, in desperation, Iyampillai sent Wetherby an emotional email, just in time to screen her daughter by 18 months and be in their research.

“They started the intervention right away,” Iyampillai said. “It was amazing.”

That was three years ago. Now her daughter is four-and-one-half.

“By her second birthday she was a completely new child,” Iyampillai said. “Even within the first few weeks, she started to communicate for the first time ever. Once she could communicate, we were able to leave the house. She wasn’t having meltdowns anymore. By her second birthday, she was the easiest, most charming little girl.”

It was all done with long-distance video coaching. The Autism Institute experts would watch the parents interact with their child. In effect, they trained the parents to be the interventionists.

Third-year College of Medicine student Evan Schrader worked on research at the FSU Autism Institute and is helping to spread the word in the Orlando area. He led a research project with the patients of one of his faculty members, Alix Casler, chair of the pediatrics department in the Orlando Health hospital system.

The Autism Institute’s new screening tool is performing so much better than the previous tool used by Casler and two partners that they are now using it exclusively — and “our goal is to have her whole group use it by the time I graduate in 2020,” Schrader said. According to his research project, the average age of detection with the new screener was 1.6 years, roughly twice as early as the 3.1 years with the previous tool.

If autism can be caught early, Wetherby said, the outcomes can be promising.

“If we can prevent the challenging behavior so they can learn to communicate and talk and thrive in school, and still have autism, that’s a good outcome,” she said. “The cost for one child with autism can range from $1 million to $2.4 million over a lifetime. And a lot of that is adult care that we can prevent. I want kids with autism to grow up and be employed.”

Though Wetherby is soft-spoken, her voice rises impatiently when she considers the unnecessary toll that autism is taking on our children.

“Think about any other condition, like childhood leukemia,” she said. “Imagine if I said to you, ‘Average age of diagnosis is 4 years, but we know how to detect it by 1½.’ That would be alarming. Why is it not alarming that we’re not picking up autism earlier? By teaching children to communicate earlier, you can prevent a lot of the consequences and promote brain development.”

Ron Hartung is assistant director of communications for the Florida State University College of Medicine.
Address: 129 Commerce St, Apalachicola, FL 32320, USA

Title: TSO plays 'Seven Last Words,' Beethoven's 9th in evening of beauty, pain | Music roundup
Summary:
Buy Photo Tallahassee Symphony Orchestra premieres "Seven Last Words" on Sunday. (Photo: Democrat files)

Ten months before he died, Leonard Bernstein conducted one of the most moving performances of his life — a special Berlin Celebration Concert in what was formerly East Berlin featuring a multi-national orchestra and chorus performing Beethoven’s Ninth Symphony to commemorate the fall of the Berlin Wall.

I watched a video of that concert on YouTube recently. It took place Christmas Day 1989 and Bernstein is not at the top of his game. He’s paunchy and moves stiffly at first — the fire of his youthful and passionate presence on the podium banked by age and infirmity. But you can see him warm to the orchestra and the music as the performance spools out and he gets caught up in the magic and emotion of Beethoven’s monumental masterwork.

There’s a moment where you can actually see Bernstein becoming Lenny, the young maestro who conducts with his soul as much as with his mind and body. After the second movement concludes, just before the exquisite, lyrical Adagio section, he stands on the podium facing the orchestra, which awaits his cue. Eyes closed, brow furrowed, it’s as if he is at prayer or is gathering the strength for a great task.

And then he opens his eyes and cues the the start of that gorgeous Adagio molto e cantabile with his big, blunt hands. And by the time he gets to the final, magnificent movement — the “furioso” and choral finale — you can see him singing along, fully engaged and transported by the music. Oh, and he’s leading the players and singers through the Ninth without notes or score before him.

By the end, Bernstein seems exalted — smiling, grimacing, even leaping on the podium. And after the last note fades, Lenny stands again with his eyes closed, his face lifted, his body still thrumming with the music.

Tallahassee Symphony tackles Beethoven's "Ode to Joy" Sunday. (Photo: Paul de Hueck, courtesy the Leonard Bernstein Office, Inc.)

It’s not the best performance of the Ninth, but it’s one that embodies the symphony’s power to move not only the audience, but the players, the singers and the conductor. For the occasion, Bernstein with tinkered the paean to brotherhood and unity by Schiller that Beethoven set to music for the choral finale — he changed the word “freude,” or “joy,” to “freiheit,” or “freedom.”

In this age of snark and spite and short attention spans, it is probably unfashionable and even naive to adore the Ninth. But oh, how I do adore it! I love it as a sublime piece of musical genius, crafted by a beloved composer who was nearly stone deaf when he wrote it. It is the final complete symphony by Beethoven, and it is a perfect piece of music throughout.

The Democrat has already written about this weekend’s Tallahassee Symphony Orchestra doubleheader, first in an excellent story by Nada Hassanein on Joel Thompson’s composition “Seven Last Words of the Unarmed,” which will lead off the TSO’s performance Sunday afternoon in Ruby Diamond Concert Hall with special choral guests the Morehouse College Glee Club and FAMU Concert Choir.

There was also an article inviting students to attend an open rehearsal of the piece, and an op-ed column by Jessica Langois on how Thompson’s composition is a call for “radical empathy.”

It will be a powerful and powerfully moving concert, and attendees will be well advised to bring hankies — for such music opens the heart and makes it overflow.

And if concertgoers aren’t wrung out after the first half of Sunday’s program, the second half ought to finish them off. The TSO is ending the concert with the Ninth Symphony, which will be the featured work on Saturday night’s program as well.

The TSO and guest choruses perform the Ninth Symphony at 8 p.m. Saturday in Ruby Diamond Concert Hall. Tickets range from $25 to $52. The TSO and choral groups also perform “Ode to Understanding,” a concert featuring Joel Thompson’s “Seven Last Words of the Unarmed,” as well as Beethoven’s Ninth, at 3:30 p.m. Sunday in Ruby Diamond. Tickets range from $20 to $60. Visit www.tallahasseesymphony.org.

If you can't make it in person, the concert will be live streamed at wfsu.org/live.

Here’s what else will ravish your ears this week:

Hawk soars

Atlanta-based Southern rock foursome Brother Hawk returns for a show with Pat Puckett and Lil’ Grizzly Boogie Band at 9:30 p.m. Friday at The Wilbury, 513 W. Gaines St. Brother Hawk will no doubt be digging into the tunes on its latest mighty fine album “The Clear Lake.” Cover is $5 for 21-plus, $7 for under-21. Visit the Facebook event.

Springtime tunes

Chris Janson headlines the pre-Springtime Tallahassee concert at Kleman Plaza Friday. (Photo: Al Wagner / Invision / AP)

Kick off the Springtime Tallahassee weekend with a free music festival featuring headliner Chris Janson (whose hits include “Buy me a Boat”, “Fix a Drink” and “Drunk Girl”) with openers Highway 85 and Tyler Reeve from 6 to 10 p.m. Friday on Kleman Plaza. Visit www.springtimetallahassee.com.

Simply Seth

Bluesman Seth Walker brings his “Are You Open?” album tour to town for a show at 9 p.m. Friday at Bradfordville Blues Club, 7152 Moses Lane. The album debuted at the Number 2 spot on the Billboard Blues Chart and contains some of Walker’s most pointed and topical songs. Tickets are $20 advance, $25 at the door. Visit www.bradfordvilleblues.com.

Level with me

Two Foot Level, local purveyors of “folk, bluegrass, rock, Americana, and funky goodness,” share some new tunes from an upcoming album and revisit old faves at 9 p.m. Friday at Fifth & Thomas, 1122 Thomasville Road. No cover. Visit www.fifthandthomas.com.

Old friends, bookends

Mimi Hearns and Mike Palecki play at Southwood Golf Club Friday. (Photo: Emma Downs)

Harmonica player Mike Palecki and singer-songwriter Mimi Hearn have been playing music together for more than three decades, and you can hear it in their musical mind meld when the duo plays from 7 to 10 p.m. Friday at Southwood Golf Club, 3750 Grove Park Drive. It’s free. Call 850-942-4653.

Kentucky troubadour

Eastern Kentucky native Randy Wilson and son Gabriel Dansereau bring the music and storytelling traditions of the Bluegrass State to a show at 8 p.m. Friday at Blue Tavern, 1206 N. Monroe St. As Kentucky poet laureate James Still, with whom Wilson collaborated on a poetry production, wrote, it’s “hard nowadays to find a genuine Appalachian singer of superior talent untouched, untainted, and unspoiled by media, stage and screen. Randy Wilson is the one.” Cover is $5. Call 850-212-5204.

Reasonable Doubt

No Doubt tribute band Subliminal Doubt channels the band’s biggest hits at 8 p.m. Friday at The Yard in Railroad Square Art Park. Tickets are $10. Visit 850tix.com.

Jumpin’ Jimini

Rachel Hillman debuts her new band, Jiminikrikit, with Jack Straub on bass, Holly Riley on fiddle and Felix Allen on drums at 8 p.m. Friday at Proof Brewing Company, 1320 S. Monroe St. Hillman will mix her fine originals in with covers that span early jazz, '50s and '60s bossa nova, surf rock and modern indie pop. No cover. Call 850-577-0517.

Mudcat on the line

Rootsy bluesman Mudcat mixes up a pot of Piedmont and Delta blues, gospel, Americana and Cajun music at 8 p.m. Saturday at Blue Tavern, 1206 N. Monroe St. Mississippi born and Georgia raised, Mudcat honed his craft busking — that makes for a performer who’s light on his feet and deft with a song. Cover is $5. Call 850-212-5204.

Latin conjugation

Tocamos Mas brings its infectious and highly danceable Latin vibe to everyone’s favorite tiki bar at 8 p.m. Saturday at Waterworks, 1133 Thomasville Road. Stake out your spot on the dance floor - it’s impossible to sit still when Tocamos Mas gets to cookin’. Cover is $5. Call 850-224-1887.

Favorite son returns

Buy Photo Johnnie Marshall comes home to the BBC Saturday. (Photo: Democrat files)

Blues guitarist Johnnie Marshall brings it back to where it all started for him at 9 p.m. Saturday at Bradfordville Blues Club, 7152 Moses Lane. Tickets are $20 advance, $25 at the door, if any remain; Marshall’s shows always sell out. Visit www.bradfordvilleblues.com.

Patio music

Enjoy Sunday Afternoon Patio Tunes with Spoonbill and Blacksunblackmoon at 7 p.m. Sunday at Waterworks, 1133 Thomasville Road. No cover. Call 850-224-1887.

Around the world

FSU’s fine world music program presents another installment in its World Music Ensemble series when Trinidadian-style steel pan band Mas N Steel joins the Old Time Ensemble, which focuses on the traditional music and dance of North America, for a concert at 7:30 p.m. Tuesday in Opperman Music Hall. It’s free. Visit www.music.fsu.edu.

Go Gothic

New York singer-songwriter Peg Simone returns to Tallahassee for this year's film festival to present a “Southern Gothic Pocket Opera.” (Photo: Kati Schardl)

The last time New York singer-songwriter Peg Simone came to Tallahassee, she collaborated with local artist Linda Hall to stage a mesmerizing music-performance piece that was spooky-good. She returns to team with Hall for a “Southern Gothic Pocket Opera” presented by Tallahassee Film Festival at 7:30 p.m. Thursday at All Saints Cinema, 918 Railroad Ave. The performance will be followed by a retrospective screening of the cinematic classic “Night of the Hunter.” Tickets are $10; admission to this pre-fest event is included for All-Access and VIP Festival pass holders. Visit www.tallahasseefilmfestival.com.

Pepper stepper

Pepper bassist Bret Bollinger reaches out to fans during the band's sold-out concert at Vinyl Music Hall in November. (Photo: Jody Link/GoPensacola.com)

Bret Bollinger has been one of the guiding lights of Pepper for more than two decades, helping shape the sound of contemporary reggae. He brings his jelly-tight side project The Bad Habits — featuring Jeff Nisen on guitar and backing vocals, Andre Davis on bass and Patrick Salmon on drums — to get irie with Resinated, Sway Jah Vu and Morning Flowers at 8:30 p.m. Thursday at The Wilbury, 513 W. Gaines St. Tickets are $18 advance, $22 day of show, with a $2 under 21 fee at the door. Bollinger will play tunes from his solo EP “Lo-Fi,” along with your favorite Pepper hits. Visit the Facebook event.

Classical sounds

Music director and conductor Dr. Alexander Jiménez leads the FSU Philharmonia in concert at 7:30 p.m. Thursday in Ruby Diamond Concert Hall. The program includes works by Berlioz, Prokofiev and Sibelius, with featured soloist Josefína Guzman on violin. Tickets are $10 adults, $7 seniors and non-FSU students, free for FSU students. Call 850-645-7949.

Currys are comin’

Buy Photo The Currys play the intimate From the Heart Recording Studio space in Sopchoppy Thursday. (Photo: Democrat files)

Beloved area Americana trio The Currys is making the rounds near and far to promote its latest harmony-drenched and twangy recording, “This Side of the Glass.” After a jaunt up the Eastern Seaboard, brothers Tommy and Jimmy and cousin Ethan bring it closer to home for an intimate performance made just for local fans (and there are many) at 7:30 p.m. Thursday at From the Heart Recording Studio in Sopchoppy. Tickets are $20; reservations are strongly urged. Call 850-559-9038 or email fromtheheartrecordingstudio@gmail.com.

Folk-blues at the Tavern

Jon Shain will perform Thursday at Blue Tavern. (Photo: Submitted)

Guitarist Jon Shain and bassist F.J. Ventre have been making music together for more than three decades, starting when they met as teenagers in high school in Massachusetts. Now based in North Carolina, the duo has fleshed out its folk-blues sound to include the rock, pop and rockabilly elements that ornament the lush and lovely rootsy album “Tomorrow Will Be Yesterday Soon.” Hear them perform at 8 p.m. Thursday at Blue Tavern, 1206 N. Monroe St. Cover is $5. Call 850-212-5204.

And the beat goes on . . .

Enjoy the art of a tale well told with Saundra Kelley & Friends Storytelling from 7 to 9 p.m. Friday at Black Dog on the Square in Railroad Square Art Park. No cover. Call 850-841-7778. . . . Clever Girl dives into its big bag of clever covers with opener Madison Avery at 8 p.m. Friday at The Junction at Monroe, 2011 S. Monroe St. Cover is $10. Visit www.junctionatmonroe.com. . . . Three Billy Goats Gruff heats it up from 7 to 10 p.m. Friday at the Apalachicola Ice Company in Apalachicola. No cover. Visit www.apalachicolaice.com. . . . Legendary local band Eli’s 50th anniversary celebration continues with a show at 9 p.m. Saturday at Corner Pocket Bar & Grill, 2475 Apalachee Parkway. Cover is $10. Call 850-574-2724. . . .

The JRive Music Jazz Quartet, led by Joshua Rivers, entertains from 8 to 10 p.m. Saturday at Black Dog on the Square. (Photo: Zimmerman)

The JRive Music Jazz Quartet, led by Joshua Rivers, entertains from 8 to 10 p.m. Saturday at Black Dog on the Square in Railroad Square Art Park. Cover is $5. Call 850-841-7778. . . . Let the music move you at Rumbavana Latin Dance Night at 9 p.m. Saturday at Southwood Golf Club, 3750 Grove Park Drive. Admission is $10; ladies get in free till 11 p.m. Call 850-942-4653. . . . Three Billy Goats Gruff play from 7 to 10 p.m.Saturday at Tamara’s Tapas Bar in Apalachicola. No cover. Call 850-653-8272. . . . The Classical Guitar Society presents a showcase from 6 to 8 p.m. Sunday at Black Dog on the Square in Railroad Square Art Park. It’s free. Call 850-841-7778. . . . The Bob Dogan Trio leads the First Tuesday Jazz Session at 8 p.m. Tuesday at Blue Tavern, 1206 N. Monroe St. Cover is $2. Enjoy the skewed musical oeuvre of Tao Jonz & the Ontological Elephants at 8 p.m. Wednesday at the Tavern. Cover is $2. Call 850-212-5204. . . . Feast your ears on the Thursday Dinner Jazz Session at 7:30 p.m. Thursday at Waterworks, 1133 Thomasville Road. No cover. Call 850-224-1887. . . . Nosh to the yacht rock sounds of Naugahyde Park at Food Truck Thursday from 6:30 to 9:30 p.m. Thursday at the Shops at Lake Ella. Call 850-222-2254.
