Title: Venezuelan family facing deportation granted extension
Summary:
- A Venezuelan family facing deportation will be able to stay in Tampa for at least one more year.

Jennifer Infante, her husband, and their two children, went before immigration authorities Tuesday in a last-ditch effort to avoid going back to Venezuela.



"Our lives were in danger," said Infante, who has worked tirelessly to keep her family together.

The couple's daughter, Madison, was born in the United States, and is therefore a U.S. citizen. But with strict orders to go back to their country, the family was worried they would be separated from their daughter.



However, ICE officials granted the family a one-year extension.

"They have to take into account what's going to happen to the U.S. citizen if the family gets deported," said Paul Palacios, an immigration attorney for Migrants Foundation.

According to Palacios, immigration authorities likely weighed multiple factors specific to this family's case, including Venezuela's current political and social turmoil.

Infante says her family came to Florida five years ago after receiving death threats in their hometown of Maracaibo, the capital of the state of Valencia. Her husband, William Paredes, served as a K9 officer and said he refused to give into corruption.



Shortly after arriving to Florida on tourist visas, Infante and Paredes applied for asylum. The request was denied, but as their case played out, they welcomed a baby girl.



The couple says returning to Venezuela at this time would be a nightmare. With long power outages, limited food, medicine, skyrocketing inflation and crime rates, Infante says surviving would be a struggle.

The family's attorney, Paul Palacios, contacted Sen. Rick Scott and Sen. Marco Rubio for assistance in this case. Palacios said it definitely helped.

Though the family only has one more year to stay in the United States legally, they hope Congress passes a bill that would grant Venezuelans temporary protective status. Several U.S. senators, like Rubio and Scott, have expressed their support, but President Trump has not said whether he will sign off on it.



"We will continue to fight," said Infante, who vows she will do everything to keep her family safe.
Address: 3213 W Kennedy Blvd, Tampa, FL 33609, USA

Title: Man pleads guilty to kidnapping Jayme Closs, killing her parents
Summary:
Copyright 2019 Nexstar Broadcasting, Inc. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten, or redistributed. FILE - In this Wednesday, Feb. 6, 2019, file photo, Jake Patterson appears for his preliminary hearing at Barron County Circuit Court in Barron, Wis. (T'xer Zhon Kha/The Post-Crescent via AP, Pool, File)

Copyright 2019 Nexstar Broadcasting, Inc. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten, or redistributed. FILE - In this Wednesday, Feb. 6, 2019, file photo, Jake Patterson appears for his preliminary hearing at Barron County Circuit Court in Barron, Wis. (T'xer Zhon Kha/The Post-Crescent via AP, Pool, File)

BARRON, Wis. (AP) - A Wisconsin man pleaded guilty Wednesday to kidnapping 13-year-old Jayme Closs, killing her parents and holding her captive in a remote cabin for three months.

Jake Patterson, 21, pleaded guilty to two counts of intentional homicide and one count of kidnapping. A count of armed burglary was dropped. The intentional homicide counts carry a sentence of life in prison.

Patterson had said he would plead guilty in a letter sent earlier this month to a Minneapolis TV station, saying he didn’t want the Closs family “to worry about a trial.”

Patterson admitted kidnapping Jayme after killing her parents, James and Denise Closs, on Oct. 15 at the family’s home near Barron, about 90 miles (145 kilometers) northeast of Minneapolis. Jayme escaped in January, after 88 days in Patterson’s cabin in near the small, isolated town of Gordon, some 60 miles (97 kilometers) from her home.

According to a criminal complaint , Patterson told authorities he decided Jayme “was the girl he was going to take” after he saw her getting on a school bus near her home.

Jayme told police that the night of the abduction, the family dog’s barking awoke her, and she went to wake up her parents as a car came up the driveway. While her father went to the front door, Jayme and her mother hid in the bathroom, clutching each other in the bathtub, with the shower curtain pulled shut.

They heard Jayme’s father get shot. Patterson then found Jayme and her mother. He told detectives he wrapped tape around Jayme’s mouth and head, taped her hands behind her back and taped her ankles together, then shot her mother in the head. He told police he dragged Jayme outside, threw her in the trunk of his car, and took her to his cabin, the complaint said.

During Jayme’s time in captivity, Patterson forced her to hide under a bed when he had friends over and penned her in with tote boxes and weights, warning that if she moved, “bad things could happen to her.” He also turned up the radio so visitors couldn’t hear her, according to the complaint.

Authorities searched for Jayme for months and collected more than 3,500 tips. On Jan. 10, Jayme escaped from the cabin while Patterson was away. She then flagged down a woman who was out walking a dog and pleaded for help. Patterson was arrested minutes later.
Address: 200 S Parker St, Tampa, FL 33606, USA

Title: Local student moves forward with device designed to stop speeding near buses
Summary:
ASTATULA, Fla. - News 6 first introduced viewers to Astatula Elementary student Julia Dumont two weeks ago when she had had just won the Lake County Regional Science Fair with an invention designed to keep students safe while getting on and off the school bus.

When News 6 traffic safety expert Trooper Steve Montiero saw Julia's "Magic School Bus" project, he knew he just had to meet the 10-year-old girl.

Julia visited Montiero at the News 6 studios. She brought along her prototype, a 7-foot PVC pipe, equipped with yellow reflective tape and flashing LED lights.

"This is the most impressive thing I've ever seen from a grade school student," Montiero said. "The idea is 100 percent spot on. The concept is genius and what I get excited about is your intent behind it. You're just truly trying to help people and save lives."

Montiero presented Julia a certificate of appreciation for her safety innovation.

"It feels really good to know that someone who actually deals with traffic is helping me, trying to push me forward," she said.

Julia said her next step is appearing before the Lake County School Board to ask members to put the bar on buses, and Montiero said he'd love to go along with her.

"Looking at this, I would go with you, because this is something I feel would legitimately reduce crashes almost immediately and save students from being hit," Montiero said.

To learn more about Julia's invention, check out our previous story here.

Copyright 2019 by WKMG ClickOrlando - All rights reserved.
Address: 4466 N John Young Pkwy, Orlando, FL 32804, USA

Title: Fundraisers for 8-year-old killed in hit-and-run garnering community support
Summary:
A note from mom is attached to a photograph of 8-year-old Layla Aiken at a memorial site. Layla was killed by a hit-and-run driver Monday morning. (Photo: Ricardo Rolon/The News-Press USA TODAY NETWORK - FLORIDA)

A fundraiser created on Facebook started by Layla's family friends had raised more than $34,000 as of Tuesday morning. The fundraiser details say Layla was waiting at the bus stop with her brothers.

"Her family is heartbroken and completely unprepared for such a devestating (sp) loss and we, as their friends, would like to help ease their burden any way we can," the fundraiser says. "Please help us lay this angel to rest."

The fundraiser page said more than 1,000 people donated as of Tuesday morning, and the page received dozens of comments from people expressing their condolences to Layla's family.

A memorial including notes, flowers, balloons and plush animals, is now visible on the corner of NE 3rd Avenue and NE 19th Terrace in Cape Coral Tuesday afternoon at the site were Layla Aiken was killed while waiting for her school bus. (Photo: Ricardo Rolon/The News-Press USA TODAY NETWORK - FLORIDA)

Read the full story: Cape Coral police seize truck, eye person of interest in hit-and-run that killed 8-year-old girl

A separate fundraiser was created on GoFundMe. People have donated $4,868 of the requested $12,000.

The language of the fundraiser reads:

"Something no parent wants to hear, that your child didn’t make it. While waiting for the school bus, Layla was involved in a hit and run, and did not survive the impact. This isn’t something you can ever prepare for, and I’m hoping to help with the funeral costs.



Layla was just 8 years old, and had the whole world in front of her. So smart, funny, and the sweetest soul. Not a day went by that she wasn’t filled with smiles and laughter."

More: Police identify 8-year-old who died in Cape Coral hit-and-run Monday morning

Address: 2442 Dr Martin Luther King Jr Blvd, Fort Myers, FL 33901, USA

Title: Cape Coral police seize truck, eye person of interest in hit-and-run that killed 8-year-old girl
Summary:
CLOSE It was a dangerous year on Lee and Collier roads in 2018. Megan Kearney, mkearney@news-press.com

The Cape Coral Police Department released new details Tuesday in the investigation of an 8-year-old girl who was killed Monday morning while waiting at her school bus stop.

Police said they seized the red pickup they believe was involved in the fatal hit-and-run as evidence, and they have developed a person of interest in the case. Police are not releasing details about the person's identity "as the investigation is still in its infancy," a news release said.

Police said the truck was traveling south on NE 3rd Avenue approaching NE 19th Terrace while Layla Aiken was sitting on the edge of the roadway on the northeast corner, waiting for her school bus.

"For an unknown reason," the truck made a sharp left turn traveling eastbound on NE 19th Terrace before the front of the truck struck and rolled over Layla, police said. The truck left the scene eastbound on 19th Terrace toward Andalusia Boulevard "without rendering aid or providing information."

More: Police identify 8-year-old who died in Cape Coral hit-and-run Monday morning

More: Fort Myers man identified as victim in Sunday hit-and-run on Palm Beach Boulevard

More: Hit-and-run victim is third pedestrian fatality on Palm Beach Boulevard in two weeks

Layla was taken to the hospital, where she died Monday. Police responded to the crash at about 6:20 a.m.

"The lead investigator and other Cape Coral Police personnel are working diligently to resolve this tragic case with the correct disposition based on the totality of the investigation as soon as possible," the news release said. The Police Department is also working with the state attorney's office on the investigation.

According to city data, there are no sidewalks on or near the road where Layla was hit.

Sidewalks in Cape Coral Trouble scrolling? Move your finger or cursor to the right side of the screen. This map of sidewalks was created using data from Cape Coral's Open Data Portal. This data is based primarily on aerial imagery from 2014 and is updated periodically, but the accuracy of the data may vary.

Graphic by Janie Haseman / The News-Press

Assistant City Manager Connie Barron said via email that the city generally limits the installation of sidewalks to major roadway arterials and collector streets. But the city has added sidewalks to local streets that serve as a "pass through" for cars going from one major road to another. For example, SE 8th Street from Cultural Park to Santa Barbara.

Barron said there was a streetlight at the intersection of the accident, and that the city's priority for streetlight installations was bus stops.

Amber Rollins, the director of KidsAndCars.org in Kansas, said it is important for parents to start talking to their children about traffic safety at a young age. She also said that schools should reinforce the messages.

"I have a 2-year-old, and we talk about how cars are dangerous and looking both ways before you cross the street," she said. "I know that he doesn't comprehend it, but we still talk about it. You want to kind of get that ingrained in them from a very, very early age.''

NEWSLETTERS Get the Breaking News newsletter delivered to your inbox We're sorry, but something went wrong Urgent developments you should know now, not later. Please try again soon, or contact Customer Service at 1-800-468-0233. Delivery: varies Invalid email address Thank you! You're almost signed up for Breaking News Keep an eye out for an email to confirm your newsletter registration. More newsletters

KidsAndCars.org has a long list of tips for students and drivers on its website that are related to school bus safety. One of the organization's recommendations fis for children to stand five giant steps away from the road while waiting on a school bus.

"You want to talk to your kids about where is the safest place to stand," Rollins said. "Talking to your children about how just because they can see the car doesn't mean the car can see them is really important."

A Lee County school district safety team inspected the bus stop after Monday's crash.

"They just go back to review the stop to make sure that nothing has changed since it was last inspected or selected and to make sure it meets all the requirements to be considered a safe stop," school district spokesman Rob Spicker said. "That was the determination that was made."

Fundraiser for the family

A fundraiser created on Facebook started by Layla's family friends had raised more than $34,000 as of Tuesday morning. The fundraiser details say Layla was waiting at the bus stop with her brothers.

"Her family is heartbroken and completely unprepared for such a devestating (sp) loss and we, as their friends, would like to help ease their burden any way we can," the fundraiser says. "Please help us lay this angel to rest."

The fundraiser page said more than 1,000 people donated as of Tuesday morning, and the page received dozens of comments from people expressing their condolences to Layla's family.

Do you have information?

Police said they have been collecting surveillance video from the area. If you believe you have video or other information about this case, you can contact the Cape Coral Police Department at 239-574-3223 or submit an anonymous tip here. You can also text a tip to CRIMES (274637) by including "CCPD+" before your message.

Title: Navy lieutenant gets 10 years for using internet to seek sex with child
Summary:
JACKSONVILLE, Fla. - A Mayport Navy lieutenant was sentenced to 10 years in federal prison for using the internet to attempt to entice a child to engage in sexual activity, the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Middle District of Florida announced Monday.

Michael Douglas McNeil was also ordered to serve a five-year term of supervised release and to register as a sex offender.

McNeil has been detained since his Aug. 30 arrest, which the Jacksonville Sheriff's Office said was part of Operation DUVAL, standing for Disrupting Underage Virtual Abuse Locally. JSO detectives teamed with nearly a dozen other law enforcement agencies in the trolling sting.

According to court documents, on Aug. 27, a detective with the Clay County Sheriff’s Office, who was posing online as a family member of a 12-year-old handicapped child, received a message on a social media app from McNeil, who identified himself as “Mark.”

Prosecutors said McNeil expressed interested in having sex with the “child” and was told that the “child” was 12 years old.

Over a four-day period, according to authorities, McNeil and the undercover detective discussed plans for McNeil to meet the “child” for sex and McNeil asked for several photos of the “child,” sent the undercover detective an explicit photo of himself, and asked specific questions about the “child’s” sexual experience and abilities.

McNeil was arrested when he arrived at a Starbucks in Orange Park, where he thought he was going to meet the girl, authorities said.

During an interview, McNeil admitted, among other things, that he showed up to meet the “child” because of his “curiosity” about “a younger girl," according to the DOJ.

The case was investigated by the Clay County Sheriff’s Office, U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement’s Homeland Security Investigations, the Naval Criminal Investigative Service and the Jacksonville Sheriff’s Office.

It is another case brought as part of Project Safe Childhood, a nationwide initiative launched in May 2006 by the Department of Justice to combat the growing epidemic of child sexual exploitation and abuse.

Copyright 2019 by WJXT News4Jax - All rights reserved.
Address: 4 Broadcast Pl, Jacksonville, FL 32207, USA

Title: Opening arguments to begin in trial of Pinellas man accused of dropping daughter off bridge
Summary:
Opening arguments to begin in trial of Pinellas man accused of dropping daughter off bridge Copyright 2019 Nexstar Broadcasting, Inc. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten, or redistributed. Copyright 2019 Nexstar Broadcasting, Inc. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten, or redistributed.

PINELLAS COUNTY, FL - (WFLA) - Opening arguments are expected to begin Monday in a high-profile murder trial in Pinellas County after years of delay.

For the first time, a jury will see evidence centered on John Jonchuck. He's the man accused of dropping his little girl to her death off of the Dick Misner Bridge near the Sunshine Skyway.

5-year-old Phoebe was killed four years ago and now a jury, which was seated Friday will begin hearing evidence that will ultimately lead to a decision on her father’s fate.

The jury is comprised of nine men and seven women. The trial is expected to last up to four weeks.

Jonchuck was being treated at a mental health facility up until recently. The judge warned the jury that he is medicated and they must not let his present condition in court or side effects from the medications affect their decision making process.

If found guilty, he could get life in prison, but if the jury decides he's innocent, he'll stay in a mental institution.

State prosecutors will not seek death penalty in this case.

Title: DUI suspect hits motorcycle in Levy, kills man, teen girl
Summary:
David Anthony Lewis, 40, and Suzanne Lewis, 14, both of New Port Richey, were killed.

A man and teenage girl from New Port Richey were killed on State Road 24 in Levy County Sunday after state troopers say a drunken driver crashed into a motorcycle.

David Anthony Lewis, 40, and Suzanne Lewis, 14, were killed in the crash near Cove Street around 4:38 p.m., according to a Florida Highway Patrol media release.

The Lewises were traveling south on SR 24 when a Ford F-150 truck, driven by Savannah Leigh Wilson, 29, of Chiefland, crossed the center line and hit them head-on.

The Lewises were wearing helmets but died on scene.

Wilson was arrested and transported to the Levy County jail.

She is facing two counts of DUI manslaughter, driving with a suspending license and other charges.

Title: Toddler found wandering alone in West Palm Beach park
Summary:
WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. - Authorities have found the mother of a toddler who deputies found alone in a Palm Beach County park Friday night.

The Palm Beach County Sheriff's Office said deputies found the girl around 8 p.m. Friday in Haverhill Park. Deputies canvassed the area around the park and made loud announcements. Deputies also contacted 911 dispatchers to see whether anyone had reported a girl missing. However no one came forward to claim the girl and no one had reported her missing, authorities said.

Deputies believe the girl is around 2 years old.

Authorities have not decided whether to press charges against the mother and are still investigating the circumstances surrounding the case.

The Florida Department of Children and Families is currently caring for the girl.

Title: Former Winter Haven man charged with 'horrific' sexual battery on young children
Summary:
Winter Haven Public Safety Director Charlie Bird: "The path of emotional and physical destruction he caused is reprehensible and we will do everything within our power to make sure he will never be able to hurt another child again."

WINTER HAVEN — After a four-month investigation that started in Winter Haven and ended in Knoxville, Tennessee, a 37-year-old man was arrested for sexual battery on a child under the age of 12.

Winter Haven Police Department arrested Manuel Tavis McGhee, charging him with two counts of sexual battery on a child under the age of 12; charges, they say, stem from repeated sex abuse on two children when McGhee lived in Winter Haven.

The mother of one of the victims, identified as Victim A, notified police in late 2018 that her daughter told her she had been abused by McGhee.

In an interview with investigators, the 15-year-old said she had been abused from age 5 to 11, according to the police.

The girl revealed "extremely horrific and explicit details of the abuse she incurred from the age of five," according to a forensic interview with police.

Additionally, she told investigators her brother, identified as Victim B, who is a couple of years older, had endured the same type of abuse during those same years.

In 2013, two separate reports about McGhee were made to the Lakeland Police Department, involving Victim B and two other alleged victims in Lakeland that year. Both incidents were reported and investigated but formal charges were ultimately dropped, according to the WHPD investigation. During those Lakeland investigations, officers then had reported that McGhee said he had been accused of similar acts in 2006 while stationed at Fort Bragg in North Carolina with the U.S. Army.

In that case, McGhee had been charged with 15 counts of sexual battery on a child but the case was ultimately dropped by the U.S. Army, which had requested to prosecute the case instead of local authorities, "due to a lack of evidence and McGhee's denial of all allegations," WHPD spokeswoman Jamie Brown said in a press release.

"The incidents were very similar to the incidents that occurred in the Winter Haven case," she added.

Based on McGhee's history of allegations, Victim A and Victim B were interviewed in December.

Victim B said the abuse started when he was 8 or 9 years old in North Carolina. The description of the abuse mirrored what Victim A reported, noted Brown.

Victim B also told police that the abuse continued in Lakeland and Winter Haven.

Regarding the 2013 allegation by Victim B, he told investigators recently he was afraid of what McGhee would do to him if he shared details. But by the time Victim B spoke to Winter Haven police, Victim B disclosed the details because McGhee had moved away and he said he didn't feel threatened any more.

WHPD detectives followed the North Carolina allegations and met with a Georgia woman identified as a victim in those reports.

This woman said that when she was nine years old McGhee had abused her, and the pattern was identical to the other victims that were interviewed, according to WHPD reports.

A sibling of this victim also detailed abuse in a separate interview with Winter Haven detectives, according to a WHPD media release.

Based on the totality of the statements made by numerous victims across multiple agencies, Winter Haven detectives obtained a warrant to arrest McGhee. He was taken into custody in Knoxville and is awaiting extradition back to Florida.

"I can say one thing — that I am so proud of our detectives and their tenacity to ensure that there are no more children that this monster can hurt," said Winter Haven Public Safety Director Charlie Bird. "The path of emotional and physical destruction he caused is reprehensible and we will do everything within our power to make sure he will never be able to hurt another child again."

Kathy Leigh Berkowitz can be reached at kberkowitz@theledger.com or at 863-802-7558. Follow her on Twitter at kberkowitz@thel1.
Address: 300 W Lime St, Lakeland, FL 33815, USA

Title: Mental health and suicide prevention town hall held in Coral Springs
Summary:
The Parkland and Coral Springs communities came together to turn their suffering and grieving to hope and healing.

A mental health and suicide prevention town hall was held inside Coral Springs City Hall Wednesday evening.

The goal was to educate parents on how they can help their children who may be suffering in silence.

“It’s been difficult, but it has been getting better,” mother Melissa Blank said.

Her son, Jonathan Blank, was inside Building 12 when a gunman opened fire, killing two classmates and injuring others inside his classroom on Valentine’s Day last year.

“We need to be more proactive," Blank said. "Teachers are going through training and I’d like it to be spread out to the communities.”

Blank joined other parents in a crowded room to ask mental health experts questions about the resources that are available for their children.

Cindy Arenberg Seltzer of Children’s Services Council of Broward County broke down some sample questions loved ones should ask their child, especially the young people who survived and suffered after last year’s tragedy in Parkland.

Have you thought about hurting yourself? Have you done anything to forward that desire?

“It’s important for people to understand that all of these emotions that they’re going through are natural and normal, and that they are not alone,” Arenberg Seltzer said.

The town hall comes after two Parkland survivors and a father of a little girl who was murdered in the Sandy Hook massacre took their own lives, all within days of each other.

“It opens up some more wounds with our community. Everybody is really stepping up, we want to prevent any further tragedy that’s stems from our incident here,” said Sgt. Carla Kmiotek with Coral Springs Police.

Some parents of the shooting victims like Broward school board member Lori Alhadeff and Max Schachter attended the event.

A city leader tells CBS12 News there is a plan in place to help Stoneman Douglas students cope when they return to school Monday.

If you are in a crisis, call the toll-free National Suicide Prevention Lifeline at 1-80-273-TALK (8255) for immediate help, or dial 211 to connect to an expert. They are available 24 hours a day, seven days a week.

All calls are confidential.
Address: 1100 Fairfield Dr, West Palm Beach, FL 33407, USA

Title: 'I need closure:' Video shows emotional encounter between triple murder suspect, brother
Summary:
Recently released video shows an emotional confrontation between a triple murder suspect and his brother shortly after their mother, father and brother were killed in their Chuluota home.

The video of suspect Grant Amato and his brother Jason Amato was recorded at the Seminole County Sheriff's Office on Jan. 26, one day after Chad Amato, 59, and Margaret Amato, 61, and Cody Amato, 31, were found dead.

Grant Amato was initially identified as a person of interest then arrested on murder charges days later. The video was released Wednesday as Grant Amato was in court asking to be granted bond, which the judge denied.

In the video, Jason Amato grapples with the fact that his mother, father and brother are dead and it seems like his surviving brother is responsible.

[RELATED: Worried co-workers led to slain family's discovery, 911 calls show | Person of interest in Chuluota triple homicide found in Orange County | Family killed in Chuluota shooting identified, son still person of interest]

"I want to believe you, Grant, but you're the last person that I could put in that house," Jason Amato says in the video. "I know what's happened over the past six months. I can understand the troubles that you've gone through, but it's hard for me to think that you would break to this point, but who else could I blame?"

Both brothers reference Grant Amato's involvement with a Bulgarian cam girl to whom he wired $200,000 to fuel their pornographic, online relationship, according to the Seminole County Sheriff's Office. Deputies said Grant Amato stole that money from his family, which led to a rift in their relationship.

Jason Amato asks why his brother continued to talk to the woman despite his family telling him that he would be kicked out of the house if he continued the online relationship.

"I don't know apart from just, like, that feeling when you care about somebody, when you've been with them for how many months," Grant Amato says.

Still, Grant Amato insists that the Bulgarian woman was in no way associated with the crime, but he can't provide an alternate theory as to what happened to the family.

"I don't understand why, I don't understand why it happened. I was taking my steps forward despite everything that I was supposed to do, that I was supposed to be doing," Grant Amato said.

Jason Amato begs for answers.

"I'm sorry, I don't believe you and I probably will have resentment the rest of my life whether you did it or didn't do it, but I need closure. I need to know what happened to my mother, my father and my brother, Cody, because I wasn't there to (expletive) help and that hurts me. That hurts me a lot, man. I may not have been able to stop you, you may have hurt me, too, but at least I would have known what happened," Jason Amato says.

He tells his brother that he's not welcome to stay at his home with him because he felt that it could put his life at risk.

"I don't know what else to say. I'm scared for you and I'm scared for myself and I don't feel comfortable with you being around me alone. I'm sorry," Jason Amato.

He also expressed that he's conflicted because he doesn't want his brother to be sentenced to death.

"Even if you did, it's gonna be so hard for me to figure out what to do with you. You do not deserve jail but I can't come to (expletive) have an attorney press charges for you to be killed," Jason Amato said.

Prosecutors filed a notice to seek the death penalty against Grant Amato on Feb. 14.

"Grant I need you to be honest with me man, I need to have closure and if it doesn't come from your mouth and I have to hear it from an attorney or law enforcement or the news, it's going to be harder for me," Jason Amato says. "And I know if you can take mom and dad and Cody's life it's hard for you to comprehend that my emotions are gonna be that, but it's unbelievably scary, Grant."

Before leaving, Jason Amato tells his brother that he will handle funeral and other arrangements by himself.

"Until I'm given verifiable information that you did not do it, I don't think you have the right to make that decision. You already made the decision on whether or not they can live or not," Jason Amato says. "That's not your job."

The 16-minute video ends with the two men hugging.

"I do love you though, remember that, just like mom, dad and Cody loved you. Nobody loved you any more or any less," Jason Amato says.
Address: 4466 N John Young Pkwy, Orlando, FL 32804, USA

Title: 'She was my daughter': Jury in Jonchuck murder trial watches interrogation room video
Summary:
'She was my daughter': Jury in Jonchuck murder trial watches interrogation room video Video Video

PINELLAS COUNTY, Fla. (WFLA) - Day two of the high-profile John Jonchuck murder trial is underway in Pinellas County.

Jonchuck is the man accused of dropping his 5-year-old daughter Phoebe to her death off the Dick Misener Bridge near the Sunshine Skyway in St. Petersburg four years ago.

The trial was delayed several years, but a jury comprised of nine men and seven women was seated Friday.

State prosecutors say they will not seek the death penalty in this case. If found guilty, Jonchuck could serve life in prison. If the jury finds him innocent, he'll stay in a mental institution.

On Monday, the jurors heard opening statements from prosecution and defense teams.

DAY 2 UPDATES:

On day two of the trial, the jury first heard testimony from three additional officers who were involved with the investigation into Phoebe's death. During that testimony, jurors saw the large Swedish Bible that officers say Jonchuck had on him the night Phoebe died. Officer shows Bible from night Phoebe...

After that testimony concluded, prosecutors started showing video of Jonchuck in the interrogation room after being taken into custody back in 2015. Much of the interrogation room video shown so far features Jonchuck sitting by himself waiting to be questioned.

At one point, Jonchuck starts talking to the authorities in the room about a conspiracy and "something bigger going on" that's "beyond me, beyond everything."

Jonchuck: 'I think there's something...

"It's almost like - I'm not being weird - this is like a conspiracy. I went looking for answers, I've always had problems growing up like wondering who I was and what my purpose was," he said.

In the video, Jonchuck also talks about going to a church and speaking with "Father Bill." Jonchuck told a detective in the room that the father said he "wasn't going to be ready this Easter but next Easter" and that, "I was the pope."

Jonchuck talks about 'conspiracy'

After almost an hour of being in the interrogation room, Jonchuck asks about his daughter.

"Is Phoebe OK?" he asks the detective sitting with him.

The detective responds asking who Phoebe is. After a long pause with his head in his hand, Jonchuck responds, "Phoebe was my daughter."

Jonchuck: 'Is Phoebe OK?'

Judge Chris Helinger called the prosecutors and defense attorneys to her bench after watching about an hour of the interrogation room video. Judge Helinger decided to call for a lunch break, putting court in recess until 2 p.m.

When court resumed, the jury watched the rest of the interrogation room video before attorneys cross-examined a detective and a former Hillsborough County deputy.

Jonchuck's mother Michele then took the stand and got emotional talking about her granddaughter Phoebe, who she referred to as her "princess angel."

Jonchuck's mom takes the stand

Jonchuck's mother was excused after giving testimony about swim lessons for Phoebe and who was caring for the girl.

Prosecutors then called Sgt. Kenny Miller to the stand. Miller was assigned as the lead detective on the case involving Phoebe's death. While on the stand, Sgt. Miller described getting to the scene around 1:20 a.m. Jan. 8, 2015 and seeing crews searching for Phoebe.

Miller testified that the girl's body was found just after 1:30 a.m.

"The boats were coming in and I saw Phoebe come off one of the rescue boats and they were performing CPR on her," Miller said. "She was wet, she had what looked like pajamas on. And she looked very pale."

Miller said he did not see any signs of life and did not see Phoebe breathing.

Sgt. Miller testifies about getting...

While Sgt. Miller remained on the stand, attorneys continued to show the video of Jonchuck in the interrogation room after being taken into custody. At one point, Jonchuck asks where the detective is who is supposed to question him. He then comments, "I just want to go to bed, I don't want to talk to anybody."

Jonchuck: 'I just want to go to bed'

Shortly after Jonchuck makes that comment, the video shows Sgt. Miller walk into the interrogation room. He then begins questioning Jonchuck about what happened for about eight minutes.

Interrogation room video: Sgt. Miller...

DAY 1 RECAP:

The prosecution's opening statement lasted more than an hour. During that time, attorney Paul Bolan walked the jury through the events that took place at the Dick Misener Bridge just after midnight on Jan. 8, 2015.

Interrogation room video: Sgt. Miller...

Bolan also addressed the defense's argument that Jonchuck was insane at the time of his daughter's death.

"The defense will argue that the defendant was insane at the time that he committed this murder. And I want you to keep in mind that the defense has to establish that by clear and convincing evidence," he said. "You've been read a jury instruction for insanity but I'm going to read it to you again because it's important and we need to consider it. And we need to consider carefully what these words say. A person is considered to be insane when he had a mental infirmity, disease or defect. But the analysis does not stop there. Someone is not insane just because they have mental illness, just because there's something wrong with them or they may say things that sound strange."

Prosecutor addresses mental illness...

The defense team also walked through the events of the night of Phoebe's death, talking about Jonchuck's actions before, during and after his daughter's death. Attorney Jessica Manuele did not deny that Jonchuck dropped his daughter off the bridge, but called it an act of insanity.

"What happened just after midnight (that night) was tragic. That night, John Jonchuck Jr. took his daughter, whom he loved more than anybody in the world and dropped her over the side of the Dick Misener Bridge," Manuele said. "It didn't make sense at the time, it doesn't make sense today. It will never make sense because it is insanity."

Defense begins opening statement

Manuele told jurors that Jonchuck got out of his car on the bridge holding a large Swedish Bible, then got his daughter Phoebe out and dropped her off the bridge. She argued that Jonchuck was calm and did not hurry away, despite a St. Petersburg police officer witnessing what happened.

Defense gives statements on night of...

The defense team also urged jurors to focus heavily on the evidence without letting emotion get in the way.

"Nobody is disputing that what happened that night was tragic. But if you feel that your heartstrings are being intentionally tugged on, pay attention to that," she said. "We have to focus on the evidence."

After opening statements wrapped up, two witnesses were called to the stand. The first was St. Petersburg Police Officer William Vickers. Vickers is the officer who was on the Dick Misener Bridge when Phoebe was dropped.

Officer William Vicker recalls night...

In his testimony, Officer Vickers talked about his actions after Phoebe was dropped.

"I was immediately concerned for the child. I advised radio of what had happened. I was shocked but my immediate concern was the health, welfare and safety of the child," he said.

Vickers also described hearing a "faint scream and a splash" after Phoebe was dropped from the bridge. The officer says he then climbed down a nearby service ladder to try and search for the child.

"It was in the 40s, low 40s. The winds were gusting over 20 miles an hour. At a couple points, I was nearly blown off the bumper walkway area at the bottom of the bridge," he said, adding that the water was rough, dark and cold.

"I continued to call until a fire rescue boat arrived in the area. At that point, I got on to assist in searching and coordinating between police and fire resources," Vickers said. "I looked at my watch a couple of times thinking 'we gotta find her, we gotta find her.'"

'We gotta find her': Officer...

The second witness called to the stand was a toll collector who gave a brief testimony about what he saw the night Phoebe died.

After the first two witnesses finished testifying, the judge ended court for the day and instructed jurors not to listen to, watch or talk about anything related to the trial.
Address: 200 S Parker St, Tampa, FL 33606, USA

Title: Lake Worth man attacked woman, puppy at Indian River County home, deputies say
Summary:
CLOSE If you see a crime being committed, leave anonymous tips on the Treasure Coast Crime Stoppers hotline, web site or smart phone app. 2019 GINNY BEAGAN/TCPALM Wochit

INDIAN RIVER COUNTY — A Lake Worth man was arrested early Sunday after deputies said he attacked his ex-fiance and punched her puppy when it tried to defend her.

Deputies charged Brian Dosio, 51, with burglary of a structure with assault and battery, battery domestic violence by strangulation, driving under the influence, petty theft and misdemeanor cruelty to animals.

He was being held Tuesday morning at the Indian River County Jail in lieu of $127,500 bail.

More: Teen charged in violent attack, carjacking behind Vero Beach gas station

Deputies responded to the woman's Indian River County home about 1:45 a.m. Sunday.

In an arrest report, deputies said Dosio broke into the home following an argument at a bar and attacked the woman, pushing her to the ground and strangling her.

Brian Dosio, 51, of Lake Worth, was arrested after deputies said he broke into an ex-fiance's Indian River County home and attacked her. (Photo: CONTRIBUTED PHOTO BY INDIAN RIVER COUNTY SHERIFF'S OFFICE)

When her 9-month-old puppy attempted to bite him during the struggle, the woman told deputies Dosio repeatedly punched the animal with a closed fist.

Dosio was stopped in his vehicle a short time later in the 600 block of Highland Drive Southwest. Deputies determined he was "extremely intoxicated," according to the report.

More: Fellsmere man charged with lewd and lascivious battery of girl half his age

The keys to the woman's van, valued at about $200, were found under the driver's seat, the report said.

Eric Rogers is a breaking news reporter for TCPalm and FLORIDA TODAY.

Title: 'Woman at War' battles climate change with a bow and arrow | Movie review
Summary:
Halldóra Geirharðsdóttir is determined to stop a new heavy-industry development by any means necessary in "Woman at War." (Photo: Magnolia Pictures)

“Woman at War” opens with a scene preparing us for the film to come: A woman, alone in the desolate, green highlands of Iceland, expertly (and cleverly, with bow and arrow) takes out a major electrical line running to a bleak, corrosive industrial facility. A game of cat and mouse with a helicopter ensues and our archer escapes in a surprising and delightful way, one with a clear suggestion: The past may still be of help.

The archer is Halla (an excellent Halldóra Geirharðsdóttir), a 50-year-old environmental activist working towards the destruction of the local aluminum industry. She lives a double-life: one, as a choir instructor and a second as a radical activist. At one, in her clean, bright apartment, Halla’s face aligns with two portraits of Gandhi and Mandela. How are we to take this suggestion?

"Woman" walks a line between sincerity and dry humor (aided in part by a fantastic, minimalist score) that manages a quietly warm film about impending environmental disaster.

In the midst of her plans to write a manifesto, Halla receives a letter from an adoption agency. She’s been accepted and a young girl awaits her in a Ukrainian orphanage. The timing is inconvenient, of course. We discover — through her relationship with a government mole (Jörundur Ragnarsson), who also happens to sing in her choir — that the government is closing in.

The film relies on conveniently timed events and coincidentally placed characters, but director Benedikt Erlingsson embraces a surrealist undertone. A three-piece band and Ukrainian a cappella trio appear often in the background of scenes, breaking the fourth wall to light a cigarette or check a tweet. It feels like a wink and a nod in a film that could easily take itself too seriously. Yet Erlingsson uses the score earnestly, as the three Ukranian singers move closer and closer to the live band until the two eventually merge, mirroring the journey Halla must take.

Erlingsson’s film questions what it means to be a hero. Labeled by the media forces as the “Mountain Woman,” Halla ends up with a type of alter-ego that feels reminiscent of the superhero genre of late. Yet Halla also feels more tangibly heroic than the CGI characters of the Marvel and DC Universes.

As the stakes get higher, Halla becomes more and more part of the land she is trying to protect — she hides in holes, bogs and ice caves, gets massively dirty, and more than once must use sheep as various forms of disguise. Here is a film ripe with allusion for how we must interact with the world Halla is trying to save.

“Woman at War” succeeds largely because it doesn’t conform to expectations. Erlingsson continually shifts our gaze, providing us with new viewpoints for how to witness the drama of simply being a woman, of being someone constantly at war, waged purposefully or not.

By the end, we’re left feeling the title might also be commenting on something larger than Halla’s personal war against the aluminum industry.

Alex Jaros is a PhD student in fiction at Florida State University. His work can be found in Narrative Magazine, Glimmer Train, Fiction Southeast, Bird’s Thumb, Ghost Proposal and elsewhere.

IF YOU GO

What: “Woman at War” presented by the Tallahassee Film Society

When: 6 p.m. Friday, 7 p.m. Saturday, 5 p.m. Sunday

Where: All Saints Cinema, 918-1/2 Railroad Ave.

Tickets: $10, $7 for students and TFS members

Visit:www.tallahasseefilms.com

Title: Downtown 'visionary' Susan Myers passes away at age 74
Summary:
FORT WALTON BEACH — Susan Myers returned to her birthplace in 1990, and the rundown buildings and overgrown lots littering downtown stunned her.

Myers made it her mission to restore Brooks Street where her family once lived and where she grew up.

She succumbed to pancreatic cancer Sunday. She was 74.

Tom Rice, owner of Magnolia Grill, calls her a visionary. The historic restaurant and museum built in 1910 was given to Rice by Myers, who financed its restoration.

“She could look at old properties and old buildings and see the value in re-purposing,” Rice said. “She wanted to bring downtown back to life. She just had a sense of style. She was a smart businesswoman.”

A descendant of John and Harriet Brooks, who were original settlers of Fort Walton Beach, Myers redeveloped the area originally known as Camp Walton.

Among her projects were the Camp Walton Condominiums, the old grocery next door, the Miramar Office and Condominiums, the old Harbor Light Restaurant, the French Quarter Condominiums and Magnolia Grill to name a few. Additionally, Myers planted trees and preserved historic ones.

Myers also created the original mural on the Brooks Bridge.

“I think she is the only person who had a vision and knew how to preserve history,” said Ted Corcoran, Greater Fort Walton Beach Chamber of Commerce president and CEO. “I do not think we would be where we are now as a community without her renovations that resurrected downtown.”

Okaloosa County Commissioner Carolyn Ketchel also credited Myers for the resurgence of downtown.

“She made major contributions to our area,” Ketchel said. “She really came back and said, ‘I want to make a difference in this community.’”

Myers moved back to Fort Walton Beach with her husband, Scott, to take care of her ailing mother, Diana “Billie” Pryor Sloat. Her mother was the first baby born in Fort Walton Beach.

The Myers moved away in 1968, traveling the world for 28 years while running their own consulting practice (both were industrial psychologists). Her husband died in 1996 from cancer.

In a recent Chamber of Commerce video, Myers said she loved Fort Walton Beach more than any other place. She recalled her father, Capt. John Sloat, would take people out on fishing trips in the Gulf of Mexico.

“It was just a rich time growing up here,” Myers said. “We just loved to be in Fort Walton.”

Myers, like her family members, has always been active in the community. She served on the Fort Walton Beach City Council and many other community organizations. The author and real estate developer earned induction into the Okaloosa County Commission on the Status of Women’s Hall of Fame in 2005.

Education was also important to Myers. She recalled in a Jan. 16, 2017, Daily News story that her great-grandfather John Thomas Brooks, who was a Civil War veteran, signed documents with an "X."

Her grandparents, W.C. Pryor and Sarah Frances Brooks Pryor, were education advocates. Her grandfather was the first superintendent of schools in Okaloosa County, while her grandmother was a philanthropist, businesswoman and the city’s postmistress for 28 years.

“When I was looking for an organization to support, I wanted something that was local, and something that was educational,” she said. “The college has a permanent presence in Northwest Florida, with deep roots in the community, much like my family.”

Myers donated $1 million to the Susan Myers Learning Resources Center at Northwest Florida State College.

“I thought and thought about different names,” Myers told the Daily News. “But the foundation officials kept coming and putting my name on it. They basically dragged me kicking and screaming until I finally agreed.”

Myers also established a separate, $90,000 bequest to fund six scholarship endowments in honor of Sarah Frances Brooks Pryor, W.C. Pryor, M. Scott Myers, Susan Pryor Sloat, Diana Pryor Sloat and John Gregory Sloat.

Longtime friend Ann Moore said she admired Myers, who received an associate’s degree in humanities from the University of Florida, a bachelor’s degree in political science from the University of Colorado and a master’s degree in industrial psychology from Southern Methodist University.

“She is one of the most brilliant women I have ever known,” Moore said. “She is more accomplished than any woman I have ever known. But she was quiet about it. She didn’t want any accolades.”

Liz McCartney recalled growing up with Myers on Brooks Street where Myers’ grandparents lived.

“She was a down-home girl,” McCartney said. “You had to love her, if you knew her. She was just a wonderful person.”
Address: 2 Eglin Pkwy NE, Fort Walton Beach, FL 32548, USA

Title: Parkland community worried after 2 survivors’ suicides
Summary:
Parkland Mayor Christine Hunschofsky said Monday that community leaders, government officials, parents, police and others held an emergency meeting Sunday after a second Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School student apparently killed himself over the weekend.

FORT LAUDERDALE — Tragedies like the Marjory Stoneman Douglas High and Sandy Hook Elementary school massacres eventually fade from view, blunted by other mass shootings and the passage of time. But for the survivors, the pain can never end.

The father of a Sandy Hook victim killed himself Monday, just days after two Stoneman Douglas students also took their lives. The Florida deaths have officials in Parkland and nearby Coral Springs renewing their communities' focus on the suicide prevention and mental health resources that remain available 13 months after a gunman killed 17 people at the high school.

In Newtown, Connecticut, where 20 first-graders died along with six staff members six years ago, the body of 49-year-old Jeremy Richman was found outside his office Monday morning.

Richman's daughter Avielle was fatally shot at Sandy Hook. He had visited Florida last week and met with the parents of Stoneman Douglas victims, said Lori Alhadeff, whose 14-year-old daughter Alyssa died there.

Richman and his wife oversaw The Avielle Foundation, a group they started dedicated to preventing violence by better understanding brain health.

"Our hearts are shattered, and our heads are struggling to comprehend," the foundation said in a statement. "Tragically, his death speaks to how insidious and formidable a challenge brain health can be and how critical it is for all of us to seek help for ourselves, our loved ones and anyone who we suspect may be in need."

Multiple suicides among mass shooting survivors can be alarming, but mental health experts said the Florida deaths are not surprising. They come amid a rising nationwide trend: More than 47,000 U.S. suicides occurred in 2017, at the highest rate in at least half a century — 14 per 100,000. Suicide is the second-leading cause of death among U.S. teenagers.

"One of the big risk factors for suicide is exposure to violence," said Dr. Louis Kraus, chief of child and adolescent psychiatry at Rush University Medical Center in Chicago.

Even if they weren't hit by bullets or didn't see shots fired, "anyone who was at that school is at risk," Kraus said, and should be screened.

"The scars simply don't go away with a fresh coat of paint," he said.

Psychologist April Foreman, a board member at the American Association of Suicidology, said survivors are more prone to suicide and thus must be vigilant about mental health check-ups just as if they had a family history of breast cancer or heart disease.

With help, people can overcome their suicidal impulses, she said.

"It's not a foregone conclusion that this will happen to everyone who's been exposed to this and the majority of people who are suicidal don't go on to die. They go on to recover and live," she said.

The first suicide took place March 16. Cara Aiello told WFOR-TV last week that her 18-year-old daughter Sydney had suffered from survivor's guilt — her friend, Meadow Pollack, died in the attack.

Sydney had been diagnosed with post-traumatic stress disorder and struggled to attend college because she feared being in a classroom, but never asked for help, her mother said.

Coral Springs police officer Tyler Reik confirmed Monday that a Stoneman Douglas sophomore apparently killed himself Saturday, but said an official determination had not been made pending an autopsy. The boy's name was not immediately released.

Community leaders, government officials, parents, police and others held an emergency meeting Sunday after the second student suicide, Parkland Mayor Christine Hunschofsky said.

The biggest push will be to alert parents to talk to their children about whether they are having suicidal thoughts and outline the danger signs for them, such as personality changes or a preoccupation with death, she said.

The groups also want students to look out for each other, and noted that the community counseling and resource centers that opened after the attack still remain available.

The task has been made more difficult as Stoneman Douglas students are on spring break.

Hunschofsky said that while there is concern the two suicides could lead to more, it is more dangerous not to discuss what happened.

"We cannot be afraid of talking — the only way we are going to identify people who need help is to talk about it," she said.

A 16-year-old Stoneman Douglas sophomore who was in a classroom where three students died on Feb. 14, 2018, told The Associated Press on Monday that she tried to kill herself four times before she entered therapy.

At first, she was ashamed, she said, fearing that accepting counseling would mean she "couldn't' handle my problems" and "I was broken." But her attitude changed with the support of therapists, family and friends, said the girl, who the AP is not naming because of her age.

The girl said she fears not every Stoneman Douglas student who needs counseling is getting it and noted that some teachers seem uncomfortable talking about suicide and simply want to move on.

In Connecticut, Richman was among the Sandy Hook relatives suing Infowars host Alex Jones for contending the Newtown shooting never happened.

Neil Heslin, whose son, Jesse Lewis, was killed at Sandy Hook, said the families' grief has been compounded by such conspiracy theories.

"Every day you get up, you expect to get punched in the chin," Heslin said. "I give Jeremy credit for what he accomplished with his work and his amazing strength that grew through the years."

Newtown Police Lt. Aaron Bahamonde said Richman left a suicide note, but did not disclose its contents.

On Monday, residents streamed into the Resiliency Center of Newtown, which was set up shortly after the shooting as a place for therapy and for people to gather to talk. Richman worked with the center in providing "brain health" first aid for children and others.

His friend, Stephanie Cinque, the center's executive director, said people are angry, sad and shocked by his death.

"There's mixed feelings throughout town," she said. "Grief is complicated. It's very sad for the family, the children, the entire community. So today we're letting people know it's OK to have those feelings."

The emotional scars survivors feel last for decades.

Columbine High massacre survivor Heather Martin was not physically injured in the 1999 shooting that left 13 dead, but said she took years to emotionally overcome the attack. She helped form the Rebels Project, named after Columbine's mascot, to assist mass trauma survivors.

"Resilience is connecting with other people and gaining strength from other people," Martin said. "You don't always have to be the strongest person."
Address: 501 W 11th St, Panama City, FL 32401, USA

Title: Parents charged after leaving toddler in a park by herself Friday night
Summary:
Advertisement Parents charged after leaving toddler in a park by herself Friday night Share Shares Copy Link Copy

UPDATE - Parents of toddler left at a West Palm Beach park have been charged with child neglect.Around noon Saturday, the mother of the child, Jolanda Larose Alexandre, 38, of West Palm Beach, called and reported the child missing.Deputies responded to their home in the 5000 block of Stacy Street in West Palm Beach.The mother and father of the child, Mackenson Alexandre, 34, of West Palm Beach were arrested and charged with child neglect.Both parents told deputies they did not realize they left their child at the park Friday night.DCF responded to the home and removed seven other children from the home.PREVIOUS STORY - PBSO says that as of Saturday morning, it has not identified the little girl found wandering alone Friday night at Haverhill Park.Numerous deputies checked the area, loud announcements were made and a reverse 911 call was initiated. All met with negative results.DCF responded and currently has custody of the child, who is thought to be about 2 years old.Anyone knows who the child is- or who her parents are, or has any other helpful information, is urged to contact PBSO Dispatch at 561-688-3400.PREVIOUS STORY - Just before 8 p.m. Friday, deputies responded to Haverhill Park in West Palm Beach and located a little girl walking inside the park alone.The Palm Beach County Sheriff's Office believes the child can be possibly 2 years old. She was wearing a pink short-sleeved shirt and a white and gold tutu with clear plastic shoes. Numerous deputies checked the area, loud announcements were made and a reverse 911 call was initiated. All met with negative results. DCF was notified, responded and currently is in possession of the child. If anyone knows who the child is or who her parents are or has any other helpful information is urged to contact PBSO Dispatch at 561-688-3400.

Title: Cape Coral teen reported missing and endangered
Summary:
The Cape Coral Police Department is seeking help locating a missing and endangered teenager.

Tori Ann Beard, age 17, was last seen around 5 p.m. Saturday in the 1600 block of SW 12th Terrace. She was last seen wearing a black jacket with white stripes and a hood, red hat, black shorts, and gray sneakers.

Beard is described as 5-foot-1, 104 pounds, with red hair and hazel eyes. Anyone with information on her whereabouts is asked to contact the Cape Coral Police Department at 239-574-3223.
