Title: Roundabout eyed to ease busy Gateway intersections, but some fear confusion
Summary:
Fort Myers Roundabout -- Planned for the intersection of First and Seaboard streets and Palm Beach Boulevard (Photo: SPECIAL TO THE NEWS-PRESS)

More homes, more businesses and more traffic have proven to be a formula for more traffic accidents and more congestion in the Gateway Community east of Fort Myers, may force residents and visitors to either work through their panic attacks over maneuvering roundabouts or spend more time and gas waiting for lights to change.

Lee County transportation managers say the increased traffic on roads in Gateway are causing spikes in the number of accidents and it's time to make some changes to make travel safer.

The experts say it is time for the modern convenience of traffic control to come to a couple of busy intersections in the complex laid out by Westinghouse Gateways Communities Inc. more than 35 years ago.

Contemporary News-Press reports referred to the area as a controversial development of "5,567 desolate acres" on which "the most important development" county officials had ever dealt with, could jeopardize Lee County's water supply.

County Commissioners will be asked to approve nearly $375,000 for traffic studies at Gateway Boulevard and Griffin Drive and at the boulevard and Commerce Lakes Drive with an eye toward building roundabouts or installing traffic lights at the intersection.

Buy Photo Cape Coral Roundabout -- At SE 47th Terrace and Vincennes Blvd. (Photo: Ricardo Rolon / The News-Press)

"Over the past few years, traffic volumes have increased to the point where (the intersections have) become a traffic crash problem," said Rancy Cerchie, the county transportation director in a memorandum to commissioners.

The county has reported 33 traffic crashes, 24 of them T-bone accidents, at Griffin and Gateway from 2015-18. The Commerce Lakes and Gateway intersection has seen 75 crashes, with 50 of them the dangerous T-bone right angle crash.

"A review of possible traffic control changes showed that a roundabout is the best alternative in improving safety without adding excessive delays," Cerchie wrote. "A traffic signal would improve safety but motorists would have longer delays."

"The traffic situation at those intersections is very serious, we’ve had a number of accidents, but none fatal,thankfully," said Bill Guy, vice chair of the elected Gateway Services Community Development District Board of Supervisors.

The idea that installing the circular merge maneuver on Gateway roads as a safety measure is not something Guy is ready to embrace.

Bonita Springs Roundabout -- Design for roundabout built on Old 41 Road as part of reconstruction of downtown Bonita Springs. (Photo: City of Bonita Springs.)

"I would be in favor of a traffic light or other device as opposed to roundabouts," he said. "I know that some of the engineers think they are wonderful but take up an awful lot of ground and it takes a lot of time for people to get used to it."

Advocates of roundabouts for some intersections say they reduce the amount of time people sit and wait at intersections after all the cross-traffic that is going to pass during the light cycle has gone through.

A county spokesman said the recommendation was based on traffic projections extending to 2040, suggesting that roundabouts are considered a solution for the next two decades.

Gateway has grown to more than 10,000 people, according to some estimates, an increase of nearly 20 percent since the 2010 census. With an average age in the early 40s for both men and women, much of the community is family-oriented which means more daily traffic trips for everything from Girl Scout cookie sales to proms.

NEWSLETTERS Get the Breaking News newsletter delivered to your inbox We're sorry, but something went wrong Urgent developments you should know now, not later. Please try again soon, or contact Customer Service at 1-800-468-0233. Delivery: varies Invalid email address Thank you! You're almost signed up for Breaking News Keep an eye out for an email to confirm your newsletter registration. More newsletters

"Oh yes, when we get our new high school in two years, it will be even worse," Guy said. "Teachers and buses need to get to the school, it will be a lot more traffic."

Gateway High School is expected to open for the 2020-21 academic year.

Buy Photo Estero Roundabout -- Built at Williams Road and Via Coconut Point (Photo: Amanda Inscore/The News-Press)

Several new businesses have located in Gateway and across Daniels Parkway from its southern entrance, the Lee Port Authority continues to develop its Skyplex complex which has the potential to inspire traffic to use Gateway as a convenient shortcut to the north or east via State Road 82

Gartner Inc. has expended its space in Gateway and is one of several companies looking at space across Daniels Parkway in a business park being developed on Southwest Florida International Airport land. The Gartner campus at Skyplex has room for another building.

Alta Resources LLC, which operates call centers, is also expanding on to the airport's Skyplex park, which is expected to add around 800 new jobs.

Still being considered for the airport property is a 400-acre motorsports complex, which a Port Authority spokeswoman says is still going through preliminary evaluations by both the investor and the airport.

Roundabouts have been widely accepted but are still controversial in some places. The Estero Village Council rejected three roundabouts on Estero Parkway to leave room for two lanes of traffic.

County Commissioners are being asked to approve close to $375,000 for the needed work to design the two intersections.

'Projects like this really piss me off': Historical Commission says no to McGregor roundabout

Title: He’s just like any other boy, except that he let his hair grown down to his back. Here’s why he did it.
Summary:
Please enable Javascript to watch this video

WEST JORDAN, Utah – A Utah boy is helping other kids by growing out and giving away his own hair - with a personal reason for his unique way of giving back. On Thursday afternoon, Morgan Gero indulged in a round of Apex Legends in his bedroom as one hand furiously clicked away on the keyboard and the other made quick movements with the mouse.

Morgan enjoys video games, and a quick look around his room shows something else he loves – Star Wars.

"The force is strong with this one," bold lettering states above his window as a life-size cutout of Anakin Skywalker stares down from one of the walls.

It's clear Morgan is like any other 12-year-old boy – but some people mistake him for a girl. It's because Morgan's hair flows down to the middle of his back.

"It's annoying when people just think I'm a girl," he said. "Usually when I go into the boys bathroom, people kind of look at me funny. Even the adults look at me funny. They're like, 'What are you doing in this bathroom?'"

What Morgan's doing is growing his hair out for kids who lost theirs because of medical issues and treatments.

"Those kids who really need hair," he said. "So yeah. I could help them out."

After two years, Morgan's locks have reached the right length to donate to Wigs for Kids.

His mother, Sandrine Gero, took Morgan to chop off 12 inches Thursday afternoon.

"Alright, you ready?" hairdresser Marion Gallagher asked before she separated the hair into small pony tails, and snipped them off one-by-one.

The process was pretty painless, and important – especially for a kid who has suffered some serious medical problems of his own.

"I was born earlier than I was supposed to [be born]," Morgan said. Sandrine said she went into labor at 27 weeks. Morgan lived his first weeks of life in the NICU, and Sandrine said he almost didn't survive.

"It was really hard. It was very traumatic for both me and my husband," Sandrine said. "We did not know if he was actually going to live."

Morgan beat the odds and didn't suffer any lifelong health conditions.

He knows other kids like him aren't as lucky, and he said he wants "to help kids feel normal."

This isn't the first time Morgan has donated his hair.

Four years ago, he began to grow his hair out. He donated it for the first time two years ago. Then, he started the process again.

Even though Morgan said it will be nice to not get any more weird looks with his new short haircut, he plans to keep going.

Morgan will grow his hair out a third time as he continues to give back to this cause.
Address: 500 E Broward Blvd #800, Fort Lauderdale, FL 33394, USA

Title: Celebrate women during March and beyond
Summary:
Rev. Candace McKibben (Photo: Candace McKibben)

I was standing in the outdoor gardening area of the Home Depot trying to decide between New Guinea Impatiens and Pentas for the flower bed I was creating for my son and daughter-in-law, when I realized that NPR was playing over the sound system. I do not usually go to the Home Depot during the week and at such an early hour, and am not accustomed to hearing talk radio in the gardening section.

Maybe it was my wonderment at hearing talk rather than music, but it was as if I heard for the first time the disclaimer I have probably heard thousands of times about public radio not discriminating against a number of groups, including women. “Women?” I said out loud to no one. It felt archaic, insensitive, even ridiculous in 2019 to have to make such a disclaimer.

Though I have certainly felt my share of discrimination as a woman in ministry through the years, hearing this disclaimer felt particularly poignant and painful to me that misty morning in Jacksonville at the Home Depot.

On Friday of that same week, I was listening to NPR where I am accustomed to hearing it, in my car on the way to work, when I heard a remarkable story for International Women’s Day on Morning Edition.

It had aired originally on Jan. 14, 2019, on All Things Considered, and I understand why the editors found it worthy of broadcasting again. Featuring the anthem, “Quiet,” written by artist MILCK (Connie Lim), the program detailed how and why the song was written and how it has taken on a life of its own around the world since discovered at the Women’s March in Washington in 2017.

Connie Lim co-wrote “Quiet” in 2015 as a way to help her cope with being sexually assaulted and abused when she was a teenager. She thought of it as her personal therapy song, reminding her to speak out no matter what about things that matter. In the interview on NPR, Connie recalled how as a child she had been taught “to sit properly, to speak less, to smile more, to lose weight and just be this perfect little girl.” After a haunting dream in 2015 in which she told her abuser that she could not keep quiet, she was encouraged to translate the wisdom of her dream into a song.

The next year during the 2016 Presidential campaign, Connie found herself reliving some of her earlier trauma because of the ways in which women were being portrayed by some covered in the national media. In response, she decided to share her song with a broader audience. She invited some a Capella singers in Washington, DC to join her at the March to sing it.

Though not on stage, they captured the attention and hearts of many women there as they sang the song repeatedly to any audience they could generate as they wandered amidst the massive crowd. A filmmaker in the crowd captured the singers on her cell phone and her post went viral. Today the anthem has been sung around the world and translated into other languages, deeply resonating in the hearts of women of many different places and cultures.

I know that when I heard this broadcast on NPR on International Women’s Day, I was moved to tears. You can hear the song at: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QZD05-ZvQFs

Inspired by International Women’s Day, March is National Women’s History Month. The month-long celebration started as a local week-long celebration in Santa Rosa County, California, in 1978. In 1980, President Jimmy Carter issued the first Presidential Proclamation declaring March 8-14 as the first National Women’s History Week. He noted that though men and women have built our nation, too often women are unsung and their contributions go unnoticed.

Carter affirmed that, “the achievements, leadership, courage, strength and love of the women who built America is as vital as that of the men whose names we know so well.” In 1987 Congress declared that a month, rather than a week, be devoted to Women’s History and since that time we have as a nation celebrated National Women’s History Month in March.

In our own community during March for the last 13 years, we have honored 25 women to know and, more recently, five young women to watch, celebrating the ways in which their achievements, leadership, courage, strength and love have enhanced our lives. It is a beautiful gesture but we know that there are thousands of unsung heroes who deserve our respect and admiration, not only for what they have accomplished, but simply for who they are as human beings.

Discrimination is a painful experience for all who know it and the more we can all do to give everyone a voice and a sense of belonging, the richer we all will be. During March and beyond let the girls and women in your life know how much they matter.

The Rev. Candace McKibben is an ordained minister who serves as the director of faith outreach at Big Bend Hospice and as pastor of Tallahassee Fellowship.

Read or Share this story: https://www.tallahassee.com/story/life/faith/2019/03/15/celebrate-women-during-march-and-beyond/3167200002/
Address: 277 N Magnolia Dr, Tallahassee, FL 32301, USA

Title: 25 Women: Tracy Thomas blazes a trail with heart and soul
Summary:
CLOSE Meet the 25 Women You Need to Know in March. Tallahassee Democrat

Tracy Thomas grew up on a 40-acre farm just outside Tallahassee. When she talks about the property, it seems to spring up around her.

She is the eldest of roughly 50 cousins she would see on Sundays when the families gathered for church.

“We were busy, as kids. We fished a lot. We played outdoor games. We just had fun,” Thomas says.

Thomas is a 50-year-old professor of physical therapy at Florida A&M University. She is one of the 25 Women You Need to Know. Now in its 13th year, the program is the Tallahassee Democrat’s way of honoring women who lead. Look for their profiles during March in print and see videos on tallahassee.com.

By Mother’s Day this year, Thomas will have completed her second doctorate, which may make her the only African-American woman in the nation to have a doctorate in both pharmaceutical sciences and physical therapy.

But Thomas’s path hasn’t been without its obstacles. When she first started as an undergraduate student at FAMU on an academic scholarship, Thomas flunked out of her pharmacy school program.

“Of those several grandchildren in our family, that was just unheard of. And so, while there were people that were, like, ‘Well, we knew she wasn’t going to’…my mother just never gave up,” Thomas says.

A couple years later, Thomas sailed through that same course again in graduate school with flying colors and set the curve for her class. With her exam pinned to her scrubs, a score of 105 out of 100, Thomas went to the nursing home where she and her mother both worked.

There was a brief exchange where Thomas’s mother asked what an exam was doing pinned to her daughter’s scrubs and a proud young Thomas boasted about her new scores in the class.

“And she goes, ‘Huh, you could’ve done that all along,’ and walked off!” Thomas says.

She laughs at the memory.

Buy Photo Dr. Tracy Thomas, one of Tallahassee's 2019 25 Women You Need to Know. (Photo: Alicia Devine/Democrat)

“That’s my mom. I have since learned that she would literally be just beaming to other people. But to show me?”

Thomas shakes her head. She says her mom never wanted her to get a big head.

The first thing Thomas notices about other people is how they carry themselves — if they’re “warm and open, and if they’re approachable.”

Thomas’s grandmother passed down to the young girl an appreciation for storytelling, especially for the stories in the Bible, her favorite book.

“Growing up in the country without cable television, she would tell me (the Bible) has the best stories,” she says. And her favorite movie is, “hands down, ‘The Color Purple.’”

The advice Thomas has for young people comes from her Christian upbringing and the stories her grandmother cultivated within her.

“Trust God, trust the process, never give up on yourself. For me, that has been key,” Thomas says. “I can now say that all the little phrases that my grandmother used to say to me — ‘there’s nothing too hard for God. Try him and believe Him.’ — I used to be like, hmm, OK. But I know those things to be true now.”

The Moore Agency logo (Photo: The Moore Agency)

Presenting the 25 Women

The 25 Women You Need to Know and 5 Young Women to Watch is presented by Moore, a nationally ranked communications and marketing agency.

Title: Lee County sheriff arrests third suspect in botched North Fort Myers armed robbery
Summary:
CLOSE This is a six-month review of the most-read crime stories in Lee County on news-press.com from September 2018 to February 2019. Vonna Keomanyvong, vonna.keomanyvong@naplesnews.com; 239-213-5380

A Fort Myers man is facing multiple aggravated assault and burglary charges in connection with a botched armed robbery in early February in North Fort Myers.

Robert Louis Diaz, 26, was arrested Wednesday, the third of three male alleged suspects in the crime.

The botched armed robbery happened Feb. 9 and led to one suspect being hospitalized with a gunshot wound and two others arrested, according to the Lee County Sheriff's Office.

Diaz (Photo: Special to The News-Press)

The injured suspect was shot by a victim of the armed robbery, which took place at approximately 2:20 a.m. at 560 Pine Island Road, a LCSO news release said. That address is a complex that includes Little Caesar's, Computer ER, A-Plus Affordable Appliances and Allstar Professional services.

More: One suspect shot, two others arrested for armed robbery in North Fort Myers Saturday

According to the LCSO, three armed male suspects entered a business and confronted the victims. One of the victims shot one suspect who was transported to an area hospital.

Diaz was charged with four counts of aggravated assault with a weapon, one count of burglary, and two counts of violation of probation. He remains in Lee County jail on $130,000 bond and will be arraigned April 15.

Joshua Tatlock (left) and Killian Irberseder were arrested after an alleged armed robbery at a North Fort Myers business that resulted in a third unidentified suspect being shot by a victim. (Photo: news-press.com)

Joshua Tatlock, 32, and Killian Irberseder, 18, fled in a vehicle and were found and detained by alert deputies shortly after the call was received. Tatlock and Irberseder were linked to the attempted robbery and arrested. Both are charged with armed burglary of an occupied structure and aggravated assault.

Connect with this reporter: MichaelBraunNP (Facebook) @MichaelBraunNP (Twitter)

Want more News-Press breaking news coverage? If you're already a subscriber to the News-Press, thank you! If not, please subscribe to keep coverage of News-Press breaking news coming.

Title: New WPB mayor hopes to move forward, 'inspire young people'
Summary:
Hide Transcript Show Transcript

GOING FORWARD AND PLANNING ON BEING THE NEXT AYOR OF WEST PALM BEACH. >> THANK YOU. THANK YOU SO MUCH, MAN. ARI: KEITH JAMES HAD JUST LEARNED HE HAD WON THE ELECTION TUESDAY NIGHT, JUST LEARNED HE WOULD SOON BE THE MAYOR OF WEST PALM BEACH, AND HE COULDN’T HELP BUT SHOW JUST HOW MUCH IT MEANT. TERRI: YOU SOUND EMOTIONAL. >> I AM. BECAUSE I KNOW HOW MUCH WORK WENT INTO THIS. ARI: WEDNESDAY AFTERNOON, A LESS EMOTIONAL KEITH JAMES IS READY TO HIT THE GROUND RUNNING. >> I WAS THE ONE CANDIDATE THAT REALLY FELT BULLISH ON WEST PALM BEACH AND FELT THAT WE SHOULD MAINTAIN OUR MOMENTUM. ARI: JAMES SAYS HE HAS THREE TOP PRIORITIES. AFFORDABLE HOUSING IS ONE. ANOTHER IS REDUCING CRIME BY ENCOURAGING OFFICERS TO BE MORE INVOLVED. >> RATHER THAN DRIVING THROUGH SOME OF THESE NEIGHBORHOODS WITH THE WINDOWS UP, THE AIR CONDITIONING ON, THEY NEED TO GET OUT OF THE CARS AND INTERACT WITH THE COMMUNITY. ARI: JAMES’ THIRD PRIORITY, HOMELESSNESS. HE SAYS HE WANTS TO REMAIN COMPASSIONATE, BUT NOT JUST TO THE HOMELESS. >> WE NEED TO RESPECT THE RIGHTS OF THE PRIVATE BUSINESS PEOPLE AND FOLKS WHO JUST WANT TO ENJOY SOME OF OUR PUBLIC SPACES, AND SO WE’LL HAVE AN ENFORCEMENT ELEMENT. ARI: AND DON’T THINK JAMES DOESN’T RECOGNIZE WHAT THIS ELECTION MEANS. >> YOU GUYS ACT LIKE SOMETHING HISTORIC HAPPENED TONIGHT. ARI: THERE HAVE BEEN OTHER AFRICAN AMERICAN MAYORS OF WEST PALM BEACH, BUT THEY WERE ALL ELECTED TO COUNCIL AND THEN APPOINTED MAYOR. KEITH JAMES IS THE FIRST AFRICAN AMERICAN TO BE ELECTED TO THE OFFICE OF MAYOR OF WEST PALM BEACH. >> I HOPE IT INSPIRES SOME YOUNG PEOPLE, THAT AFRICAN AMERICAN YOUNG PEOPLE, LITTLE BOY OR LITTLE GIRL, TO SAY YOU KNOW WHAT, I CAN GROW UP TO BE MA

Advertisement New WPB mayor hopes to move forward, 'inspire young people' Keith James is first African-American elected mayor of West Palm Beach Share Shares Copy Link Copy

Less than 24 hours after winning the race for West Palm Beach mayor, Keith James said he can’t wait to get started.“I was the one candidate that really felt bullish on West Palm Beach and felt that we should maintain our momentum,” James said in a one-on-one interview with WPBF 25 News.James said he has three top priorities.One is adding more affordable housing in the city.Another is reducing violent crime by encouraging police officers to be more involved.“Rather than driving through some of these neighborhoods with the windows up, air conditioning on, they need to get out of the cars and interact with the community,” James said.James’ third priority is curing the city’s homelessness problem.He said he wants to remain compassionate but not just to the homeless.“We need to respect the rights of the private businesspeople and folks who just want to enjoy some of our public spaces, and so we’ll have an enforcement element,” James said.On another note, James also said he does not underestimate the significance of his victory.While there have been other African-Americans to serve as mayor of West Palm Beach, they were all elected to the City Council and then appointed as mayor in what was mostly a ceremonial position.James is the first African-American to be elected to the office of mayor of West Palm Beach.“I hope it inspires young people, African-American young people, little boy or little girl, to say, ‘You know what? I can grow up to be mayor one day or congressperson or lawyer or whatever,’” James said. “Just to inspire them to pursue their dreams.”James is set to be sworn into office April 4.

Title: Ukrainian teen's hair nearly 8 feet long
Summary:
UKRAINE (WFLA/CNN) - A teenage girl in Ukraine has hair so long, it drags on the ground behind her!

Olena's hair is so long she holds the record for longest hair in her country at EIGHT FEET LONG!

Olena's mother says she does not do anything too special to grow it so long, just normal shampoo and conditioner.

In case you're wondering, washing it takes a half hour and braiding it, another 30 minutes. Olena hopes to break the world record for her age group, and eventually take on the adult category.
Address: 200 S Parker St, Tampa, FL 33606, USA

Title: Dozens of K-9 units visit terminally ill Wisconsin girl who loves dogs
Summary:
Please enable Javascript to watch this video

HARTLAND, Wis. – A terminally ill Wisconsin girl who adores dogs got a visit over the weekend from more than 35 K-9 teams from across the state.

Emma Mertens, a 7-year-old who was recently diagnosed with a brain tumor, has received countless letters of encouragements and photos of pups from all around the world – but this Saturday she got to meet dozens of police dogs in person.

Officers and their furry counterparts were all smiles as they greeted Emma and her family, posing for plenty of photos.

"There are no words....Pure Joy!," reads a post on Team Emma's Facebook page. "Thank you to everyone who took the time to organize and participate in this."

In late January, Mertens was diagnosed with Diffuse Intrinsic Pontine Glioma (DIPG), a rare brain tumor. A family friend thought it would be nice to raise the spirits of the little animal lover with a letter from her dog. She asked her friends to do the same.

Mertens has received more than 75,000 well wishes from across the world. Team Emma's GoFundMe has raised nearly $125,000.

To share your dog pictures with Emma, send them to:
Address: 500 E Broward Blvd #800, Fort Lauderdale, FL 33394, USA

Title: Young rapper to perform at Legoland
Summary:
WINTER HAVEN — Alaya High, a 12-year-old hip hop artist known as That Girl Lay Lay, will perform at Legoland Florida Resort on March 27 as part of the park’s opening of The Lego Movie World attraction.

Alaya appears as the freestyle rapper in “The Catchy Song” from the newly released “The Lego Movie 2: The Second Part.” She has more than 40 million views across her social media channels and has appeared on “The Ellen DeGeneres Show.” At 12, That Girl Lay Lay is the youngest female rapper to sign a record deal, according to a Legoland news release.

A media event for the opening of The Lego Movie World begins March 27 at 9 a.m.
Address: 300 W Lime St, Lakeland, FL 33815, USA

Title: Former Naples High School teacher accused of sex with student pleads no contest in separate case
Summary:
CLOSE Brock Smith, the former Naples High School teacher accused of having sexual relations with a minor, listens to Collier Circuit Judge Ramiro Mañalich during a hearing on Feb. 8, 2019. Jake Allen, jake.allen@naplesnews.com; 239-213-6042

The former Naples High School teacher accused of sex crimes against two students pleaded no contest Tuesday in one of two cases he is facing.

Brock Smith, 31, pleaded no contest to felony charges of transmitting harmful material to a minor and using a computer service to seduce, solicit, lure or entice a child for pornography.

Buy Photo Brock Smith, the former Naples High School teacher accused of sex with a student, listens to his attorney, public defender Shawn Nagle, before he pleads no contest to some charges in front of Collier Circuit Judge Ramiro Mañalich on Tuesday, March 12, 2019. A jury trial for his other charges is pending. (Photo: Jessica Rodriguez/ Naples Daily News)

Around July 16, 2017, Smith requested to follow a girl on Instagram. Through Instagram direct messages, he told her to delete the message thread and add him on Snapchat, according to an arrest report.

The girl then added Smith to her Snapchat account, and Smith sent her lewd messages, the report states. Smith sent the girl a photo, via Snapchat, of himself nude, standing in front of a bathroom mirror brushing his teeth, according to the report.

More: Former Naples High teacher accused of sex with student expected to plead no contest to some charges

More: Former Naples High teacher accused of sex with student, 17, faces trial Friday

Buy Photo Brock Smith, the former Naples High School teacher accused of sex with a student, pleads no contest to some charges in front of Collier Circuit Judge Ramiro Mañalich on Tuesday, March 12, 2019. A jury trial for his other charges is is pending. (Photo: Jessica Rodriguez/Naples Daily News)

Smith then requested that the girl send him a photo, the report states. He continued to message the girl through Snapchat for about a week and told her "that he was free in the mornings to meet for sex" when his wife would be out of town, according to the report.

Collier Circuit Judge Ramiro Mañalich did not sentence Smith on Tuesday; sentencing is set for May 9, court documents show.

In another case which is to be set for trial, the former teacher faces two felony charges of engaging in sexual activity with a person 16 or 17 years old, court documents show. The girl in the case is expected to be at an April 29 hearing.

More: Judge OKs contested evidence against former Naples High teacher accused of sex with teen

More: Trial delayed for former Naples High teacher accused of sex with student

Buy Photo Brock Smith, the former Naples High School teacher accused of sex with a student pleads no contest to some charges in front of Collier Circuit Judge Ramiro Mañalich on Tuesday, March 12, 2019. A jury trial for his other charges is pending. (Photo: Jessica Rodriguez/ Naples Daily News)

Smith told investigators that he had sexual intercourse with the girl in a bathroom where she was employed, the arrest report states.

Smith was arrested on Aug. 14, 2017, after an investigation from the Collier County Sheriff's Office and the state Department of Children and Families.

Smith was hired by Collier County Public Schools in 2011 and worked at Naples High School for six years prior to his arrest. He also was a coach for the school's football team.

After School Board members approved his dismissal at a Sept. 26, 2017, meeting, Smith was fired, then-Collier school district spokesman Greg Turchetta said at the time.

Title: US pulls all diplomatic staff from Venezuela amid unfolding horror
Summary:
A view of the facade of the American embassy in Caracas on Jan. 24, 2019, in Caracas, Venezuela.

CARACAS, Venezuela - The U.S. said late Monday that it is pulling its last remaining diplomats from Venezuela, saying their continued presence at the country's embassy in Caracas had become a "constraint" on U.S. policy as the Trump administration aggressively looks to oust socialist President Nicolas Maduro.

The announcement came from Secretary of State Mike Pompeo in a tweet shortly before midnight comes as Venezuela struggles to restore electricity following four days of blackouts around the country.

The U.S. has led an international effort to replace Maduro with opposition leader Juan Guaido, who vows to hold a new presidential election. Guaido is backed by some 50 countries, while Maduro maintains support from countries such as China, Russia and Cuba.

Maduro ordered all U.S. diplomats to leave Venezuela in late January because of its support for Guaido, but he later retreated and allowed them to stay. The U.S. still withdrew the bulk of embassy personnel, leaving a skeletal staff led by career foreign service officer James Story.

Pompeo said the remaining diplomats would be out of Venezuela by the end of the week but gave no indication of future policy steps despite past warnings that "all options" - including the use of military force - are on the table for removing Maduro.

The move came after another day of chaos as power outages that began Thursday evening continued to cause problems for Venezuelans, leaving them with little power, water and communications.

People converged on a polluted river to fill water bottles in Caracas, and scattered protests erupted in several cities

A 3-year-old girl with a brain tumor languished in a Caracas hospital, awaiting treatment after doctors started surgery but then suspended the operation when nationwide power outages first hit on Thursday, said the girl's fearful mother, who only gave her first name, Yalimar.

"The doctors told me that there are no miracles," said Yalimar, who hopes her daughter can be transferred Tuesday to one of the few hospitals in Venezuela that would be able to finish the complex procedure.

The girl's story highlighted an unfolding horror in Venezuela, where years of hardship got abruptly worse after the power grid collapsed. On Monday, schools and businesses were closed, long lines of cars waited at the few gasoline stations with electricity and hospitals cared for many patients without power. Generators have alleviated conditions for some of the critically ill.

President Nicolas Maduro said on national television Monday night that progress had been made in restoring power in Venezuela. He also said two people who were allegedly trying to sabotage power facilities were captured and were providing information to authorities, though he gave no details.

Guaido, who heads the opposition-controlled congress, and the United States say Maduro's claims that the U.S. sabotaged the power grid with a "cyberattack" are an attempt to divert attention from the government's own failings.

There have been acts of kindness during Venezuela's crisis: People whose food would rot in refrigerators without power donated it to a restaurant, which cooked it for distribution to charities and hospitals.

The blackouts also have hit the oil industry. The country hasn't shipped $358 million in oil since the power failures started, and "the whole system is grinding to a halt," said Russ Dallen, a Miami-based partner at the brokerage firm Caracas Capital Markets.

Two large tankers are sitting empty at the Jose offshore oil-loading dock, and at least 19 other ships are waiting their turns there, Dallen said.

Engineers have restored power in some parts of Venezuela, but it often goes out again. There have been a few protests in Caracas and reports of similar anti-government anger elsewhere. Guaido tweeted about reports of looting in some cities, but details were difficult to confirm.

Security forces in the city of Maracaibo dispersed "criminals" trying to take advantage of the power cuts, Mayor Willy Casanova told local media. However, numerous videos posted on social media that purported to be from Maracaibo showed crowds roaming the streets and people running from looted, damaged buildings with no police in sight.

In Caracas, some people reported more sightings of "colectivos," a term for armed groups allegedly operating on behalf of the state to intimidate opponents.

The mood in Caracas was desperate.

Marian Morales, a nurse working for a Catholic youth group, and several colleagues handed out diapers and food from a car parked near a hospital. Police and men in civilian clothing ordered them to leave, saying they didn't have permission.

Morales said the needy are cautious about approaching to collect the handouts because of the presence of security forces.

Early Monday, an explosion rocked a power station in the Baruta area of Caracas. Residents gathered to look at the charred, smoldering equipment.

Guaido said three of four electricity transformers servicing the area were knocked out. He has blamed the blackouts on government corruption and mismanagement.

Winston Cabas, the head of Venezuela's electrical engineers union, which opposes the government, disputed government allegations that the country's main hydroelectric dam was sabotaged last week. He blamed a lack of maintenance as well as the departure of skilled workers from the troubled country over the years.

"The system is vulnerable, fragile and unstable," he said.

Spain's airline pilots union asked for Spanish airline Air Europa to stop flying to Venezuela after one of its crews was attacked at gunpoint in Caracas. The Sepla union said two pilots and eight more crew members of a flight from Madrid were assaulted on Saturday while going from the airport to their hotel in the Venezuelan capital. None of the crew members was injured.

Air Europa responded by ordering the crews of flights to Venezuela to not spend the night in the country, according to the union.

The administration of U.S. President Donald Trump imposed sanctions on a Moscow-based bank jointly owned by Russian and Venezuelan state-owned companies, alleging it tried to circumvent U.S. sanctions on the South American country. The U.S. said it is targeting Evrofinance Mosnarbank for supporting Petroleos de Venezuela SA, the state oil company previously targeted by sanctions in January.

Evrofinance said it was carrying out its activities normally despite the announcement and pledged to "meet its obligations to the clients and partners in full."

The U.S. and the other governments that recognize Guaido as Venezuela's interim president say Maduro wasn't legitimately re-elected last year because opposition candidates weren't permitted to run. Maduro says he is the target of a U.S. coup plot.

___

Associated Press writer Christopher Torchia contributed to this report.

Title: Amber alert issued for 2-year-old girl
Summary:
An Amber Alert has been issued for a missing two year old girl from Wisconsin. (WPEC)

An Amber Alert has been issued for a 2-year-old girl from Milwaukee, Wisconsin.

Nolani's Mother reported her missing after Dariaz L. Higgins did not return the child as planned on the afternoon of March 11th.

Dariaz Higgins is known to also go by the names Dariaz Taylor and Dariaz Lewis.

Law enforcement considers Dariaz armed and dangerous and asks that anyone that sees him or the child, to not attempt to make contact but instead call 911 immediately.

Title: Police investigate death at Winnie Palmer Hospital
Summary:
Woman stabbed 11-year-old daughter to keep her from having sex, affidavit says

A mother accused of fatally stabbing her 11-year-old daughter more than a dozen times Sunday did so because she thought the girl had been having sex, according to an arrest affidavit. Orange County Sheriff’s Office investigators said 28-year-old Rosa Alcides Rivera pulled up to Winnie Palmer Hospital for Women and Babies on Sunday asking for help for her 11-year-old daughter. Police said medical staffers checked on the girl and determined that Aleyda Rivera was dead. After the girl was pronounced dead, hospital workers told investigators the mother became "argumentative" with hospital staff before producing a knife. Police said she admitted to killing her daughter and can be heard on police body camera recordings saying “my baby is gone.” The hospital was briefly locked down and the main entrance remained closed during the incident.Rosa Rivera later told investigators she killed her daughter to "prevent her from having sex" with men, the affidavit said. She's charged with first-degree murder. Investigators said the girl had been stabbed 15 times and they believe it happened inside Rosa Rivera's car. People at a home Citadel Drive told investigators Rivera had arrived around 7:30 a.m. Sunday and started pounding on the front door. The witnesses told investigators Rivera was accusing a man of having sex with her daughter. Investigators said Rivera has relatives who live in the Citadel Drive home and she was hoping to move into the house. Rivera told authorities she had never seen her daughter having sex and said her daughter never told her that she was having sex. Rivera is being held in the Orange County Jail without bond.

The hospital was briefly locked down and the main entrance remained closed during the incident.

Title: Orlando teacher accused of molesting student may have other victims, officials say
Summary:
ORLANDO, Fla. - The Orange County elementary school teacher accused of molesting a student could have more possible victims, according to an arrest warrant.

Records show Julio Soto, 49, a teacher at Castle Creek Elementary School, was taken into custody last week after a student said Soto touched her inappropriately.

The girl, who sprained her arm in her physical education class last month, said Soto is her teacher for part of the day, normally for the afternoon portion, according to the warrant.

[RELATED: Orlando elementary teacher remains in jail after molestation allegation | Elementary school teacher​ arrested on child molestation charge, officials say]

Because she was injured, she couldn't take part in the activities in her physical education class and was sitting out to the side when Soto approached her and asked her to come upstairs and fix her test, deputies said.

The girl told investigators she agreed to go with him to his classroom, which is located on the second floor, the warrant said.

When they got upstairs, Soto told the girl he was going to try to find her tickle spot and began touching her above her clothing and eventually underneath it, deputies said.

When she told him to stop, Soto replied, "Oh, OK," and stopped, then did it again, and again stopped when she told him to, according to the warrant.

Soto went back to her desk while the girl finished her test. When she was done, he told her there were two minutes left of the physical education class and that she should go back downstairs, deputies said.

The girl said she asked Soto if anyone could see them in the classroom and he said they couldn't because a privacy paper was in place over the door, according to the warrant.

Deputies said the girl didn't initially tell her parents about the alleged incident because she was afraid of how they would react, but she eventually told her friends because she "couldn't take it anymore," the warrant said.

Soto was taken into custody at a Publix shopping plaza located at the intersection of Chuluota Road and East Colonial Drive, about 2 miles away from the school.

Since his arrest, Soto has been placed on administrative leave and will not be placed in a classroom while there is an open internal investigation.

He's been teaching at Castle Creek Elementary since August 2015.

Parents on Monday didn't comment about the allegations but said they received a voicemail from Principal Monica Johnson about Soto's arrest.

"We take any and all allegations very seriously, and the safety of our students is my first priority," Johnson said in the recorded message.

Soto's defense attorney told an Orange County judge on Saturday that his client has no criminal history and is the father of an 11-year-old girl and 16-year-old boy.

Soto on Monday remained at the Orange County Jail without bond and has been ordered to stay away from the alleged victim and minors.

Officials said detectives are investigating possible other victims. Anyone with information is asked to call 407-836-4357.

Copyright 2019 by WKMG ClickOrlando - All rights reserved.
Address: 4466 N John Young Pkwy, Orlando, FL 32804, USA

Title: Florida man accused of impregnating 12-year-old girl
Summary:
Suspect told the eight-month-pregnant middle school student that he loved her and planned to raise their daughter with her as a family.

LAKE WORTH — A Lake Worth man is accused of raping and impregnating a 12-year-old.

Edgar Ramos-Mendez, 23, was arrested Friday after Palm Beach County sheriff's investigators determined he was the father of the now 13-year-old girl's unborn baby. He faces charges of lewd battery and impregnation of a child and is being held in the Palm Beach County Jail with his bail set at $400,000. Jail records show he also has a hold for another agency, though the details of that case were not immediately available.

Ramos-Mendez, a Mexico native and citizen living in Lake Worth, met the girl in a city park when she was 11, the girl said. He told her he was 19.

They exchanged numbers and went on a few dates, the girl told deputies in an interview last month.

He raped and impregnated her at his cousin's Lake Worth home when she was 12, she said.

The girl called Ramos-Mendez while investigators listened in. He told the eight-month-pregnant middle school student that he loved her and planned to raise their daughter with her as a family.

The age of consent in Florida is 18 years old, according to Florida Statutes. People between the ages of 16 and 17 can give consent to a partner up to the age of 23. Anyone 24 years old or older commits a felony if he or she engages in sexual activity with someone under the age of 18.
Address: 300 W Lime St, Lakeland, FL 33815, USA

Title: Wildwood's Hampton has secure legacy as he steps down
Summary:
Richard Hampton knew early on he wanted to be a basketball coach.

What the longtime Wildwood Middle High School girls coach didn’t know was the path his career would take and the lives he would eventually impact.

However, now that he has stepped down as coach and the curtain about to fall on a 30-year career as an educator at Wildwood — he is retiring at the end of the school year — Hampton has begun to reflect on a journey that includes countless accomplishments — and even a few disappointments.

“I’ve had a great run here,” Hampton said. “We’ve won a lot of basketball games over the years, but I’ve never considered that to be what I’m most proud of. For me, it has always been seeing the girls who have come through our program become responsible adults, wives and parents. We’ve also lost a few over the years — girls who didn’t make it through the program — and that has always bothered me because I wasn’t able to impact those kids in a positive manner.

“Winning a few basketball games along the way is great, but seeing these kids grow up into positive role models for their families and in their communities is what has made everything worthwhile.”

That Hampton considers his success on the basketball court to be secondary speaks volumes, considering his achievements in 15 years — over two stints — as the Wildcats’ girls coach.

Hampton’s recently completed seven-year run as coach on the Wildcats’ bench was the most successful in school history. It included back-to-back Class 1A state championships in 2017 and 2018 and three Final Four appearances (2015, 2017 and 2018).

In his first go-round as head coach, Hampton led the girls team from the 1991-92 season through the 1999-2000 campaign, taking them to the Final Four in 1994 and 1996, and finishing as Class 2A state runners-up in 1994.

Overall, Hampton’s coaching record at Wildwood is 268-164, including a sterling 128-44 mark from 2013 until 2019.

Since he hails from Kentucky, where basketball — college basketball, in particular — reigns supreme, it probably isn’t surprising that Hampton developed a passion for the sport as a youngster. He played the game as a student at Clay County High School and at the next level for Union College, an NAIA school in Barbourville, Kentucky.

At Clay County, Hampton played for longtime coach Bobby Keith, who won a state championship and more than 700 games in a coaching career that spanned 29 years — 27 of which were spent at Clay County.

Hampton said watching Keith inspired him to follow in the coach’s footsteps.

“I used a lot of what I learned from watching (Keith) throughout my career, all the way up through my last game,” Hampton said. “When I was a player, I would ask (Keith) why he called for a certain play at specific times. The ins and outs of the game always fascinated me and provided me with a motivation to try and fix things. For me, basketball was a chess game with life-size pieces and (Keith) taught me how to move those pieces.

“He was the epitome of a high school coach.”

With his playing days over and a college degree in hand, Hampton and his wife, Sherri, set out to make a life for themselves.

How did the couple end up in Wildwood?

“I’ve always considered it to be a little bit of a fate,” Hampton said.

Hampton’s mother in-law bought a house in Wildwood in the 1970s, which he said provided enough incentive for the young couple to make a trip to Sumter County to look for work.

“Within two weeks, we both had jobs,” Hampton said. “Sherri was at South Sumter and I was at Wildwood. And we’ve been here for the last 30 years.”

Hampton’s first foray into coaching was as an assistant for Wildwood’s boys team. After a couple of years in the second seat on the bench, head coaching positions for the boys and girls teams opened up and Hampton applied for the boys job.

When that didn’t pan out, Hampton applied for — and was named — Wildwood’s girls basketball coach.

“After that, the rest was history, I guess,” said Hampton, a wry smile creeping across his face. “I never thought much about coaching girls before I applied for the job and still not sure how ended up switching over to coaching girls. But I’m sure glad I did.”

Despite never having coached girls, Hampton quickly learned the difference between coaching boys and coaching girls. He was able to adapt and also used the lessons he had learned from his high school mentor.

“For me, girls always seemed to have an eagerness to learn,” Hampton said. “They appreciate the time you spend with them on and off the court and they really respond to coaching. I never really had a problem adjusting to coaching girls, because I was fortunate enough to have players who wanted to learn as much as I wanted to teach. It was a perfect marriage, so to speak.”

And the feeling was mutual.

“What can you say about a man who would take a group of girls, absolutely no relation to him, and father them as his own?” said Tarra Blackwell Hogan, a key contributor on Wildwood’s 1994 state runners-up. Known as Tarra Blackwell in her playing days, her playing career at Wildwood earned her a scholarship to Florida Southern College and a degree in Criminology.

“He knew our personalities and how to motivate each one of us. Make no mistake; Hamp could be tough. He could rake you up one side and down the other. But he would also turn around and show his love for you with a simple hug. We always knew he had our best interests in mind, putting us ahead of himself.“

Blackwell said Hampton quickly became more than a coach to his players.

He cooked for them.

He taxied them around town.

And — most important — he was a counselor and teacher.

“Hamp always made sure our grades were always on point,” Blackwell said. “He knew every one of our mother’s by their first name and didn’t mind calling them. Hamp taught me so many life lessons when I didn’t realize I was being taught. He will always be one of the biggest mentors in my life, and I’m confident that every girl he’s ever coach can say the same thing.

“I’m forever grateful to him and I will love him for the rest of my life.”

Kari Niblack, an All-State performer who powered the Wildcats to state championships in 2017 and 2018, echoed Blackwell’s sentiments.

Niblack is a freshman at West Virginia who was recently named the Big 12 Conference’s Sixth Man of the Year.

“He never let me be satisfied,” Niblack said. “He helped me become the player I am today by pushing me past my limits. He always pointed out what more I could do and then showed me how to get there. And he did that with every one of his girls.”

Even though he is still relatively young — he will not turn 60 for several more years — Hampton is comfortable with his decision to step down as coach and as school principal. His wife will retire, too, and the couple have already begun making plans for the future.

“Fortunately, my parents are still alive, so I’ll get to go back up to Kentucky and spend some time with them,” Hampton said. “We’re both in good health and still young enough to really enjoy our retirement and spend some quality time together. We’ve bought a house on the coast down state, so we’re not going too far away.”

Retirement will also afford Hampton the time and ability to take road trips and watch many of his former players in action. He also expects to show up on occasion in the “Woodshed” — the moniker given to the Wildwood gym — to watch the Wildcats in action.

As a fan.

“This will be the first time I’ve been able to go see my kids — my former players — play in college,” Hampton said. “It’s going to be so much fun to see Kari and Danasia (Bogle, a member of the 2018 championship team) and Jada (Perry, who played on the 2017 team) play. I’m also going to watch Ashtin (Ingram, another longtime Wildcat who signed recently with the College of Central Florida in Ocala) play a few games next season.”

Regardless of what he does or where he goes in retirement, Hampton will never forget his career at Wildwood, as a coach and educator. He walks away on his own terms, proud that didn’t overstay his welcome.

The basketball program, he feels, is in “good” shape for his successor and students have plenty of reasons to be proud of their school.

“I’ve had a great run,” Hampton said. “These girls I’ve had, who have played for me and those who were just students, they’re the pride of the whole thing. I’ve always wanted Wildwood — the school and the community — to know I’ve always had their bests interests at heart and wanted everyone to be proud of Wildwood High School and Wildwood Middle High School.

“I will always bleed Wildwood blue.”
Address: 212 E Main St, Leesburg, FL 34748, USA

Title: Boys & Girl's Club's Youth of the Year turns barriers and bullying into opportunities
Summary:
Islande Victorin used to duck her head and hide in the back of the room during her leadership classes at the Boys & Girls Club in Immokalee.

She didn’t want to speak when she was called on; she was self-conscious about not grasping English and having an accent. She and her family moved to the United States from Haiti in 2011, when Victorin was 10 years old.

The day Victorin’s instructor, TaSheekia Perry, asked Victorin to speak in class for the first time, a friend stood up and said Victorin didn’t speak English. Perry said Victorin could speak in Creole and the friend could translate for her, but she needed to introduce herself to the class.

Islande Victorin, 18, poses for a portrait at the Boys and Girls Club of Collier County Bolch Campus in Immokalee on Friday, March 1, 2019. Victorin is the recipient of the Boys and Girls Club of Collier County Youth of the Year award. (Photo: Alex Driehaus/Naples Daily News USA TODAY NETWORK - FLORIDA)

“Islande rolled her eyes so hard at me I thought they were gonna roll out of the sockets,” Perry said. “I think she felt I was embarrassing her in front of her peers.”

Victorin said her classmates could be cruel. As hard as she tried to learn, fellow students laughed at her for not speaking the language. When she couldn’t express herself the way she intended and tried to clarify, they laughed some more. They made fun of her height and called her a giraffe.

“It was tough, but that only pushed me to work harder,” Victorin said.

Her leadership, character building and youth development classes pushed her out of her comfort zone. As Victorin improved her language skills, she started participating more and gaining more confidence. She could stand up for herself when she was bullied, and she could stand up for others when they were being treated unfairly. She became a role model to her peers at the Boys & Girls Club Bolch Campus in Immokalee. She also tutored elementary school students through the Guadalupe Center’s Tutor Corps program.

More: Boys & Girls Club honors Golden Gate teen's perseverance

She still struggled at times even as various mentors helped her build confidence. Victorin wanted to change her accent, but Perry told her that was a part of who she was. They would simply work on ways to project her voice and slow her speech so she could communicate the way she wanted.

NEWSLETTERS Get the News Alerts newsletter delivered to your inbox We're sorry, but something went wrong Get alerted to the latest stories to stay on top of the news. Please try again soon, or contact Customer Service at 1-844-900-7105. Delivery: Varies Invalid email address Thank you! You're almost signed up for News Alerts Keep an eye out for an email to confirm your newsletter registration. More newsletters

“When she became confident in her voice, she became more assertive, spoke out against things hurting other people and was able to share herself in a more confident way with others,” Perry said. “I think it all started with her voice.”

Islande Victorin, 18, poses for a portrait at the Boys and Girls Club of Collier County Bolch Campus in Immokalee on Friday, March 1, 2019. Victorin says that the Boys and Girls Club, along with many other organizations she's involved with, have helped her gain confidence and leadership skills. (Photo: Alex Driehaus/Naples Daily News USA TODAY NETWORK - FLORIDA)

Now 18, Victorin’s tenacity, confidence and leadership earned her the title of Boys & Girls Club of Collier County’s 2019 Youth of the Year. She was celebrated during a ceremony in late February and moves on to the state Youth of the Year competition the weekend of April 11.

Youth of the Year is the Boys & Girls Club of America’s top recognition program and requires nominees and winners to exemplify leadership skills, service, academic excellence and healthy lifestyles.

She earned a $4,000 college scholarship from the Boys & Girls Club of Collier County for her win. A senior at Immokalee High School, Victorin plans to attend Arcadia University in Pennsylvania, about an hour north of Philadelphia. She earned a full scholarship to the private university through the Guadalupe Center tutoring program.

She has been away from her parents and two brothers for days or weeks at a time, like during one summer when she attended Brown University for three weeks and earned college credit, but going out of state for university will be a longer goodbye. Victorin plans to study psychology. She loves to work with children and may take that route wherever her career takes her.

More: Boys and Girls Club of Collier County's Youth of the Year

For three of her high school years, Victorin tutored kids from kindergarten to second grade in reading, writing and math at Pinecrest Elementary in Immokalee. She also tutored new students who needed some extra help learning English as a second language.

Her role as a mentor goes hand-in-hand with a defining moment in her life: her baptism. Victorin said she decided to be baptized through her Baptist Church in Immokalee.

It was a big decision to make, she said, one that made her happy and a little scared for the future.

“You have to know what it means and what kind of a decision it is because it’s a lifelong commitment,” Victorin said. “To me it was basically deciding that I’m living and working for God and that my decisions, my actions, I have to project myself in a positive manner and not in a way that gives reasons (for people) to put me down.”

That commitment to her faith shaped the way she mentored youth.

Islande Victorin, 18, talks to a group of her peers after being awarded the Youth of the Year award at the Boys and Girls Club of Collier County Bolch Campus in Immokalee on Friday, March 1, 2019. Starting in August, Victorin competed with other teens as she wrote essays, gave a speech, and went through multiple rounds of interviews before winning the award. (Photo: Alex Driehaus/Naples Daily News USA TODAY NETWORK - FLORIDA)

“I’m very conscious of my actions because I know these kids are looking up to me,” Victorin said. “I’m basically a role model to them, so I have to know what I’m doing.”

She wants to succeed at everything she does and be brave in all her pursuits. She said she’s come to realize she has what it takes to take risks and be successful.

“I see Islande in a leadership role in whatever she does in her future,” said Perry, the leadership instructor.

Victorin is the pride of her mentors, peers, colleagues and family.

The little ones she has tutored throughout her high school years are especially proud.

She connected with them by sharing her experiences with them and talked to them about how she has overcome obstacles with a strong support system, according to Deanna Peterson, one of Guadalupe Center’s Tutor Corps coordinators.

She’s taught her kids that it’s OK to ask for help, be bold and take risks.

“Now all the younger students want to be just like Islande and go to college when they ‘get big,’” Peterson said.

More: NFL player visits Boys & Girls Club in Immokalee
