Title: In Golden Gate Estates, backyard shooting ranges spark debate
Summary:
CLOSE Members of the public practice shooting at the Collier County Sheriff's Office's gun range, which is open every first and third Saturday of the month Alex Driehaus, Naples Daily News

In Golden Gate Estates — where residents have long been drawn to large, affordable lots and privacy away from the bustle of the urban coast — a fight over backyard shooting ranges has been brewing as local officials say a sweeping state law prevents them from regulating what some see as a growing public safety concern.

Collier County used to have a variety of local ordinances on the books that kept recreational shooting in neighborhoods in check, but a 2011 law backed by the National Rifle Association forced county officials to repeal those rules.

Though local governments had been preempted from passing ordinances regulating firearms for decades, the 2011 law threatened city and county officials who defied the state with hefty fines and even removal from office.

CONSIDER SUBSCRIBING TODAY: Help support local journalism

Since then, law enforcement officials say they have seen an increase in incidents related to makeshift shooting ranges in the sprawling subdivision with stray bullets damaging property and, in a couple of cases, injuring neighbors.

Deputies want residents to exercise their rights safely, but because the state statute doesn’t spell out what residents have to do to shoot recreationally on their property, as long as it’s “reasonably safe,” law enforcement officials are left with few options, said Lt. Gary Martin, the Collier County’s Sheriff’s Office’s Golden Gates Estates commander.

And the definition of safe can be subjective, Martin said.

Tom Mulligan shoots a target at the Collier County Sheriff's Office's gun range in Golden Gate Estates, on Saturday, Feb. 16, 2019. The range is open to the public every first and third Saturday, excluding holidays, from 8 a.m. to noon. (Photo: Alex Driehaus/Naples Daily News USA TODAY NETWORK - FLORIDA)

“We had a guy, I believe it was last year, that was shooting a rifle through a mattress. He thought it was safe,” he said. “We’ve had people shooting into buckets. We’ve had people shooting into piles of mulch.”

For deputies, Martin said, the issue becomes a public safety concern when other people’s property is damaged or people feel their life is in danger because of their neighbor’s shooting habits.

Related: Backyard shooting ranges fall through enforcement cracks

A Golden Gate Estates man who deputies say struck a neighbor in her residence while he was firing a handgun in his backyard for target practice was arrested in late December. Days later, the polarizing issue sparked dueling petitions online and heated discussions on social media.

An online petition from a Golden Gate Estates resident calling for stricter rules to regulate so-called backyard shooting ranges on one-acre properties has garnered more than 1,000 signatures since Jan. 3.

“People feel like it sounds like a war zone sometimes,” said George Guyer, who started the petition, referring to those who have commented online. The police officer and longtime Golden Gate Estates resident is worried about the well-being of his teenage daughter and others.

“It’s not about the Second Amendment,” said Guyer, 47. “I just want people to be safe.”

A target diagram painted on the wall shows the possible issues that could be affecting a shooter's aim at the Collier County Sheriff's Office's gun range in Golden Gate Estates, on Saturday, Feb. 16, 2019. (Photo: Alex Driehaus/Naples Daily News USA TODAY NETWORK - FLORIDA)

Opponents to an outright ban fired off their own salvo of petitions soon after Guyer started his.

One advocates to keep the existing rules, but change berm and distance requirements instead, and enforce stricter punishments for those who violate laws.

“Keep the law for shooting, for those of us that abide by the rules and know what we are doing,” the petition states. It was started by Golden Gate Estates resident Brandon Garcia and has garnered more than 200 signatures since Jan. 7.

Garcia, a sergeant in the Florida Army National Guard who has a berm in his own backyard and regularly shoots there, said he understands other residents’ concerns.

He said he wanted to look for a “middle ground” approach that would satisfy both sides. A starting point could be requiring berms to be at least 6 feet high, said Garcia, 37.

NEWSLETTERS Get the News Alerts newsletter delivered to your inbox We're sorry, but something went wrong Get alerted to the latest stories to stay on top of the news. Please try again soon, or contact Customer Service at 1-844-900-7105. Delivery: Varies Invalid email address Thank you! You're almost signed up for News Alerts Keep an eye out for an email to confirm your newsletter registration. More newsletters

“I totally understand people are worried about bullets,” he said.

Shell casings lie scattered around Barry Garabedian's feet at the Collier County Sheriff's Office's gun range in Golden Gate Estates, on Saturday, Feb. 16, 2019. Garabedian, who lives in Naples during the winter, says he tries to come to the range as often as he can because, he says, the facilities are excellent and the instructors are very helpful. (Photo: Alex Driehaus/Naples Daily News USA TODAY NETWORK - FLORIDA)

Another petition, created on Jan. 6 by Dan Huffman, asks County Commissioner Bill McDaniel, whose district includes Golden Gate Estates, to support backyard shooting ranges.

“Many moved out to the Golden Gate Estates for the freedom of open spaces and against the restrictions of the rest of Collier County!” the online petition states.

“This is a rural area so don't let the knee jerk reactions of those who do not understand this impose restrictions on those who want to continue using the Estates and not have unnecessary restrictions placed on it! This includes responsible people and their use of THEIR property for backyard ranges!”

More than 350 people have signed that petition, which has since been closed. Efforts to reach Huffman were unsuccessful, but in an update on the petition website he asks supporters to get the word out “before there is one more thing lost” to the Estates area.

McDaniel has heard his constituents' concerns. But there’s likely not much the county can do about it.

“It’s a statutorily preempted process,” McDaniel said in an interview earlier this year. “We’re not allowed to meddle with the backyard shooting.”

Kathy Tironi talks to her husband, Joe Tironi, as he reloads his gun at the Collier County Sheriff's Office's gun range in Golden Gate Estates, on Saturday, Feb. 16, 2019. (Photo: Alex Driehaus/Naples Daily News USA TODAY NETWORK - FLORIDA)

Incidents increased in 2018

Martin, with CCSO, said deputies patrolling the Golden Gate Estates district have seen an uptick in incidents related to backyard shooting ranges since the county had to roll back its local ordinances.

The Golden Gate Estates substation began to informally keep track of backyard shooting range incidents in 2017, said Sheriff’s Office spokeswoman Michelle Batten.

In 2017, there were eight incidents in Golden Gate Estates. The following year that number climbed to 15. (Because the numbers are based on an informal tally, the actual number of incidents could be higher, Batten said.)

In 2018: Background checks for gun sales spiked as FL legislators debated controls

In 2018: Audit: Florida failed to complete gun background checks on hundreds of applicants

When deputies get a call about somebody’s property being struck, they try to track down the shooter based on the trajectory or the noise, if the firing is still occurring, Martin said.

“In a lot of cases, they’re very apologetic, they can’t believe that what they were doing caused damage to somebody else’s property,” Martin said. “And oftentimes the neighbors in some way, work it out themselves.”

Even ranges that appear to be set up safely at first glance can be problematic.

Deputies have encountered instances where residents have “range quality” berms, but then place targets that stick out above the berm, Martin said. One resident had a 6-foot-tall dirt berm, but the upper part of the target, “what would’ve been the head and shoulders,” reached over the top of the berm, he recalled.

“So when he was shooting at them, he was actually shooting over the berm,” Martin said.

Sergeant Jeff Tayar replaces targets at the Collier County Sheriff's Office's gun range in Golden Gate Estates, on Saturday, Feb. 16, 2019. (Photo: Alex Driehaus/Naples Daily News USA TODAY NETWORK - FLORIDA)

And at times there are consequences more serious than damaged property.

The 21-year-old woman who was struck in December told deputies she was sitting at her dinner table next to a window when she heard a crash and felt something strike her right arm and side. She suffered a laceration to her arm and broken skin and bruising to her right side, and was treated at a hospital, according to a Sheriff’s Office report.

In 2016, a 14-year-old girl was injured when a man who was shooting at a small berm in a backyard in Golden Gate Estates accidentally struck a neighbor’s home. The girl’s family told the Daily News at the time that if the bullet hadn’t hit her left hand, breaking a couple of bones, it could have hit her mother's face, neck or shoulder.

“The lots are real narrow and real long, so your neighbors could be close depending on what direction you’re shooting,” Martin said.

When people ask him about backyard shooting ranges, Martin said he recommends they consider their civil liability if an accident happens and to “very objectively” inspect their target “from all angles.”

“Walk around to the other side and if you believe that it’s safe to shoot at it from the opposite side where your loved ones and your house and your property’s at, then perhaps it’s safe enough for you to shoot at from the side that you’re considering,” he said.

Corporal Rob Leocadio instructs Mark Soliwoda as he shoots a target at the Collier County Sheriff's Office's gun range in Naples, on Saturday, February 16, 2019. (Photo: Alex Driehaus/Naples Daily News USA TODAY NETWORK - FLORIDA)

‘Education, not regulation'

For their part, county officials say their hands are tied. And with the threat of sanctions hanging over their heads if they were to regulate the issue, some have been reluctant to even discuss the matter.

When McDaniel proposed to bring an agenda item forward to discuss some ideas, Klatzkow, the county attorney, advised against it.

“I think it's a terrible idea. I'm sorry,” he told commissioners at the Jan. 22 meeting. “...They could remove you from the dais. Now, I've never seen a preemption statute quite like that in my life.”

Instead, McDaniel said he wants to reach out to the sheriff and “see if we can develop a set of recommendations from an educational perspective just to enhance the health, safety and welfare of those facilities.”

Having a town hall meeting on the issue and increasing hours of operation at a Sheriff’s Office-run public gun range off Oil Well Grade Road have also been discussed, although the latter could be complicated by potential development that is planned in the area, McDaniel said.

The Sheriff’s Office gun range is currently open to the public from 8 a.m. to noon the first and third Saturday of each month, according to the Sheriff’s Office website. It allows only pistols and handguns.

“Education, not regulation, is the premise of what we're, in fact, talking about,” he said.

But some think even that could backfire.

“I would also caution that when you start to educate the public about the restrictions, you're also going to be educating a lot of people that might want to have backyard shooting ranges,” said Commissioner Burt Saunders during the January meeting. “They're going to find out that they're legal.”

Members of the public practice shooting targets while range instructors supervise them at the Collier County Sheriff's Office's gun range in Golden Gate Estates, on Saturday, Feb. 16, 2019. (Photo: Alex Driehaus/Naples Daily News USA TODAY NETWORK - FLORIDA)

‘A split issue’

When Guyer, whose petition sparked spirited debates on social media, first moved to Golden Gate Estates 15 years ago there were rules in place that prohibited the practice. He said he thinks it should be that way again.

“I want something done about it,” he said. “There’s just too much risk on a one-acre property.”

Guyer said he would like to see the density requirements changed from one acre or more to 2 ½ or 5 acres. He also proposes a permitting and inspection process to make sure the shooting is done safely.

“It’s clearly a safety issue,” he said. “And it’s a quality of life issue.”

Guyer knows that change will likely have to happen on a state level. He sent state Rep. Byron Donalds, R-Naples, and state Sen. Kathleen Passidomo, R-Naples, an email about the issue.

“Basically I just got the run-around,” he said.

Usually a tragedy sparks change, Guyer said. “I’m trying to prevent that before it happens,” he said.

For Garcia, the Golden Gate Estates resident who started a petition seeking a happy medium solution, being able to shoot on his property is one of the reasons he moved to the rural subdivision.

Thomas Ward shoots a target at the Collier County Sheriff's Office's gun range in Naples, on Saturday, February 16, 2019. (Photo: Alex Driehaus/Naples Daily News USA TODAY NETWORK - FLORIDA)

He said he shoots “probably once a month,” sometimes twice. At times, his friends come to join him.

Shooting at commercial ranges can get “pretty pricey” and many who shoot don’t want to drive that far, Garcia said.

Still, he understands others’ concerns.

“What if a round hits my son?” Garcia said. “How would I feel then?”

He said it’s the ones who don’t know how to be safe with guns that ruin it for others.

“Most gun owners, they take safety pretty seriously,” Garcia said.

Martin, the Sheriff’s Office lieutenant, said the topic of backyard shooting ranges is “kind of a split issue.”

“People want to be able to go out in the backyard and shoot,” he said. “They just have to be safe when they’re doing (it). They have to consider that the Estates is still populated.”

Read or Share this story: https://www.naplesnews.com/story/news/local/2019/03/15/golden-gate-estates-backyard-shooting-ranges-spark-debate/2549089002/
Address: 1100 Immokalee Rd, Naples, FL 34110, USA

Title: At least 40 dead in mass shooting at two New Zealand mosques
Summary:
At least 40 dead in mass shooting at two New Zealand mosques

Advertisement At least 40 dead in mass shooting at two New Zealand mosques Share Shares Copy Link Copy

This is a breaking news story. Refresh for updates.At least 40 people are dead after mass shootings at two mosques full of people attending Friday prayers in Christchurch, New Zealand."It's a very serious and grave situation," Police Commissioner Mike Bush said in a news conference.Of the 40 killed, 30 were at the Masjid Al Noor mosque, and 10 were at the Linwood Masjid mosque, New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern said in a news conference.She said at least 25 people were injured."You may have chosen us, but we utterly reject and condemn you," Ardern said of the alleged suspects during a news conference.Police said several bombs were found attached to vehicles in Christchurch. Those devices were defused by authorities.Four people are in custody — 3 men and 1 woman — but police said they were working to determine if others might have been involved. Police had not yet released descriptions or identities of those in custody."Let's not presume that the danger is gone," Bush said.Multiple casualities were reported, but police had not yet confirmed the number of people killed.The deadliest shooting occurred at the Masjid Al Noor mosque in central Christchurch at about 1:45 p.m. local time.Len Peneha said he saw a man dressed in black enter the mosque.Peneha, who has lived next to the mosque for five years, said he then heard dozens of shots and saw people running out in fear."I saw dead people everywhere. There were three in the hallway, at the door leading into the mosque, and people inside the mosque," he said, The Associated Press reported. "I don't understand how anyone could do this to these people, to anyone. It's ridiculous."The gunman ran out of the mosque and dropped what Peneha said appeared to be a semi-automatic weapon and fled.Peneha said the gunman was white and was wearing a helmet with some kind of device on top, giving him a military-type appearance.TVNZ reports that hundreds of people were inside the Masjid Al Noor mosque at the time the gunman entered."My husband was driving past (and) he said he took three people to the hospital — one was a little girl all had been shot," a witness told the TV station. "He wanted to take more. He said there was like a dozen people just lying on the road."The New Zealand Herald said the shooting at the Masjid Al Noor mosque lasted for at least six minutes.A second shooting occurred at the Linwood Masjid mosque, which is about 10 minutes from the Masjid Al Noor mosque.New Zealand police and media reported that one of the gunman broadcast a chilling 17-minute live video of the attack inside the Masjid Al Noor mosque on Facebook and YouTube.Police said they were working with social media companies to remove the videos.In a statement to BuzzFeed reporter Ryan Mac, Twitter said it had removed the video."We have taken down the account of the alleged perpetrator and are working to actively remove all versions of the video from Twitter," the statement read.CNN reported that Facebook said it was "removing any praise or support for the crime and the shooter or shooters as soon as we’re aware. We will continue working directly with New Zealand Police as their response and investigation continues."In a statement, YouTube said it was "working vigilantly to remove any violent footage."But it appears the platforms are struggling to keep the videos from being published as users continue to re-upload the disturbing footage.The shooting also appeared to have been announced on 8chan and discussed on Reddit. Mass shootings in New Zealand are exceedingly rare. The deadliest in modern history occurred in the small town of Aramoana in 1990, when gunman David Gray shot and killed 13 people following a dispute with a neighbor.Los Angeles Police Department announced it would increase patrols of mosques following the Christchurch attacks.The Associated Press contributed to this report.
Address: 1021 Wymore Rd, Winter Park, FL 32789, USA

Title: Belle Glade boy injured after getting attacked by pit bull
Summary:
Belle Glade injured after getting attacked by pit bull (WPEC)

A boy was hospitalized Thursday after he was attacked by a pit bull.

It happened moments after he got off the school bus at the mobile home park where he lives.

The attack was caught on surveillance video.

The boy, who neighbors say is 10 years old, was attacked in the road near the entrance of Lake Breeze Mobile Home Park at NW 18th Street and Lake Circle.

The boy was bitten repeatedly in the leg and face.

“It was horrible watching the little boy like that,” neighbor Miriam Mojica said.

Surveillance video from a nearby mobile home shows the pit bull attacking a boy.

The dog lunged at the boy, biting his leg as the frantic boy tries to get away.

Neighbors say the victim is a fifth grader at Belle Glade Elementary.

Video shows him getting off the school bus a little before 3 p.m. when the attack happened.

“The dog went behind him and attacked him from his leg first, that’s when he dropped to the floor, that’s whenever he went to his face, like bit him in his face,” Mojica said.

The victim’s cousin demonstrated how he used a broomstick to hit the dog---using every bit of energy he had---to get the animal off the boy.

“I hit it as hard as I could and that’s when it let go,” he said as he showed CBS12 News how he swung the broomstick like a baseball bat.

The video shows the boy tries to run behind a fence, but the dog follows.

Then, he runs behind a car, but the dog still doesn't give up.

“When I was looking out the window, I saw the pit bull attacking him,” fourth grader Adamaris Medina said.

A girl says she was on the school bus and heard the boy's cries for help.

“I was also crying for him ‘cause he was like yelling help,” Medina said.

One little boy says he threw rocks at the pit bull to try to stop it from attacking the victim.

“I thought it was gonna come after me,” six-year-old Brandon Medina said.

Finally, adults nearby show up and pick the child up and put him in the car. They say the boy is recovering at a hospital with non life-threatening injuries.

When deputies arrived, they say the dog lunged at them, so to protect themselves and others, they shot and killed the pit bull.

Neighbors believe someone dropped the pit bull off in the neighborhood Thursday morning.

They feel the owner no longer wanted the dog, which allowed this tragedy to happen.

A spokesperson with the Palm Beach County Sheriff's Office says the victim will need plastic surgery.
Address: 1100 Fairfield Dr, West Palm Beach, FL 33407, USA

Title: ECSO: Pensacola man instructed teen to sic dog on deputies
Summary:
CLOSE Two Escambia County Sheriff's Office deputies were attacked by a dog while attempting to make an arrest in the Bellview area on Wednesday, and the dog was shot and killed. Pensacola News Journal

An arrest report for the man accused of instructing a teenager to release a dog to attack deputies on Wednesday sheds new light on the events that led up to the attack, which ended with a deputy shooting and killing the animal.

The dog reportedly bit two Escambia County Sheriff's Office deputies on their calves during a scuffle at a mobile home in the 2100 block of Deerwood Road and then attempted to bite them later outside of the home.

That led a third deputy to shoot and kill the dog, a 4-year-old named Rosco.

An ECSO spokesman told the News Journal on Wednesday that both deputies received medical attention for their injuries and were released.

Cairo Jones, 34, and a 15-year-old who live in the home were both arrested early Wednesday afternoon and are accused of siccing the dog on deputies as they were trying to arrest Jones on marijuana charges.

More: Two arrested for allegedly releasing dog to attack ECSO deputies; dog shot and killed

Cairo Jones (Photo: Courtesy of Escambia County Jail)

ECSO deputies arrived at the mobile home on Deerwood Road around 10:30 a.m. Wednesday after an anonymous caller reported an argument in front of the home had been going on since 7 a.m., according to Jones' arrest report.

Deputies said when they made contact with Jones, he would not provide deputies with his name or any information on the incident, then threatened to sic his dog on them.

Jones then jumped up and down on a backyard trampoline while recording a deputy on his phone, and when he jumped off the trampoline, a marijuana baggie allegedly fell out of his pocket, the report states.

Deputies tried to take Jones into custody a few minutes later, but he allegedly knocked their hands out of the way. A scuffle spilled into the home, and deputies unsuccessfully attempted to use a Taser on Jones.

As the scuffle continued, Jones allegedly yelled for the 15-year-old to let the dog loose on deputies. The teen obliged and brought the dog through the front door as the two deputies were on the ground attempting to arrest Jones, according to the report.

Deputies were able to handcuff Jones, despite the dog biting them both. Deputies added in the report that the teen also resisted arrest, but they detained her after a short struggle.

A third deputy said that as the other two deputies exited the home with the suspects, the dog ran up to one of them and "barked viciously," then turned and tried to bite the third deputy. He said he then pulled out his gun and shot the dog twice, the second time as a way of "taking it out of its misery."

ECSO responds to two officers who were attacked by a dog as they were reportedly attempting to make an arrest on Wednesday, March 13, 2019. The dog was shot and killed. (Photo: Jody Link/online@pnj.com)

Macey Hardenbrook, Jones' live-in girlfriend and mother of the 15-year-old, told the News Journal at the scene on Wednesday that she saw her daughter in a patrol car shortly after the incident and saw the girl had bruises on her face.

Hardenbrook, who was not home at the time of the altercation, said her daughter was hurt during the scuffle.

"My daughter's face was bruised," she said. "They swung her onto the ground."

Hardenbrook also said her dog was very possessive of her children when she was not home.

"That was a $2,000 dog, he had done training to be a guard dog," she said.

She also admitted that her dog had bitten people in the past.

"If you come into my yard and I'm not home, he'll bite," she said.

Jones is charged with aggravated assault on a law enforcement officer, battery, resisting arrest and marijuana possession. As of Thursday afternoon, he was still in jail on $42,000 bond.

The State Attorney's Office said the 15-year-old faces a felony charge of aggravated assault on a law enforcement officer and will be tried as a minor.

Jake Newby can be reached at jnewby@pnj.com or 850-435-8538.

Address: 101 E Romana St, Pensacola, FL 32502, USA

Title: Netflix, ‘Longmire’ star Bailey Chase talks about growing up in Naples, acting career
Summary:
Naples native Bailey Chase co-stars with Spencer Locke in a new Netflix Original movie, "Walk. Ride. Rodeo." (Photo: Photo courtesy of Greg Peters)

Bailey Chase for years has played the character that viewers often dislike.

The Naples native and father of three says he's enjoying his new roles, including the new Netflix Original movie "Walk. Ride. Rodeo." that premiered earlier this month.

Chase, 46, gained prominence for his acting from 2012 to 2017 on the Western crime series "Longmire," in which he played the role of an ambitious Wyoming sheriff's deputy, Branch Connally.

“More than anything, the arc that I got to do on 'Longmire,' that character Branch, he hit all the notes," Chase said in a recent telephone interview.

"It gave me a confidence as an actor that I could do anything, I could play good. I could play bad. And by portraying these newer characters, that’s how I connect with the audience more. Then they start rooting for you.”

In his latest role, based on a true story, Chase plays Cory Snyder, the father of Amberley Snyder, a successful rodeo barrel racer who returns to the sport after a car crash.

In real life, Bailey and his wife, Amy, have three children: twin 2-year-olds (a boy and a girl) and a 4-year-old daughter who was born in Santa Fe, New Mexico, when Chase was still shooting "Longmire."

“For me as a dad, to play that role, as an actor, you go to those places where I’m imagining my girl in a hospital bed and in a wheelchair," Bailey said.

“Since 'Longmire' and becoming a dad, I feel like I can play anything.”

Happy Mother’s Day to all the amazing Mama’s out there (miss you Mom) and to my beautiful wife for these 3 little backseat drivers ❤️🚌 pic.twitter.com/dln0pQr4cT — Bailey Chase (@Bailey_Chase) May 13, 2018

Born in Chicago, he grew up in Naples, living in the seaside town from age 4 through his freshman year at Naples High School. He transferred to the Bolles School in Jacksonville, where he played football and baseball and graduated from the private school before heading to Duke University in Durham, North Carolina.

After graduating from Duke with a bachelor's degree in sports psychology, Chase said, he decided to fulfill "a boyhood dream" and headed to Los Angeles instead of New York.

"I came out here, being a Florida boy," Chase said. "The climate was a little bit better. I was living at the beach, waiting tables and going to acting class.”

He eventually traveled overseas to become a student at the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art, to study Shakespeare.

When he returned to the U.S., he landed a role on "Buffy The Vampire Slayer," a television series that ran from 1997 to 2003. For the next few years, Chase portrayed Chris Robert Hughes on the soap opera "As The World Turns."

He co-starred as "Becks" Scott in the ABC comedy-drama "Ugly Betty," which ran from 2006 to 2010, and on the TNT series "Saving Grace" that ran between 2007 and 2010.

Bailey Chase, from left, Laura San Giacomo, Bokeem Woodbine, Leon Rippy, Holly Hunter, Gregory Norman Cruz and Kenneth Johnson appear in the TNT network television program "Saving Grace." (Photo: Frank Ockenfels/TNT/File)

But his most notable role came in 2012, on "Longmire," which began on the A&E channel and, later, Netflix. Robert Taylor starred as Walt Longmire, a stoic, rugged, no-nonsense sheriff; the actor revealed his Australian accent away from the camera, Chase said.

"He’s a good dude," Chase said of Taylor. "It was a strong cast. We were all distinctly different.”

Longmire" also co-starred Katee Sackhoff, Lou Diamond Phillips and Gerald McRaney, known for his TV roles on "Major Dad" and "Simon & Simon" that Chase said he grew up watching.

Actor Bailey Chase, who grew up in Naples, stars with Spencer Locke, from left, and Missi Pyle in a new Netflix Original film "Walk. Ride. Rodeo." that premiered March 8, 2019. (Photo: Photo courtesy of Greg Peters with Netflix)

Upcoming work for Chase includes a role this summer on season 4 of "Queen of the South," a crime drama on the USA Network. Chase said he's been flying to New Orleans for filming and returning home to LA every weekend.

All he said he could reveal about his character is that he's "a jazz musician with a dark past."

Chase said he still has family in Florida, including a brother who's a builder based in Ocala. He hasn't been in Naples for more than a decade but hopes to visit again one day.

“Growing up down there, I couldn’t wait to get out," he said of Naples.

"But once I got into my 20s and my 30s, I always enjoyed coming back home. Naples will always be home. It's so humid; it just has a feel and a smell. It’s very nostalgic for me.”

Title: Man suspected of abducting 2-year-old charged in mother's shooting death
Summary:
- A Wisconsin man -- with ties to Florida -- who is centered in an Amber Alert will face a murder charge in the death of his child’s mother, police said.

The Amber Alert for two-year-old Noelani Robinson was issued Monday afternoon, according to FOX 32. At the time, officials in Milwaukee, Wisconsin said the suspect, Dariaz Higgins, and father of Noelani, did not return the child to her mother, and is suspected of abducting the little girl.

Noelani’s mother, 24-year-old Sierra Robinson, was found fatally shot shortly after 1 p.m. Monday near 91st Street and W. Mill Road, according to FOX 6. The news outlet reports that the Milwaukee County District Attorney’s Office has charged Higgins in the deadly shooting, which also injured 28-year-old woman, who was taken to the hospital.

Higgins is believed to be armed and dangerous. If you see him, officials ask that you call 911 immediately. The father and daughter were last seen driving a 2014 black Cadillac with the Florida license plate, HVCZ95.

Sierra’s mother, Latosha Bryant, spoke to FOX 6 and said her daughter was living in Las Vegas, but flew to Milwaukee over the weekend to pick up Noelani, who was staying with Higgins. Bryant said she isn’t sure why Higgins took Noelani, or where they may have gone.

Bryant released the following statement:
Address: 3213 W Kennedy Blvd, Tampa, FL 33609, USA

Title: Gatorland welcomes in their first ever baby emu
Summary:
- Gatorland has welcomed in their first ever baby emu.

Named Beeper, the emu was born at the park during the first week of March. According to Danielle Lucas, Gatorland's Animal Care Director, Beeper weighs 391 grams and is expected to grow very quickly. He should be fully grown in just six months.

“We are thrilled to have our very first baby emu born here at Gatorland. We will know in a few weeks when we do bloodwork if our baby is a boy or girl,” said Lucas.

Beeper will begin to be in public view in the park in just a couple weeks, Gatorland reported. Adult emus can already be seen in the area of the park closest to Pearl's Restaurant.

Gatorland reportedly acquired seven emus in 2008. This is the first time that they have had eggs and a baby hatch, though. Emu eggs typically incuabte about 70 days and are rotated five times a day by hand. Staff are said to be watching other emu eggs in incubation right now to see if others will hatch.

Gatorland opened as a roadside attraction in 1949. It stands today as a family-fun adventure full of wildlife and learning.
Address: 35 Skyline Dr, Lake Mary, FL 32746, USA

Title: Get to know these fearless female space explorers
Summary:
CLOSE These brave women are here to remind you that you can do anything. Rachael L Thomas, FLORIDA TODAY

Here on the Space Coast we’ll soon be launching some incredible female astronauts for the first time since 2011. But before commercial spaceflight with astronauts happens later this year, learn about the fearless female space explorers.

There is a reason NASA has embraced the term crewed instead of manned when talking about human spaceflight, because since 2013 the space agency has had equal parts female and male astronaut classes.

There are more inspiring women than can fit into one article but let's meet a few, shall we?

More: Far out! First all female spacewalk (ever) set for March

A Virgin Galactic test pilot

Kelly Latimer is a retired lieutenant colonel in the U.S. Air Force and now is a test pilot for Virgin Galactic. Latimer has logged more than 6,200 hours flying 40 different aircraft, including NASA's space shuttle carrier aircraft and the agency's airborne observatory, the Stratospheric Observatory for Infrared Astronomy, known as SOFIA.

With Virgin Galactic, Latimer will fly SpaceShipTwo -- and later this year she may be responsible for piloting the space plane with the first paying astronauts on board.



“I always had this passion to be an astronaut, just from as long as I can remember that’s what I’ve wanted to do,” Latimer said.



Watch the video below to hear why Latimer became a test pilot.

Flying spaceships is just for boys? Nope. Meet our Test Pilot, Kelly Latimer. She’s spent over 6,200 hours in the air flying more than 40 different types of aircraft. What drove her to become a test pilot? #IWD2019pic.twitter.com/9OTUReyRbA — Virgin Galactic (@virgingalactic) March 8, 2019

Russia’s only current woman cosmonaut

Russia flew the first two women in space, starting with Valentina Tereshkova in 1963. While Russia launched a woman into space years before the U.S. space program, only two women have flown for Roscosmos since 1984. The Russian space agency currently only has one female cosmonaut: Anna Kikina.

She is currently training in Star City, Russia, with other cosmonauts and astronauts but does not have a spaceflight planned right now. NASA astronaut Christina Koch recently bumped into Kikina during their training.

I’m not usually the type to fan girl. But when you bump into the one current woman cosmonaut and you’re both training in the same building, it’s hard not to. She was learning manual Soyuz docking and I was co-pilot training. Honored to share the same uniform as you, Анна Кикина! pic.twitter.com/ZhQ1ChZSVC — Christina H Koch (@Astro_Christina) October 19, 2018

Laura Seward Forczyk, the owner of Astralytical, a space consulting firm, told Ars Technica last September the current Russian culture isn’t supportive of women in “high-powered careers.”



Here’s hoping Kikina inspires more girls and women in Russia to apply for the next cosmonaut class, which is open to people over 35 years old with specific degrees in STEM fields.

The first African-American woman to fly in space

Mae Jemison became the first African American woman in space on Sep. 12, 1992 when she flew aboard Space Shuttle Endeavor. (Photo: NASA)

In 1961, Alan Shepard was the first American to launch into space on Freedom 7. It would take more than three decades before an African American woman would visit space. That incredible human was Dr. Mae Jemison.

Jemison became the first black woman to visit the International Space Station in 1992. Now 62, she has continued to inspire people of color to pursue careers in science, technology, engineers and math fields with her company the Jemison Group.

Friday’s Google Doodle for International Women's Day includes a quote from Jemison, “Never be limited by other people’s limited imaginations.” According to Space.com the quote comes from Jemison's 2009 speech at the Biomedical Research Conference for Minority Students.

NASA's first female astronauts to fly on Boeing's CST-Starliner

This year NASA’s commercial crew spacecraft by SpaceX and Boeing are set to launch U.S. astronauts from Cape Canaveral for the first time since 2011.



NASA announced the first nine astronauts to fly on Boeing’s CST-100 and SpaceX’s Crew Dragon last August, including veteran astronaut Suni Williams and NASA astronaut Nicole Aunapu Mann.

Williams has made two trips to the International Space Station totaling 322 days flying on both the Space Shuttle and Russian Soyuz spacecraft.

When others said you couldn't, you said "We can do it!" 💪

To the pioneers of space, our #Starliner teammates and @Commercial_Crew astronauts @AstroDuke and @Astro_Suni, thank you for building the future and daring to explore. #InternationalWomensDay#BalanceForBetterpic.twitter.com/PoCMim9GJJ — Boeing Space (@BoeingSpace) March 8, 2019

With more than 3,000 flight hours in over 30 different aircraft, Williams served in the U.S. Navy flying helicopters on relief and combat missions. Later, she became a test pilot and instructor. Williams was deployed when she was selected to be a NASA astronaut in 1998.

Williams told News 6 last August the gender of an astronaut or pilot shouldn't matter.

"When I was a helicopter pilot, when I did my first spacewalk, when I was living on the space station ... the helicopter doesn't know if I'm a girl or a boy," Williams said. "The space station doesn't know, the spacesuit doesn't know. So why should it really matter, right?"

More: SpaceX Crew Dragon splashes down in Atlantic Ocean to complete successful test flight

The first crewed test flight of Boeing's Starliner will be Mann's first trip to space. If an uncrewed flight slated for no earlier than April goes well that launch will happen in late summer.



Mann earned the nickname “Duke” as a lieutenant colonel in the Marine Corps. She served on combat operations in Iraq and Afghanistan and as a test pilot for the F/A-18 Hornet and Super Hornet. Mann was selected as part of the 2013 NASA astronaut class -- the first class to be equal parts men and women.

She told News 6 last August after her assignment on the Boeing Starliner she hopes the return to human spaceflight in the U.S. will empower the next generation of space explorers.



"Hopefully, it motivates them to study hard in school and think about what they want to do and think about how they want to contribute to this mission to exploring space," Mann said.

The first all-women spacewalking team

CLOSE A spacewalk scheduled for March will be the first every conducted by all-female crew. Rachael L Thomas, FLORIDA TODAY

Astronauts working on the International Space Station have completed 213 spacewalks since 1998. However, on March 29 NASA astronauts Christina Koch and Anne McClain will become the first women to conduct a spacewalk without any men.

Canadian Space Agency flight controller Kristen Facciol announced on Twitter March 1 she will be on console while McClain and Koch conduct the first all-female spacewalk.

As a young girl, @Astro_Christina dreamed of going to space. Next week, that dream becomes a reality when she launches to the @Space_Station! Learn more about Christina & the other members of the Expedition 59 crew. https://t.co/0B48RUOxos#InternationalWomensDay#IEW2019pic.twitter.com/ZdewH4cRQu — NASA STEM Engagement (@NASAedu) March 8, 2019

McClain has been working on the space station since December and will conduct another spacewalk with NASA astronaut Nick Hague on March 22, according to NASA.

Koch and Hague launch for the space station March 14.

Copyright 2019 by WKMG ClickOrlando - All rights reserved.

Address: 1 Gannett Plaza Ave, Melbourne, FL 32940, USA

Title: Sheriff: Mom Rose Alcides Rivera killed 11-year-old daughter to keep her from having sex
Summary:
Rose Alcides Rivera, 28, pulled up to a hospital in Orlando asking for help for her daughter on Sunday morning, but the girl was already dead from multiple stab wounds, sheriff's investigators said. Then, they say Rivera pulled a knife on hospital workers before being arrested.

ORLANDO — A woman accused of stabbing her daughter to death told investigators she killed the 11-year-old to keep her from having sex, authorities in Florida said.

Rose Alcides Rivera, 28, pulled up to a hospital in Orlando asking for help for her daughter on Sunday morning, but the girl was already dead from multiple stab wounds, sheriff's investigators said. Then, they say Rivera pulled a knife on hospital workers before being arrested.

She later told investigators she killed her daughter to "prevent her from having sex" with men, authorities said. She is charged with first-degree murder in the death of Aleyda Rivera.

The mother told first responders "my baby is gone," the Orlando Sentinel reported. The child had 15 stab wounds to her back and a defensive wound on her right arm.

Orange County Sheriff's investigators said the incident started early Sunday when the mother took her daughter to the home of a man and accused him of having sex with the child. Witnesses told detectives the child denied having sex with anyone.

An arrest report said Rivera first denied stabbing the girl but eventually admitted to killing her. "Rivera stated she stabbed her daughter while in the car, and while stabbing her she was attempting to make her more comfortable," an investigator wrote in the report.

The mother told detectives she believes her daughter is in heaven.

According to the report, Rivera said she didn't see her daughter having sex with the man, nor did the girl tell her she was having sex.

Rivera had a superficial cut on her arm, which authorities believe was self-inflicted.

A lawyer wasn't listed for her on jail records.
Address: 300 W Lime St, Lakeland, FL 33815, USA

A man who deals with children every day is accused of molesting a child.Julio Soto taught at Castle Creek Elementary School.Soto appeared before a judge on Saturday. He is charged with one count of molesting a child under the age of 12.According to the arrest affidavit, last week, some students at the school told an assistant principal their friend claimed to have been molested by Soto. A Florida mother accused of stabbing her 11-year-old daughter more than a dozen times Sunday did so because she thought the girl had been having sex, according to an arrest affidavit.

Orange County Sheriff’s Office investigators said 28-year-old Rosa Alcides Rivera pulled up to Winnie Palmer Hospital for Women and Babies on Sunday asking for help for her 11-year-old daughter, but the girl was already dead from multiple stab wounds.

Advertisement

Police said medical staff checked on the girl and determined Aleyda Rivera was dead.

Hospital workers told investigators the mother became "argumentative" with hospital staff before producing a knife. Police said she admitted to killing her daughter and can be heard on police body camera recordings saying “my baby is gone.”

The hospital was briefly locked down and the main entrance remained closed during the incident.

Rosa Rivera later told investigators she killed her daughter to "prevent her from having sex" with men. She's charged with first-degree murder.

Investigators said the girl had been stabbed 15 times and they believe it happened at a home on Citadel Drive in Orlando.

People at the home told investigators Rivera had arrived around 7:30 a.m. Sunday and started pounding on the front door. The witnesses told investigators Rivera was accusing a man of having sex with her daughter.

Rivera is being held in the Orange County Jail without bond.

Title: Woman kills 11-year-old daughter to keep her from having sex, deputies say
Summary:
A 28-year-old woman stabbed her 11-year-old daughter to death Sunday because she thought the girl was having sex with men, according to an arrest affidavit.

Rosa Alcides Rivera faces first-degree murder charges in the death of her daughter, Aleyda.

Authorities said Rivera stabbed her daughter at least 15 times in a car and drove her to Winnie Palmer Hospital in Orlando. Hospital staff began to assist Rivera and realized her daughter was dead, the affidavit said.

Orange County Sheriff John Mina said Rivera stabbed the girl while inside the vehicle, then drove her around before going to the hospital, and by that point, the child was dead.

Hospital security surrounded Rivera and called an off-duty Orlando police officer who was working security at Orlando Regional Medical Center for assistance, and he placed Rivera in handcuffs, officials said.

Rivera had cuts near her wrist and was taken to a hospital, where she was cleared medically, officials said.

In an interview, Rivera first told detectives a man had stabbed her daughter before running away. She later said she had killed her daughter and her "baby is gone," according to the affidavit.

Officials said the incident began at a home on Citadel Drive, where Rivera had accused her mother's boyfriend of having sex with her daughter. Witnesses told officers that the girl had denied having sex with him, the affidavit said.

According to officials, Rivera said she killed her daughter to prevent her from having sexual relations with men. She said she believed her daughter was having sex with men because she "smiled different," according to the affidavit.

Mina said there appears to be no validity to Rivera's claim that her daughter was sexually active.

"We don't believe it's credible," Mina said.

Rivera also told detectives she attempted to make her daughter comfortable while she was stabbing her, according to authorities.

"We're all parents, we're all mothers and fathers, and these cases are horrific and tragic, especially any time a child is killed, and then to know that this child was killed by a mother. Basically, a mother is the first line of defense to this sometimes very cruel world," Mina said. "It's very very hard on all of us in the community."

Officials said Rivera then harmed herself, resulting in the cuts to her arm, before she arrived at the hospital.

Although authorities did not say if Rivera had any prior contact with law enforcement, he said the incident comes as a reminder to report suspected domestic violence.

"I think the message is that domestic violence continues to happen not only in this community, obviously across the nation. When people see things, or notice things they need to call the authorities so that … we can stop these tragedies before they happen," Mina said.

Bianca Fernandez, a family friend, said Rivera moved back to the Orlando area from Texas in December and has been acting different ever since.

"She's been starting problems with the whole family, like, everybody," Fernandez said. "She's trying to look all crazy on TV. She knew exactly what she was doing."

Authorities said Aleyda Rivera attended West Ridge Middle School, where grief counselors will be on hand Monday to talk to her classmates.

"One of our students was tragically killed over the weekend. Our thoughts and prayers are with the family as they go through extremely difficult time," Principal Matt Turner said. "Your child may speak with you and share this sad news. Students will have varied reactions to the death of any peer. Any reaction is normal in the grief process and I encourage you to openly discuss with your child their feelings and reactions."

Watch News 6 and stay with ClickOrlando.com for updates.
Address: 4466 N John Young Pkwy, Orlando, FL 32804, USA

Title: Former Space Coast home delivery business owner appears on 'Shark Tank' to pitch Moink
Summary:
CLOSE See how Alyssa and Zach Brown, an ER nurse and firefighter, won over the "Shark Tank" sharks with the Moki Door Step and walked out as millionaires. USA TODAY

Will the sharks take a bite out of meat?

Lucinda Cramsey, founder of Moink, or moinkbox.com, sure hopes so. She pitched her custom meats-to-home delivery service to Mark Cuban, Jamie Siminoff, Kevin O'Leary, Lori Greiner, and Daymond John on "Shark Tank."

The episode airs at 10 p.m. Sunday, March 10, on ABC.

Cramsey also founded spacegirlorganics.com when she briefly lived in Melbourne. Space Girl delivers fresh organic produce to the Space Coast and parts of Orlando, while Moink ships products nationwide. After 30 days here, she moved "back home" to Missouri and temporarily ran Space Girl from afar before turning the reins over to a friend. She started other home-delivery businesses, but Moink, by far, is the most successful.

"Florida is near and dear to my heart and part of the story of how I got to where I got," Cramsey said by phone. "The week I started doing deliveries in Florida was the week that I met my future husband. Even though we met on the East Coast, we grew up 45 minutes from each other. It just so happens that 'Shark Tank' will air eight years to the day from the time I started Space Girl."

During her short stay in Melbourne, she was a single mom to Fiona, who's now 12 years old. "I moved halfway across the country with $5,000 and a baby on my hip," Cramsey recalled.

The story comes up in the episode.

"Being in the 'Shark Tank' is an extremely nerve-wracking situation. I was sweating in places that I didn't know I could sweat!" Cramsey joked. She described the experience as business boot camp. "You should know your numbers, but nothing can prepare you for this surreal environment. They don't know anything about you when you walk in. It's not like a first date. Exactly what you see on TV really is real."

To celebrate the episode, Cramsey, who lives in La Belle, Missouri, with her husband, Adam, daughter Fiona and son Henry, plans to watch it with "the whole town."

"I literally live in a town of 600 people. To me, Melbourne is a big city," she said.

Lucinda Cramsey, an entrepreneur from Labelle, Missouri, familiarizes the Sharks with her ethical and customizable meat subscription delivery service on "Shark Tank." (Photo: Eric McCandless, ABC)

"Our entire small town will meet up at the only place we can meet, which is the bar. We are having a good ole fashioned carry-in" (since the Cramseys don't have a TV or cable or high-speed internet).

Said Cramsey: "I'm excited to see how it turns out."

For more information about "Shark Tank," visit abc.go.com/shows/shark-tank. For more information on Moink or Space Girl, visit lucindaclark.com.

Sangalang is a digital producer at FLORIDA TODAY.

or jsangalang@floridatoday.com.

Title: Missing 4-month-old girl found in Orlando; parents fled to avoid custody order, sheriff says
Summary:
Four-month-old Skylah Singleton was last seen in in Deltona, Florida. Authorities said she may be with one or both of her parents, Elliot Singleton, 26, and Chloe Wall, 18. Anyone with information on Skylah's whereabouts should call 911.…

DELTONA, Fla. - A 4-month-old girl reported missing Saturday morning in Volusia County was found in Orlando after her parents fled the area to avoid a judge's order to surrender the baby, Volusia County Sheriff Mike Chitwood told clickorlando.com

The Florida Department of Law Enforcement issued a missing child alert for Skylah Singleton. She was last seen in the area of the 2900 block of Snow Drive in Deltona.

Chitwood was holding a news conference on the missing infant when deputies informed him Skylah had been found in Orlando.

The sheriff said Skylah will likely be taken to Orlando Regional Medical Center for evaluation. When she was born the sheriff said she had heroin in her system.

Authorities said the baby was likely with her parents, Elliot Singleton, 26, and Chloe Wall, 18. Both parents were found in Orlando and arrested, Chitwood said.

Sheriff's Office officials said in a news release both parents were released from jail earlier this week and they left the area to avoid a judge's order to surrender their baby to the state.

Detectives said Wall's mother may have driven her daughter and the baby to Orlando and bought them supplies to go out of state.

Volusia County authorities got a tip that the baby was at a home in Orlando and worked with Orange County law enforcement to place the address under surveillance. Just before 3 p.m., the girl was found, according to the sheriff.

Chitwood said anyone who was harboring Wall and Singleton may also face charges.

Edgewater police arrested Wall on drug possession charges Tuesday. Singleton was also arrested on charges of resisting without violence.

"At the time of the arrests, Skylah was in the vehicle with her parents, where police found prescription pills and paraphernalia used to smoke crack cocaine," Volusia County Sheriff's Office public information officer Andrew Grant said. "Wall is believed to have a history of drug abuse. Skylah tested positive for the presence of drugs in her system immediately after she was born."

Deputies said after the parents' arrests, the Florida Department of Children and Families determined Skylah should be taken into state custody for her own safety. The family did not cooperate with DCF, and when Wall and Singleton were released later Tuesday, they left the area with the girl, according to the news release.

Wall's mother, Jennifer Wall, 41, was arrested Saturday morning in Deltona. Deputies said she provided false information during the missing child investigation to conceal the baby's location and defy the court order.

"Grandma is a piece of human garbage," Chitwood said of Jennifer Wall for helping her daughter avoid surrendering the baby.

Chitwood said the judge's order was for temporary removal of the infant "to get the child the care that the child needs and isn't getting."

Address: 4 Broadcast Pl, Jacksonville, FL 32207, USA

Title: 4-month-old girl reported missing in Deltona
Summary:
Anyone with information on the whereabouts of Skylah is asked to call the Volusia County Sheriff's Office at 386-736-5999 or 911.

DELTONA, Fla. - A 4-month-old girl was reported missing Saturday morning in Volusia County, according to the Sheriff's Office.

The Florida Department of Law Enforcement issued a missing child alert for Skylah Singleton. She was last seen in the area of the 2900 block of Snow Drive in Deltona, Florida.

Authorities said she may be in the company of Elliot Singleton, 26, and Chloe Wall,18. They may be traveling in a 2007, white Cadillac DTS, New York tag number FBW1838.

Authorities did not provide any other information.

Anyone with information on the whereabouts of this child is asked to contact the Volusia County Sheriff's Office at 386-736-5999 or 911.

Title: 9 wild Florida stories you may have missed this week
Summary:
0 9 wild Florida stories you may have missed this week

You know the drill. You read a crazy headline, click on it, then scroll down far enough to get confirmation. Yep, it happened in Florida.

The men and women of Florida were busy this week doing their best to do the Sunshine State's reputation for the outlandish proud.

Here are our nine favorite Florida stories of the week that made us laugh, cringe and face palm:

>>> Can't get enough Florida Man? Check out the "What the Florida" section on the WFTV mobile app <<<

1) That can't taste good... It happened earlier this year in California -- a man was caught on camera aggressively licking a doorbell. But not to be outdone, of course, a Florida man had to jump on board the bizarre trend. This time around, a man can be seen outside a Lake Worth home licking a Ring doorbell multiple times. Read more about what was captured on camera here.

2) BRAAAAAINS 🧟‍♂️ A man stole a truck then led police on a wild chase through busy golf courses, narrowly missing at least one woman, Lady Lake police say. According to police, the man stated that “people were eating his brains out,” then took off running and stole a company vehicle, leading to the chase. Watch the full video of the pursuit here.

Man says someone is ‘eating his brains,' rips up golf courses in wild chase, #LadyLake police say | Watch the video here: https://t.co/iL8CZAjN2v pic.twitter.com/oMEJGTCuQu — WFTV Channel 9 (@WFTV) February 14, 2019

3) Hold my beer! One man was arrested after police said he allowed an underage girl to take the wheel during a trip to the store, according to the Brevard County Sheriff's Office. Deputies came in contact with the vehicle where the man said he allowed the girl to drive to the store "to get her a snack and himself another 18 pack of beer," according to an arrest report. Click here for the full story.

#Florida man arrested for allowing underage girl to drive to store for beer and snacks | Read more: https://t.co/DGJzx6b8fK pic.twitter.com/RLAVSQrT7z — WFTV Channel 9 (@WFTV) February 15, 2019

4) Ouch. A Florida man is facing a domestic battery charge after his girlfriend accused him of throwing a burrito at her. A deputy arrived to find burrito filling on the woman's "face, neck and left chest/shoulder area," the arrest affidavit said. Read more here.

5) Watch out! A Florida woman is accused of knocking an older woman’s dentures out of her mouth by throwing a television remote at her, TCPalm reported. Find out what led up to incident here.

6) Math is hard. A Florida man received an income tax refund of $980,000 two years ago -- but he only reported income of $18,497, the Tampa Bay Times reported. It took a while, but Internal Revenue Service officials smelled something fishy and filed a federal forfeiture complaint in U.S. District Court in Tampa, the newspaper reported. Find out how it happened here.

7) Poor puppy 😟 A dog has died after a man's gun discharged while he was cleaning it. 21-year-old Michael Shehan told an officer that he accidentally shot himself and his German Shephard while cleaning his gun at his residence in Ormond Beach. Click here for more.

Florida man accidentally shoots himself and his German Shepherd while cleaning his gun | Read more: https://t.co/xuynt5y8fM pic.twitter.com/bgwVSXmcnr — WFTV Channel 9 (@WFTV) February 13, 2019

8) Yikes! A woman faces multiple charges after she threatened a deputy with a "visit from the KKK" during an arrest, according to the Volusia County Sheriff's Office. Read more about what she said to the deputies who pulled her over.

9) Monkey business. The case of the missing monkey has been partially solved. Kali, a 12-year-old Goeldi’s monkey, was returned to the Palm Beach Zoo by detectives just before midnight Tuesday. Zoo officials said that on Monday, someone forced their way into the habitat, cutting the mesh on the enclosure where Kali lives and stole her. What we know about why she may have been taken.

Title: First black woman in space speaks to FSC
Summary:
LAKELAND — She played with Barbie Dolls and chemistry sets as a child. And she loved the stars.

NASA astronaut, engineer, entrepreneur, physician and educator Dr. Mae C. Jemison, the first black woman in space, was the featured speaker Friday morning at Florida Southern College's 136th-Year Founders Day Convocation and was named the college's 85th honorary chancellor.

"I was this little girl who assumed she would go into space," Jemison said.

"And I made it," she said, noting that the opportunity came with the help of others.

Jemison, 62, served six years as a NASA astronaut and was the first woman of color to go into space. eAdmitted to NASA's astronaut training program on June 4, 1987, she joined six other astronauts on the space shuttle Endeavour on Sept. 12, 1992. She also has been on television many times, including a guest appearance in an episode of ''Star Trek: The Next Generation."

"Dr. Mae Jemison has found numerous ways to demonstrate how technologic advancements can benefit our society, while inspiring others to pursue their own dreams of improving the world," said FSC President Anne Kerr.

She also is a medical doctor and served as the area Peace Corps medical officer for Sierra Leone and Liberia. A professor at Dartmouth College, she focused on technology designs for sustainability for industrialized and developing nations, according to her bio.

"We look at science to solve so many problems," she told those in attendance at the Branscomb Auditorium on the FSC campus.

A child who grew up in the 1960s, she remembers being afraid for her dad on the day Martin Luther King Jr. was shot.

Many changes were taking place in the world at the time, she said. Civil rights, women's liberation, space exploration, science advances.

"All these new things were happening, and I wanted to be a part of it," she said.

She spoke about empowerment and what it means.

"It involves belief," she said, "belief in the right to be involved, belief that you have something to contribute, belief that you can risk making the contribution."

Quoting Mzee Julius Nyerere, she said, "While they were trying to reach the moon, we were trying to reach the village.''

''We were able to reach the village because of space exploration."

A firm believer in "connections" and "inclusiveness across disciplines," she said that when she was considering what to do with her life, she found she had so many options. Her fascination with science was evident as early as kindergarten, she told The Ledger after the convocation.

"I loved space, stars and dinosaurs," she said, and yet she also enjoyed dancing. To be a dancer, or a doctor, she said, "Those are the points when you have to make a decision where are are going to make your main focus."

Pulling from her many experiences has fueled her academic and space interests.

Jemison leads 100 Year Starship, a global initiative that is funded through a competitive grant from the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency to ensure the capabilities for human travel to another star within the next 100 years. She also founded The Jemison Group Inc., a technology consulting firm that mixes critical socio-cultural issues into the design of engineering and science projects. This includes things like satellite technology for delivering health care and implementing solar dish Stirling engine electricity in developing countries. Her group researches and develops science and technology companies, such as BioSentient Corp., a medical device and services company.

What was the motivation for Jemison to chase her dreams and ambitions all the way to space and back?

"I have as much right to be in this universe as any speck of stardust," she told The Ledger.

Kathy Leigh Berkowitz can be reached at kberkowitz@theledger.com or at 863-802-7558. Follow her on Twitter @kberkowitzthel1.
Address: 455 6th St NW, Winter Haven, FL 33881, USA

Title: Jim White brings new album, 'Waffles, Triangles & Jesus,' to Sopchoppy | Music roundup
Summary:
Sometimes when I’m feeling oppressed and downtrodden, I mentally cue up a song from my favorite Jim White album, 2001’s “No Such Place.”

If I’m feeling particularly bleak, it’s usually “Handcuffed to a Fence in Mississippi.” That song never fails to cheer me up because, hey, things could be worse and at least I’m not handcuffed to a fence in Mississippi watching my significant other drive off in my prized Trans Am, and also because it is an awfully jaunty tune (with juicy, chirpy production by Morcheeba) despite the subject matter, with the hopeful refrain “things is always better than they seem.”

But my all-time favorite go-to in times of woe and stress is “10 Miles to Go on a 9 Mile Road.” It’s the most oddly optimistic song about slogging along the pitted, rocky road of life towards the dimly glow at the end of the tunnel.

After a burbling sitar intro bleeds into a fuzzed-out guitar riff, White sing-speaks the song’s main mantra:

“Girl, I got ten miles to go on a nine mile road

It's a rocky rough road, but I don't care

For life's nothing if not a blind rambling prayer

You keep your head held high, walkin' and talkin’

’Til the power of love deliver you there.”

The bridge is ornamented with daffy blips and bloops, the aforementioned guitar fuzz and a percolating little finger-picked riff, and the song goes out on a loop of “the power of love . . . the power of love.”

My spirits are elevated just thinking about it.

The singer-songwriter Jim White will bring his off-kilter wit and musical acumen when he delivers his latest deliriously uncategorizable album to From the Heart Recording Studio in Sopchoppy Saturday. (Photo: jimwhite.net)

White, a North Florida homeslice who grew up in Pensacola, travels through these parts fairly frequently. Which is a good thing, because the quirky charisma of his recordings is magnified to the nth power in person. You can surf the wave for weeks after seeing White perform, as he will this weekend.

The self-dubbed “enigmatic Southern Gothic anatomist” is returning to deliver his latest deliriously uncategorizable album, the enigmatically titled “Waffles, Triangles & Jesus,” at an intimate concert at 7:30 p.m. Saturday at From The Heart Recording Studio, 55 Rose St. in Sopchoppy.

“The new record is all over the map, it’s quite a crazy quilt,” White told former Democrat columnist (and good friend) Mark Hinson back in 2017. “Nothing goes together. . . I’m just going to make songs that I always liked and wanted to do.”

White joked to Hinson that the songs on “Waffles” belong on “the soundtrack for the end of the world.”

“We needed a psychotic soundtrack for the launching ramp off into oblivion,” White laughed. “These are very strange songs. I’m going to have to do a lot of talking between songs. There’s no way I can play these songs back to back without people getting a hernia. Bring your mental hernia belt with you.”

Sounds about par for the course for a Jim White show. Come on down to Sopchoppy and see for yourself. Tickets are $20; reservations are strongly recommended. Call 850-559-9038 or email fromtheheartrecordingstudio@gmail.com to reserve a seat.

Let the power of love deliver you to some live music this week. Check it:

Keep those riffs a-rollin’

Steady Rollin’ Bob Margolin rolls into the Bradfordville Club on Friday. (Photo: Special to the Democrat)

Legendary bluesman and former Muddy Waters Band guitarist Steady Rollin’ Bob Margolin steams in for a night of slick licks and hot riffs at 9 p.m. Friday at Bradfordville Blues Club, 7152 Moses Lane. Margolin is a bona-fide icon - that’s him shredding in Muddy’s band in “The Last Waltz,” y’all. Tickets are $25 advance, $30 at the door (if any remain available). Visit www.bradfordvilleblues.com.

Scotty beams in

Trumpet maestro and Count Basie Orchestra leader Scotty Barnhart brings an all-star quintet featuring Bill Peterson on piano, David Detweiler on sax, Mikailo Kasha on bass and Avion Wright on drums for an evening of jazz starting at 8 p.m. Friday at Blue Tavern, 1206 N. Monroe St. Cover is $10. Call 850-212-5204.

Booty-ful rejuvenation

Much-loved local band Revival, featuring vocal goddess Avis Berry, celebrates a year of rejuvenating and uplifting body and soul at the place it all began at 9:30 p.m. Friday at Fifth & Thomas, 1122 Thomasville Road. Formed a year ago, the band has undergone a couple of transformations — adding keyboardist/vocalist Lyndon Thacker when Mason Margut moved to Atlanta — but the core remains the same, with Berry, Jeff Davis, Dillon Bradley-Brown, Chris Skene and Allijah Motika making the magic happen onstage. No cover. Visit www.fifthandthomas.com.

Porter by the sea

Milwaukee-based singer-songwriter Willy Porter escapes the frozen north for the balmy breezes of the Forgotten Coast when he visits for a show co-hosted by Cat Braaten at 7:30 p.m. Friday at The Gallery at High Cotton in Apalachicola. Porter’s career has spanned two decades, 11 albums and stages around the world as he has evolved a spellbinding style that fuses pristine guitar playing with muscular songcraft. Doors open at 6:30 p.m. Tickets are $25. Call 850-316-0630.

What are words for?

Black Dog on the Square in Railroad Square Art Park presents “A Night of Poetry with Carolina Hospital and Maureen Seaton” from 7 to 9 p.m. Friday. Hospital is a poet, essayist, novelist and professor at Miami Dade College whose new poetry collection “Key West Nights and Other Aftershocks” has just been published by Anhinga Press. Seaton has authored 21 poetry collections, most recently “Sweet World” and “Fisher,” and currently teaches English/Creative Writing at the University of Miami. No cover charge. Call 850-841-7778.

Pickin’ and singing’

Award-winning duo Compton & Newberry explore the backroads and byways of old-time acoustic and bluegrass music at 7 p.m. Friday at Unitarian Universalist Church of Tallahassee, 2810 N. Meridian Road. Tickets are $20 adults, $10 for children 17 and younger. Email hpardue@comcast.net or call 850-567-2078.

Sonic ‘Sunrise’

The Jerry Thigpen Trio celebrates the release of its latest CD “Sunrise” at a show at 8 p.m. Saturday at The Junction at Monroe. (Photo: Special to the Democrat)

The Jerry Thigpen Trio invites a host of musical friends to help celebrate the release of its latest CD “Sunrise” at a show at 8 p.m. Saturday at The Junction at Monroe, 2011 S. Monroe St. The disc is a 12-song all-original package that features instrumentals, ballads, blues numbers and rockers. Music guests will include Nashville violinist David Davidson, keyboardist John “J.B.” Babich and vocalist Lucia Fishburne. Tickets are $10 advance, $12 day of show. Visit www.junctionatmonroe.com.

Black is back

Buy Photo The Nick Black Band oozes the blues Saturday at Bradfordville Blues Club (Photo: Democrat files)

The Nick Black Band oozes the blues for an encore performance at 9 p.m. Saturday at Bradfordville Blues Club, 7152 Moses Lane. Black, the former guitarist for Victor Wainwright, has built his take on the Memphis sound around a hot horn section and his own soulful vocals. Tickets are $20 advance, $25 at the door. Visit www.bradfordvilleblues.com.

More bounce to the ounce

Get your booty moving at the Throwback Throwdown with New Orleans DJ Tony Skratchere’s trademark Yacht Bounce mix of ‘70s and ‘80s hits with modern beats at 8 p.m. Saturday at The Yard in Railroad Square Art Park. Tickets are $5 advance, $10 day of show. Visit 850tix.com.

And the beat goes on . . .

Cat Family Records presents “Folk the Wilbury” with Tommy Cooper Music (also his CD release party), Slow Low Crow, Fort Defiance, Landon Gay and Dylan R.P. Allen at 8 p.m. Friday at The Wilbury, 513 W. Gaines St. Visit the Facebook event. . . . . Put your party boots on and head for the dance floor when Crooked Shooz cranks up the boogie machine from 8 to 11:30 p.m. Friday at the American Legion Hall at Lake Ella. Admission is $8 for one, $15 per couple. Call 850-222-3382. . . . Hang out with Hot Tamale from 7 to 10 p.m. Friday at Southwood Golf Club, 3750 Grove Park Drive. No cover. Call 850-942-4653. . . . Three Billy Goats Gruff is ready to rumble at 9:30 p.m. Friday at Dux Liquors & Decoy Lounge, 3332 Crawfordville Hwy, in Crawfordville. It’s free. Call 850-926-3212. . . . Hogtown punk posse Mike Llerena & the Nerve joins Sinkwell and Cool Now for a show at 8:30 p.m. Saturday at The Bark, 507 All Saints St. Cover is $5. Visit the Facebook event. . . . Langtry, led by Patrick McKinney, plays sensitive songs for tough times from 8 to 10 p.m. Saturday at Waterworks, 1133 Thomasville Road. Cover is $5. Call 850-224-1887. . . . Multi-instrumentalist and man-of-all-songs Jon Copps brings his bag of tricks and songbook to fill the listening room from 8 to 11 p.m. Saturday at Blue Tavern, 1206 N. Monroe St. Cover is $5. Call 850-212-5204. . . . Feel the thunder when Three Billy Goats Gruff plugs in from 6 to 10 p.m. Saturday at Paddy’s Raw Bar on St. George Island. No cover. Call 850-927-2299. . . . Rachel Hillman hosts Singer-Songwriter Night from 6 to 8 p.m. Sunday at Black Dog on the Square in Railroad Square Art Park. No cover. Call 850-841-7778. . . . Celebrate National Sloppy Joe Day with food and drink specials and music by Thousand Dollar Hen at 6 p.m. Monday at The Junction at Monroe, 2011 S. Monroe St. No cover. Visit www.junctionatmonroe.com. . . .

Buy Photo Bagels & Biscuits comes “Back for the Schmear” Tuesday at Blue Tavern. (Photo: Democrat files)

Bagels & Biscuits comes “Back for the Schmear” from 8 to 10 p.m. Tuesday at Blue Tavern, 1206 N. Monroe St. Cover is $2. Call 850-212-5204. . . . Filmmaker and musician Sammy Tedder presents his film “Local Waters: Wild Places - A Musical Journey into the North Florida Wilderness” at 7:30 p.m. Thursday at The Gallery at High Cotton in Apalachicola. Free admission. Call 850-316-0630. . . . Lee C. Payton & the Gangbusters mix it up with rockin' originals & rollin' cover tunes at 8 p.m. Thursday at Blue Tavern, 1206 N. Monroe St. Cover is $2. Call 850-212-5204.

Title: Jazz singer: Naples chanteuse finds her future in past music
Summary:
CLOSE Cobby Brzeski, a recent graduate of The Berklee College of Music in Boston, performs her song "Be Mine" on March 14, 2019, in the Naples Daily News studios. Alex Driehaus, Naples Daily News

After the turn of that tassel on the college mortarboard, most of us are headed for a job, 401(k)s, organizational structure and an apartment.

Cobby Brzeski is headed for a nightclub tour of the West Coast.

Brzeski, a Naples native, has already begun here, peppering dining spots and bistros around her hometown with emails and samples of her silky vocal-flute combination. She has stepped up her jazz-tinged songwriting in hopes of some commercial contracts. But a life onstage begins with getting onstage.

The Naples High graduate and Berklee College of Music alumna, is determined to write and perform, and anyone who hears her won't question her decision. Despite winning concerto competitions and Bach festivals, the petite, blonde 25-year-old has a heart full of repertoire from the swing era, the smooth sounds of Billie Holiday, the Andrews Sisters and Helen Forrest.

"A vintage girl in a contemporary world," says her publicity.

"Be Mine," her upbeat signature tune, could have been sung by her idols, and it has a way of sneaking into your head for an all-day stay: "I always ask her to sing that one. It's my favorite," declared her mother, Teryl Brzeski.

"This is my dream job," her daughter explained. "I love performing. I love writing songs. I aspire to positively affect the world with my music and just spread joy."

Cobby Brzeski is working her way up the California coast, from San Diego to Pismo Beach. But first she plays four dates in the Naples area (see information box).

She already has recorded her first disc, "Bring On the Swing." It's an extended-play blend of her own tunes and bedrock standards such as "Misty" and "The Nearness of You," backed by some like-minded Berklee friends. Its buttery sound is about to be applied to a second disc, "All of Me," which she records in Boston in late March. With a few stops to sing in Boston night spots, of course.

Plan to hear the kind of free-flight scatting perfected by her role model, Ella Fitzgerald, along with Brzeski's jazz flute and vocals. Don't miss her instrumental riffs, from the Herbie Mann school of upbeat, breezy flute work. They're what brought her to the music world.

"A singer tends to put a face to jazz," she explained. "I found the combination of being a flautist and a vocalist is something interesting to people. It's like 'Oh wow! You sing AND you play the flute!' People like the combination of instrument and vocal."

NEWSLETTERS Get the SWFL Eats newsletter delivered to your inbox We're sorry, but something went wrong Restaurant reviews, foodie news, cooking tips, Q&As, and dining updates. Please try again soon, or contact Customer Service at 1-844-900-7105. Delivery: Thurs Invalid email address Thank you! You're almost signed up for SWFL Eats Keep an eye out for an email to confirm your newsletter registration. More newsletters

Its underpinnings actually come from violin lessons. Brzeski studied it from age 5 to 15, and calls her experience a great foundation for jazz.

"I started out playing the Suzuki method, playing everything by ear, and that was one of the most valuable parts of my musical training," she said.

Brzeski is an advocate for school music; she credits the Collier County school music programs with finding the instrument she loves.

"When I went into middle school band, I got a chance to try out all kinds of instruments," she said. The flute caught her eye. "I thought, hey, this is s cool instrument — and it was the only one I could make a sound on," she conceded, laughing.

Infatuation turned to devotion: Brzeski played in the high school marching and concert bands, and joined the Naples High jazz band, but not as a flautist.

"They didn't have parts written for flute. So I had to pick a different instrument," she recalled. "So I decided to play trumpet." She largely taught herself, she said. (For the record, she can also play drums and guitar.)

In high school Brzeski won the concerto competition of the Naples Music Club and the outstanding musician award of the Bach Ensemble competition. But she wasn't receiving the jazz education she longed for.

"I grew up with completely classical background. Classical violin, classical flute. I didn't really know how to play jazz except for what was written on the page," she said. So when she graduated, Brzeski's first dream wasn't college but the Interlochen Academy's post-graduate program.

It only took a vocal class and a course in improvisation with its jazz studies director, Bill Sears, to convince her that solo performance was the life she wanted .

She doesn't only enjoy golden-era standards jazz. R&B, funk and indie rock are on her playlists, too. "I listen to a lot of different stuff."

Brzeski also believes the ability to outfit a melody with jazz didn't end with the '60s: "The are plenty of new songs that would work well as jazz."

Brzeski is less impressed with contemporary jazz that is only riffs: "That's more like music for musicians." For Cobby Brzeski, and soon, she hopes, for the world, melody-based jazz music is a comeback media: "I'd really like to see it more prominent again."

Cobby Brzeski

Where and when:

Ches Boet, 755 12th Ave. S., Naples. 7-10 p.m. Friday, March 15

Cavo Lounge, 9108 Strada Place, No. 14120, Naples, 7-10 p.m.. Saturday, March 16

North Naples Country Club, 10095 U.S. 41 N., Naples, 8 p.m.-midnight, Sunday, March 17

Gulf Cost Big Band concert, Cambier Park bandshell, 755 Eighth Ave. S., Naples. 2 p.m. Sunday, April 7.

Information: cobbybrzeski.com

,
